text: I got this keyboard for my office but still use the older Natural Keyboard Elite at home. The older keyboard is much more comfortable and responsive and I really wish Microsoft would bring it back.This keyboard, while more attractive than the older model, is much harder to use. The keys are a lot stiffer and control key commands are slow. On the Elite, you can pretty much press the control key and the alphabetic key at the same time. On this keyboard, you have to hold down the control key a brief moment before you press the other key. If you don't, unexpected errors occur - for instance if, when copying text, you hit the "C" key too quickly, it deletes the text and won't paste it when you hit ctrl-V.The function keys can be used for internet scrolling, but since I primarily use my mouse for that, I just find that all the extra keys and functions clutter up the keypad. Plus, the letters are harder to see on a black background, although on the plus side, it doesn't get as dirty as the cream-colored Elite. And while, in theory the strip at the bottom of the keyboard ought to be more comfortable because of the padding, it isn't.I could live with all the other issues if it weren't for the stiffness of the keys and the sluggishness of the response when using ctrl commands.  I'll take the comfort of an ergonomic keyboard over a standard keyboard any day, but it's almost worth paying the exorbitant fees to find an older model just because of how much easier the actual typing is.This keyboard just goes to show that keyboards are, perhaps, like women - just because one is younger and pretty than another doesn't mean it's better.

This is an almost perfect little novel, about two unlikely comrades on a quest to find a dozen eggs in Leningrad (fondly called Piter by the characters, for St. Petersburg) during the siege of the city by the Nazis.But if the plot itself is little more than an excuse to take the reader through war-torn WWII Russia, the characters make up for it.  From the narrator, a 17-year old Jewish boy who's been living in the besieged city on his own, to the man he's unwillingly partnered with on his quest, the charming good-looking would-be novelist, Kolya, to the girls forced to do things they never would have done during peacetime.Benioff manages the difficult feat of making you feel the anguish of war and privation without ever being maudlin or melodramatic.  If there's a flaw, it's the unnecessary prologue, but even that is so well-written that it doesn't much take away from Benioff's ability to place us in a time and place worlds apart from our own and make us feel like we know it and the characters almost as well as our own city and loved ones.The prose flows so well you can read this easily in one sitting, but like all good books it stays with you long afterward.

This food jar worked great at the beginning, but last night I ran a side by side test of this food jar and a newer (& slightly larger one by Stanley).  At 10:00 p.m. I put water that measured 204 degrees with a Thermapen instant-read thermometer and in both jars and sealed each tightly.  At 9 a.m. (11 hours later) the temperatures read:1.  Smaller food jar - 69 degrees, i.e., room temperature2.  Larger, newer jar - 148 degrees, still above the "danger zone" for foods.These jars are supposed to keep food hot for 15 hours.  So while I would trust the newer one for food heated in the morning to still be hot at lunchtime, the smaller one has to be trashed, which is too bad, because it's the perfect size for a side of soup, easy to clean, and the overlid functions as a bowl and is a good size for either sipping or for eating from with a spoon.

Curcumin, the active ingredient in turmeric, is purported to do great things for inflammation and digestion.  Can't say I notice a huge difference taking them, but I always notice when taking something is a problem, and there's none here.  No stomach upset, no discolored urine, no nothing.  So I am going to trust the studies that show that it works and keep taking it to see if there's a difference over time.  In the meanwhile, Jarrow Formulas is a good company and this seems to be a quality product.

The bottle's pretty.  And it's nice to be able to fill water from a fountain if you're somewhere you can't refill your bottle from any other source.  But you have to run water through the filter for 15 seconds and insert it into the built in-straw to activate it, so it's wasteful, plus you have to drink the water through the straw for it even to work.  And you have to replace the filter every couple of months.Oh, and the filter removes the taste and odor of chlorine, but nothing else.  If that's all you care about, I guess this does the trick.But since for a little over a Jackson you can buy a carafe-type filter that will also remove lead and other organic compounds, unless you really need more than one bottle of water at a time from an over-chlorinated, but otherwise safe source (the bottle won't purify water), you're better off buying one of those, or a fixed water filtration system, and a bottle you can pour from or drink out of like a glass.

I've been using Dragon NaturallySpeaking since version 8. Those earlier versions were more trouble than they were worth. Even as late as version 11, I found that I had to go back and retype quite a number of things I had said.With this latest version of Dragon, Nuance Communications has finally gotten the speech recognition right. I find that I need to do relatively few corrections; in fact, so far this review I haven't had to do a single one, a first.The software isn't as good at detecting speech from a digital voice recorder; however, the software is compatible with quite a few of them and it still beats transcribing things by typing them in fully.The software works best when you speak in complete sentences - it has a little more of a problem detecting words correctly when you say them one at a time with no context.There are new and improved options in version 12, such as being able to set the hotkey for starting dictation to sleep, rather than off, when you start the program.I know that some people have said that this option is much slower to print which are speaking onscreen, but I've found the opposite to be the case. This is the first version of Dragon I've used that didn't cause me to inadvertently test how many naughty insults I knew, although it still possible to train Dragon to learn new words and the speech recognition on those is pretty darn good.I can honestly say for the first time that I recommend this program without hesitation. It took me a third of the time to do this review that it would have without it.

After being diagnosed several yeas ago with a severe Vitamin D deficiency, I did a ton of research into the different forms of the vitamin and concluded that oral D3 was likely to be best at bringing up the actual levels in my body and not just the level of measurable vitamin D in the blood (which some sources said prescription high-dose D2 would do).Years later my vitamin D levels are fine and they've stayed that way based on taking between 1,000 and 2,000 mg./day.  At 2,500 mg, the Jarrow Formulas is a little higher than what most people need for maintenance, but not yet getting into the potentially dangerous territory some doctors say results from taking more than 3,000/day for extended periods of time.It's hard to tell whether there's any difference between Jarrow and other brands, but I've taken Jarrow supplements before and find them easy to digest.  Plus, it's considered a safe, reliable brand.

If all you want is a straight up digital recorder that fits easily and unobtrusively in a pocket and transfers files easily to a computer this definitely isn't the way to go as there are recorders on the market that are smaller and lighter, albeit at a cost; but this one will still fit into a pocket or purse (though it will be a bit on the bulky side) and it comes with a version of Dragon Naturally Speaking 11 for use with recorders.  As I have Dragon Naturally Speaking 12 premium version, however, I did my testing with that.The pluses:Lots of features for changing recording and playback quality.  Better quality comes at the cost of more space, of course, but you can upgrade to a removable memory card with more space than the 2 GB internal memory, which still has quite a bit of room.Buttons are fairly intuitive which is good, because you have to figure out how to open the manual, which is hidden on the recorder, and pick the right language, and even then it's a bit obtuse.The best part, of course, is its compatibility with Dragon, but you'll still have to do some work because the transcription is far from perfect (see below).You can record in four different qualities of MP3 or in wav format (wav takes up more memory).The unit shuts off automatically (you can change this) if you haven't done anything for several minutes.  You can also set it to record and shut off at set times, and can use it as an alarm clock.You can make it voice activated, useful for those awkward dates or for when you want to know if you talk in your sleep.The buttons are easy to learn by touch, good for those of us with weak eyes.In all pretty useful out of the box, better if you can stand a little time reading the manual.The minuses:Playback volume directly on the recorder is pretty low, but attaching the recorder to a computer is easy and solves the problem.  The included cable is ridiculously short, however, only a couple of inches, but it's the same set up that works with other apps so you might even have a longer one lying around or you can buy one.Now onto what you really want to know, how does it work with Dragon.  Here's a little out of the box try done three ways.  Dictated into the recorder and transcribed with Dragon 12.  Dictated straight into Dragon 12.  Typed straight it.  As you can see the transcribed from a recording was worst, but straight into dragon was pretty good, much better than in the past.  Basically good for backing up notes, or for transcribing when you mostly remember what was said or useit alone for notes and speak clearly in a quiet room.This example was just me in a quiet room talking to a cat on the same table.How the recording was transcribed:Were during the test to see whether this actually works to transcribe my voice so if for instance that were doing interview would this be transcribe falls in Dragon assuming the swirling on the table in front of me and there weren't a lot of noise calyx tested outHow it came out when I dictated it directly into Dragon Naturally Speaking 12 premium version:Sena were doing a test to see whether this actually works to transcribe my voice so if for instance I were doing an interview with this be transcribe of all in Dragon assuming this were like on a table in front of me and there weren't a lot of background noise okay let's test it outWhat I actually said:Xena, we're doing a test to see whether this actually works to transcribe my voice so if, for instance, I were doing an interview would this be transcribable in Dragon assuming this were, like, on a table in front of me and there weren't a lot of background noise.  Okay let's test it out.As you can see, straight into Dragon it's not too far off, but it does lose quite a bit in the recorder.  Not so much I can't clean it up and between the transcription and some tweaking it's fine.  But you'll need to work on it.  No getting around it.  Hopefully it gets better as I do.I'm still pretty happy with it and hopeful it will get better.  All in all, I still expect it to save time.

Yu's "How to Live Safely In a Science Fictional Universe" was one of the most original novels I've read in some time, so I was really excited to read his first published collection of short stories.Unfortunately many of these are ideas in search of a story, and the only one that really sucked me in was Hero Absorbs Major Damage, which might not be comprehensible to anyone who's never played a role-playing game, despite its grander, more universal theme.  That it manages to be funny, sad and moving at the same time is quite an accomplishment.Still, if not everything lives up to that one story, you have to admire a collection that deals with topics as diverse as a zombie on a shopping spree and people who live through others' painful moments so they don't have to. There's more going on here than just clever science fiction ideas, so I have to applaud Yu's efforts at the same time that I wish they weren't so wildly inconsistent.

I'm not sure why this product is supposed to be better for people over 50 and I suspect it's just a marketing tool aimed at the large number of Baby Boomers who have now passed the half century mark.  That said, like regular Glide, this product slides smoothly between the teeth and gets the job done.  It's somehow both slicker than regular Glide (harder to keep from sliding around your fingers) but able to put a little more edge against the teeth, possibly because it's a little bit wider.  Marketing or not, it's a good product.

I usually only buy only 100% cotton shirts. I didn’t realize until after I had ordered it that this was a cotton/polyester blend, but when I received the shirt it almost felt like it was all cotton. It had a softness and texture that I was familiar with, so I’m OK with the Oxford NY T Shirt.Usually I take an XL in a shirt depending on where it comes from. Some stores tend to run large, while others definitely require an XXL, especially after washing. If you normally take XL, you will probably want the XXL unless you want a tight fit. I also think that the Oxford NY T Shirt seems to be a little bit on the short side, especially for an XXL. Maybe that is the “Updated modern fit” that the product page refers to.The quality of the shirt is pretty good. The fabric is a little thin, but not too thin. The collar is not flimsy like some other T shirts that I have gotten recently and the stitching seems durable, especially for a shirt at this price. The charcoal heather is nice and dark. Hopefully it won’t fade too much with multiple washings. The shirt must be washed in cold water on the gentle cycle and can by tumbled dry on the low temperature setting.Overall I think the Oxford NY T Shirt is a good value, and is pretty well made.

Thermo Pro’s TP-01 Digital Instant Read Thermometer is a perfect addition to anyone’s kitchen. It has a rugged build that won’t break if dropped on the floor, an easy to read LCD display and easy to use controls – On/Off and degrees F/C. Its stainless probe has a skinny tip on the end to easily pierce meat, but the thermometer can be used to measure the temperature of other things too. Its temperature range is from -40 to 302 degrees F or -40 to 150 degrees C. The digital readout has tenth of a degree for accuracy and it takes about 20-30 seconds to get a precise reading, when the temperature stabilizes. I used my analog instant read thermometer to compare the difference in temperature and both came within a degree of each other.The Thermo Pro TP-01 has plastic cover the probe slips into to protect it when not in use. Unlike my analog thermometer it does not have the temperatures for different types of meat printed on this cover, but instead it comes with a booklet with the USDA Recommended internal temperatures. I have a feeling this booklet will get lost pretty quickly in the kitchen. I guess I can look at the other thermometer’s probe cover or on the internet if that happens.The Thermo Pro does not have an auto shut off, so it can accidently be left on if the switch is not turned off. This is probably by design for constant long-term readings. Luckily the battery is easy to replace. There is a place to pry the display off on the side and access the battery, which is the button type like a watch battery (see pics), just be careful of the wires that go down to the probe.The Thermo Pro TP-01 is a good, basic instant read kitchen thermometer that anyone can use. It’s good for the barbeque (after removing meat from the grill), roasts, breads, liquids, etc. It is not designed to be kept in the food while cooking, but to get an internal temperature reading when removed from the heat source. It is not dishwasher safe (none of them are), but just requires a little bit of soap and water on the probe and a quick dry with the towel before storing. The product comes with a 90 Day Warranty. This is a nice device for the price.A free sample product was provided for review.

I recently started cataloging my music and DVD collection into a database, and the Ruban bar code scanner helps to save so much time and manual inputting of information. There are programs available that will pull in all of the information on the DVD, CD or whatever you scan simply by scanning the barcode. This bar code reader is perfect for that sort of application. It would also be great be great for a small business or light industrial use. Although I feel it is well made, I don’t think it could hold up to the incessant use of a busy supermarket or other high volume application. Those applications require scanning guns costing hundreds more.There isn’t much to setting up the Ruban barcode scanner. Some very minor assembly is required to the stand such as inserting the gooseneck into the plastic sleeve and tightening a screw at the base and another on the holder. Anyone can do that. If necessary, the base could be screwed into a flat surface for stability, or even weights could be glued to the bottom, though if the gun is positioned correctly in the holder with the gooseneck slightly forward it is good enough.The cord on the reader has an Ethernet connector with a large strain relief on one end that plugs into the jack on the gun, the other end is a standard USB connector that plugs into a computer or other peripheral. The Ruban barcode scanner is pretty much plug and play on a Mac or PC. When plugged into a Windows machine it will need to load the driver first which takes about 30 seconds and it is installed. The Mac silently loads the driver, and nothing pops up on the screen when the gun is plugged in. When the barcode reader is plugged in a green light appears on the top and it will beep three times to let you know it is ready. When scanning is taking place the green light will go out, and the red laser turns on and reads the barcode. When the barcode is successfully read the gun will beep and the green light turns back on.There are no “real” instructions for the barcode reader, though it does come with small booklet that gives the specs of the device and settings that can literally be scanned into the barcode reader. For instance, you can scan the barcode for “Continuous Mode” and put the reader into the stand. Then you just need to pass an item underneath and it will scan without pressing the trigger. This is great if there is a ton of items that need scanning. There are also other settings to change the volume and tone of the beep, different types of barcodes, country settings, and communication settings such as baud rate, data bit, parity, etc.The barcode reader can be used on a standard PC basically anywhere that the blinking input cursor is visible. In Word this is what I get when I scan the barcode on the box - X000T4PR6P.  If you scan an item in Google it will bring up information on the product as well as merchants selling it. Other programs such as inventory and point of sale programs will use the barcode reader in their own ways. It is a very versatile device.Prices for barcode readers are all over the map on Amazon. Some are Bluetooth, some are 2.4 GHz with a dongle, some have stands, and some do not. I can’t vouch for any other product than the Ruban bar code reader, but I think it is a well made, scans barcodes quickly, and is comfortable to hold. Recommended.A Free Sample Product was provided for review.

The Porta Source IG800W Portable Invertor Generator is a well-built compact unit. It comes well packed from the factory, and the instructions are clear and easy to follow.Before starting the IG800W it needs to have oil added to it. This is probably the hardest thing that needs to be done to operate the generator. In order to check, add or change the oil one of the red panels on the side needs to be taken off by removing four screws. Porta Source provides a Phillips head screwdriver to aid in the removal. Once the panel is removed, just unscrew the cap to the oil reservoir and add the proper amount. The cap has a mini dipstick to check the level. Filling the oil was easy, no funnel was required, and no drips occurred, though I did wipe the area with a rag when finished. Once the oil has been added, gasoline needs to be added to the fuel tank and it is ready to start. Since the generator has a four cycle Viper engine there is no messy mixing of two-cycle oil, it uses 87 octane regular gas or better.There are six easy steps to starting the generator: turns the fuel cap air vent to open, turn the fuel valve switch to on, push the engine switch to run, press the primer bulb six times, move the lever to choke, and pull the starter cord. The generator started on the first try. Once it is started, move the choke lever to run and the IG800W is operational. The generator is pretty quiet and has rubber feet at its base to dampen any vibrations. The IG800W has a single three prong AC plug to plug an extension cord or power strip into. Just remember the running wattage is 700 watts with a maximum of 800 watts, so be sure not to exceed that. If you do, there is a circuit breaker than can be instantly reset once you correct the issue. The motor on the generator will fluctuate based on the amount of power that is needed, which also helps with gas conservation. There is economy mode which also helps to save fuel, but I’m not exactly how yet.The power output of the Porta Source IG800W is clean and steady, unlike my older Coleman 2600 watt generator that has choppy power. The Porta Source has “Pure Sine Wave” circuitry that allows it to power even sensitive electronics without surges and dips in power that could damage them. I did a test and plugged in two lamps next to each other, one in the IG800W and another in an my old Coleman 2600 watt generator and the difference is pretty dramatic. The Coleman would dim and brighten while the Porta Source was just steady on, without any fluctuations.While I haven’t gone camping or had a power outage yet to really use the IG800W, I have a feeling that it will perform really well. Hurricane Joaquin may be heading this way, so I may get to test it out. The Porta Source is built really rugged and I think that it will last, but since it is made in China, you never know. One of things that I like best about the unit is that when you are done using it, you can put it on a shelf in the garage until it is needed again. It comes with a one year for everything but the motor, which has a two year warranty.

I guess it depends upon what quadcopter you have if it is worth paying the premium price for the Lowepro Droneguard CS 300. This case is about twice the price of my Syma X5-SW-1. If you have a Parrot BeBop, which is what is shown in the product pictures, then it would be a better option considering that quadcopter runs about $500.I really like the Droneguard 300 CS. The protection is not so much based on padding on the inside of the case, but more on the hard shell case on the outside. Most of the outside of the case has a nice durable canvas like material glued tightly to what I assume is composite plastic shell. The back of the pack has some padding, as well as on the straps to give some comfort to your back and shoulders in case there is a long trek involved to get to the flight area.This case will NOT hold a DJI Phantom or Inspire, or Yuneec Typhoon Q500, it is not deep enough. For larger craft Lowepro makes the CS400, thought that looks like it can only handle a Phantom or 3DR Solo.Inside the case are four movable partitions that Velcro to the bottom of the case so that you can configure it the best way to fit your quadcopter and equipment. The quadcopter is safely secured by Velcro straps that attach to these barriers. There is also an oval barrier that can be made square to hold a transmitter, tools and various other items. The zippered pouch has two removable Velcro barriers just like the case has. This is good for smaller parts, cameras, batteries, etc. The zippered pouch provides a little more additional padding than the case provides. On the inside top of the case has a Velcro removable flat panel with a handle that has many loops to hold props, cables, tools, pens, etc. It has a zippered pocket that will hold a small tablet, papers or manuals. There are also similar nylon loops on the front of the pack as well as a zippered pocket that only goes about half way down and is quite tight. The main zippers have nice lanyard type loops that make it easy to zip and unzip the pack.The Lowepro Droneguard CS 300 is a quality case, though in my case, the Droneguard CS300 is probably better quality than the quadcopter it is protecting. For more expensive drones this case would provide great protection and is probably worth the price.

Netsun’s 10 foot Lightning to USB cable looks identical to a genuine Apple cable at a glance. It does not have the Netsun logo on the lightning connector (like in the picture), but does have the USB symbol on the USB connector. Apple does not make a 3 meter cable, but the Apple Store sells one from Belkin for $29.99. For that price you can almost get four of Netsun’s 3 meter cables.The Apple cable feels like it has a slightly thicker wire to it, but visually it’s hard to tell. The cable strains on Apple’s cable near the lightning and USB connectors are a little bit longer and a little bit stiffer, which indicates it probably won’t wear out as fast as Netsun’s cable, but Netsun has a “Lifetime Guarantee”, so if a cable wears out “You will get a free replacement shipped out, with no questions asked” according to the Amazon product page. The only problem is there they don’t tell you how to contact them. They need to provide this information with the product package, which is just a small ziplock bag. Even a small piece of paper inserted in the bag would suffice, or a sticker placed on the back of the bag would work fine. Instead you have to search for the NetSunDirect Customer Service link on the vendor’s storefront. Hopefully their customer service is good, and hopefully they don’t require you to mail the defective cable back to China. If that is the case it’s probably cheaper to just buy another one.I haven’t had any problems or errors while charging or syncing with this cable. Even though it does not state that it is “Apple MiFi Certified” like Belkin or Anker cables it does the job, and connects just fine.Overall Netsun’s 3 meter cable is a good value and works just fine, especially for the price.A Free Sample Product Was Provided To Review.

1:01 MinsThe Syma X5 SW-1 is a great quadcopter for beginners. That’s good, because that is exactly what I am, having lost one quadcopter that now resides about 65 feet up in my neighbor’s pine tree. It gives me great pleasure to review the latest release from Syma.When you open the box, you can see that it is packaged quite well in a white plastic tray with a clear cover over it. Taped underneath the tray is the phone clip, instruction manual, screwdriver, landing gear and extra battery so be sure to lift the tray out of the box. The manual is written in somewhat of a broken English, a few of the diagrams have labeling errors, but for the most part you can understand what it is saying. Syma provides plenty of pictures and drawings to help you figure things out.There is some minor assembly needed before flying. The four landing gear need to be placed into their holes and screwed in to the underside of the aircraft using the included screwdriver. Flipping the quadcopter over will necessary to accomplish this. There is only one screw per landing gear so it is an easy task. If you want to install the prop guards (beginners will definitely want to do this to save blades), there are two holes that the guards fit in near the props with a screw in the center to keep them in place. Once that is complete the only thing left to do is attach the camera, which slides on the bottom of the battery compartment. You will hear a click. The camera’s cable just needs to plugged into its jack and the Syma X5 SW-1 is just about ready to fly.The quadcopter comes with one battery preinstalled in its battery compartment, which is at the rear, the end with the blue blades. The door is on a hinge and there is a little shelf where the battery rests. Before flying I would recommend charging the batteries with the included USB charger because the flight time is only about six or seven minutes on a full charge and you will be disappointed when the battery is spent after just a few minutes To remove the battery from the Syma X5 SW-1 you need to find the wire and carefully pull the battery connector away from the aircraft connector. The battery then needs to be attached to the USB charger that has the same connector as the quad. There is a light within the USB connector that will go off when the battery is fully charged. It takes about an hour or two depending on the charger. Dedicated USB chargers seem to charge the batteries faster than plugging them into a computer or phone charger. Before the first flight four AA batteries will need to be acquired for the remote control unit, these are not included.Before flying it is necessary to download the Syma FPV app on your tablet or smartphone which allows you to see what the camera sees, record video and take still pictures. There is a clip that mounts to the transmitter’s antenna that you can attach the phone to. The clip sits on nice and tight, and it clamps my iPhone really well. The transmitter itself is pretty light and feels somewhat hollow inside which is good because when you add the weight of the phone in your hand you get tired of holding it. Unfortunately, the transmitter does not have a lanyard hook like some other brands. All of the buttons at the bottom of the transmitter are just molded into the case. They are hard plastic - fake, bogus, and non-functional. There is a small LCD screen that is not backlit and hard to see, especially in the glare of bright sunlight. It basically shows the amount of trim, the speed, the mode (1 or 2), throttle and direction, and the battery strength of the transmitter. Most of the time while flying you won’t be looking at this screen, it really doesn’t help that much. The button on the left side of the transmitter changes the speed (high or low) as well as puts the aircraft into “Headless Mode”, while the button on the right side makes the quadcopter perform 3D Eversions, otherwise known as flips. The 3D Eversion button does not work on my transmitter. When I tried it with a different Syma transmitter it worked, so the problem is not with the flight controller, but probably a wiring issue within the transmitter. It does make a beep when depressed, so it is making contact. In mode 1 (which is the most common), the left stick is throttle and rotate left and right. The other stick controls the angle of attack, which will make it travel in the direction the stick is commanding it go.Flying the Syma X5SW-1 is challenging and takes awhile to get even the basics down (which I am still trying to learn). The good news is this is a very forgiving aircraft. It is stable and virtually indestructible. If it hits an object it bounces off of it without any damage. It can even fall out of the sky from high up and just land on its gear that absorbs the impact. Just avoid the trees. It can easily get caught up in a tree, and if the prop guards are on they grab the branches and hold on until it can be retrieved or a lot of wind comes along to knock it out. The hardest thing to learn about flying a quadcopter is learning the orientation when it is flying towards you where left is right, right is left, and forwards is backwards. The white propellers and different colored navigation lights are supposed to help you out with this. Luckily Syma has a setting out called “Headless Mode” in which the flight controller will figure out the orientation for you and you just point the sticks where you want the craft to go. This is helpful for beginners, but those who want to become pros may want to leave this off and practice, practice, practice flying. I’ve heard that eventually this kicks in and you will get it. So far I have not.The exclusive blue color is easy to see while flying against the clouds and blue sky, but a little less visible when flying closer to the ground. My previous white quad was definitely more noticeable at lower altitudes; nevertheless the blue color is still quite visible in the daytime. The X5SW-1 just disappears in the night sky. The only things visible are the four navigation lights on the bottom.Because this quadcopter is so light weight it has problems flying in winds over 5 mph or so. In high winds you can give the transmitter full angle of attack towards the direction of the wind and the aircraft will just sit there as if hovering rather than travelling in that direction. The higher the altitude the more susceptible it is to winds and also having it fly away by getting caught in a sustained breeze. It is best to make sure that you fly on high speed and have a large enough space to fly the quadcopter especially on a windy day, because it will get pushed further and further away the windier it is. On gusty days it’s best not to fly at all.As a beginner, I find it extremely difficult to fly FPV using the app on my iPhone. I need to have a visual on the aircraft at all times. I have also noticed that there is a significant lag the further away the aircraft is from the transmitter. I know this because after the quadcopter has crashed to the ground it is still flying straight on the app and I can watch it crash on the screen. This lag would cause some issues if only flying FPV like hitting an object before it is visible on the screen. The FPV range is pretty good, luckily the transmitter range is better, so you can bring the SX5SW-1 back into range. If you fly out of FPV range the picture will just freeze until the connection is re-established. Since both the FPV WiFi and the transmitter are on 2.4 GHz frequencies I think they do cause some interference between each other. If I remove the camera the craft seems to fly better at a further distance away from the transmitter (not to mention longer flying time). Other manufacturers (such as DJI) usually separate the controller and FPV frequencies to avoid this issue.Recording video or taking still photos from the Syma X5SW-1 must be done through the Syma FPV app that you load onto your phone or tablet. The aircraft mounted camera does not have a micro SD slot to record on. This is a major flaw with this quadcopter because everything is dependent on the WiFi signal being broadcasted from the moving aircraft. While the signal is usually pretty good, there are times where it freezes up and may ruin otherwise flawless video footage. Besides the camera being dependent on WiFi, the recorded video only ends up at 480 X 360 once it is exported to the phone or tablet from the app, even though it fills the entire widescreen while being viewed in flight. Since there is no gimble the camera is also at the mercy of the aircraft’s movements, but at this price point I would not expect any sort of image stabilization. Obviously this is not videographer’s quad, but someone who just wants to have fun flying, learn how to fly to prepare for a larger aircraft, and get some basic video footage to show their friends.For the price point you really can’t beat the Syma X5SW-1 as long as you realize its limitations. It’s flight range is 50 meters (about 150 feet), the video footage is acceptable, but not great, the FPV has a lag which grows the further it is from the transmitter, the WiFi signal (camera) does interfere a little which makes the range a little bit less, and it cannot fly in windy conditions. For a beginner this is a great quadcopter. It is a nice mid size craft that it very stable and won’t get visually lost in the sky as soon as it is airborne. It makes a great quadcopter for those who want to take learn how to fly, then take the next step and get an aircraft costing thousands of dollars. In many ways the Syma X5SW-1 is harder to fly since it completely manual and needs attention 100% of the time. The more expensive quadcopters have GPS guidance, flight programming, auto take off and landing as well as data telemetry and maps that constantly give you two way feedback. The X5SW-1 has none of that. The only way it communicates with you is by blinking its lights on the craft itself (if you can see them) to tell you the battery charge is about to expire.A sample product was provided for free to review.

The ultimate in cheesy 70's antics! Roller disco, 8 track tape players getting stolen, motorcycle jumping, off road racing, and of course CB Radios, wow! Let's face it CHiPs was cheesy the minute it aired in the late 70's and everybody knew it, but everybody loved it just as much. That's what makes this a classic show and it's still fun to watch. Please keep the series coming, and don't wait so long between seasons! The DVD quality looks great, I'm sure it looks better than when it was originally broadcast. Sound is good, dialogue is clear, music is cheesy. The 5 disc 6 set comes with a slipcase and a 4 page booklet with episode summaries. CHiPs is highly recommended over today's television!

Crabby Digital makes one fine micro USB cable. This is the most distinctive cable that I own. The micro USB connector is very high quality, feels very durable, and is not coming off no matter how hard it is tugged. It is flat so it can easily connect to phones with tight cases. The larger USB connector does not look like any other USB I’ve ever seen. It looks like it would just fall out of the socket, but actually grips it quite well. It must be inserted with the USB symbol facing up. It will not make a connection if inserted upside down. That may be the only flaw I have with this cable. I’ve heard that there are newer connectors of this type that can be inserted either way.The cable itself is a generous six feet long with a strap that can bind up any of it that is unused. The flat cable design prevents tangling, which is always a problem with rounded cables. The wire has a very unique posable quality to it, you can actually make a sculpture out of it if you wanted to. Although this cable has a lifetime guarantee, the address on the box says “(Not a return shipping address)” and there is no other documentation, so Crabby really needs to clarify how this guarantee works. If I have to ship the cable back to China, no thanks. Overall I find Crabby Digital to make a fine high quality cable with unique qualities I haven’t seen in other cables.A free sample product was provided to review.

The Teikis Cocktail set makes a good gift for the amateur bartender. While I wouldn’t call this professional quality equipment, it is good enough for the average user.The steel for the jiggers is decent quality, it doesn’t feel like it will dent very easily. They have a polished finish on the outside and a brushed finish on the inside. The double sided 30 and 50 ml jigger is a bartender classic, while the single 25 and 50 ml jiggers are of a more modern design.The glass for the shaker is a bit small in diameter, so it has to fit pretty far into the steel shaker, only allowing a few inches for mixing, but that is probably enough. The fit is not perfect within the shaker and it takes some adjustment to find the right spot where the liquids won’t leak out when shaking, but it does work if placed correctly. The glass is nice and thick with rounded edges at its mouth that help with sealing the mixture in. It has half ounce measurements on the side as well as basic drink recipes for Dry Martini, Daquiri, Margarita, Bloody Mary and Manhattans. The strainer is a tad small for the mouth of the shaker, so some ingredients may get by along the edges, so it’s best to pour at and angle to avoid this.For those who prefer to have their drinks stirred instead of shaken (don’t invite James Bond to your party) there is long bar spoon with a nice twisted design. If you spin it around it sort of looks like a barber pole. The steel is strong and the spoon will not bend or break unless a lot force is used and its destruction is intentional. I like how the other end of the spoon has a flat end so that it can rest on the bar standing straight up.There is a big organic bartending movement going on using fresh ingredients, and the wooden muddler could help out bringing out the flavors in your herbs and fruits. The muddler is ergonomic, feels solid, and has just the right amount of stain and finish to show off its natural elegance.Although the box not specifically state this, I would imagine all but the muddler are dishwasher safe. Teikis has a nice cocktail set for the money, and despite a few issues, this would make a nice gift. It is presented nicely in the box and is decent quality for someone who wants to explore the world of concocting libations.A free sample product was provided to review.

Lancaster Caramel Company was Milton Hershey’s original candy company founded in 1886. Lancaster is an updated version of his recipes 125 years later.The tin is generic in the familiar Hershey’s brown color with a Lancaster logo sticker on the side, but I think that is entirely appropriate considering the simple Amish life of Lancaster, PA. There is also a cardboard sleeve on the top that shows the three different varieties inside, and a sticker on the bottom with the ingredients list and nutrition information.There are three different kinds of candy which all have distinct stripes on the ends of the label, so you can pick out the flavor that you want out at a glance. The plain caramel has a plain wide tan stripe, the Vanilla And Caramel has thin tan stripes with white in between them, and the Butterscotch and Caramel has thin tan, yellowish and white stripes.When you unwrap the candy you notice that it is shiny and has a slightly sticky feel to it. The candies that I received were so fresh and the caramels were so soft. Each flavor obviously has its own unique taste, and I can safely say that I do not have a favorite. I have bought the plain caramels before in the store and liked them a lot. They tasted very similar to Werther’s Chewy Caramels, but a bit better. The Butterscotch and Caramel flavor has the balance just right, not too much or too little Butterscotch flavoring, while the caramel shines through on it’s on merit. The Vanilla and Caramel flavor is creamier than the plain and once again the balance between the caramel and vanilla flavors is just right. They are all just plain yummy and addicting. I had to get the tin out the room just now since I was starting to binge eat them.Like I said earlier the tin I received was so fresh and the caramels were so soft and chewy. I would imagine that this might vary depending on delivery conditions and how long they are warehoused. The texture is so smooth and creamy, these are not like Kraft caramels that have a slight grit and dryness to them. Some might find Lancaster a bit sweet, I can see that, but I think most people will find them just about right. If you are a caramel lover like I am, you will definitely like this Lancaster assortment. The price is also about right considering I pay about $4 for a 4 ounce bag at the store.

The TP-Link HA100 Bluetooth Music Receiver is a great versatile product that anyone with older equipment needs to have. Most people have an old set of computer speakers laying around from a long retired desktop computer. You can put them to use with this device and have music in a room that you didn’t have it in before. Another use is to bring older stereo equipment up to date giving it Bluetooth capability. I have an older Denon receiver that does not have Bluetooth, Airplay or even HDMI capability. With the TP-Link HA 100 I now have the capability to listen to the music on iPhone and home media server through the Plex app on the phone. Welcome to the 21st Century old stereo! This device can even give Bluetooth music capability in the car. You will need a USB to car power adapter, and your car’s stereo would need an AUX input for this to work, but it is totally doable, it worked on my old Pioneer car receiver without an issue. Of course you will have to control the music from the phone itself, so it is not exactly handsfree. The unit is so flexible it will plug into any audio device that has either a stereo 3.5 mm jack or RCA jack input.I’ve been using another Bluetooth receiver on a set of old computer speakers, the Avantree Roxa which does the same thing as the TP-Link HA100. While the sound is every so slightly warmer than the HA100, the range on it is terrible. That is not the case with the TP-Link Bluetooth receiver, the range is phenomenal for any Bluetooth device that I’ve ever used. TP-Link claims the range is 66 feet. I would say it is at least that. I was able to go downstairs to the kitchen in the house, which is the furthest point away from unit that I could get without going outside the house. The Avantree Roxa would breakup if I just stepped out of the room.The TP-Link HA100 is so easy to setup. Just attach the USB cord to a USB port or to AC power with the included adapter, then either plug in the RCA cables (White is left and TRed is Right) or the 3.5 mm jack to the input of your speakers or receiver and the other end of the cable to the output of the Bluetooth Music Receiver. For some reason the left and right channels are reversed on my unit, or the wiring of the RCA cord is, and I had to plug the red plug in the left channel and the white plug in the right channel to get the correct phase. Next, the device should have a white LED on the front that indicates it is in pairing mode. Search your Bluetooth listing for TP-LINK MUSIC and connect to the unit. Pairing instructions vary by Bluetooth device, so follow the instructions included with the phone or tablet you are trying to pair. Android devices can pair by NFC, but I only have an iPhone and cannot test how this function works.The audio quality of music files vary greatly, most are compressed .mp3 files. When the audio files are played over Bluetooth they are compressed even more to allow for streaming. Some sound quality is sacrificed at the expense of convenience. You will never get audiophile quality over compression, but you can get some really good sounding audio if the original file is sampled correctly. The TP-Link sounds really great. There is good bass and a clear, crisp high end. It comes very close to the Avantree Roxa in sound quality, with the Roxa providing an ever so slightly warmer sound, but the incredible range of the HA100 would definitely make me recommend TP-Link’s Bluetooth receiver. The unit is small and can be tucked most anywhere, and the price does not break the bank.

You never really know how good a surge protector is until you actually need it. By then, you better hope that you have a good one that will protect your equipment. Until that time a surge protector is just another place to plug in your equipment.The Woods Multimedia Surge Protector can handle up to 1000 Joules, the lowest range of what Woods calls their “Extra Protection” tier of 1,000-1999 Joules, which is the amount of energy that the device can absorb when activated. Woods offers a $150,000 connected equipment warranty protection, which isn’t bad. The average person will have not have gear nearing that value attached to this power strip. The maximum power that this unit can handle is 1800 watts. The EMI / RFI noise filtration will block some WiFi range extenders and home automation equipment modules.The Woods Surge Protector is made of a medium grey brittle plastic with a cheap feel to it that seems like it could break somewhat easily if dropped on a hard floor, I won’t be performing this test to find out though. It has coax protection in case a spike comes through the cable or satellite wire and not the AC power. This would protect your cable set top box as well as your connected TV. All six outlets have sliding safety covers so that young children cannot poke things into the openings and risk possible electrocution. Each outlet is evenly spaced, so the big brick type adapters plugged into the power strip may cover up more than one plug. There is a lighted red on/off rocker switch on the side, and red surge and green ground status LED’s on the front. The four foot cord has a right angle plug, which is better than those 45 degree plugs some surge protectors have. Overall there is nothing special about the Woods Surge Protector, but there is nothing bad either (except maybe not having more space for larger brick adapters). The $150,000 connected equipment warranty offers a sense of security for the cheap price of this device.

You can't beat this sunshade for the price. The outside is made of a durable faux leather, while the inside has a microsuede feel to it . There are 48 suction cups in the rear that stick to the back of your phone to hold the shade in place. The shape is held together with two velcro strips on each side . When you unfasten the velcro, the sunshade lays flat like in the picture. There is enough clearance so that the clip can hold the phone, while the suction cups suck onto the back of the phone to hold the sunshade in place. I am using an iPhone 6 , but there may be enough clearance inside the shade to fit an iPhone 6 plus or the Android equivalent. You don't only have to use this sunshade for the DJI Phantom. Any FPV with a phone clip should work. I am using mine with a Syma X5-SW and it works fine. I highly recommend this FPV Cellphone Monitor Sunshade.One more thing, the price range on this product is crazy. I've seen the exact same product from another vendor for $50 - a far cry from the under $5 I paid (with free shipping). So look around for the best price.

Earlier in the season I borrowed my brother’s gas powered Troy-Built power washer to clean the deck, porch sidewalk house, etc. I found that experience to be less than extraordinary. The washer was noisy, the gas fumes were smelly and the exhaust burned my foliage when I used it near the house. Sure it was a little bit more powerful, but I wasn’t stripping paint or any heavy-duty use like that.The Briggs And Stratton Powerflow Pressure Washer was really easy to put together. Basically, you attach the handle with some bolts, then attach the hoses and spray gun, and you are all set. The manual says that you need to lubricate the O-Rings and connections to the high pressure hose, nozzle extension, and spray gun, but a quick feel indicated that this was done at the factory already. The manual states to use the lubricants sparingly, a light film is all that is required, and that is what I felt, so there was no need to apply any more.Connecting the hoses is simple. On one side of the unit you connect your garden hose, on the other side you connect the high pressure hose. To the high pressure hose you connect the spray gun and to the spray gun you connect the nozzle extension, where you connect the 7 in one nozzle. Once the hoses are connected, water supply is turned on and GFCI is tested, it’s time to turn the unit on. The master switch is on the bottom front of the washer and will begin pressurizing as soon as the switch is thrown, then the noise will stop – unlike a gas washer where the idle noise is continuous and gets louder when in use.There are seven settings on the unique 7 in one nozzle, three high pressure modes (Maximum, General, and Gentle) and four high flow modes (Fan Spray, Fan Spray With Soap, Extended Reach – for second story cleaning, and Extended Reach With Soap). The nozzle is very convenient and easy to turn. There is also an extra red nozzle that is the “Red High Pressure Nozzle” which gives the most cleaning power. I didn’t have a reason to use this one yet. The 7 in one nozzle comes in quite handy. When I was using my brother’s power washer that had four or five separate nozzles. I dropped one of them into the ivy when I was switching it, and it took awhile to find it. The 7 in one nozzle prevents losing any nozzles because there is no need to take it off, just turn it to the desired setting.Operation of the unit requires pushing in a safety switch, then pulling the trigger on the spray gun. Pressing the safety switch each time you want to pull the trigger gets old fast. It is a horizontal switch in an awkward place that you have to push in, and requires some force. On the other hand, those who have kids will be grateful the unit has this switch. I can’t see a young kid being able to push this safety in.When you press the trigger on the spray gun (after pressing the safety) the pressure washer kicks in. It sounds like a vacuum cleaner when the motor turns on, and it wasn’t nearly as loud as my brother’s gas powered unit. I used the unit without soap and was amazed at how well it cleaned the green mold off of the side of the house without anything but water. Normally I would scrub and scrub and scrub with bleach to remove the green, and even that didn’t remove it all and required a lot more work.The next thing I cleaned was the concrete area in front of my garage, which turned green with algae, mold or whatever. I was amazed at the results. The concrete looked clean and refreshed. It looked even whiter once it dried. I was impressed.On another occasion using the unit I cleaned up some pavers, a stone birdbath and even my car’s tire rims also with great results. Next time I will wash the entire car and try the soap tank out.There isn’t much to the cleanup of this machine. First shut it off, unplug it from AC power and turn off the water supply. Next shoot out any pressurized water from the unit and remove the water supply hose, then remove the high pressure hose and remove the hose spray gun remove the 7 in one nozzle from the spray gun and remove the nozzle extension. Everything needs to wiped down with a damp cloth including the unit. The unit needs to be turned on each side side for two minutes to empty any remaining water. There are holders on the sides that both the spray gun and nozzle extension snap into for storage as well as spot in the middle of the tray to store the 7 in one nozzle. The “Red High Pressure Nozzle” needs to stored on the end of the nozzle extension wand. That is something that annoys me since it is small and bound to get lost when I have to take it off the wand and replace it with the 7 in one nozzle, which will be used most of the time. It’s almost like when the unit was designed they forgot to include a place to hold this nozzle, then after the unit went into production someone in a meeting said to just store on the end of the extension rather than to correct the mistake. The AC power cord storage hook is too small for the amount cord plus the heavy GFCI, it needs to stick out further and be a little bit longer. I think there should also be a spot where the GFCI should snap into on the side of the handle to prevent it from dropping to the ground when moving or storing the washer. Hose storage is a little bit better, though after the initial use you will never get the tight curl that it came with and will get tougher to hang on the hook the more it is used.While I wouldn’t use this unit for marine or any heavy duty cleaning, it is fine for general household cleaning. I liked my experience with the electric unit much better than my brother’s gas power washer. It serves my needs just fine, and if I need to strip paint or something like that I will borrow my brother’s again, but for me the Briggs & Stratton Powerflow+ is a really nice unit. I still have a lot more to clean with it, and so far I have not run into any of the issues that others have had. I highly recommend this power washer.
The unreleased Real People album finally sees the light of day. Real good stuff.

The Mobilink Intelligent Charger does a great job charging all of my devices. I don’t have an Android phone or tablet, so was not able to test the Quick Charge 2.0 jack, but it is backwards compatible and can be used like a regular SmartUSB charging jack. I have connected my iPhone, wireless keyboard, my GPS, Bluetooth Speakers, and even my Syma quadcopter batteries all at the same time to the Mobilink and it charges them all quicker than their standard chargers. The plastic housing is heavy and durable and doesn’t feel like it would shatter if dropped on the floor or a hard surface like some other products that I’ve tried. The ABS+PC fireproofing shell provides some peace of mind if for it shorted out for any reason, but the charger seems very well built, so I don’t think that is very likely.  The unit can be used while travelling without a transformer with its automatic 100-240V  voltage switching, and the 6 foot AC cord has Velcro so you can make the cord a desired length, which is nice if you have a short cord run. The only thing that I would have like to have seen on the Mobilink Intellegent Charger are LED status lights for each port so that you could tell at a glance if a plugged in device was charging, almost done, or finished charging. With a two year warranty, Quick Charge 2.0 and 100% Money Back Guarantee you cannot go wrong with this device.I was provided a free sample product for this review.

One thing that I can say about Sony’s BDPS6500 Blu-ray Player is that the picture quality is absolutely stunning. The Triluminos technology lives up to the hype. Although I currently don’t own a 4K television, I would imagine the 4K upscaling would be excellent as well, but I will have leave that analysis for someone else. The audio quality is also pretty spectacular. I am using the coax digital output rather than HDMI, since my receiver is a little bit dated and does not have any inputs of that type. One quick note, this device lacks optical audio output and composite (analog) jacks, make sure your audio system will accept HDMI or digital in if you plan on connecting it to surround sound.Sony has gone to a minimalist style following their diamond cut series of Blu-Ray players. There are only two buttons (power and open/close), a green power LED and a USB port on the front of the unit – no display at all. The unit sure packs a lot of features into a box that is smaller than my recently upgraded cable set top box (in fact it rests on top of it - making sure I am not covering up any vent holes of course). Sony has created a nice flagship Blu-Ray player here, although it does have a few quirks.One of the quirks of the BDPS6500 has to do with self-burned data discs containing .mp4 files. The player had no problem seeing the files on the disc and then no problem playing them for about a minute or less. After that, the machine mysteriously just stops playing the file, reboots showing the Blu-Ray splash screen, and then shuts off (The LED goes out). It did not seem to matter what data disc I put in, every one did exactly the same thing. Strangely enough, the exact same files are on a home media server and play fine while streaming (More on that later). For the minute that I was able to play the data discs, the playback quality was superb. The video was crystal clear, the colors were vibrant but accurate and the audio was crisp. Any self-burned disc in DVD format did not have this issue, they played just fine - looking and sounding great.Another quirk I found had to do with DNLA and my media server. When I chose my server, then Videos >> TV Shows >> All Shows >> (Folder With TV Shows name) many of the folders would display “No Playable File In This Category”, but when I selected  “By Folder” and a few other categories, the program played just fine, with no problems. I usually use a Plex client (I currently use it with Roku and my iPhone) and everything works fine through that wonderful system. For this device, Plex is still in Preview through the Opera store. Once it is out of preview I will solely be using it for local streaming, so this will be a non-issue fairly soon. Since there is a workaround to play these files, it’s really not much of a problem anyway.Finally, the last quirk I will mention is that after a couple of days of not being used the Blu-Ray player has the tendency to lose its internet connection and give itself a self-assigned IP address. When this happens, the only way to resolve that issue is unplug the unit for about thirty seconds and plug it back in. At that point, your home network’s DHCP server will assign it a legitimate IP address on your network and re-establish the internet connection. No matter how many times I tried to reconnect from the network settings on the unit I could not get rid of the bogus self- assigned IP. Unplugging it is the only thing that did the trick. Perhaps this has to do with a power saving feature, or needs to be addressed with the next firmware issue, I don’t know.The BDP6500 plays DVD’s and Blu-Rays just great, I couldn’t be happier with the playback from them. It streams Netflix with stunning clarity. The colors were vivid and audio clarity was excellent. The Wi-Fi connection is rock solid (when it does not have a self-assigned IP), Netflix did not buffer once while watching a movie, of course a decent router helps here as well. One thing that puzzles me is why Sony did not put a 5.0 GHz Wi-Fi radio or Gigabit Ethernet in this brand new player. You would think that they would be outfitting the latest 5.0 GHz AC band technology rather than relying on the old 2.4 GHz n band. The same goes with the Ethernet. Most people have Gigabit routers installed these days, so why wouldn’t this player come with that. It certainly can’t cost that much more for these components.Besides Netflix, Sony has pre-installed several apps to the intuitive home page including Hulu, Amazon Instant Video, Pandora, YouTube, and a few more, with the ability to add many apps of your choice. Several of the apps require an account or a paid subscription. The Pandora app had a flat boring look to it and for some reason it took several minutes to load the next song providing long gaps of silence between tunes. On some stations the next song never did load, and I had to go back to the home screen and re-launch the app. My six year old Panasonic Blu-Ray player does a better job at Pandora playback, with much quicker song loading. The You Tube app was a much better experience. It loaded quickly, is laid out nicely, and is easy to search for videos. The picture and audio quality varies based on the quality of the original video, but the BDP6500 does its absolute best to upscale and provide the greatest experience possible. 1080p videos look awesome, and there is no buffering. Many of the other apps are for international viewers or of specific interests – gadgets, kids, sports, etc. The apps vary in quality and content, some are done well, while others are terrible. The Flixster app does not allow the user to log in and watch the Ultraviolet content they may have on their account, so to me that is disappointing. The Opera web browser app can be slow and clunky. It is sometimes very hard to read and many videos won’t play on it. You will inevitable reach for your phone’s browser over this one, but I guess it’s ok.Speaking of your phone, Sony has a really nice iOS or Andorid app called TV Sideview, which will turn your phone into a nice multifunctional remote for the BDP6500 that has a trackpad and keyboard, and all of the physical remote functions as well. TV Sideview also incorporates a nice TV Guide with recommended programming and a DNLA controller that will even turn on the player if it is shut off. Since we are talking remotes, the physical remote that comes with this unit is pretty nice. It’s small but fits nice in your hand and everything is within easy reach of your thumb. There is a dedicated Netflix button that brings you right to that app and a Favorites button for which you can assign favorite apps. There are controls to turn your TV on and off, change the volume and input. You don’t have to have a Sony TV; you can enter a specific code based on the brand.One thing I am not, and that is a gamer by any means, but Sony’s BDP6500 IS! Sony provided my with a Dualshock 4 Game Controller and a month’s subscription to Playstation Now to test out the gaming aspect of the device and all I can say is WOW! All of the games that I played streamed like a charm with 1080p graphics and what appeared to me to be full surround sound. They were smooth and so detailed! Too bad I stunk at everything that I played except maybe Wheel Of Fortune. I’m going to have to let a gamer discuss Playstation Now in more detail, but as far as I can see it works great. One thing I don’t like about it is that the controller cannot be used wirelessly. It must physically be connected via USB cable to the Blu-Ray player. That may turn off some true gamers.One final word on the BDP6500, and that is Sony got the CD player right! When you insert a CD into this machine it searches the Gracenote database, correctly finds the CD and retrieves the track names and cover art and plays the CD just like a streaming player would. This is much better than some older players, which just gave “CD Track 1” as the information on the screen. The audio from the CD also sounds great. Well done Sony.Pros:Nice Picture QualityGreat Audio QualitySmall FootprintDVD’s and Blu-Ray playback is fast and flawlessNetflix plays back with stunning quality (when in HD) – no bufferingNice You Tube appOpera Store App adds the possibility of many more apps including PLEX media player (currently in PlexPass Preview)Excellent iOS and Android remote app with DNLA controller and Program GuideNice Remote control – feels good in the hand, and has on/off volume and input controls for multiple TV brands (not only Sony).Playstation Now streams games without a Playstation console (game controller not included)Excellent CD playback with cover art and track names – looks like a streaming playerCons:Problems playing .mp4 files on data discsDNLA is temperamentalSometimes loses internet connection when not used for daysLacks 5.0 GHz WiFi and AC Protocol – only has 2.4 GHz n bandLacks Gigabit EthernetThe Grey, flat Pandora app sometimes leaves long gaps of silence between songs.Opera Web Browser is slow and clunkyGames Controller needs to be attached to unit by USB cable – cannot connect wirelessly

Teikis has a pretty nice measuring set here. The measuring cups have a matte finish and are made of heavy, durable stainless steel that won't get dinged if they are dropped. The flat bottom makes sure that they won't tip over while you are measuring. I like that they have straight sides and are not taped like my current set of measuring cups. The only weak point I see is where the handles are welded onto cups, they are not all one solid piece of metal. Teikis also includes a 3/4 cup measuring cup which a lot of sets do not have, yet a lot of recipes call for. Be sure to wash the measuring cups before using them since there appears to be specks of black debris from processing in spots. The cups are dishwasher safe.The measuring spoons are nice. They are also made from durable stainless that cannot be bent easily, unlike my current set of spoons. The polished finish makes sure your measurement slides out easily. Each spoon has the measurement stamped into the handle, it is easy to see and won't wash off. The spoons are dishwasher safe.While I like its straight, untapered sides, the glass measuring cup is a little bit peculiar. The first thing you notice is that it does not have any CUP measurements which is the standard for US cooking, only ounces and milliliters, with a 1/2 liter marking above the ounce markings (which I find a little strange - why mix US measurements with metric?). When I'm cooking, I don't want to do any unnecessary converting. The markings are easy enough to read and appear to made of the same material as my old liquid measuring cups, which in time wears off with washing. Although the glass seems pretty thick, and has that greenish tint around the edges, the company does not tell you exactly what kind of glass it is and what it can take. Is it Pyrex? Tempered? Is it Microwave safe, Oven Safe, etc.? It's a mystery. The only thing they print on the outside of the box is that it is dishwasher safe. That's good, just not good enough. We need to know a little more. I would be afraid of it shattering with any amount of heat applied to it.Teikis provided a free sample product for this review.

SanDisk makes great memory for a decent price. My Tom Tom said that it was out of memory, so I bought this Micro SD card. It was recognized immediately after I inserted it and was asked if I wanted it formatted. Of course I said yes and now I have another 7.6 Gigs (after formatting) of memory to play with, which will probably be enough for the lifetime of the GPS.

Imogen Studio’s +CAM Pro is wireless network camera designed for monitoring your home, business or property from a remote location. Lately, a growing number of these cameras have popped up including Belkin’s WeMo camera, Nest’s DropCam. D-Link’s Cloud Cam, just to name a few.Setting up the camera is similar to setting up a WeMo device. First download the free iSecurity + app and turn on the Wi-Fi setup switch. The camera will emit its own WiFi signal that you attach your device to, then start the app and it will detect the camera. Next it searches for your home’s Wi-Fi and asks for the password. This connects the camera to the internet using the iSecurity/Seedonk app that you must register for in the next step, creating a login.After successfully logging in you are at the main window where you can see the cameras that were configured during the setup. If you tap that camera the app tries to connect to the camera, however I’ve had mixed results with the app connecting each time. Usually the camera connects right away on the local network, but not always. Sometimes there is a delay and sometimes it does not connect until you try to connect again. There does not seem to be any specific reason why it won’t connect. For example I was at my brother’s house (he has no firewall) on his Wi-Fi and could not connect at all try after try, while at the local Home Depot it connected right away on their Wi-Fi. By default the audio from the camera is turned off once the connection is established. It can be turned on by tapping the speaker button on the control panel at the bottom of the screen. There is also a microphone icon you tap on it to talk allowing two-way conversation, and icons to record photos and video of what you are seeing which are saved in “Photos” on the iPhone for later viewing.While the Product Description on Amazon’s page indicates that this camera can run in 640x480 or 320x240, at up to 30 fps resolution, The specs below that indicate that the sensor’s resolution is 1600x1200 with 720p video quality and electronic pan, tilt and zoom controls (which don’t seem to exist anywhere in the app). The box and limited documentation do not contain any specifications either, so Imogenstudio is making things incredibly confusing by not providing the correct information.In any event, there are no settings to change the resolution or capture rate and nothing to indicate what resolution you are actually viewing. Any stills or video that was captured from the screen shows up with a resolution of 320X240 with the video at 8.4 fps, so you are getting pretty low quality. The video has a slightly soft focus to it rather than being crisp and sharp and colors are fairly muted and not realistically saturated. I would imagine that a highly compressed picture is the reason for this.The night vision capability is about average for a camera of this price, though I put on the auto setting I still found turned it on in a room full of bright sun. For all of these reasons I would only use this as a casual monitoring camera and not for any real security purposes.The app to view the camera is similar to other apps for cameras of this type. You can view, record video, take snapshots, listen to audio, and talkback through the camera’s built in speaker. The app has the ability to share your cameras with friends who have to register with iSecurity+ and create their own login. This will send them a link to view their camera on a Flash enabled web browser. The “Events” button allows you to see motion activated “Events” detected by the camera in the form of a video clip.  Under the camera’s settings there is a Motion Sensitivity setting as well as a Phone Notification switch that can get annoying, because it constantly goes off when motion is triggered.  Likewise, there are several video clips recorded every time a notification is sent. Each video is time and date stamped. There is no way to select videos to delete either. Each one has to be sent to the trash individually, which is a pain. iSecurity+ allows the storage of all events for one day for free, which can be saved to Photos on the iPhone for those who don’t want to pay $9.99 a month for 14 day event retention. The camera comes with a 30 free trial to test this service out.One thing that is not mentioned anywhere in the product’s description is that there is also a web interface at app.isecurityplus.com  which allows users to see their camera’s video from the web in case their phone is unavailable. While the web interface is not as robust as the app, it does provide some basic settings.My overall impression with imogenstudios +CAM Pro is favorable, but it needs improvement all around. A camera that only has a resolution of 320x240 with an 8.4 fps frame rate is pretty useless these days. Why are the colors washed out and the focus a little soft? How come I can log in sometimes and not other times? I hope the makers of +CAM Pro will look at these issues, figure out the actual resolution that the camera really is, and hopefully make it a better experience for the user. The camera is fine to check on your pet throughout the day, see if the kids are home from school, or just look at an empty room, but it should be cheaper.

I like black teas. Probably my favorite every day tea is PG Tips from England. I also prefer Assam and Ceylon teas, as well as Darjeeling and blends like and Irish and English Breakfast teas, and a nice Chai. Most of the time I enjoy my tea with milk and sugar and I steep the teas just slightly beyond the recommended times to assure that they are strong enough, but not bitter. I’m not too fussy about the tea estate, the flush, production date, and its grading because I can’t afford the high end teas where that really matters. All I care about is taste.Capital Teas Breakfast Organic Tea has a nice robust aroma upon opening the zipper resealable plasic pouch, almost like a spicy smell to it. The leaves are small to medium in size and require an average amount to get a nice brew. For a small Brown Betty pot I generally use three small spoons of tea – one for each cup and one for the pot. Following the instructions I heated my water to about 195 F and brewed for about five minutes.This organic breakfast tea steeped up to a nice color, dark enough to take milk and sugar. Sometimes teas come out looking (and tasting) weak no matter how much tea is added, or how long it sits. Capital Teas Breakfast Organic smells nice, but the early spicy aroma is now gone and it has smells more like a Keemun than anything else Now let’s give it a taste.Yes, to my palate there is a strong Keemun and slight Darjeeling flavor. The Dimbula component is generally mild but offers some astringency. There is some Assam flavor, but it is in the background, which is surprising based on the tea’s description, that lead’s one to believe it is its main component giving it “a thick malt and full-bodied character.”Overall I find Capital Teas Breakfast Organic to be pretty good. It has a nice balanced flavor that steeps to a medium-strong cup and stands up to milk and sugar without a fight. At nearly eleven dollars for four ounces (at the time of review), it’s not exactly cheap, but it’s not the most expensive either. I guess it’s close to being competitive to David’s Tea or Teavana (now owned by Starbucks). If you can afford it I don’t think you would be disappointed.

303 ProtectsAs a convertible owner good rubber seals around the roof, doors and windows are a matter of leaking or staying dry, so I tried 303’s Rubber Seal Protectant. My car is pretty old and the rubber was starting to get a little bit grey and lose some of its elasticity. Once I applied this product I instantly saw the rubber get a little bit darker and get more supple. Sure when it is applied it is wet, so will look darker, it dries lighter than the color that it goes on, but that was still better than the untreated rubber.The application is easy. First you want to clean the seals with a wet or damp cloth to clean them, and wait for them to dry. Next, shake the bottle well and touch the rubber seal with the felt applicator while gently squeezing the bottle. You can control the amount of the product that comes out by pressure of the squeeze that is applied. It is very similar to applying liquid shoe polish to shoes. The applicator is pretty precise and gives you a good amount of control where the product will go. It even has a pleasant smell when applying it. Once all of the rubber seal surfaces are covered you can wipe up any excess with a clean towel and let the 303 Rubber Seal Protectant dry, which does not take long at all.I have a squeaky window where the rubber seal meets the glass in the back of the car. I’m sure hoping that this will help if not eliminate that issue. I’ll let you know after I have driven around. If it does help I will apply it every 3-5 weeks as recommended by the manufacturer.Update: My window chatter has completely disappeared. It looks like I will be re-applying the product in 3-5 weeks!

Amazon has lumped the reviews for multiple colors and sizes into one bundle, so be careful that the review you are reading corresponds to the product you are interested in.Belkin cables are great. They are made well, and sometimes cost a little more than other cables, but usually provide a good warranty and stand behind their products. This review is for the Mixit Gold Lightning to USB Cable – 4 feet or 1.2m in length. It comes with a two-year warranty, which is better than Apple’s warranty for their 1meter cable – that only has one year.The cable has a retro mid century modern feel with what feels to be a beige braided fabric covering (probably nylon) that compliments the connectors that are painted gold to match the color of the gold iPhone. The connectors seem solid and durable and feel like they will last for years. The four-foot length is perfect for me. The Apple cord that came with the iPhone was just too short for where I am charging it, and I have pulled the plug out of the wall accidently while looking at the phone. This length is the perfect size. It doesn’t hang down on the floor, yet allows me to look at the phone while charging without yanking the cord out of the wall socket.Because this cable is MiFi Certified, you shouldn’t get any messages saying that it won’t work on your device.
