I have been using it for weeks without any issue, and I highly recommend Belkin’s mixit Lightning to USB cable.

0:28 MinsThis is my first attempt at flying anything remotely, and as a beginner I am crashing more than flying right now. The Syma X5SW seems to take any crashes! Learning how to fly is a bit trickier than I thought, but the craft does seem to be quite stable, and I'm sure after a bit flying the X5SW will be a breeze. The most important thing as a beginner is to fly in a clear area. I haven't and that is my fault. So far I have got the copter caught in trees, almost hit the house, and came close the the power line, which I think would just make the craft drop. It just goes to show you how much the X5SW can take. Due to the limited space I haven't taken it up high yet for fear that I'd never get it back, but I'm going out to a field soon and I think that will vastly improve my skills and allow me to fly a lot higher. Since my main concern was not hitting things I never really glanced down at the FPV screen while flying. Once I am more relaxed and more skilled that will be cool to fly by. I have recorded videos on the phone, which are only 640 X 480. The quality is just OK, not great, but for the price I wasn't expecting anything cinematic. The camera does not come with an SD card slot, it records directly onto the smartphone from the wi-fi connection, so you are not going to get really high quality from the camera. If your aim is to just have fun and shoot some aerial shots, not minding some latency, than this is a good quad for you. If you are a photographer, I'd check out a different quad. Syma's X5C-1 has a better camera with an micro SD slot, but no FPV display and is cheaper than the X5SW. Overall I am pleased with the Syma X5SW, it is stable, and a good beginner quad at a good price.UPDATE: I went to the local school field where I had some room to fly this quad. At first it was dropping out of the sky and not responding to my commands, but after flying it more and more I became more comfortable with the controls and am flying it much better now. The most confusing part of flying is knowing whether the craft is coming or going, so you can adjust the controls accordingly, or just fly in headless mode and the quad will figure it out for you. Syma has updated the software of the camera and it should record in 720p, but I'm not seeing that, but it does give widescreen while flying at least. The video freezes occasionally and is not as good as having an on board SD card. Syma needs to make a camera that can provide FPV as well as record onto an SD card at the same time rather than relying on only the WiFi connection. That would really make this a good quad. I would recommend getting something like this before upgrading to a DJI Phantom or Inspire to practice before you end up crashing and wasting a lot of money.2nd Update- I think that there is definitely a problem with my transmitter. I think that there is a dead spot in my throttle, since the throttle kept stopping and the craft would drop out of the sky, restarting about half way down, almost hitting the ground.Yesterday I flew it and it was not responding to my commands to turn and ended up 50 feet in a tree, where it currently resides until a big wind hopefully will bring it down. The batteries on the controller are reading full,and the quad was not far enough away to be out of range.

My cat likes Fancy Feast Mornings cat food, so naturally I thought that she would like Nutro's Breakfast Scrambles. Boy could I be more wrong. She took one sniff of of it walked away. I tried to get her to eat it at least four times before finally giving up on it. My cat cat be finicky, but she won't even try this cat food.

The Tacwise Z3-140 Heavy Duty hand stapler is a nice upgrade from the classic Arrow T50 stapler that has been around since the 1950’s that your father and grandfather probably used. The orange plastic handle looks great and is much easier on the hands than the old steel one. The bottom portion is a nice looking silver powder coated metal. Overall this is a very durable unit and unless it is dropped from ten stories up (or more), would probably take any abuse you could give it.Loading the Tacwise Z3 is a breeze. Inserting the staples is so much easier than the old Arrow models. It’s just an action of turning over the stapler, squeezing two tabs and pulling the magazine towards you. Then, place the staples in the slot created by the magazine’s absence and putting the magazine back in place. No more dealing with that spring loaded metal thing that shoots across the room if it is not securely fastened that Arrow had.The operation of this stapler is smooth and requires less effort to drive the staples in than the Arrow T50. Your hand and arm will be thanking you for using the Tacwise Z3-140 later in the day. There is a power adjuster that the manufacturer recommends to switch when driving larger 10mm+ fasteners. The Tacwise Z3 can also drive nails and headless pins (or brads) so it is extremely versatile. I plan on using it soon to replace many torn screens in the summer porch. The magin edge adjuster looks useful. It allows stapling in a nice straight line that is adjustable for almost the entire length of the unit. There is a belt clip, and little clear window with a label where you can write your name or place an identifying mark. When not in use there is a handle lock down feature so the kids can’t shoot their eye out (Yes, A Christmas Story reference).The Tacwise Z3-140 is a quality product made in England, NOT China, and the craftsmanship shows. I highly recommend it! For The price, you can't find anything made this nicely anymore. Tacwise provides a one month money back guarantee on its product, and a three year standard warranty if it becomes defective. There is even a Product Advice and Technical Support number that at present is UK based, but there is also an email address that maybe helpful.

The cable that comes with any USB hard drive is an awkward length. It feels like it should either be a little longer, or a little shorter. The Belkin three foot USB 3.0 cable solves that issue. Now, the cable length feels right and allows the placement of either close or distant on the desktop.Belkin has made a quality cable here. It’s about twice the thickness as the cable that originally came with the external hard drives, which is what I would guess allows it to supply 50% more power to the device. Belkin does not claim the cable is any faster, just that it supplies more power to the drive. The connectors are really solid and have raised bumps that grip your fingers when attaching or removing it.The cable was tested on both Seagate and Western Digital External USB 3.0 hard drives and worked well on both, but I did not see any noticeable difference in transfer speed from the manufacturer supplied cable. Although I don’t have one, this Micro-USB 3.0 cable can also be used to charge certain Android phones like the Galaxy series. Belkin provides a two year Limited Warranty on this cable.While I am not taking off any stars off of my review for this, it is necessary to note that Belkin is charging a premium price for this cable, so price comparison based on quality is recommended before purchasing.

No / No Wild Bird Feeders stand for No Wood/ No Plastic. On the Ladybug Birdfeeder, the head, eyes and spots are all made of plastic. This is ok, but for a company whose name refers to being plastic free, this feeder is not.The rest of the feeder is red powder coated wire mesh that seems durable and will hopefully last for quite a while. The “feet” of the ladybug are perches for birds to land on. I have to agree with another reviewer that the feet are not painted well. Underneath the black is red powder coating, which is visible in many spots on the feet (You can even see this in the product picture on this page with the sparrow). Perhaps another coat of the black paint might have been helpful.The company recommends Suet, Sunflower or Peanuts to fill the feeder with. The spacing in the mesh is pretty big, so any old Wild Bird seed would just fall through this feeder, leaving a mess on the ground.  With just a few options, I chose to fill the feeder with sunflower seed. That actually is too big for this mesh, unless the smaller Black Oil is used. The directions that came with the feeder did not specify that though, I bought the regular type. I would have thought the company would have given the buyer a heads up on that.The backside of the ladybug is flat so that it may be hung against a fence, which would stabilize the feeder when a bird lands on it. There is a chain with a loop to hang the feeder from. I have mine dangling on a hook in the garden. Unfortunately, I have yet to see a bird land on the feeder and try and feed from it, but it does get a visit from the neighborhood squirrel almost daily. The poor thing hangs upside down from the top of it and seems to struggle to get the sunflower seeds out through the mesh. Obviously smaller seeds are required if birds were to ever get their beaks in the holes.The No No Ladybug Birdfeeder is made in China (hopefully not with Lead powder coating) and should be hand washed with a mild soap. The FAQ’s on this page do not appear to apply to this feeder and need to be revised. For example they indicate that the product can be dish washed, when the included documentation does not recommend it. It also says you can put Nyger and Mixed Seed in this feed, but it would fall right through the holes.This time of year is not exactly bird feeding time, the colder winter months are much better, so it is not surprising to see a lack of birds flocking to this feeder, therefore I cannot take off any stars for that. I think if I put suet in it I will have much better luck and attract small birds to it. The cuteness factor of the Ladybug Bird Feeder is quite high and it seems pretty well built, even the squirrel thinks so.

Amazon offers so many water filters (many through third party vendors), but this is the only one I have found with NSF certification. It's very difficult to really tell if the filter makes a difference, but I'm sure it does.
Nothing beats Parallels to run Windows on my Mac. It's fast and doesn't require any rebooting, just click on the icon in the dock and Windows launches.

Epson's Claria ink is expensive, especially since my printer takes 6 cartridges, but the clarity of the printing, especially on photo paper is top notch and can't be beat. Hopefully the price will come down, but I'm afraid to use non-Epson inks in my printer. I've heard some horror stories from people who have.
This network card is cheap and it is fast when connected to a gigabit network. Highly recommended.

The Adonit Jot mini is good for artists and people who need to write on their touchscreen devices. One thing that comes to mind is a vendor using Square on their phone to make purchases can offer their customer a stylus instead of using their finger. For everyday use however I find isn’t always responsive as my finger is, it makes a tap, tap, tap noise when using it, and probably in time would scratch my screen protector (or screen) if used regularly. I would imagine people who love to draw on their iPads would like this device. It draws a nice precise fine line. The built in clip holds quite well, and the cap screws on to the other end when the stylus is in use. It’s small enough to fit in any pocket, but large enough to hold on to and not get lost. One thing that probably would get lost is the tiny clear plastic disc on the end of it. I have lost it twice now, and it is a real bugger to try and find because it is teeny and clear. Unfortunately, once this little disc is lost, the stylus is useless on touch screens (well at least the iPhone). Adonit should provide a few replacement discs in the package, but unfortunately they do not, which is a big problem. While the Jot Mini is a nice stylus, I think it is only necessary when a precise fine line is needed such as jotting notes, signing documents, drawing and graphics, or mapping.

There are many things to like about Lenmar’s Undead Power Maven case, and a few things not to like. The major dislike of this case is that it needs a dongle cable to use the headphones because the bottom of the case is too long for a regular plug to connect. Lose this cable or forget it on a long trip and you’re out of luck. It’s not like you can pop into Best Buy and pick one up. That’s definitely the biggest problem I have with this case.To install the Maven, the top of the case slides off and the phone slides into a groove that precisely fits the phone into an embedded lightning connector at the bottom. Once the phone is fully seated, just slide the top back on and it is ready to use. It fits the iPhone 6 snugly without adding too much bulk or weight and its hard plastic shell would probably protect the phone decently. I’m not sure what sort of damage would be done to the battery if the phone is dropped though. Hopefully the company protects the battery well, but I’m not going to be performing that test.At first I had trouble charging the phone in the case, but it turns out that I was not using a USB charger that had enough current. It charged the case by itself, but would not charge the iPhone in it. Plugging it into a different USB charger remedied this issue. When the iPhone is in the Lenmar Maven, the phone will charge first, and then after it is fully charged, the case will start charging, which takes about two hours to fully charge.While using the case I found that the sleep/wake and volume buttons were a little bit hard to use since they are the iPhone’s actual buttons and are inset around the plastic case. I’ve seen similar cases that had the buttons built into the case to resolve this issue. I probably would have preferred that, but it’s all in the angle and fingers that are being used. Once the iPhone’s charge is depleted pressing the button on the back of the case for three seconds will give the phone “Undead Power”, which will give the phone another full charge, plus a little bit more. This process takes about an hour and a half to get to 100%.While I may not use Lenmar’s Undead Power Maven as an every day case, I will certainly use it while travelling, camping, or in a place that I know I can’t readily plug in.Pros:LightweightEasily fits in jeans front pocketCase charges quicklyA great case when going on long flights without the ability to charge, or areas without power.Raised lip around screen provides protectionEasy to install and removeMicro USB cable can be used to sync iPhoneLED intuitively shows amount of charge left on case1Year WarrantyOne Free Replacement part (headphone cable, top piece or charging cable) if registered onlineCons:Needs a headphone dongle. If this is lost, headphones cannot be used.Case cannot get wet. User guide rule #5 says to immediately remove the iPhone 6 and turn the Maven off, and not to use it again until it is completely dry.Volume control is a little bit hard to reach if the phone is not positioned correctly in the hand.Uses / Charges with a micro USB, not a lightning cable. This may not work with some iPhone accessories or car audio that use a lightning connector for connectivity.“Amplified Sound” is nothing more than a hole for the sound of the speaker, leading to a chamber at the bottom of the case with smaller front facing holes, nothing electronic.A Little bit slippery, but curved back helps with grip.Cord contains leadCase slightly bulky
The last of Michael Douglas in this next to last Season of the Streets Of San Francisco. It will always be one of my favorite cop shows.

While I Love PG Tips, I'd rather get 1.5 Kg in 6 250g boxes direct from the UK so that it stays fresh throughout the same time I'd use this large bag. The boxes only cost a few dollars more, and it's guaranteed freshness!
Cameron so reminds me of A sexier Watts from Some Kind of Wonderful in this series, and that alone makes me want to watch this series.

I was worried after reading the manufacturer's description that this scent would be a heavier aroma since it has patchouli, basil and dark chocolate tones, but it is in fact balanced just right. It does remind me of another scent that I used in the past, perhaps Drakkar Noir, but it is crisper and more elegant than I remembered that to be.Lacoste L.12.12 Noir does not go on too heavy and lasts for hours on my skin (the scratchy throat, sneezing and runny nose prove that), I just wish I didn't have the allergic reaction to it or I would wear it all of the time, I really like its sophisticated scent. Its bottle is simple black opaque glass with the trademark Lacoste Alligator glued to the corner. This is a real fabric alligator like you would see on one of their shirts, nice!Don't let MY allergies deter from the purchase of Lacoste L.12.12, though you may want to find a tester somewhere and try it before ordering it from Amazon if you also are allergic to some colognes. Those who don't have an issue shouldn't hesitate to place an order.

The weather has been so cold around here that no one has had the desire to drink icy cold frozen cocktails these days, but when I first got the Party Blast XL I made Piña Coladas that were as good as any that I have had in a bar or restaurant. Using Bacardi Piña Colada mix (the frozen kind in the can), 5 oz. Bacardi white rum and about 6 cups of ice the Party Blast XL just pulverized the ice to a delicious slush just like you’d get at a bar. There were no big chunks of ice that always seem to be there when making frozen drinks in a regular blender.I have also made some shakes and malts for dessert in the Black And Decker Party Blast XL and they come out great. There are four automatic cycles on the blender. Number three is for shakes and it is cool to watch it go. It starts out slow for quite awhile on number one, then goes to number two for just a bit, and whips up a finale with number three. The shakes and malts came out perfect every time. Not too thin, not too thick. They are really yummy. The other automatic settings are for margaritas, daiquiris, and smoothies. For Pina Coladas I used the daiquiri setting, which got the ice to the perfect consistency.  The blender also has four constant on speeds that can be run manually until you press the stop button. The pulse button allows fingertip operation for quick mix.The Black and Decker XL Blast Party Blender has a great looking red plastic base that has suction cups on all four of it’s legs insuring that it won’t go flying off the counter. It really needs that because you can feel the power of its 650-watt motor when it is engaged. The motor is loud, but doesn’t have to stay on long to get the job done. Once everything is mixed, the flip top spout makes pouring easy without having to lift the entire top off. The top fits snug, and as long as it is lined up with the spout properly and closed up, there is no way for it to spill while mixing. The top also has a handy shot glass built in for adding alcohol or other liquids. The mixing jar is plastic, but it is a heavy plastic that probably won’t crack if it is dropped (but I’m not going to test that). Cleanup is easy just remember this. The top goes in the top rack, the jar goes in the bottom rack of the dishwasher. That means no messy cleanup, and no removing the blades since they are built into the jar itself.Black and Decker has a great drink mixer here, and it will get a lot more use in the summer months.  Right now, hot chocolate sounds better.

I made my favorite beef stew with dumplings.  Great comfort food.  It tasted better in this casserole than any pot I have ever used in the last 25 years.  The flavor of the meat and vegetables were enhanced and  locked in with the cover.  The dumplings are added at the end and they quickly were finished without absorbing too much of the stew juices.I know it's cast iron but this pot is sooo heavy, I was afraid I would drop it on the counter top and crack it.  II didn't but I would need some help carrying it to the table if I decide to serve directly from the casserole pot.  Instead, I transferred the stew to a serving piece.  I am looking forward to making soups and chili and more great dishes. This is a kitchen casserole to pass on to the family.

I’m not entirely sure of Kate Atkinson’s intentions but I applaud her as a fictional nonconformist.  This novel is so different than anything else I have read, including Life After Life, I’m in awe of her brilliance and credibility.The protagonist, Teddy (Edward) Todd, is a stoic bomber for the RAF. I learned more than I ever knew about the RAF, the mechanics of the bombers, especially the Halifax (Teddy’s plane), his different crews when he’s the Skipper, the strategy of the British and untold suffering.  The average age of an RAF was 22, and only half of them survived.  And shocking to me is that Churchill did not credit them after the war.  A different perspective, for sure, of what the British, at least Atkinson, may think of Churchill.  When Teddy is challenged about dropping bombs on innocents, Atkinson surely emphasizes her theme of savagery in the final analysis.This epic novel stretches on to a century of Teddy’s life as Atkinson circles back in time to grab different points of view. The suppressed inner-workings of this British family are exposed. His mother Sylvie is a passionate woman who favors Teddy of all her children, her “best boy.” I believe I could almost touch his family.  His wife, Nancy, is independent and enigmatic; her cordiality is a mystery at times.  They have one child, Viola, who is gifted with the best dialogue.  She wins the most selfish daughter and mother award, if there were such an award.  Her responses are demeaning and nasty to her father and children, particularly her son, Sunny.  Both of her children are born on a commune, sired by Viola’s husband, Dominic, possibly a bi-polar, child-like jerk. Viola’s daughter, Moon, serves as the philosopher symbolizing the inability of the family to communicate with each other.Teddy, despite his love for family, cannot express his thoughts.  He actually feels more comfortable as a bomber pilot than returning to the safety of family.  His childhood love of nature evolves into a small journalistic job after the War.  Atkinson emphasizes the goodness of Teddy and I wonder if he genetically passed on his inability to show emotion.  The British stiff upper-lip and all that may not be elusive.  Ursula emerges (sister to Teddy and star of Life After Life) when Atkinson wants to provide the reader with some humor and reality.This novel is incredible, and I have only presented a cursory sample of this sprawling work.  Reading Atkinson’s Afterword is somewhat illuminating but left me more in amazement of her intellect.  Every scene and piece of dialogue is preparing the reader for the end of the book.

I was more than pleasantly surprised when I unpacked these sheets.  They were ultra soft and after washing and putting them on a queen bed, they remained soft and smooth.  Microfibers are made from various materials but the packaging did not give any other content information except 100% microfiber. There were some wrinkles but they smoothed out on the mattress after a short time.  I did not iron them (nor would I ever iron sheets)!Since it is not fair to compare these sheets to a high thread-count cotton sheet, I can recommend these particular microfiber sheets for softness, lack of shrinkage and comfort.  The price posted was very reasonable for a complete set, which included one queen flat sheet, one queen fitted sheet (suitable for thicker mattresses) and two standard pillowcases.My only complaint is the color; it's grey and grey sheets are blah and these are no different.  I would never order that color but apparently they come in other colors and prints.  An excellent product with an outstanding price point.Amend: after another washing, the sheets are OK but too thin. 5/12

Reminiscent of crime fiction without all the gimmicks, this solid translation is for those readers seeking authentic mysteries. Set in the Pont-Aven, a quaint village, it is a far cry from Paris; Commissaire Dupin polices this small community.  He captured my interest from the beginning; he is the typical irritable authority, but his caffeine addiction and method of solving crime is far from clichéd.The 91-year-old owner of a local hotel is found murdered on the restaurant floor. Dupin is called in and always seems exasperated as if disturbing his morning coffee and croissant is a nuisance.  However, his distinctive nature and temperament is at odds with the common techniques of his Breton colleagues.  It’s this sharp cynicism of Dupin that drives the plot. As a clever team, they produce multiple murder suspects.The contrast and suffocating sense of Pont-Aven and the sophistication of Paris play a solid role.  The French are know for their skillful ferreting out of the facts and meticulous approach to catastrophes.  And this story is no different.  I was fooled by the denouement as Bennalac inserted red herrings along the way.There is usually greed and secrecy involving murders and this theme does not deviate from that philosophy.  However, the difference is that this book is entertaining and does not insult an experienced crime/mystery reader.

I thought this would be another product that "talked a good game" and really didn't work as advertised.  This set really works.  Do we need it?  Maybe not, but it makes your champagne and sparkling wine usage much easier.  The pliers, very rich looking, gets the cork out of the bottle.  The sealer keeps the bubbly for another day.  Great gift and looks expensive

Plunged into a setting of cooking and eating, I devoured this debut novel.  What a quirky, brilliant work of sorrow, humor, and foresight mixed with real recipes.The novel opens in the cold, stark areas of Minnesota with an incredible episode of stinky, Scandinavian lutefisk prepared by Lars Thorvald.  Lars, with an incredible palate and a purist, escapes this business and marries a tall, exciting sommelier with the name of Cynthia.  They have a baby, Eva, but Cynthia, is adverse to motherhood and leaves Lars with the infant to raise on his own.  Lars obsessively loves his daughter.  Cynthia does not physically re-appear until the end of the book.Enter feisty, quirky characters who are part of Eva’s life and Stradal manages to connect them in a sharp, introspective narrative.  The author’s use of imagery and imagination explodes on the pages.  Eva’s economically poor upbringing is almost palatable in the grubby apartments she lives.  The secondary characters provide the foundation for Eva’s adventures.  Their names are wonderful:  cousin Braque and her son, Hatch, Octavia Kincade, Celeste Mantilla, all serve a purpose defining the mixture of foods and international appeal.  Stradal’s characters take advantage of Eva’s talent but soon learn they cannot compete with her.  She is irrepressible.  This tall, interesting-looking woman is kind and sensitive.  Pat Prager, the most conventional of his characters, has more sides to her personality than the reader first imagines.Eva’s adventures and genius ability places her with a diverse group of chefs and men who are besotted with her.  Her originality and super palate leads her to stardom among those who love and can afford the best food.  She developed a pop-up supper club where an invitation is costly and coveted.Stradal’s writing frequently reminded me of John Irving, brilliant, quirky characters with immense talent who experience heartache and some joy.  The symbolism of food in this novel mirrors Eva’s robust spirit.

If you are interested in reading an introspective memoir that makes you as uneasy as the writer, this could be a unique exercise. Alexandra Fuller, growing up in Rhodesia to exotic, unconventional parents, leaves Africa and marries an American, Charlie Ross, and later moves to Wyoming.Her wedding is miraculous as she provides us with snippets of events.  Despite the fact that she develops malaria, her parents alleviate some of the symptoms and she is now a bride with a high fever.  One of the most poignant interchanges takes places at the wedding when a Polish father from the Catholic mission advises her that the first year of marriage is hard and then it gets worse.  She is astounded by his remark and laughs at him since he is a celibate man who probably has lived in the bush too long.  And then his response, “I should know. I've been married to God for fifty years.”We never really know Charlie, he is the father of her three children and I can never really determine the divide between the two of them.  There are some complaints and narratives but maybe he is a symbol of her double allegiances.  She is from Africa but she is not really African, and maybe not an American, either.  The book becomes centered on her divorce; there are immoderations in Wyoming and extreme tragedies in Africa.  Alexandra’s mother loses three children, one of which, Alexandra may be partly responsible for her death.  She looks up to her father; she seems to live on every word and can regurgitate his homilies often.I was caught up in the chaos and beauty of Africa.  Living in this environment is living with extremes.  America does not deliver the peace she believes she is promised.  She tries to make sense of all that has happened to her. It is difficult for all of us, who suffer from overpowering emotions.

This product is applied after moisturizer.  You only need to squirt an amount that equals the size of a dime.  The meteorites provide an excellent primer and enhance skin to a luminous glow.  Guerlain has had this product in their line for a long time, it is not inexpensive and luckily, a small amount is all that is needed.  I highly recommend it.

This company is not well known for a thicker mat which made me quite curious in regard to the quality and durability. Thin mats are adequate for sedentary movements.  This mat did not have any offensive odor when unfolding it for the first time. The thickness of this "Sticky-Grip" mat is more than appropriate for dynamic movement in a yoga class or in one's own home.After performing movements that would could have moved the mat, I was very pleased that there is a sense of traction for balancing and yoga toes would most likely not be needed for more gripping.  The mat did not slip, even during a hot yoga class.  I was so pleased that I would compare it to the quality of Manduka.  This is a fair-priced mat with the proper thickness and weight.

Oh, Anna Benz, your creator, Ms. Essbaum shaped you into a modern narcissistic, sexual addict fashioned after Anna Karenina and Madame Bovary.  Although you are an American, she cajoled you into marrying a Swiss banker, Bruno, nine years ago and dropping you in Zurich. In those nine years, you had three children, Victor, Charles (your favorite) and Polly Jean.  You never really made any friends, not that you wanted them, and instead became an aimless, manic woman who suffered for all your sins.And Anna’s suffering is profound.  The author initially made me hopeful when she teamed her up with Doktor Messerli, a psychoanalyst, who interprets her dreams and coaxes her to write a journal.  Their sessions are monumental,  as we can observe the escalation of Anna’s problems and her reticence to consider her maladies.  But Anna, posing as a housefrau, is too busy with her sexual relationships, which are presented in ultra graphic scenes bordering on extremes.  Overindulgences are Anna’s way of coping, like an alcoholic that cannot stop drinking.  She knows she should stop but takes many chances.  Even though she may envision the consequences of her actions, she inflicts more damage despite the grave reprisals.In this particular part of her life, Anna is attending a German class and she apparently sends signals to men who want to have tryst (I’m being kind with that word).  Archie is the chosen one and their meetings are frequent and rather surreal.  Violence is not excluded from this novel and her sexual encounters, often ferocious.  leave Anna nonplused.  She seems a like a dead woman walking and as promised, the consequences befall her.  Every mother’s nightmare becomes her own.  Castigation and acts of horrific abuse are also in the cards.The novel is well written but I became somewhat exasperated without a strong plot and wanted less despair for this complicated housefrau. Anna’s freedom to “wile”“away her day while her mother-in-law cared for her children seemed incongruous.  Ms. Essbaum’s literary allusions were first-rate but the scenes seemed to click-clack like the Zurich trains.

The dynamics and tentative balance of the Lee family is a study in racism and the fierce battles to belong.  The technical talent of Ms. Ng is remarkable.  She is able to move the reader from the climax of the plot and invade our senses with flashbacks of this family in crisis.A terrible tragedy occurs to Lydia, the teenage daughter of Marilyn and James Lee, an “American” mother and Chinese father.  No one knows the feeling of exclusion from society better than James, who apparently feels ostracized even as an adult.  He is a college professor, teaching the history of the cowboy, of all things.  He is accustomed to ridicule and wants his children, particularly Lydia, to have many friends, popularity and feel a part of a social crowd.Marilyn, on the other hand, is angry because she did not become the doctor or scientist and decides Lydia will be the one to attain those goals.  Living vicariously through Lydia is a main thrust of the story.  It is a sad commentary on our society and the mistakes too many parents make when believing their children want what they want.The family is dysfunctional, the oldest child, Nathan, is overly anxious to leave the nest and poor Hannah, the youngest, is almost totally ignored and starving for affection.  Ng’s most credible perception of the family’s catastrophe is seen and through her eyes and heart.  She is the omniscient one without knowing it.Marilyn’s presence as a mother comes at a great cost to the family.  Her expectations preclude her from delving into her children’s hearts and knowing who they are.  For an intelligent woman, she really believes her children have the same aspirations as she does.  James is floundering and because he does not have a sense of belonging, it becomes a tragic tale.The plot is precise and the author’s prose enriches the story as the fabric of this family is shoved aside.  It is heartbreaking but there are responsibilities that Marilyn has abandoned.  At one point in their lives, Marilyn leaves and returns to school, abandoning her family.  James is not equipped to help his children get through this upheaval.  When Marilyn returns, she asks the children if they behaved while she was gone.  She did not apologize or offer any explanation.  Tragic consequences are now entering their lives. This is an outstanding first novel; I highly recommend it.

I inherited my family’s Regina Electrik Broom.  I think it was first made in the 1960’s and it’s still working!  I never gave it away because it does the job on a wood floor by picking up the crumbs, glass particles and some dust.  The cup needs to be emptied and it’s quite loud and, of course, it must be plugged into an outlet that will accommodate the length of the cord.So here is this fabulous Black and Decker Lithium Stick Vacuum and after working with this new efficient technology, I may finally donate my Regina Broom.  We assembled this easily and put it to its test on the floors and carpets. Only one screw was needed to assemble, really one screw.  Needless to say, I am totally impressed.  Not only does it have enormous suction capability, it is quiet, lightweight, bagless, and good-looking. We tried it on the sofa and it suctioned the invisible crumbs with no effort.I particularly appreciate the design except I cannot find a place to store the rotary brush; it’s the only design flaw that I can find.  The vacuum held its charge for about 20 minutes at least and charging is easy.  The lithium battery is not replaceable, however. The product “feels” expensive, it is not junkie, it all fits together.I liked the balance of the product probably because the head of the vacuum rotates from side to side with me.  It doesn’t work against me.  This is a vacuum that has definitive changes to meet my needs.  I am not an obsessed housecleaner by any means, but if I’m doing it, I want it to be easier.  This product removes the word “chore,” from the task!

I don’t have a mode of comparison but this promises to be a “lifesaver” for me.  I like the velvet pouch so I will be aware by touch that I have it with me.Since it is my first, the manual is quite important.  It offers detailed explanations of the product overview, charging and checking the power level and how to charge my devices.My first thought is that with my charged power bank, I don’t have to meander around the airport and crawl on the floor to charge my phone or tablet.  It may seem trivial, but it’s a real inconvenience to look at my phone, know my flight is delayed and I need to charge my phone immediately to make endless calls to book another flight and notify others.  If you have ever tried to squeeze in among those who are charging, you will understand the importance of this solution.I like the size of the power bank and ran a trial of charging two devices at the same time.  The manual also offers trouble-shooting ideas, which is another feature.  The sentences in the manual are clear and concise.

I am somewhat tech savvy, working in offices for years and learning to adjust to new hardware and software.  This printer should have been an easy installation.  I have a Mac, which required the removal of a hard orange-colored package.  I did not really have the strength but after working with it for about 10 minutes, I disengaged it.  I could not have accomplished any of this without accessing a Canon video on their website.  It was complicated for me and not intuitive and it would have been simpler if I had a PC.This is a humongous personal printer.  It is almost the size of an office desk printer.  I worked with Canon Office products for years and they surpass their Home products in every area.  If I recall, they are separate companies and the Canon office products were sold to businesses only.  They are expensive but they are state-of-the-art and even though, we were trained to use their equipment, the manuals were easy to understand.I have a small home office Canon color printer now.  It is much lesser in size and it eats up the ink.  The printed product is mediocre.  This printer, Maxify – a perfect name, produces a crisp sheet and it is fast and the paper did not jam, even once.  The color is acceptable, does not live up to Laser quality.  However, this printer does not scan, duplex, copy or fax.  It probably will serve as a good workhorse for big printing projects.  If you want a printer only and want to run large jobs, this product could fit your needs.  However, most home printers can take up less space and are multi-functional.

I’m not usually excited about novels that include recipes, but this narrative had a clever hook using recipes written in the 1700’s.  The instructions for the recipes are straightforward, as is the originator of most of the recipes.  Biddy “Obedience” Leigh is the under-cook at Mawton Hall.  She is a zealous cook who is planning to leave her post for married life.  Of course, there would be no story if this plot were played out; instead, the master, an old, ugly man surprises everyone and marries the young Lady Carinna.Lady Carinna recognizes that Biddy is a quick study and requests her help on a long journey.  The journey is not, of course, what Biddy expected, and many odd demands and resourceful ideas are expected of this young cook.The format of the book is set up in a flashback of eighteen months.  The story opens with a ghastly discovery by Lady Carinna’s opportunistic brother.  The novel centers around Biddy who becomes a woman of courage and wit against the backdrop of the late 1770’s.  Her passion for cooking is mixed well with the author’s clever ability to move from cooking to murder, slavery, romance, loss and ultimately, friendship.  The author uses a complicated technique to move the mystery along.  It is a fun book; at times, I thought the plot became a bit cumbersome and the dialogue could be confusing.  However, the author’s efforts in writing an innovative story should appeal to many readers.

Max Lerner was always star-struck.  He was mildly obsessed with celebrities and when he lands a writing job for KNOW, a sorta-like People or Entertainment Weekly, he is in the right place to live out the dream.  He has a beautiful live-in girl friend, Samantha, the love of his life since childhood.  She is a wanna be actress and she encourages him to write; she is a big influence in everything he does.  He adores her.  Well, when she finally is cast in a respectable part, she falls in love with the leading man, who happens to be a childhood idol of Max, Johnny Mars.  How inconvenient.The book provides us with Max's acuity as an interviewer, he has the ability to ask the right questions and move in and out of the movie star circles.  When Samantha cuckolds him, he is devastated for years and years.  He only wants her and apparently feels he is incapable of loving another woman.  This situation drags on for too long despite the fact that Samantha is married and is fawning and servile to her famous husband.  She maintains a connection with Max as she jet sets around the world and trusts him with her secrets and feelings.  He has never betrayed her.  Max continues to meet women but no one can open his heart, except maybe one woman he meets on a movie set.  This meeting is weak, makes little sense and her characterization is vague from beginning to end.A tragedy occurs and then a final tragedy, which was a not surprising twist to the novel.  The author writes well; his prose is smooth and he leads the reader from paragraph to paragraph with ease.  The book was better than I thought, and I'm giving it four stars for some of his insights and raw knowledge of the movie industry.

These special wax candles provide scents that are not overpowering yet permeate the room with a pleasing odor.  I chose the FALL HARVEST for a mixture of fall scents.  Pumpkin Spice is my favorite followed by Autumn Leaves and Cranberry.  The trio is a sensible mix and evokes memories for me of a lodge in the winter and a warm living room with a fireplace.The size of the candles are convenient and take little space.  Snuffing out the lighted candle is quite simple by screwing the cap on and then I can re-use it.  No mess.  I like the variety of scents and look forward to trying others.

Once again, Alyson Richman demonstrates her talent and meticulous knowledge in a fervent novel.  As I wrote in my previous review of THE LOST WIFE, she enhances the customary (if there is a typical) novel of the Holocaust from a different angle.  In that wonderful book, she grabbed the reader's attention with painting and art as a sharp contrast to the horrors of the Nazis.In this treasure, the author finds music as the powerhouse to transport the reader to the agonies, bravery and love of the German's victims.  She brings beauty to a vicious story; this novel takes places in Italy.  I learned about the Italian Resistance, who seemed to single-handedly try and push back the Germans.  Not much was mentioned of the Italian army except for Mussolini's efforts to be on the "right" side for his own victory.Highlighting the Bertolli family, from Verona, whose only child, Elodie is a remarkable cello musician with a photographic memory. Elodie joins the Resistance after the Fascists beat her father for playing music.  Once again, the cruelty is almost impossible to comprehend.  This small group of Italians, trying to avoid annihilation of their families and homeland, are boundless in their courage and intellect.Elodie has special jobs to pass messages and they require her musical talent and perfect memory.  Not all goes well, of course, and the fate of her mentor and lover robs her of all that is good.  She is a strong character, however, and continues to fight for her country, her mother and her own survival.Richman brings in another intelligent character, a medical doctor who also suffered an imaginable loss.  She is able to intertwine their lives, without too much coincidence but some scenes are a bit sappy.  This slight weakness did not trump her elegant writing and providing a musical point of view with passion and clarity against the ruthlessness of the Nazis.  This book emphasized the Nazi's equal opportunity liquidation of Jews and non-Jews.  There is beauty in the story written with love of a classical music for the cello and the surreal beauty of Italy.

Nicole Helget’s tactile images of Minnesota from 1830 to 1870 connect the metaphors and the plot.  From the very first chapter, the author paints a vivid picture when a logjam paralyzes the town on the St. Croix River.The story is based on twins, Clement and Angel, the latter growing up in a rich but chaotic, and often insane environment.  Clement, separated from his sister grew up in an orphanage, under the care of Big Waters, who was also shunned by her tribe and relatives.  The mother of the twins is Lydian, who after running away from Beaver Jean, a trapper, leaves her twins in the nunnery.  Sentimentality is a void for this young mother and this lack of mawkishness is also present in Angel.Most of the story is presented in flashback giving in to a random plot.  The motivation of the characters was often without credibility and justification of their actions elicited more questions about character development.The strength of the novel is Helget’s superb prose and the juxtaposition of the pioneering Minnesota spirit with the harsh weather and surrounding.  I could almost feel the overpowering weight of the weather and the starkness of the historical time and terrain.  However, the plot lacked strength with characters whose motives and actions left me indifferent.

I am quite light-skinned and when I was asked to try Shade 05, I thought it might be too dark.  I am more than pleasantly surprised that it blended with my skin tones.  Since you can build up the coverage, there is flexibility with this foundation, which I find unusual and of high quality. I have had the cosmetic on for over 12 hours, and my face remains fresh looking, I do not have to touch it up or apply an extra coat or a separate powder product.  I am very pleased to be introduced to this cream foundation.  I usually use liquid but this formula is easy to apply and a welcome change from other products.

I have been using single serve coffee cups for years.  We bought a Keurig years ago before it became popular in homes and offices.  Through the years, we tried many, many brands and roasts.  I came upon Tim Horton after reading about this Canadian company and decided to try it.  I like a medium roast and it is the best I have tasted.  It is smooth, not too harsh but loaded with good coffee flavor.  It is my favorite.  I also have served it for company, and there is always a comment, "this is really good coffee."  HIghly recommend.

It's fall 2008 and the economy is tanking, the recession is rearing its ugly head.  Hard working Americans are losing their jobs because of the toxic wickedness of the bankers and mortgage brokers, who never really were punished.  Instead, many honest employees lost their jobs and their homes.Grisham paints a quick picture of this horrific time and links it to a large New York law firm who panics and initiates a steady firing of the many associates.  One of these associates is our heroine, Samantha Kofer, an Ivy League graduate of Georgetown and Columbia Law and a third year associates.  She is among a tier of associates who are "furloughed."  Not fired outright, but on leave and the law firm shows its largesse by offering one year paid healthcare insurance if these employees work for a non-profit group for that duration.  Such irony, isn't it?  These cold-hearted, covering their assets, are willing to pay twelve months of coverage if they work, without pay, for some organization that is the antithesis of their philosophy.  Actually, the firm is paying for their COBRA, which they are most likely entitled to under law.So Samantha mulls over the proposition.  She talks to her divorced parents who are attorneys, the father disbarred and the mother working for the government.  They both recommend other avenues rather than working for free.  However, to move the plot along, Grisham entertains us with all the non-profits being deluged with prospective lawyers and they have no room for any more volunteers.  One would think they would accept as much free, licensed lawyers as possible. After much soul-searching, Samantha finds an internship in Appalachia at the Mountain Legal Aid Clinic.She steps out of her world of privilege and into one of inequality and poverty.  She enters the beauty of Appalachia and the stark contrast to the suffering of coal miners.  Their pain and complicated black lung disease has been inflicted by the politicians and the owners of the mining companies.  They are ruthless and have devised plans to refuse benefits to sick miners and they need to continue to work to save their families from starvation.Samantha is relegated to living in a garage apartment of one of the paid lawyers and she learns quickly the methodical rape of the mountains by the mining companies via strip mining.  Those that sold their land to the companies were cheated. Samantha meets the Gray brothers; Donovan is a brilliant attorney who knows how to fight the bad guys.  His brother is Jeff, who is loyal to his brother and the land.  Grisham brings us two detailed cases, both of which are heartbreaking and instruct the reader on meticulous legal machinations.These cases are fascinating and specific and bring the aching suffering of the miners and the pillage of the land into reality.  Samantha's character is a dichotomy.  She is often sympathetic, sarcastic, flippant and conventional.  I had difficulty buying into her transformation and ability to have superficial relationships with men. Grisham has more success with male protagonists.  However, Grisham's talent to disgrace the coal industry for its prejudice and disrespect is haunting.  He is a major novelist and hopefully, he will bring some shame to the coal business, and maybe justice.

The towels are well designed in terms of the pattern coordination and the different sizes.  I particularly like the wash cloth, it's a good item to keep by the sink and since all of these items can be washed, it serves a good purpose for wiping the sink and counters.However, I compared these towels to super-absorbent towels I was given as a gift about a year ago.  These towels do not hold a candle to my other ones.  They are not absorbent, the moisture seems to bead off and I needed to pick up another towel to really dry an item.They may be OK if I run out of other towels, but I would not buy them as they are flimsy for their purpose. I also would not buy brown, it's not bright enough.AMENDED: I thought I would give these towels another try during our Thansgiving dinner post washing dishes marathon. They were worthless. Two of my guests who were helping used the towels to dry and the water on the dishes remained on the dishes and glasses. They both commented. I tried to us them again and agreed. Don't waste your $$$ on them.😰

The title and the photograph were so compelling, I was almost sure I was going to read an upscale mystery with some great twists.  Having read many of Margolin's previous books, I thought he might have finally hit a homerun.The photograph, Woman With A Gun, suggests a period piece with the antique firearm.  Instead, we have a cluttered murder story with the typical young writer, Stacy Kim, smart and creative who chucked a Harvard education to get an MFA and write a best seller.  She has little writing background; in fact, she apparently received her only kudos from one short story.  Not able to get her creative juices flowing, she takes a dull job as law firm receptionist in New York and one day visits the Museum of Modern Art during her lunch hour.  She sees the work of photographer, Kathy Moran, and knows the Woman With A Gun could become her blockbuster novel.She leaves New York, quits her tedious job, and moves to Oregon to learn the origins of this photo.  She discovers an unsolved murder, involving the dead husband, Raymond Cahill and beautiful (very recent) wife, Megan Cahill, the bride holding the six-shooter.  Margolin presents some of the plot in flashback spanning 2000 to 2015.The most interesting character is Jack Booth, who was a special prosecutor with the Oregon Department of Justice, assigned to assist in the Cahill murder.  He is portrayed as a crackerjack attorney, but Margolin depicts him as a nave man whose attraction to Kathy Moran never wanes. Kathy, former attorney, famous photographer, and intermittent drug user and rehab resident, uses and abuses Jack and Jack doesn't get it. Hard to believe.The other male characters are attorneys, a cold-blooded killer, a bartender and the primary murder victim.  Kathy Moran was the most interesting female, but her characterization was flimsy and repetitive.The mystery is easy to solve and I was hoping for more depth to the plot and the characters.  It was predictable and cursory.  He did not connect some of the characters to the plot and the women were sure smarter than the men.  There were a few good scenes, mostly involving Kathy Moran, but the others were clichéd.

The book itself is a work of art.  The quality of the photography and the paper allows the ink to drink in her magnificent stylized dishes.  The format of the book is equal to the presentation:The book is divided into Breakfast, Pasta & Rice, Meats, Seafood, Vegetables, Soups & Stews, Sandwiches, Snacks and Desserts.  This layout makes sense and within each section, the recipes are original with a twist to some classics.  For instance,, the grilled cheese is french onion soup in a sandwich, ordinary french toast becomes peaches and cream french toast.She has an explanation prior to giving the reader the Ingredients and Method (how you put it all together). The short intros enhance the recipe with a personal history and some tips, giving the reader/cook more explanation and confidence.There are two small criticisms: many of the ingredients are not those one would have in your conventional cooking kitchens and the type is very light and small.  The ingredients are bold-faced but the font for the Ingredients and Method is small and light.

Mike Greenberg created a semi-plausible character, Jonathan Sweetwater, who is the only child of the deceased liberal senator, Percival Sweetwater III. The last time he has seen his father he was nine years old and this loss of father/son relationship remains a mystery to him.  However, now  Jon has an ideal life, with his wife, Claire, the love of his life and his two happy, healthy children, Phoebe and Drew.Despite refusing his father's inheritance, Jonathan makes it on his own and moves near the pinnacle of the corporate ladder of a Wall Street firm at 40 years old.  His boss, Bruce, is also a friend and they play basketball almost every morning where "Johnny" wipes him off the floor, so to speak.Jon's life is shattered when, upon arriving home early, he thinks he discovers conjugal infidelity.  He is almost paralyzed with angst and cannot breathe.  Rather than confronting the possible situation head-on, he believes if he could learn about this father, it might help him handle these dire circumstances.  After speaking to his own mother, who is the first wife, he decides to track down and meet the other five wives.  He travels far and wide, from cities to mountaintops, and meets each woman; they all "happen" to be home or available on these surprise visits.  They are glib women who loved Percy dearly.  He left them heartbroken but they managed to survive with large bank accounts.  They each tell him something about his father, but none of it is really earth shattering. There is no epiphany.The book is a page-turner despite the predictability of the plot. There are a few secondary characters that trump the boring wives.  One is the private investigator who seems to be out of a Damon Runyon story and the other is Ken Siegel, the head of corporate security, who is more realistic.Our Jon is a sentimental guy who finds great joy in his family and his children's school.  Despite the fact that Jon seems to drink his way through every meal, he finds comfort as his journeys come to an end.  There is a twist at the end of the book and there is a rather weird, tawdry scene in the children's school, which surprised me. Claire remained somewhat of a mystery, but Jonathan is an open book.

Liane Moriarty's talent provides us with narration from her superb, multi-faceted characters.  She introduces us to abuse and bullies through Madeline, Celeste and Jane.  These may seem like ordinary women but their differences draw them together and they are intelligent analysts of motivation.  Under the setting of a school in Australia (it could have been in the U.S.), we learn of the wretched pain of Jane and her son, Ziggy.  Beautiful Celeste is more than a victim of a rich husband with twin boys.  Madeline, twice married, may seem superficial but she is anything but shallow.I could not put the book down.  The author cleverly used a literary technique of a police "interrogation" warning the reader something bad happened on the annual Trivia Night.  We do not know until the end of the book which character suffered the most from the Big Little Lies. A great title, a worthy book, crystal clear.

I thought somewhere during the first third of the book, this wasn’t real.  The characters are standing and moving around studying the works of art of the missing husband, Peter Morrow.  They are all attempting to delve into the meaning of this absurd art and are struggling with an answer. It resembled a circular dance.Clara, wife of Peter Morrow, is a famous artist, who has gone beyond technical drawing.  Her art has life and meaning.  She and her husband Peter separated a year prior with the promise they would reunite one year later and discover if their marriage could be filled with love and respect for each other.  Clara is much more successful professionally than Peter.  Is he jealous?  Does he not love Clara anymore?  Peter does not show up on the scheduled day of return, so dreadful.  And Clara was going to put steaks on the grill and buy croissants, too. Oh dear.She enlists Armand Gamache, a retired Inspector, who has his own problems as he attempts to block out his past travails and enjoy retirement with his lovely wife, Reine-Marie.  This story takes place in Three Pines, a picturesque village in Canada.  The characters are philosophical; Myrna, who is a therapist and bookstore owner, is a close friend of Clara’s and travels with her to find the long lost Peter. There is Armand’s son-in-law, Jean-Guy Beauvoir, who seems deliberate, but Myrna feels that Armand is too critical of him. Annie, daughter of Gamache and wife of Jean-Guy, is given short shrift.  The emphasis is on the Morrows’ art professors, who are elusive at best.The plot is so thin, it is almost transparent.  From the very melodramatic scene when Clara is observing Armand reading a book on a bench, the genre is way overplayed. The ending was contrived; I did not discover a genuine theme to the book except that we all have a different way of “finding” ourselves and becoming useful.  There is also an allusion to Somerset Maugham’s “Appointment in Samarra,” which could have emerged as a more poignant theme and plot, but the author did not carry this through.

If you are a coconut lover and are not too fussy, this snack could serve as an ample substitute for the real thing.  The texture is soft and the taste resembles many "natural" products that are supposed to mimic processed snacks or ones with real sugar.  I know sugar is not the best for us, but there is nothing like real sugar, real chocolate and real coconut .The size is quite small, three bites and you're finished.  It left a grainy taste in my mouth.  In a pinch, I would grab this snack to satisfy a coconut craving and some sweetness, but it would make my top ten list for snacks.

Charlotte Baird was small; her hands were small, her face was small, she was tiny in structure and yet she had big ideas.  She was a young girl ahead of her time.  As an heiress to the Lennox fortune, she was sought after by both sexes.  She was astute and not naïve about the ploys of her half-brother, his wife and her aunt.  Goodwin emphasized her love of photography (which was most likely fictional) and would identify her human subjects with animals.  Her betrothed is Bay Middleton (apparently some distant relative of the Katherine, the Duchess of Cambridge).  And here we were led to believe that the Middletons were out of their league when Kate became engaged to William!  Bay Middleton was no slouch. He had the typical wit of a ladies' man and he was a very talented rider and superb fox hunter.The passion for fox hunting brings The Empress of Austria to England.  She is a beautiful woman who captures the attention of  the European upper class and "Sisi,"" as she is called by her family, is determined to get what she wants.  She is a bit eccentric, traveling with a pet monkey and surrounds herself with people who will amuse and excite her. The description of her hair is fascinating which validates her reputation of narcissism. She meets Bay Middleton and they become the center of gossiping royalty since she is married to the Emperor of Austria.  But does he really love Charlotte? Or does not like being told what to do by the Empress?  What?  This is pedestrian.As the story unravels, there are some good scenes that define the characters of the main players but the history was inaccurate, sometimes by a decades.  The scene with Queen Victoria was amusing but quite predictable. The juiciest bit of fact is that Bay Middleton had an out-of-wedlock child with another woman, which was alluded to in the opening of the novel.  This child was Clementine, who became the loving wife of Winston Churchill, whose own mother was American.In addition to the accuracies, the dialogue had this consistent cadence of condescending conversations, (excuse the alliteration) filled with half-truths and sarcasm.  This became annoying.  I expected so much more from the book; it was disappointing.Historical novels can be difficult because many authors fuse fact with fiction.  Daisy Goodwin apparently went overboard with "poetic license," so much so that the lack of historical accuracy confounded me.  The imprecise chronology overshadowed the plot and certainly the characterization.  Not until the Author's Note at the end did she redeem herself explaining some of  the obvious mixture of history and fiction.

Sizes are good, but they are flimsier than I expected.  It would be nice if thicker metal was used.  Also insides of the tips are smooth.  Perhaps some textur would provide a more secure grip.  Although, I have not had a problem with food slipping out.

My son loved this set.  He is a fan of Minecraft and he was very excited to build it.  He is 7 and he finished it all by himself in two evenings. The dragon is pretty cool.  It has a button in its back, which, when pressed, causes wings to move up and down.  The lighted brick is nice too.  I wish there were three of them - one for each tower.

I used these bleach crystals in place of liquid bleach for laundry.  I washed white towels, bed spreads, and a comforter.  All came out clean and white.  I like that there is less chlorine smell than with the liquid bleach.  It is also more convenient to dispense, since you do not have to handle a large bottle trying to pour and not to spill liquid bleach.  Each container has a measuring cup at the top, and the amount of crystals suggested for use is a lot smller than the amount of liquid bleach I measure out arbitrarily.  Speaking of spills, cleaning up crystals would be easier than cleaning up liquid.
Watched it with my seven year old son.  He likes it.

I heard about benefits and decided to try.  I expected a little tartness, but the berries are sweet with bitter aftertaste.  They were not too dry and chewyness was as expected from dried fruit.  I will finish the bag, but probably won't get more.

These BIC razors have thick rubber handles and three blades.  The shave was close and without irritation.  The handle is very comfortable to hold and feels secure.I use disposables when I travel.  For every day shaving I use a double edge Merkur with Feather blades or an electric shaver.  These BIC will do nicely for the occasional use I need disposables for.  They are a bit more expensive than Gillette Sensor 2 Plus disposables that I normally buy from Costco.

This is the best grill brush I've used to date.  Bristles are tough and clean GRill GRates GReat, it reaches between the bars, it is sturdy, the handle is angled so that it is comfortable to use and keeps your hand away from the heat.  I already own one brush and I bought this second one as a present, and it was a hit.I've been using the brush for a few months, and, at this point, I cannot think of any negatives.  There are several branded and unbranded versions of this brush on the interwebs.  Some cost more than others.  I purchased from two different sellers (including this one), one had a brand name printed on the handle and this one didn't, but the brushes are identical.  The small silicone brush bonus is nice, it works well for painting ribs with BBQ sauce.

Tonight's Made From Scratch Taste (R) Yummers awards go to: High Fructose Corn Syrup,  Hydrolyzed Corn Protein, Disodium Inosinate, Disodium Guanylate, Autolyzed Yeast Extract, Malic Acid, Caramel Color, Natural Flavors  Dextrose, and Xantan Gum.Traditional Bloody Mary recipes do not ask for anything sweet.  This mix lists high fructose corn syrup and sugar among ingredients, and the sweetness comes through in the finished product.  I think it is absolutely unnecessary.  Although I think the flavor of the mix is OK with strong tomato taste, and well-balanced acidity and spiciness, and the texture feels like tomato juice should, I think the mix would be better without sweeteners.  Additionally, there are preservatives, colors, flavors, and xantan gum in the product, which you would not have in a made-from-scratch cocktail.  I am surprised by the amount of extra ingredients in this new product considering that consumers now are seeking more natural products.I am also confused by sea salt and salt listed separately.  First, I do not understand the need for two salts.  Second, I thought all salt was sea salt even if it is now mined from an area where there is no longer a sea.Bloody Mary is not a difficult cocktail to make, and it doesn't require any exotic ingredients.  If you make it often, it would make sense to prepare it as recipe calls for it from individual ingredients.  This mix would be nice to have on hand for an unexpected request for a Bloody Mary cocktail.

I have a very sensitive skin and I often get irritation from shaving.  After I started using this face balm, I am getting less irritation and it subsides quicker.I've been using this product for a week.  I like how it makes my skin feel smooth but not greasy.  I also like the pump container which allows control to dispense a small amount enough to cover the face but not to waste the product.  I think the smell is a bit mediciney, but it does not linger.Overall, I am impressed with Thrive face balm.  It works for me.

This paper is  soft and absorbent just like Northern Quilted Ultra Plush we buy.  Due to the lack of cardboard core, the rolls are compressed for compact storage, and they fit perfectly into the flat middle drawer at the bottom of my 60" Wyndham Collection Sheffield single sink vanity.  The rolls were easy to expand for placing on the TP holder.  Initially, the roll didn't hang straight, so I took it off and formed the hole to be as round as possible and now it hangs just like a roll with core.I like this product because the quality of TP is good, and the coreless feature makes them "green"  - less materials are used and less pollution and garbage is generated during manufacturing, transporting, and disposal.
I have slip-on work shoes and I need a horn to prevent damage to heels.  A plastic horn I had broke, so I found this metal horn.  It is very sturdy and the extra length makes using it very easy.

Although the package is branded LENMAR, the battery is stamped Sony.  I always had good luck with Sony button batteries.  My watch is working again and I saved a bunch of money vs going to a watch repair shop.  The seller - MyBatterySupplier - shipped quickly.

761 has replaced 551, which died from water damage.  This vacuum runs on the daily schedule at 9 AM and does a not-too-bad of a job of keeping the living room, dining room, and the kitchen floor clean.I thought higher and newer model would be better, but it is pretty much the same, maybe a tad quieter.  The robot occasionally gets stuck on power cords, occasionally gets hung off a step (nose falls off the step, and the vacuum just hangs there until I get home), occasionally misses areas (I think random pattern is not the best choice for a robot vacuum, it would be better if it mapped the room first).  It is also quite dumb.  A few days ago I watched it bump into a console table leg, back up a bit, turn 360 degrees, and bump into the same leg again.  It did this for 5 minutes until it finally turned 90 degrees and scooted away.I had 551 for a couple of years and I was surprised to see no noticeable improvement in logic and performance.  For the next robot vac, I think I will try a Neato.

This book was an easy and interesting read for my seven year old son.  He didn't expect it to be about Charles Dickens, he thought it would be about ghostsd because of the cover art.  Still, he liked it.

I always wear gloves when biking.  Before these I used Harbinger 155 StretchBack weight gloves, which worked quite well but finally wore out.  Zookki gloves look cool and fit my hand perfectly.  The palm side is covered in non-slip rubber-like paint and the outer edge has padding.  These gloves ensure comfortable non-slip grip. Good bicycling gloves.

Easy to cut to fit.  I used them in a new shoe that had a flat uncomfortable insole with no arch support.  These insoles made shoes more wearable.  I do not feel any "massaging", but the gel heel and the arch support made the shoe feel much more comfortable.  I hope they last, because on other Dr. Sholl's insoles the fabric top usually separates soon from gel bottom. If this happens, I will revise the rating down.

I purchased white AlpineSwiss Stefan shoes on a different website, which doesn't allow leaving detailed feedback, but I felt like expressing my opinion about these shoes, so I am posting here.Shoes look good with my Levi's 501s in Burrough.  That 's about all for positives.I wear 8.5 size shoes, so I ordered these in 9 (rounded up as directed by the seller).  I think size 8 would be a better fit for my foot.  The insole is completely flat, practically without cushioning, and zero arch support.  I used Dr. Scholl's Massaging Gel Extra Support Insoles to make these shoes more comfortable.I do not like extra thick padding around ankle, I think thick collars make these otherwise streamlined shoes look heavier than they are.  However, jeans cover that area, so it is somewhat OK, but I wouldn't wear these shoes with shorts.  I found that these shoes get pretty hot, with all the padding there is little air flow.Also, the included shoelaces are ridiculously long.  I couldn't adjust the standard shoelace bow knot so that neither loops nor ends dragged on the ground.  I pulled white shoelaces from my white Cole Haan Air Ryders which these AlpineSwiss Stefan shoes were intended to replace.With new insoles and shoelaces I made these shoes wearable, so i rate them OK.  However, that's an additional spending of ~$20 ($15 insoles + $5 shoelaces) on top of $25 I already spent on these shoes.  They are still not very comfortable, and I will not buy these shoes again nor will I recommend these to anyone.

My seven year old son likes this set.  He built the large spaceship pictured on the box.  Instructions for this toy are included.  Instructions for other 23 toys need to be downloaded.  The design has a "skeleton" built out of clear laser pegs with various colors LEDs inside, which is then wrapped in "skin" made of clear lego-like bricks.  The power is supplied from a base which houses three AA batteries.  There is a flexible cable included which allows tous to be taken off the base and still have power.The spaceship is large and used almost all pieces in the set.  One laser peg broke at installation along the seam and I had to glue it back together with Krazy Glue.  The construction is not as solid as Lego sets.  Particularly, connections between lighted Laser Pegs seem loose even though I ensured they are fully connected.  Designs need to have more reinforcement from regular bricks to ensure that toys can be played with.I think the quality of pieces and strength of designs need to be addressed to justify the price

I needed a glove to play catch with my son.  This glove is well made and is reasonably priced.  The large surface makes catching the ball easy.There is a Velcro strap on the back of the glove which can be tightened to ensure secure fit.  However, even without the strap, the glove fits tight on my hand pretty tightly, and I do not have large hands.  I am hoping it will stretch a little with time for a more comfortable fit.

Yeah...  I liked the idea of getting rid of a huge Costco-sized blue mouthwash bottle on my white bathroom counter and replacing it with this nice-looking dispenser.  Unfortunately, looks is all it has.First, I noticed that the dispenser has no padding on the bottom, and the metal directly contacts my pure white quartz counter top.  Not ideal.  Hopefully it doesn't rust and leaves rust circles, or just leaves black streaks on the counter. I think every other bathroom counter item I have has either padded or smooth plastic bottom.Second, it takes several pumps to fill the top reservoir.  Not one or two, but several.  I hope my wife doesn't walk on me dispensing mouthwash from this thing...  You'd think a large dispenser like this could accommodate a pump capable of transferring 10 ml into the top reservoir in a single press.

Even though my son is still far from college age, we want to start planning for financing his education.  There are a lot of resources on this topic available on the internet, but this book consolidates them in one place.  Chapters are concise and to the point. Very helpful.

We buy Charmin Ultra Soft at Costco.  My wife likes how soft, strong , and absorbent this TP is, and she prefers it to the Kirkland brand even though Charmin cosdts more.I compared Amazon's version to Costco's version of Charmin Ultra Soft, and these rolls are smaller and narrower, so we will stick with the Costco version.

I usually get Sony or Renata batteries for my watches, and have never had any regrets - they last and do not leak.  This battery fit perfectly and my watch is back in service.  Seller MyBatterySupplier ships quickly.

My son read these books when he was 6 and now 7.  He got hooked on the first book and asked for each subsequent book.  He read them all on his own without me having to ask him to read.At $5 per book they are pricey, as I wouldn't pay $20 for a set of 4 of these or for one book that had all for stories.  However, I think the language, illustrations, and stories are appropriate for the target audience.

Socks fit well.  I wear this type of sock with boat shoes or running shoes and shorts.  I did a bit of walking in these socks and they stayed comfortable  - no stretching and sliding up of the heel.  White and gray are the colors in will use.  Instead black socks only with dress pants to work and elsewhere, but I use longer dress socks.  I do not have use for short black socks, but my wife said she'll use those.  They can be machine washed.  There is a "hand wash only" symbol on the package, but it is manually crossed out.Socks arrived relativel quickly from outside of the USA.  They were packaged in a nice printed glossy box.  I thought the packaging was an overkill, since most often sports socks are offered in simple plastic bags.

I use these as trash bags in the SimpleHuman kitchen trash bin.  They fit fine and seem strong enough to not rip.  The size is good forour family, the bag gets filled up with trash and thrown away before it begins to stink, a bigger bag wod atart to smell before getting full.  These bags are clear, so the stuff inside is visible.

The bulb works well.  I have other 40W equivalent LED lamps and this bulb is similar to those in brightness.  The light distribution is slightly less than 360 degrees but only because LED bulbs have bigger bases than non-LED ones.  The color temperature is nice, it is not extra white or bluish cool like some other LED bulbs.  There is no buzzing or humming coming out of this bulb.  The bulb looks very clean with the white base, and there are no markings (brand name, warnings, etc) not even a sticker on the base, which makes the bulb well positioned for applications where the light bulb is exposed.  The overall quality seems to be quite good.However, the bulb is significantly more expensive than 40W equivalent LED bulbs I already own, but it does not seem to provide any advantages  over them.  There are cheaper options, which should be considered, especially if replacing multiple light bulbs as it gets pretty expensive.  In our home we already had CFL bulbs, and savings from switching to LEDs are less than if switching from incandescent to LEDs, so the price of LEDs matters.

Usually, I use Oxyclean with my laundry loads, and I have noticed that laundry looks and feels cleaner when I use it vs. when I do not.  In my opinion, this product works as well as Oxyclean, but is considerably more expensive.  Additionally, this powder seems to be finer than Oxyclean, so opening the container, digging out the scoop, and scooping the product all created dust clouds which I inhaled, and which caused bitter taste at the back of my throat.  For some reason I thought it was a tub of pods, but the tub contains powder and a scoop.

The pillow is soft and flexible.  It forms to the shape of our tub and adds soft support for head and shoulders.  Suction cups make the pillow stay securely on the tub.  The cover cleans and dries easily.  Be careful to not puncture the cover, it voids warranty.

I bought this system for my grandparents who are 90 and 87.  It is different from their previous non-Panasonic system, but they learned main functions very quickly.  I chose this system for large keypad with large numbers, and my grandparents have commented on how easy it is for them to see numbers.  When I speak with them, the sound is really clear, and they say they can hear me very well.
