I am personally not a huge fan of any Beef sticks ( I am not much of a red meat person at all) but my husband loves beef sticks and is the type of person that can literally have a beef stick and be good all day until diner. The past few times he had picked one up, he said they had really just gone way off the grid in taste and they always tasted dried out, so I have been on the hunt for a beef stick that meets a man's high expectations ( We all know men and their beef, right? )I had never heard of this brand before but when I was offered a chance to receive these at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion, I knew I wanted to try them. When they first arrived, my husband did not get all excited like i had hoped, so I simply put the package  on his nightstand and waited......I didn't have to wait long because the draw of fresh beef sticks was just too irresistible to him and that night when he came to bed, you could see the longing in his eyes...for beef sticks!!!!Now, many women would be all upset that their men noticed the beef sticks with more enthusiasm than they did them, but, I did have more online shopping to do :) In the middle of looking at these amazing..wait..he was eating a second BEEF STICK!!!SO I had to ask..are those beef sticks good? Now, this is a man that mind you, as I said above, can literally eat one beef stick and not need anything else to eat until dinner, so this was surprising.  So, in between bites, he started explaining that yes, these beef sticks were really good, so I told him i needed more than just "good" to write a real review, so he thought that was an invitation ot go in to a never ending dialogue, however, these were his findings:Pro's:Very, Very juice - not dry at all and actually taste like beef, and much better than some well known name brands he has tried.You do not need vampire teeth to chew these, they are again, moist and the texture is great, not like you are eating a stick of beef jerky.Flavor: Super flavorful like a burst of beef with some spices mixed in ,unlike anything he has tasted before.Filling : much more filling than other beef sticks and seem to last longer after he eats one instead of being hungry again in an hour ( he told on himself there, I now know that he sneaks cheese, crackers and anything else easy throughout the day)Con's :It's hard to only eat just one because they are so goodUnable to find any locally ( so he has to rely on me to order more, so he needs to be really nice, I think a new diamond since I found these gems, right? )The wife who doesn't really eat beef ate one and now he only has 4 left ( I had to try it , ya know, I did need to taste for myself)The kids now want one to try also since they heard him talking about these and he doesn't want to shareOverall, these deserve 5 stars. They are made great, have amazing flavor ( they really do, I did try one and was superbly impressed and could actually see myself eating one of these every once in awhile and I would normally never touch a beef stick ever) The beef sticks are very moist and simply YUMMY!As stated above, I did receive these at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinions.

I am a garden lover and you can find me outside year around constantly making sure my plants and bushes are well cared for, so it's important to me to have good Pruning Shears at all times.  I liked the look of these and the idea of the bonus gloves, so when I was offered a chance to receive these at a discount in exchange for an honest and unbiased review, I immediately ordered and hoped they worked okay.I am happy to report that not only do they work okay, they actually work really well. The Shears are well made, and really easy to grip. The handle appears designed so that it is actually easier to grip , and as I used them this morning for a couple of hours, I noticed that by the way the handle was designed, my hands did not tend to get as tired as they normally do with the large hard to hold shear handles I normally use.The Shears themselves are nice and sharp, and now that I have had the chance to use these for quiet a long time, I am impressed with how well they work on even thicker vines and plants that I sometimes have to get out the very large shears or hedge trimmers for.These also have a locking mechanism that works well. I had no problems locking and unlocking the blades when I needed to use then put them away.  The work very well for small jobs also and make nice clean cuts where you need them too.The gloves that come with these work well also, and have good grip on them ( amazing grip actually) and are made well and work perfect fro holding the shears or even grabbing vines from a Rosebush if you need too.Overall, 5 stars for a well made product that works well for what it is designed for.I did receive these at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion and all opinions are based on my personal experience with these Pruning Shears.

This is a fun wig, especially considering the election is coming up fast. I think everyone who has seen this on either my kids or my husband playing around with it, knew right off the bat exactly who it was suppose to be .The wig comes in the typical package that you would see any costume Wig come in, and the wig itself is covered with a Wig net which you normally expect to see on higher end wigs, so that was unexpected but made me feel like right off the bat, this wig may be better quality than you would find in a Halloween shop and I was right.The wig does feel a little more like real hair than you find on your normal everyday costume wigs, and appears to be well made. I have 5 teenage boys who have all tried this on, as well as my husband, and they all have different size and shape heads and this fit any of them just fine, so I think anyone would be able to wear this with ease ( even a woman with a lot of hair, as i pinned all of my hair up and still was able to out this on and I have very long, thick hair )The wig is funny and would make a great costume piece even after Halloween, obviously since the election is just starting to heat up , this would be funny!Overall, it is a great costume wig, the hair stays in place, it fits anyone, does not lose "hair" strands that we have seen, and is just funny!I did receive this at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion and all opinions are my own.

When I first received this pillow, I can honestly say that I thought I had probably wasted my money, just based on the appearance and how it came. It was in this what appeared to be, very small carry type case that I thought no way could hold a full size pillow. Once I started to get the pillow from the bag, well, I was even more sure that I had wasted my money because this pillow was flat as a board, I mean that in every sense of the word.So I decided I had best read what this pillow bag said, because something just did not seem right. According to the instructions, you were to let your pillow fluff itself basically over the first 24 hours. So, while my pillow was "fluffing itself" I decided to wash the cover, as I was not a big fan of the smell. Many may like the smell, I am just super sensitive to all smells , so in to the wash it went.  I actually went about my business and forgot about the pillow until the next afternoon when I was making my bed and decided to see if the pillow was ready for me to try and  this thing was literally 3 times or more the size it was when I took it out of the package. I do like my pillows a little fluffier, so I helped it along and fluffed it up more as I would with any other pillow I have. Now, it was to my desired size. So, if you get this and it doesn't get as fluffy and thick as you would like on it's own, you can help it along just by doing what you would normally do with any pillow you own when you fluff them each day.  The actual pillow part of this appears well made, stitched very well.Once I had my pillow how I wanted it, I retrieved the cover from the wash and the smell has dissipated when washing, so I was happy with that, and the cover itself appears to be well made, no loose stitches or dropped or pulled stitches and the cover is nice and thick also. It was very easy to put the cover back on the pillow, even though the pillow was now full size. The cover had not shrank in the wash at all, and still held the same shape.  You can use any normal size pillow case on this pillow with the cover on it.I have now been sleeping on this pillow for about 4 nights. It is very comfortable. It does hold it's shape very well even when you are suing it nightly, and unlike any other memory foam pillow I have had, it does not "sink" in when you lay your head on it. ( My Pet Peeve with my other memory foam pillows I own already)  I have recently had major level 4 Cervical Spine surgery and finding a pillow that I actually like to sleep on has been a challenge. I actually prefer sleeping with 2 pillows but prefer having 3 on my side of the bed so that I can prop myself up if I need to ( I find that after this surgery, I am sometimes more comfortable simply sleeping in a semi sitting position but still require pillows to achieve sleep ) So, I think I will probably end up buying 2 more of these for me and a couple for my husband over time, as he likes the pillow also.This pillow is perfect for using behind your back when you are sitting up in bed, or even behind your back on the couch if you have spine issues or back problems like I do.  If you have tried other memory foam pillows and like them, then you will love this one ( or even if you tried them and didn't like them because of the way they sink in when you put weight on them) It's like using a form yet at the same time , soft pillow ( I know that is a contradictory statement but it really is an accurate one) It will stay fluffed for you and not sink in with weight on it, but will still feel super soft for you.I do suffer from major migraines brought on by Brain surgery a little over a year ago and find that the right pillow can help with my headaches, and my headaches do seem like they are a little less with this pillow, but it will take time to decide if this is from the pillow or not. I will update my review with my findings after I have used this for a month or two.Overall, I will give this 5 stars, well deserved. It is well made, holds it's shape, easy to keep clean ( The cover is removable at any time and you can wash this in your normal washing machine)I did receive this at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion, and all opinions are based on my personal experience with this Bamboo Memory Foam Pillow.

One of the first things I noticed about this Wooden Oil Box was that is was well made. The wood appears to be quality and is beautiful unfinished wood. The box, though the wood is unfinished,is very smooth , you can tell that time and attention was spend getting this wood as it is so that you will not get splinters when opening, closing or moving the box.The Hinges are very well constructed, attached securely to the wooden box so that you will not have to worry about the lid falling off and your oils rolling across the room. You could easily varnish this with a clear varnish, or a darker wood stain to fit your personal taste, possibly even  do an intricate carving of your own or a burned on design if you wanted to really make it personal ( A great gift idea if you know someone who loves oils) Inside the box the dividers are secured and immovable . You can place your oils inside without having to worry that a divider will move ( which happened to me with another box I had and when the movable divider came loose, two of my oil collided and broke, which was a mess)The box has enough room for 52 bottles and also a place for your roller tubes. My oils all fit easily in to the spots , since this is designed just for that. I like the curved spots for the roller tubes, you can easily see which tube is which by the way this is laid out.This also comes with 6 Roller tubes, which are awesome for making your own oil mixtures. I made a sleep mixture, relaxation/stress mixture, allergy mixture and a headache mixture ( I use the headache one often and love that I now have a roller tube for this) It also comes with droppers for your oils and small round stickers that you can place on your oils so that you know exactly which one you are grabbing without having to pick up ever bottle just to find the one(s) you need.The roller tubes are well made, heavy duty and super easy to use and roll on. The droppers help you to get your oils in to the roller tubes as well so that you do not have to attempt any messy pour in's.Overall, I found this to be a great purchase worthy of 5 stars. The box is well made, well designed , and beautiful.I did receive this at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion and all opinions are based on personal experience with this Oil Box and it's accessories.

I have been attempting my hand at drawing once again, after years of not even picking up a pencil for drawing. So, when I was offered a chance to get these colored pencils at a discount in exchange for my honest opinion opinion, I decided why not give these a try and pick up drawing again.The first thing I noticed was that the pencils themselves were already sharpened, and although one or two had broken off in the box at the tip, the colors displayed were very vibrant. ( Broken at the tip is not an issue, as this could happen with any pencil you buy that comes per-sharpened) These colors are awesome when they actually go on paper as well. Where many colored pencils end up not looking like the actual color they appear at the tip, these are actually more vibrant than they appear, so that was a huge plus.My son is an amazing artist, and takes advanced Art classes in college, he typically spends hundreds on good quality pencils, and will not even use typical colored pencils even when at home just playing around, so when I ask him to try these out and got the funny look, he picked them up and began examining them. He first said that the weight of an actual single colored pencil was a tad heavier than the ones you would buy from a big box or discount store. That was a good sign he said, because although artist like lightweight tools, that a little heavier of a colored pencil usually means they are higher quality and as long as they are not heavy like a normal #2 pencil, then they are good, so that was a plus for him. So off he goes in to his bedroom and emerges a couple of hours later and showed me what he had drawn with these, and the colors really do pop and his lines were clean and crisp, with no difference in the width that you might see from a normal pack of colored pencils a child would use.My son says that although these are not the highest quality of colored pencils you can buy, he would definitely sue these for his practice drawings or when he was home just creating art for his brothers or sisters or even possibly for his class work on those times when they are allowed to use different materials than the high quality ones that most of his lessons require. He really likes these and thinks that they would be great for any child who is truly interested in Art or for anyone who enjoys drawing or using good quality colored pencils without having to spend a fortune. He says these are quality made, and will give you a smooth even line when using them. A great buy on these from his perspective.Overall 5 stars because based on the quality, the way they portray on different types of paper ( we used typical drawing white paper, craft paper, canvas) these are well worth the money especially considering you get so many of these for such a good price1 Above average colored pencils!I did receive these at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion.

A great muscle roller. This is my second product like this, and when my last one fell apart after just a couple of months, I was looking for one that would hold up longer I hoped. I recently got back in to working out at the gym, but hated having to either bring a lock for a locker or hang my keys on the hook with everyone else and stick my valuables in places only women can:) So, this seemed like a good solution when I was offered a chance to receive this at a discount in exchange for an honest review, I was concerned though because it was meant mainly for running and I am not quiet back to running yet.I had no need to be concerned, because this is an awesome Fitness belt that seems like it was made for everyday people like me who go to the gym or work out by walking at the park or through the neighborhood. Granted, I am sure this is great for runners since it was made for them, but I much prefer to think it works better for normal people too ( Not that runners are not normal hah)My 20 year old son actually tried this on as well and used it one day, and he is a runner, and he is insistent that he is going to buy one for himself, in the meantime , mine is hidden away because I like it too! He actually said that this seemed to adhere to his skin better than the ones he has yet it did not "stick" to his skin and that it kept his phone secure while he ran and he could listen to his music, he is not fond of Armbands, so this was a plus for him also.The belt is well made, the stitching is exceptionally done well, no loose stitches, dropped stitches or pulled stitches. The fabric is amazing, especially if you put it right on bare skin, you do not have to worry about road rash from this belt ( a.ka. scratchy clothing items or accessories ) because this fabric is very soft and breathable as well and even if you manage to work up a sweat while this is touching your bare skin, you can throw it in the wash and it will smell, and look as good as new ( Obviously I know this from my son wearing this and he runs in only shorts and shoes/socks )You have plenty of room in the hidden pockets of this belt so that you can carry your keys if you need, valuables, etc without having to worry about them falling out of pockets or like me, having to carry a purse or lock with you when you go to work out. I have an iPhone 6 and this also fits my phone perfectly, so when I hop on the treadmill at the gym, I can listen to my music instead of listening to the music they have playing or watching T.V.Overall, I would give this 5 stars. i have purchased other running belts before but this by far exceeds my expectations and I would recommend this to anyone. I also like the Lace Locks that come with this, I had never used those before even though I see them everywhere and in every shoe store i go in to ( Which, I will admit, is alot) and the lace locks can get fairly expensive, so this bonus was a good bonus and considering it is included in the price, it's a win-win situation!I did receive this at a discount in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion and all opinions are based on my personal experience with this belt ( and one from a runner's point of view via my son as well)

One thing I have never cared for when purchasing a Yoga Towel, has been the non-slip backing that everyone seems to think adds something to a Yoga towel, but personally which I feel is a pain. This towel is perfect because nto only does it actually stay in place, I do not have little pieces that feel like rubber all over the towel that hold it in place.I really love the color of the towel as well, it is so bright and vibrant. The towel appears to be very well made, the stitching is excellent with no loose or dropped stitches, and no loose or pulled threads on the towel itself. The towel fits nicely on your Yoga mat and you can even use the "sleeve system" that is on the towel to tuck it on your mat if you so prefer. It does stay on better, depending on your actual mat size. If you prefer to lay your towel right on your mat without using the sleeve system, you can spray it with a touch of water so that you are not sliding around or , since most are doing Hot Yoga with this, obviously your sweat can take care of that too. hah.The towel is long, which was a plus for me, because i am tall and prefer my mats to be longer than most mats,and always buy longer ones, so this was a good investment for me. The towel is not super thick, which is even better, I love how it easily dries you but it is not so thick that you cannot properly dry off with it. No one wants a thick fluffy towel for drying off the sweat, so score again on this Yoga towel. Recycled materials also make this a favorite for me, because we could all do a little more of our share of recycling, or let people like NamaSTAY do it for you and you know you are buying quality recycled products.The towel is Microfiber, which is quick to dry you off and the towel itself dries just as fast. It is machine washable and after washing several times now, the towel looks just as good as it did the first day I used it. The applique on the towel is very detailed, and although it is at the edge of your towel, it does not in any way interfere in your Yoga workout.Overall, 5 stars for a well made, vibrant, quick dry yoga towel.

I love my oils. I received this mop for free in exchange for an honest review, and that's what you're getting. I personally found the video review another reviewer did to be most helpful for getting an idea of how this thing actually works. After trying it myself, I mostly agree with the three star reviews. This is just a mop. It didn't work particularly great on my (admittedly scary level of dirt) laundry room linoleum, and I wound up spot cleaning the worst spots with a rag. However, for my laminate wood floors, I don't know that I've found anything else to work so well. The spinning action got out just the right amount of water so the mop wasn't too damp, and it cleaned surprisingly well. I hate cleaning my laminate wood because it almost always has streaks. But this mop got it streak-free and clean in a very short amount of time using just vinegar and water. And my kids fight over who gets to mop because they love the spinning action. For that reason I bumped this up to four stars.

At the time of writing this review, this set is on sale for less than $10. For that price, don't walk, run to get you some. That's a smokin' deal. Based upon the normal price of $24.95, I still think this is a good set. The tools look and feel like I would expect from something with the Cuisinart name. They have a nice weight, sturdy construction, and generous length so you can flip and grill without singeing your arm hairs. My only complaint, and the reason I took off a star, is because I can't see a good reason for the tongues to have silicone tips (which are not removeable). I didn't realize that this set isn't dishwasher safe and I put the tongues through the dishwasher, which resulted in spotted silicone, and it just feels weird to be using silicone on the grill anyway. Overall, this is a nice set, though, and if it's on sale, don't hesitate.

This is a fantastic mat for the price. It unrolls easily and stays unrolled during my practice, unlike some others I have tried that roll up partially and won't stay flat. From day one, this unrolled easily and stayed put. It has a great amount of stickiness/traction and I didn't have any problems with sliding. I like the design of it and the circles give me a frame of reference to help with my alignment. I'm not a huge fan of the pink color but it's not obnoxious and definitely not a dealbreaker. The only complaint I have is that the mat does have a mild smell when my face is right up next to it, but it's not too overpowering and it has seemed to fade over time. Overall, I think this is a great choice for the price.

This necklace has become my "wear it with everything every day" necklace. I've barely taken it off, even to sleep or shower. It's incredibly light-weight so I forget that I have it on, but it looks expensive. The chain is very delicate and almost disappears against the skin, so the butterfly itself is the only thing you really notice. I love that the color and the detail has invited many compliments, but it's casual enough for everyday wear. The only reason I took off a star is because the chain IS so lightweight, it tangles very easily when not on your neck. When the necklace arrived I had a really hard time untangling a knot in the chain. I've kept it on since then, though, so I haven't had further problems with tangles.

Here's the list of pros, in my opinion:* Relatively lightweight* Works fairly well for spot cleaning: spray the spot with the mister on the nozzle, let it sit a few minutes, give it a little scrub and the hand sucks it all back up.* You can clean until the battery runs out without needing to dump the 'gray water.' It held a surprising amount.* Ideal for hitting stains on the stairs, or for cleaning a section of upholstery/carpet in the car.* Doesn't take up too much space and fit on a shelf in my laundry room.But, there's also a list of cons:* Does not work while plugged in, so your battery has to be charged or you need to wait a few hours until you can use it.* Battery only lasts for 20 minutes. This was actually more time than I needed to do stains on an area rug, but if I was doing a whole stair case it would be annoying to stop in the middle to charge it.* How well it removes the stain is largely dependent on your level of patience and attention to detail since you are the one manning the hose and working on the stain. I am comparing this to the standard SpotBot, which you just set on the stain and walk away, then come back when it beeps and move it to a different spot.* Replacement cleaning solution can get expensive. I suggest mixing the minimum amount and then making more if necessary, rather than making too much and wasting it.Overall Impression:I've always liked Bissell Spotbots for hitting those stains in between a professional carpet cleaning. This is a nice addition to the line up, especially if you have carpeted stairs or fabric upholstery. The regular spotbot wouldn't work for those things. But if you are mostly going to use this on carpet, I still like the one that sits on the floor and does all the work. This will not replace a good cleaning by a carpet cleaner because it would take forever to do a large area, and your results will be inconsistent. It works as expected, but I wish it was also possible to plug it in to finish a job if the battery runs low.

Overall, we really like this thing. It works great for catching grasshoppers and observing them, and the price is reasonable. The reason I'm not giving it five stars is because of some misconceptions I had on this critter barn before we got it (based on the picture and the description):1. It does have a light, but it's tiny (run with watch batteries) and does not illuminate the whole cage like the picture would lead you to believe. It's hardly noticeable unless your room is very dim. My kids still think it's fun, I just don't find it much of a selling point.2. It does not have any sort of built in reservoir for holding water. I'm not sure exactly why I thought it did (maybe because water was mentioned in the description) but it's just a run-of-the-mill plastic rectangle with a lid. You can put water in it, for minnows and such, but to me it makes more sense to use it dry for catching bugs.3. The "magnifier" on it is just a circle of warped glass and isn't much help in seeing the bugs better. We haven't used that feature much.4. The plastic cover for the hole where you drop bugs in is easily lost. I wish there was a string attaching it to the lid. We may rig one up ourselves and there IS a hole conveniently already drilled in it so it shouldn't be hard.5. It's not very big, only about 6.5"x4," but it holds a lot of grasshoppers and it is light enough for little hands to carry around.Those are my only complaints. This isn't a true habitat by any means, but it's definitely a step up from the empty yogurt container we usually use.

This 5-tab set of dividers from Avery might be my favorite yet. They are NOT pocket dividers, so don't expect to hold or corral any loose papers with them, but if you have a large stack of papers in your binder that you want divided into sections, these can't be beat. The large white rectangle that you see on the picture is actually opaque so you can see through it to the sheet underneath. This is helpful because you can see what the next page contains without turning the divider. I love the thick color border on each one: it adds a pop of color to my binder without being distracting or obnoxious. The tabs fit perfectly in my binder: they are bigger than 8.5x11 paper so you can easily grab each tab, but they do not overhang the edge of the actual binder. I also like that the labels can be printed or hand written, and they are sized so that a thin border of color remains around the white. They look really clean and classy. I couldn't be happier with these dividers and will buy them again.

I'm going to agree with another 3-star reviewer who stated that this reminded him of the shave he got from a cheap drugstore razor: the power just isn't there. In my husband's words, "It just doesn't seem to have high enough rpm's to do the job well." The motor is quiet, it cleans itself, it has a nice look and feel in the hand, but the actual shave wasn't anything to write home about. My husband has gone back to using his old Panasonic ES8243A Electric Shaver Wet/Dry with Nanotech Blades for Men, which cost less and has been working fine for years. It's louder, yes, but the motor doesn't balk at a few days' worth of stubble and it gets the job done. This Norelco just seems a little wimpy for the price.

I have a set of these towels with the red stripes. So far, after a month and several washings, they have held their color extremely well. The red has not faded at all and there is no bleeding onto the white or into the wash. They get softer with each washing and do work very well for drying dishes. I wouldn't say that they are "magic" towels by any stretch, and they don't necessarily work better than my ecloth microfiber cloths or other dish towels I have. They do dry glass quickly and efficiently and I haven't noticed linting or streaks. As far as the size goes, they have shrunk a bit and are no bigger than a standard kitchen towel. I still prefer my Old-Fashioned Cotton Flour Sack Towels 30 Inch x 30 Inch Set of 3 because they dry dishes well, yet are big enough and light enough to use for covering rising bread dough.

What to say about a book that took over 70 pages to reel me in, that I almost gave up on, and then suddenly found myself unable to put down?This book, to me, felt like a mashup of a John Green book and Daughter of Smoke and Bone. It is at times almost exhausting with its wordiness and cutesy font gymnastics, and yet captivating in its imagery. It's not one to give up on but to roll with and be swept along by and see where it goes.It manages to land on that tenuous precipice between books written for teens and books about teens that anyone can enjoy. I would have no problem handing this to my 15-year-old niece and knowing she would love it, and also recommending it to my married friends.Magonia sets the stage and pulls the curtain back on a world where ships sail the skies, unseen by the "drowners" living on Earth, surrounded by squallwhales and heartbirds and pirates. This book introduces Aza Ray, kidnapped in infancy and left with a human family, slowly drowning on human air most of her life.On the weirdness scale, this one ranks about an 8. There are birds that shift into bird people. There are blue skinned Magonians. There are little doors in people's chests where their heartbirds live. You have to not get hung up on that. Because much like the movie Avatar, by the end of the movie, the blue people look way more normal than the humans. It grows on you. It becomes familiar. It makes you want more.This book is balanced with well-developed and believable characters (yes, even the blue and bird-like ones), a light romantic thread of friendship-based love warring with a magnetic pull to someone of her own kind, and the unspooling of a bigger adventure to come.In a heavily saturated and overrun genre, Magonia managed to catch my attention and keep it, and left me asking myself this question.Yes, a fish may love a bird… but where shall they live?I can't wait to find out.

This is the first installment of an ongoing series about a bunch of kids who are a part of a reality show much like the "Amazing Race." They've been divided up into teams and have to solve clues as they make their way through the different habitats, in this case, the rain forest. The storyline relies heavily on the reality show theme, and kids who are fans of the show will probably enjoy that.After reading this out loud to my family, and having two of my kids read it to themselves, here are the pros and cons from my perspective as a homeschooling mom:PROS:*the book includes interesting facts about several rainforest creatures and the habitat, weaving them in both the storyline and also as a few "break out" sections where a different creature is highlighted.*both my second and fourth grade sons were able to read it and enjoy it. The writing is at about a third grade level I would guess.* the pictures added a lot and were helpful in visualizing the different environments the kids were in*my kids are interested in finding out what happens nextCONS:*My kids haven't seen any episodes of the Amazing Race, so that aspect of the story was kind of lost on them.*I personally didn't care for the antagonists in the book actually being a group of kids on the other team who were the main characters "good friends" from back home. They had all applied for the show together and when they got there they found out they would be on separate teams. That would have been fine, but that other team of kids was the main source of conflict in the story as they cheated and sabotaged the main character's team. I am not sure what message the author is trying to send here, but it seems like an unnecessary source of conflict for this book. They are in the amazing, and DANGEROUS, rain forest... surely, that in itself could have presented enough challenges without diabolical scheming from people he considered his friends.*This book only covers the first leg of the race. You have to wait for, and pay for, the next two or three books in the series in order to find out how the race ends. That may really frustrate some kids.OVERALL:This is a good reader for a second or third grader. I didn't enjoy it very much as a family read aloud, mostly because I felt like the interpersonal drama and dialogue distracted a bit from their adventure. I also didn't particularly like the attitude of the kids in the story and my children didn't really relate to them, but they were still intrigued by all the fun things they got to do and would like to know what happens next. I'd be willing to check them out of the library when they all come out.

I love these felt pads for protecting my hard wood floors. I used this particular set on my heavy kitchen farm table, and they have performed very well. I like that they are peel and stick, rather than having to peel an individual sticker off of each one separately. They applied in literally less than a minute, and I can now move that heavy table all by myself without scratching the floor. It slides very easily. It did raise the height of my table about 1/4", but it is not noticeable and doesn't bother me.The only reason I didn't give them five stars is that the price seems a bit high. I have bought multipacks of pads like these at Costco (possibly a different brand) in the past and felt like a got a better deal. But if you really need something heavy-duty, and the grout lines in your tile are ripping off the cheaper ones, then these should work well for you.

As far as canned coconut milk goes, this is exactly what I would expect. It's extremely thick (mostly cream with about 1/3 liquid) and is great for cooking and for recipes that call for "one can." When cooked it melts down into a wonderful thick cream, but refrigerated or at room temp, it's more like cream cheese. It's not my favorite for smoothies because it's so thick I have to stir it together first, and it also has added guar gum. For smoothies I like to make my own coconut milk using organic unsweetened dried coconut and hot water. If you google it, you will find tons of blogs and youtube videos that show how. It's very easy and makes great coconut liquid coconut milk. Its hard to control the amount of cream that you get though, so for recipes, I still prefer the canned.This is good quality and tastes great and will make consistent recipes every time. But just be aware that these are not BPA-free cans and there is added guar gum, so if those two things are an issue for you, you may want to just make your own.

I've been using this stylus to annotate PDF's on my iPad (using the GoodNotes app). So far, it's worked out better than the traditional soft-tipped styluses I have tried. The accuracy when highlighting is greater and my handwriting is, while not perfect, at least more natural and easier to control than with other styluses. I wouldn't want to use this to write or sketch for long periods of time, but for quick notes and highlighting it works great. I like how the cap on this, which is necessary to protect that clear disc over the tip, screws onto the end of the pen so you don't lose it. The clip has worked well to clip it to either my pants pocket or my iPad case.Overall, I think this is a nice stylus for writing and annotating. The clear disc is mildly cumbersome, although I can see that it's probably necessary to prevent the fine tip from scratching the screen. I don't let my kids use this one because there is no cushion on it and I don't trust them not to push or tap too hard and possibly damage the screen, but for myself it's great. If your main purpose in needing a stylus is to click on things that you have a hard time reaching with your finger, you may be able to get away with using a cheaper stylus, but for writing, you definitely want a fine tip.

A Court of Thrones and Roses is a new-adult fantasy revolving around the fae. It is a bit of a hybrid retelling of "East of the Sun and West of the Moon" with a little "Beauty and the Beast" thrown in. I was pleasantly surprised to find that while the framework from those stories is evident in the general plot, the details are unique and I wasn't always able to guess what would happen next. Maas does a good job of taking these stories and making them her own, which was nice to see because retellings can become tedious when they are too predictable. I suspect any fans of her other books will be thrilled with this new world and nothing I say will deter them, nor would I want to.However, aside from liking the plot, I was not blown away by this book. I've read Sarah Maas before (Throne of Glass) and thought that book was just ok. I was still excited to get my hands on this one and give it a try because of the early praise I was seeing on Goodreads; unfortunately, and this is only my opinion, I found the writing to be weak and lackluster, and that is the main reason why I'm only giving it three stars.In my experience, the difference between YA and NA is slim, but NA books typically have older protagonists in more mature situations and usually have more explicit sexual content than the YA "fade to black" variety. In that sense, because it has some PG-13 sex in it, Court of T&R is technically a new adult book-- yet it still felt like a YA book to me. It contained all of the typical YA tropes that just won't die: first-person narrator, insignificant young girl who accomplishes unimaginable feats, negative internal woe-is-me self talk, and more than one gorgeous man vying for her attention. If those things bug you, be advised before heading into this one.Surprisingly, I'm actually not holding the trope pitfalls against this book, though. Like I said before, I really did get caught up in the plot and it kept me turning pages quickly until I was done. My biggest complaint with this book was the writing itself. I don't expect high literature when I pick up books like this, I pick them up for a fun afternoon escape, but I still expect some degree of finesse from best-selling authors. I want descriptions that help me see things, rather than generalities such as "…So much color, so much sunlight and movement and texture… I could hardly drink it in fast enough. To paint it would be useless, would never do it justice."That told me absolutely nothing about why this land of the Fae was so breathtaking. Not all descriptions were like that, there were a few good moments, but most of the time I was unimpressed with the descriptions and the word choices. Repeated turns of phrase, such as "a chill spider-walked down my spine," become distracting when they are used multiple times, and I was considerably bothered by the incessant use of the "as if" similes. I'm not usually one to let minor writing quirks annoy me, but I felt that this book was dragged down by a classic, and severe, case of "telling, not showing." Any time the author didn't trust me as the reader to be smart enough to figure out what the characters' body language was saying, she just had the narrator explain it in painful detail. I found this insulting to my intelligence.But, those are my only real complaints.Basically, this is a beach read. An airplane read. An "I'm sick and need a distraction," read. It's not particularly well-written and the tropes might annoy the more jaded readers of the YA genre, but if you know you already like Sarah Maas's style and the plot synopsis intrigues you, give it a try. You may enjoy it more.

With this product, what you see is what you get: five opaque white (not translucent) dividers with large curved tabs that are spaced to span the length of an 8.5x11" sheet of paper. They will not overhang your papers and compete with larger pocket dividers, but they are good for making subcategories within a larger section of a binder. I tested the "write and erase" claim by making three small stars on one divider using a pencil, a sharpie, and a ball-point pen. After about two weeks I tried erasing them and found the pencil erased completely, the ball-point pen also erased but was faintly visible, and the sharpie was (expectedly) not erasable. Conveniently, I think a good thick pencil lead actually writes cleaner on these and is easier to read than a pen anyway, so that is what I recommend using.The only reason I knocked off a star was because the description says they are translucent, and that is not really accurate. You will not be able to see through them, but they are clean and crisp and functional.

This projector has, in all ways, exceeded our expectations. Even before getting a white screen to project it on, and using a wall painted a gray green color, the colors were breathtaking. Vibrant color, deep blacks, and adjustable screen size up to 300"… this is as close to having a movie theater in your home as you can get.I was nervous, as always, when receiving electronics through the mail, but the packaging was excellent and the product arrived in mint condition. For this price tag, I honestly expected quite the ordeal with setting it up, but by (temporarily) using a high bookshelf to set it on and a usb cord to connect the DVD player to the projector, everything was up and running and we were watching a movie in about five minutes. I couldn't believe it. So for ease of use, it doesn't get simpler. We haven't mounted it to the ceiling and hardwired it in yet, but I don't anticipate problems with it.We have it back about 16 feet from the wall and if we wanted to, it would fill the entire wall with no problem. Adjusting the size of the screen is as simple as turning a dial, and we keep it at about a 60" screen.We have used it with our Xbox 360 to let the kids play 4-player Minecraft and it worked without a hitch. We noticed no lagtime and they were thrilled to play on a screen that big.I would note that this is the first time I have ever been able to tell a difference between our standard DVD's and blue-ray DVD's. There was a marked difference in the color and picture quality when using a blue-ray disc. That's actually kind of exciting because it's annoyed me for years to pay extra for blue-ray and not even be able to tell a difference. If there was no improvement from a normal DVD to a blue-ray it would mean the projector had maxed out its capabilities at a lower resolution, but a blue-ray allowed me to fully experience the awesomeness that is 1080p for the first time. The first movie we tried on it was Avatar (the one with the giant blue guys, not the humorless air benders) and we were stunned. We could not believe how breathtaking the picture quality was.This is obviously not going to work as well in a room with lots of windows. It needs to be a darker room where you can control the light levels. We used it in a room with a  couple of windows that have wooden blinds, and as long as the blinds are closed we have no problems even during the day.Basically, I think this thing is flat out amazing and I have no problem giving it all five stars. Highly recommended.

These file folders are decent quality for the price. About the thickness of cardstock, they are not heavy duty, but will work fine for holding a reasonable amount of papers within a larger hanging-filing system. I like that they come stacked separately by style (left tab, middle tab, right tab) so you can pick and choose the style you need without reorganizing a huge stack of file folders. They are packaged economically, meaning shrink wrapped all together in a plain brown box. Mine were slightly bent from the pressure of the shrink wrap, but after unwrapping them and letting them sit on the shelf for a while, they seemed to relax and there isn't a visible bend or crease on them now. I did see a box of 100 file folders at my local Costco for a better price, but if you don't have access to Costco, this is a good deal.

I have several leather couches and leather seats in my car, and as much as I love them, they are a pain to condition. I was excited to try out these leather care pads because they claim to "clean and condition" all in one step. In the tub you get 12 thick felt pads that are pre-soaked with the cleaning/conditioning solution. The pads themselves are nice and sturdy and work well for the task, although they dry out fairly quickly so you would need at least two to do a standard sized couch. I found them to clean fairly well, if the pad turning dark and dingy is any indication, and they did get out a few spots where my kids had colored on the couch with markers. As far as the conditioning aspect though, I was underwhelmed. A week afterward my couch seemed just as dry and in need of conditioning as it did before. In the past I have always used Leather Honey Leather Honey Leather Conditioner which works great but is time consuming to apply because you need to first clean the couches with a leather cleaner, let the honey sit overnight, and then wipe off any excess. After using these pads to try and take a short cut I've decided the leather honey is still worth the effort, BUT I do like these Lexol pads for the cleaning step and they also did a good job of applying the Leather Honey. I just turned it over and used the other side of the pad to apply it.

So here's the deal. I really like the idea of these bins, the design, and the potential they have to keep my lazy susan organized. I used to keep my vinegar bottles in an upper cabinet but this container has allowed me to keep them in the lazy susan without them tipping over every time it spins. Even though I like the bin, this is why I gave it three stars: This particular one is a much smaller wedge and you would need EIGHT of them to fill up a lazy susan. Eight would cost a fortune. This particular size, in my opinion, is best suited to taller bottles such as vinegar and oil bottles. The narrow end is much too small to hold a can of beans etc so this size is only good for certain things. InterDesign does make a bigger size wedge, the quarter wedge, and that to me would be much more practical. Unfortunately Amazon doesn't seem to sell that particular one but I found it at Bed, Bath and Beyond. To me that size seems the most useful. It seems more expensive at $16.99, but it is equivalent to two of these 1/8th bins, so they actually end up costing less. You could even mix and match to maximize your storage potential. I will be picking up more of them, just wish the quarter wedge style was available on Amazon.

As far as pocket dividers go, these ones are quickly becoming my favorites. I love the fun, bright, cheerful colors, but please be aware that these are distinctly feminine in design and may not be for everyone. As another reviewer mentioned, the tabs do indeed overhang the edge of the binder, even when it's closed. Not by a lot, but just a smidge. At first I was worried this would be be annoying and inconvenient and prevent me from storing it on the bookshelf. As time has gone on, however, this design has grown on me more and more for the following reasons:1. Even if I have some papers in page protectors, the dividers are still big enough to overhang them so my papers aren't competing with my labels and it's easy for me to see where everything is at.2. I can get to different sections quickly and easily because, again, the divider labels are bigger and the divider itself is larger than any papers I have in there.3. My binder looks clean, cheerful, and organized.4. The plastic is thick enough to allow me to flip the whole section without fear of ripping it.5. The pockets are not exceptionally deep and they won't hold more than about 8 sheets of paper, but they are strong and the restrictions on size prevents me from stuffing everything in there and leaving it forever.All in all, these are great dividers. The reason I took off a star is because I wasted almost an hour on the Avery website trying to print my label names using their interface. I thought I had it all exactly how I wanted it, it looked great on screen, but then I went to print it and they were off by a few millimeters, which ruined the whole sheet. Since you only get one, that was annoying. I wound up using my label maker to just label them myself and it worked great. Wish I wouldn't have wasted time trying to use the printer at all.

I received two packs of these pens, one in the primary colors and one in the vivid. I love the vivid assorted pack! Dark purple, teal, coral pink, orange, and lime green. What you see on the cap is what you get on the white board. The colors are very true.What I like most about these pens is that the color is vibrant and very true to the color of the cap, you definitely know when you're getting low on ink because you can see it in the chamber on the side, and they are easy to write with. They do erase cleanly, BUT not with your finger. If you make a mistake and try to correct it by wiping the ink away with your finger, you will get a big smeary mess. That is why I always use a 3M dry eraser (the white and blue ones) and they erase phenomenally. As long as you use an eraser you will have no problems keeping your board nice and clean.Another thing I'd like to note, even though the package says "fine point" these are not super fine, like a writing pen. If you're writing on a white board, this will easily allow you to write small enough to fit a ton on the board, but if you're trying to write on something smaller (say, a laminated worksheet) you would most likely want a finer tipped pen (i.e. Expo brand fine tip).

I really like the concept of this little device and overall it works very well. I've had no problems using it with my iPhone 5 and charging from a wall unit as well as my Macbook. The white part is flexible so when you plug it into your phone it kind of bends and just dangles there while it charges. I took off one star because this only works if you have a USB adapter to plug it into (I don't have one in my car so I would have to have one with me or find one somewhere I guess for it to be practical) and I took off another star because the little metal ring that actually clips to the device is SUPER flimsy, which worries me. The key ring itself isn't flimsy, but the one holding the device to the key ring is poor quality. I would recommend keeping this in a designated spot in your purse rather than clipping to a key chain so it doesn't break off and get lost.

To be honest, I'm a little surprised at how many low star reviews this fan has as I'm hard pressed to find any flaws with it. It's got a lovely finish that really will go with just about any decor and it looks very classy. As noted in the description, it weighs about 7.8 pounds, but feels very heavy-- much heavier than any plastic fans I've ever had. I have no worries that it will stay exactly where I put it, but if I was to put it in a child's room I would definitely want to hide the cord behind a dresser. This thing is heavy and you don't want it falling on anyone. It is mid winter in Idaho so I haven't had a chance to give it a thorough work out yet, but I will say this, the times we have used the fan it has been whisper quiet. On low speed, I have to lean close to even hear the thing. On high speed it is not silent, but it's definitely quieter than any fan I've ever owned. At this point I think it well deserves the four stars I've given it, but if things change over time I will be sure to come back and update my review.

After using this program intensely for a month, I now feel ready to give my honest feedback. Fair warning, this review will be long, so if you want to cut to the chase, here it is: while this program is stunningly pretty and appears to have lots of "bells and whistles" at first glance, in actual practice it fell far short of my expectations for a program with this price tag and I would NOT recommend it to people who want an all-inclusive reading program for their child. This could possibly serve as a supplement to other reading programs, but I see many flaws in how it is designed that I will explain in more detail below. Suffice to say that if you are wanting to actually teach your child how to read, there are many programs that are far superior and actually cost much less (e.g. Reading Eggs, All About Reading, Get Set for the Code series of workbooks etc) As nice as it would be to simply fork over the money for an expensive app and then hand the iPad to your child and let it teach them to read, there is no substitute for a little one on one time working with your child. You will have MUCH better results, a much less frustrated child, and you will save a ton of money.If you are wanting a program to supplement and help fill in the gaps for your child who's attending school, then I would recommend the Reading Eggs website. Well worth the money and I wish I had known about it when my kids were in school. If you have the time and desire to work with your child yourself, we've had great success using the Get Set for the Code books to learn letter sounds (wonderful gentle introduction to each letter and fun to do together) and then moving on to All About Reading (made by All About Learning Press).Now, moving on to the nitty gritty of my review.I'm a homeschooling mom of four kids, my youngest being 5 years old and in kindergarten. I used the program primarily with him, so my review will be on the effectiveness of this program with a pre-reader who is still learning letter names and their sounds.What you get for your "purchase price" is actually a one-year subscription to use this program either on a computer or as a fully functioning iPad app. After the first year is up you can continue using the program for either $99 per year OR $19.99 per month, whichever you prefer. I find this price to be outrageous. I have purchased reading programs for this price (All About Reading) and felt it was worth every penny and then some, and I also owned the program out right and was able to keep it forever or sell it when I was through. To pay $120 to rent this program for a year is ridiculous, especially when you consider that you can get the entire Hooked on Phonics app for $50 (incidentally, I don't recommend Hooked on Phonics for pre-readers, I'm just comparing the price on the two.)  I find the price to be WAY too high.I would only recommend using this program on an iPad. We tried it on the laptop one time and it was a huge fail due to the frequent need to "drag and drop" things. My 5-year-old does not have the computer literacy to maneuver the mouse well enough to do this, so it was very frustrating for him. Luckily the website is fully functional on an iPad and once you're logged in (through Safari) it looks and acts like any other app. The app itself is beautiful and the characters used to teach the lessons are adorable. They are colorful little water droplets named the "Lingos" and each has a name and a color and my son liked them immediately.Initial set up was not hard, but parental controls and customization were extremely limited. Unlike some programs, this one does not let you see what will be taught on each level. There is no ability to customize the program to turn on the things your child needs to work on and turn off the things they have mastered. So on some levels my child was bored because the ONLY way to unlock the game and get to the next level was to complete 10 rounds of 10 questions at each "station" and there were five or six stations on each level. That meant that on level 2, my son spent over two cumulative hours playing the iPad, and worked through 600 "problems" before he unlocked the game for that level. For that much work I expected the game to be amazing, but it was a simple little game that is similar to a dozen apps I have on my phone that I got for a dollar or less. The games are definitely not going to be an incentive to complete a level. Learning should be fun, but this felt incredibly repetitious and very much like "drill to kill." I was frustrated and irritated to not be able to look ahead and see what would be covered on each level and felt the parental controls were slim to none. If you think I'm exaggerating, an example of one of the things the packaging brags that you can customize is, wait for it... turning the background music on and off.I could look past the repetitious nature of the activities and even the lack of customization if this program was doing a good job of teaching phonics and reading skills, but I was very disappointed in this aspect of the program as well. When your child begins they have the option of choosing "world 1" or "world 2" based upon their skill level. World 1 is mostly preschool type activities (e.g. recognizing shapes and "position" words such as below, beside, above, between, etc.) World 2 jumps into more preschool/kindergarten activities and my son did enjoy the first couple levels on this world. But I noticed when he got to the third level that some of the activities were causing more confusion and frustration than anything.For example, in the "Starting Sounds" activity, the child is supposed to listen for a letter sound and then choose from three little pictures the one that starts with that sound. I've done this activity with him in our Get Set for the Code book and he loves this one and is very good at it. However, in this app, the computer voice says the sound of the letter, but there is no visual cue (such as the letter appearing that says that sound).  You only hear the sound, which can be hard to hear unless you are really dialed in and is very easy to miss. Then the computer voice goes slowly through each picture, naming them one at a time. This takes about ten seconds. After she has told you the name of each picture, the child is still supposed to remember the sound that they heard in the beginning and  be able to associate it with the picture. There is no button to press to have her repeat the sound if you need a reminder. If the child gets it wrong, the cute little Lingo character in the corner pouts and tosses the star he was going to award you on the ground. If the child gets it wrong two times, a chalkboard is wheeled out to "help" them. What I expected at this point was for a little lesson about the letter that they are being asked to identify, such as, "This is the letter D. D says /d/, like dog (the picture that they are looking for)." But what actually happens is the chalkboard has two pictures completely unrelated to the sound they are being quizzed on, and they are reminded to listen really hard for the starting sound of the word, "ssssssssock and sssssssssun." Then the chalkboard goes away and the child is still left starting at pictures that don't have anything to do with sock or sun, and expected to know which one starts with D. The same chalkboard will appear with the same "lesson" every time the child makes a mistake with absolutely no variation or relation to what they are actually learning.In the letter quiz activity, they child is presented with a lineup of seven letters. They are then told the name of the letter they are supposed to identify. My son has learned about 18 of the 26 letters so chances are good that he would do well with this and I was hoping it would help him learn the ones he doesn't have down yet. However, when he got it wrong, instead of a little chalkboard demo explaining more about the letter he didn't know, it just shows the entire alphabet and sings the alphabet song. Over and over and over again. He is supposed to get through 100 rounds of this torture before he can pass the level. Instead of helping him improve his letter literacy, which he's eager to do, he wound up guessing much of the time and then feeling discouraged and frustrated when he was not able to do what they were asking for.I find this program to be not only unhelpful to early readers, but could possibly be a deterrent. My initial review was going to be two stars, but the more I think about it the more I realize that I wouldn't recommend this to anyone, especially at this exorbitant price. Invest in an actual reading program that you can do with your child, or if you really want something they can work on independently, try the two-week trial from Reading Eggs or ABCmouse.

I have an ancient copy of Toast that I used for years when I needed to burn a disc, but never really tapped into any other capabilities it may have possessed. After upgrading to Toast 12 I've been pleasantly surprised. It's very stable and works well on my Macbook running Mountain Lion. I had hoped it would allow me to import DVD's (specifically my exercise DVD's) so that I could watch them on my iPad, but so far every DVD I've tried that's not a specific "digital copy" disc has been copywritten and Toast refused to do anything with it. So, I'm still using the downloadable internet program Handbrake for that, which works very well and it's free.What I have been thrilled with so far about this program is it's ability to tackle audiobooks. It has a specific audiobook import option that allows you to check out audiobooks on CD from the library and convert them into one long continuous track. I love audiobooks but they are crazy expensive, even with an Audible membership, and CD's can just be a huge hassle. I don't want to listen only when I'm driving, I want the book on my phone so I can listen through ear buds whenever I want. Toast has allowed me to do that without jumping through the hoops I used to go through (e.g. import each CD individually and try not to get them all tangled in a big jumbled mess as you create a playlist). It takes a little while to feed each CD in and wait for it to be converted (approximately an hour to do an entire audiobook) but you can definitely walk away while it does it's thing. Considering how expensive audiobooks can be, being able to utilize my library's vast collection is a definite plus for me.

I'm going to agree with another four-star reviewer who gave this binder five stars for durability and three stars for the feel of it. When you pick up this binder, it doesn't seem like anything special and it has a strange rubbery texture that I don't particularly enjoy touching. However, aesthetics aside, if you know you need a binder that can take a lot of abuse, you can't go wrong with this one. The hinge is incredibly strong. Because of the way it's designed it's difficult to click it open by accident, but when you do want it open it truly clicks open or closed with just one finger. The pockets on the front and back cover are flexible enough to hold a decent stack of papers; someone else said it was 200 but I would have to be pretty desperate to stuff that much in it. I have used those pockets to hold thicker magazines though and it had no problem with that at all.I also like that the front cover has that blue border so you can create a cover with a standard 8-1/2x11" piece of paper and you won't have a bunch of dead space around it. It's makes for a more finished look. The price tag on this binder seems a little high at first, but if you're replacing your binders frequently because the cover is separating or the hinge is no longer holding, maybe spending the extra few bucks up front will save you money in the long run.

I really like this apron! It's pretty and functional, with two deep pockets, an adjustable neck strap (simply pull on it to lengthen), and thicker fabric that reminds me more of duck cloth rather than 100% cotton. I haven't washed it yet so I don't know yet how the colors will stand up over time, but for now it's working well. I'm 5'6" with a short waist and I have to fold it over a bit to get it to tie in the right spot on me, but I don't mind that. I knocked one star off because I don't like the feeling of something pulling on the back of my neck, even though loosening did help. In a perfect world, the apron would have two straps that go over my shoulders, but that's probably harder to make in a size that would fit most people. Oh well, can't have it all! All in all, this is a really pretty apron, the fabric is classy, and I would give it as a gift.

Okay, so I don't know if it's just me, or if there's something wrong with the particular router that I got, but I am so disappointed with this thing! I am not hardware savvy, but I can follow directions and I know how to set up and use a wireless router. This one was actually fairly easy to set up with very simplified and clear instructions, and I didn't have any trouble getting everything up and running. Or so I thought.My old router had left dead spots on the other side of the house. This router has no trouble getting a signal to the whole house (2800 sq ft, two story) but it is SO MUCH SLOWER than my old router. Even when I'm on the computer that is in the same room as the router, which is the only time I can use the 5 GHZ signal, it seems sluggish and takes a long time to boot up just simple you tube videos. I never had a problem streaming netflix to multiple devices in the past, but now if one person is using it, the other person's device is greatly affected.My husband has an app on his phone that tells you what the internet speed is and we were surprised to find it running at less than 1 MBPS; we had between 3 and 4 before. When we click the wifi off and go on cellular, it shoots back up to 4 mbps. Now, I guess it's possible that there's some magical setting that I need to tinker with, or change the IP address or whatever, but I really really hate having to jump through hoops to get things to work the way they are supposed to. I am homeschooling four kids and I don't have time to call support and walk through a list of troubleshooting tips... I think I will just plug in my old router and deal with the dead spot in the bathroom.

**update: My review was initially one star, but a comment from the developer helped me change the settings so we could move past level one. As a result, I'm upgrading my review to two stars, but I stand by everything else I said. This is definitely not the best Mavis Beacon product I've used."Original Review:I've been playing with different versions of Mavis Beacon since second grade, and thanks in part to the great instruction and practice I received in my early years, I am a proficient typist. However, this particular version had nothing in common with the older versions I remember and I found it incredibly clunky and frustrating to use. I was hoping this program would help my 10 and 12-year-old sons to improve their keyboarding skills, but here are the problems we ran into:1. Installation went fine on our older 2007 iMac running Snow Leopard (no complaints there.)2. This program is PERSONAL edition, meaning progress for only one person will be saved. So unless you are a single person, you need the family edition.3. One of my sons hates video tutorials and would rather "learn by doing," but this program requires you to watch every video all the way to the end (posture, finger positioning etc) before it will let you move on to the next part.4. Even if you watch all the videos to the end, it doesn't seem to ever let you progress. My other son watched every video, took the assessment test, and completed all three "activities" to learn the home row key, but it would never let him move on to step two. I even took the assessment test (scored 90+ wpm) and it wanted me to start at the very beginning, watch all the videos, and do the exact same steps of learning the keys, so I'm not sure why the assessment test is even included. It doesn't seem to make a difference in where you start.5. Like I said, we completed everything that seemed to be required to move on to step 2, but the program would not let us go forward. (UPDATE: I eventually was able to correct this by lowering the accuracy level needed to progress) Besides the lessons and skill assessments, there is just one section where you can "free type," which you could do on any word processor. There are no games or activities that help you practice, just repetitious drills that include a very unnatural paragraph symbol at the end of each sentence. You are supposed to hit the enter key when you reach this symbol (like an old fashioned typewriter, I have no idea what the purpose of this is) and if you don't hit the enter key it counts as an error. I found this both annoying and pointless.6. There doesn't seem to be a clear path that you progress along to learn to type, and like I said before, it seemed to freeze up and refuse to let us move past step 1 (which was to learn the home row).Overall I found this program to be frustrating and unclear. It's not meant for kids (no games), but even an adult would have a difficult time making progress with this one. My recommendation would be to stick with an older version of Mavis Beacon or go with another program entirely. My kids are currently doing well with Typing Instructor Platinum for Kids.

**UPDATE** My original review was four stars, but I'm coming back after a year of use to drop my rating. After one winter (on our covered porch, with the cover on) this fire pit is covered with rust, the bolts are loose, and overall it feels like it might fall apart at any moment. My husband says the metal is inferior quality and far too lightweight. I am not happy with how thing this has held up in the long term at all and for the price, you could probably get something nicer at Home Depot.**ORIGINAL REVIEW***We've wanted an outside fire pit for forever and have been very happy with this one. The instructions were relatively useless (no written directions, just a somewhat vague diagram) but all you need to do is attach the legs, everything else is done for you. My 9-year-old son put it together without the instructions and without my help. The black finish did scrape off fairly easily, though, and after assembly (and before ever having a fire) there were already several places that will need to be touched up with black fireplace paint at some point. Not a deal breaker, but if you are a perfectionist it might bug you.I love the design. It's large enough to accommodate several logs and the see-through design on the sides allows you to both see and feel the fire from all sides.Love the ridges on the bottom that allow for air flow under the logs and help it get going even faster. My only main complaints (aside from the paint chipping) is that the cover is either the wrong size or just chintzy, because we ripped it the very first time we tried to put it on. It also felt lighter weight than I would have expected from the picture. The lid is very lightweight and can be a little difficult to get positioned just right, which can be a pain when a fire is going. But overall I'm pleased with the function of this fire pit and I love the way it looks.

The synopsis of The Venetian Bargain had me at hello. I love historical fiction, when it's done well, and I was really hoping this would sweep me away to another time and place and shed more light on what it was like during this period in history. Where I think this novel shines is in the research the author clearly did into the medical practices of the time. She brought it to life and whenever there was a medical procedure or a treatment being discussed, I was glued to the page. I loved seeing the superstitious nature of the Venetian doctors (wearing those hideous and frightening bird masks) and treating their patients by tying a dead frog around the neck or selling placebo oils at exorbitant prices. I also liked the main character of Feyra and found her journey as a stowaway aboard a plague ship from Constantinople fairly riveting.Yet this book still fell a little flat for me. I thought the plague plot itself could have stood on its own, but things became muddled with too much backstory, too much unbelievable intrigue, and it didn't flow well enough for me. I was over halfway through the book before I felt like I was starting to see where it was going, and I was never so interested that I couldn't put it down and walk away to do other things.This is a nice book. A decent book. But is it epic or remarkable? I don't really think so. And just for frame of reference, when I compare it to books that WERE epic and remarkable, I'm thinking of The Pillars of the Earth, which is both a heartwrenching love story as well as an amazing look at what really goes into the building of a cathedral. I'm also thinking of Forever Amber (Rediscovered Classics), which is set during the Black Plague as well and did an AMAZING job of showing how truly horrific the plague was. When compared with those two books, The Venetian Bargain seems watered down and pale in comparison.

I am so in love with this tea pot. I got the red color and wanted to note that in the amazon picture (at least on my computer) it seems like it will be a bright, almost hot pink, shade of red, but in reality it's GORGEOUS. It is candy apple red, bright without being obnoxious, and offers a lovely pop of color in my gray-blue kitchen.As far as tea brewing, I couldn't be happier. It's beautifully designed: specifically, the pour spout never drips after pouring, is wide enough to facilitate easy cleaning, and I have no trouble getting every last drop of tea out of the pot. The stainless steel filter basket clips into place and reaches all the way to the bottom of the pot, so whether you are brewing one cup or four, you will have no trouble covering the leaves with water. I also love that the filter is incredibly fine-- there will be no loose tea floating in your tea, even if your leaves are very small.I'm still tinkering to find the perfect ratio of tea to water, but I've been pretty successful with 1 tsp of tea leaves for 6 oz of water. I poured some pre-measured water in before brewing tea the first time to see where the waterline would be for two cups vs three cups, and that has allowed me to make a pretty consistent pot of tea.All in all, I'm super happy with this tea pot. It's pretty enough to sit on my kitchen windowsill as decor when I'm not using it, and I would buy it as a gift for any tea drinker.

If you're reading reviews for Landline, you're either killing time till the book is released or you've never read a Rainbow Rowell book. How do I know? Because once you've read a Rainbow Rowell book you stop looking at the synopses and reviews (which never do much for me anyway) and just click the "buy it now" button. She has some sort of magic that makes her characters come to life and she writes dialogue that is so authentic and entertaining you don't want them to stop talking. I *love* the way that Rainbow writes, and I don't think that my opinion on this book one way or the other will talk a true Rowell fan out of reading it.With that being said, however, I will tell you that this is my least favorite book I've read from this author. Fangirl is still far and away my favorite, followed by Attachments, and then Landline (still have to read Eleanor & Park, but I'm saving it for when I need a guaranteed good book). If you're new to Rowell's work, start with Fangirl. If you're all caught up on her stuff, then yes, definitely give this one a go because I think it will resonate on different frequencies for each person that reads it depending upon their frame of reference.The synopsis pretty neatly encapsulates what this book is about so I'm not going to rehash it, but here's what worked for me: she made me fall in love with and root for a couple that I was introduced to fourteen years into their marriage. That is actually hard to do, because honestly, old married couples can be boring. I most enjoy reading about the journey of falling in love, so my expectations were low for the romance in this book, but I never should have doubted Rainbow Rowell's ability to draw me in. She did an amazing job of weaving together past and present so that I DID get to see Georgie and Neal's relationship from the beginning, how they fell in love, the struggles they had gone through, and by the end I was absolutely rooting for them to stay together. I saw in some other reviews that people felt the ending was left too "open," but I didn't find that to be true for me. I liked how it ended and felt satisfied with where it went.But since I only gave it three stars, obviously there were things that brought down my rating as well. I don't mind magical realism in stories, but the "magic phone" in this book felt a little clunky in how it was handled. It was an interesting way to remind Georgie about her love for her husband and the beginnings of their relationship, but in the end I can't help wondering if the author could have accomplished this without the magic phone and maybe avoided some of the loose threads it left in my mind. The plot itself was a little slow and I found it easy to put down and walk away from for a few days, but I also had no trouble slipping back into the story when I picked it back up.Overall, I liked the book. I didn't love it, but here's the funny thing about Rainbow Rowell: I've read three of her books, and only one has gotten over three stars from me. Yet I still have her listed as one of my most favorite authors. I can only attribute this to the fact that even when I don't really care for the plot of her books, her writing is always peppered with moments of brilliance and characters that shine so brightly they blind me to any flaws. I will continue to read whatever she puts out next, and I think you should too.
