The quality is fantastic (grain free, real meat, no rice and soy additives) and I feel confident this is keeping him healthy, lean and nutritious. He always cleans his bowl when I put this food out for him, he usually leaves half of his "other" wet food meals behind.  Will definitely order again!

I tried two different sizes of these before ultimately returning them all and looking for an alternative shoe/brand. I typically wear size 7 Saucony running shoes and have been very happy with them. I've bought dozens of pairs over the years without issue, but sometimes I want to try something new and (gasp) try new colors.  These Mizunos stood out to me because of their minimalist-trail style (I do a lot of off pavement running) and the funky color scheme.  The shoes themselves are extremely high quality and well constructed.  But, they wear very awkwardly on my feet.  The laces and tongue strap and contrict the top of my foot very tightly.  Even after loosening the laces to the point where they were too short to tie, the top of my foot was pushing up against the top of the shoe very uncomfortably.  Furthermore, the soles are extremely flat and provide zero arch support. I suppose if you have a very slight/thin bone structure these shoes would work nicely.  But, if you have average/round/full feet these shoes probably won't suit your feet.

Dr. McCarthy's memoir is tremendously well written and absolutely riveting.  I have read at least a dozen medical memoirs, however, this one certainly tops the list.  I especially appreciated Dr. McCarthy's talent in personifying the fear, uncertainty and emotional toll of starting out as a doctor.  This is a great read and, again, extremely well written!

I have been wearing Saucony Excursions since 2009. I grab a new pair every year and the version 8's are better than any of the predecessors! These are extremely durable and very comfortable trail runners with a great color scheme.  You absolutely cannot go wrong, for the price.  These far surpass any Asics or Adidas in terms of performance and quality. I have worn mine for 15 mile, all day walks through Manhattan, at the beach, around the lake, in the woods and in my chemistry lab.

I have a mouse drawer in my desk like most people have a cable drawer.  Gamers know what I'm talking about-- the "one mouse to rule them all' is elusive if not impossible to create or find. Logitech comes pretty darn close.  I play almost all games, but the following more often than others:- Starcraft 2- World of Warcraft- 3rd Person RPG (Pillars of Eternity, Baldurs Gate, etc...)- FPS (Call of Duty, Battlefield)I also do a significant amount of productivity app work during my day job (Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign, Audacity, general interneting...) and prefer not to change out my gaming mouse if need be.Since last year, I have been using the Logitech Proteus Core with custom weights as my de facto standard mouse.  It's a beautifully engineered mouse and has fit the bill for all of my ranging uses thus far.  I have a fingertip/claw grip and very small hands.  The Proteus is built for people like me.When I first encountered the Daedalus, I was intrigued.  It's a completely different mouse to be sure-- its lightweight, minimalist in terms of exterior features and was unlikely to displace the Proteus on my desk.  However, I must say it is an astoundingly comfortable and precise mouse with (finally) the perfect lightweight mouse "feel".  Logitech got the materials/construction JUST RIGHT.  It's low profile on my desk and has a delightful, tactile left and right click.  The programmable thumb buttons are in the perfect, natural position where my thumb knuckle lines up with the side of the mouse. As I said, the mouse is lightweight but doesn't feel hollow or insubstantial in my hand or as it glides across the tracking surface.  All along, that has been my pet peeve with lightweight mice which has led me to always gravitate towards the custom weighted mice.As a further test of character, I Photoshopped for several days with the Daedalus on my iMac which has been an equally delightful experience.  I have programmed custom keystrokes for productivity work on my Mac and now plan to send one of these to my father where he does ProTools audio work in his home studio.Logitech continues to up the bar for themselves and, in my opinion, nothing from Razer or SteelSeries comes close in terms of tracking performance, software/firmware ease of use/compatibility and customization.Give the Daedalus a go, you'll be a happy gamer.

Let me start by saying that, Yes, sometimes you *can* judge a book by its cover.  I was prowling around B&N one lonely night and happened across “The Truth Commission.” The clever cover art led me to pick up the book and fan through the pages like a flipbook and I was surprised to find doodles and footnotes (of all things!) charmingly peppered throughout the text.  I knew right away this would be a fun read.It turns out, the whimsical typeset delivered on its promise—‘Truth’ is not just a fun read, it’s a fantastic read! I absolutely loved the protagonist Normandy, whose depth is revealed in little, bite size pieces over the length of the novel.  The ironic real-life-but-totally-fantasy world is at once a hysterical Wonderland and a plausible setting.  I think that fans of Rainbow Rowells’ “Fangirl” will enjoy the layering of the story within a story within a story.Juby breaks all YA conventions here and does a great job doing it. The real, print version of the book is an extra treat with the aforementioned footnotes and doodles taking the form of handwriting/comic sketches.  The eBook version (Kindle and iBook), while more convenient, suffer a bit in translation (all of the footnotes have to be tapped deliberately, where they are housed on a separate page from the text).  However, the doodles remain intact within the text.  The audio book I have not yet listened to, but I encourage readers to at least take a gander at the real book ;-)I’m surprised that I’m the second review here, so all the more reason to shout “5 STARS!” if you’re looking for a really good book with a quirky setting and an irresistible hook, you've found it!

As other reviewers have mentioned, Purina seems to have placed their "Pro Plan" label on anything that it would stick to.  I was very disappointed to read the ingredients list in this particular dry food:Trout, brewer's rice, chicken meal, pea protein, soy protein isolate, dried egg product, animal fat preserved with mixed tocopherols (form of Vitamin E), soy protein concentrate, sodium caseinate....First and foremost, "Brewer's Rice" is a byproduct of rice processing.  This stuff is nutritionally lacking in any substantial quality.  It's the stuff that got rejected from its first and second pass down the assembly line (not good enough for packaged rice OR for making rice flour!).  The next few ingredients, particularly: pea protein, soy protein, animal fat, soy protein (again), and sodium caseinate leave me concerned.  I don't eat ANY of these processed foods, so why should my cat?In my opinion, Purina has "fudged the numbers" to get their protein count up to 45%.... Rice and Soy make up the substantial portion of this percentage, neither of which is an ideal source of nutrients for a feline.  Additionally, the fiber percentage (2%) seems extremely low compared to other high quality foods.For a 5-9lb cat, Purina suggests a feeding amount of 41-66 grams of dry food per serving. For a 66 gram serving this would be:118 calories from proteins80 calories from fats80 calories from carbohydrates~ 278 calories per servingTo me, this seems like a lot.  You would really need to take care to control your cat's portions (particularly for more sedentary, indoor cats)All in all, there are better foods out there.  If it's on sale and/or your cat is underweight, perhaps its not a bad choice overall. But for folks who are looking for a superior, healthy choice for their feline, I'd skip this one.Purina is usually so reliable too...

I love these yoga towels for my travel workouts.  They are plush, large and can be used for stretching in your hotel, hotel gym, or for laying out at the pool or spa.  I use the smaller towel for staying dry during my workout and the larger towel as a "mat".  Unlike most microfiber towels, these are not scratchy but rather more plush like a downy terry cloth.  They wash and dry in my home laundry perfectly and don't seem to shrink, pill or generate excessive lints.  I am extremely happy with these and will probably get them for my colleagues as Christmas presents. Highly recommended!

Great little portable drive.  Does not require an external power source, fits perfectly in my backpack and takes up no more space than my iPhone.  I have purchased several Seagate drives over the past few years and they seem to be robust and hold up well with nonstop travel.  I use this drive on both my Windows 7 64-Bit PCs and my Mac OSX Yosemite computers.  Data transfer is fast and reliable.  Highly recommended.

This is FANTASTIC seasoning salt.  I have been putting it on chicken, scrambled eggs, salad, french fries, popcorn, anything I would put normal salt on.  It has a nice kick with a touch of smoke flavor.  If you like spicy with good flavor, this is a great choice!  So glad I found this on Amazon, would have never noticed it at the store!

I typically don't like to print my business cards at home because they look... well... "obviously homemade."  However, the business card size is very useful for many other things.  In particular, I used these to create organic chemistry reaction flash cards as a study tool.  They are extremely versatile, nice and thick card stock and easy to use with any word processing software (whether you use MS Office for Mac or PC or an open office suite).

Great dry erase markers.  No bad smell, the fine tip stays firm with extended use and the colors and bold and long lasting.  I carry several of these with me into various scientific labs where I do short seminars, workshops and training sessions.  They always come in handy and take up no more space than a normal sized pen in my brief case. Highly recommended!

An absolutely magical book! "Nightbird" is geared towards middle school readers (age 8 - 12) and would likely not get the same vote of enthusiasm from young adults looking for sophisticated paranormal romance and that sort of thing.  This story both simple and elegant in its simplicity.  It reminds of the fairy tales of yesteryear. I was absolutely enchanted by Twig and highly, highly recommend this for your younger readers who like a little fantasy, mystery and imagination.

I just received my Speck case today and was instantly impressed.  I appreciate when a company clearly puts effort into designing something as seemingly mundane as an iPhone case.  Let's face it, more than any other companion in life, our iPhone (and its case) has to deal with all our drama.  It's a big demand to put on a little mold of plastic.I have every confidence in my Speck case however.  It's got quite a resume: 2x military-grade protection, three layers of crash protection squeezed into an impressive 0.18" rubber liner.  The Otter-box-esque rubber bumper keeps your corners and screen safe from those impressively well timed vertical drops onto the pavement that would otherwise shatter your world. And, in the event you find some feat of strength the case itself (not your phone, mind you) can't handle, Speck has doled out a generous lifetime warranty on the case.The colors are pretty darn cool. Teal and orange, I can rock it! It's slim, lightweight, adds no bulk to your modern art (aka-- the iPhone 6) and doesn't obstruct any ports (headphones, lighting adapter, speakers, mic and cameras are all given ample room to do their thing).

Very nice for adding extra shine and moisture to your hair.  As others have mentioned, it does leave your hair a little heavy-- so it wouldn't be a good "everyday use" treatment, but definitely good to use once a week or so. Very nice scent as well!

This shampoo has a very nice, unique scent.  It's light and fruity without smelling overly sweet or cheap.  I have very long, thick textured hair that requires shampooing every day if I want to style it.  This shampoo left it extremely shiny after blow dry and flat iron.  It seems to provide plenty of moisture and softness as well.  Very pleased, will definitely buy more!

This was certainly not what I thought it would be. I did not even finish the book. It was on my Kindle and I read about 65% of it and had enough. When reading the preview of the book I thought Gabriel was going to be a hired killer, after leaving the CIA, that took care of people who where doing good people bad. But Gabriel just is ready to kill everybody and anybody.  For example, three FBI agents that are protecting a person he has a hit on. He shoots them from a half mile away. I would say a great part of what he does is not even possible. He was not a person that protected good people, he just killed who ever got in his way, good or bad. Way to much for me. I hope Mr. Evans does well with his writings but I won't be there. If you like a Superman who can do anything and kill anybody then this is the book for you.

I have read all these books in order. They are basically the same. Different towns, different crimes, different crooks, mostly same Marshall's assigned to different places. That is not to say I won't read the next one. These are something that reads quickly and does not take a lot of thought. They really help to pass the time. Hunt was in the first story in the book after that he was in the background assigning the others where to go. They may have picked up a new Deputy Marshall, will find out in the next book. All the Marshall's are smart, quick with a gun, know the right thing to do and say. If you enjoy an easy read about the old west, some intelligent decisions and some gun play you will like each one of this series.

Another great John Milton read. I don't have the ability to describe just how good this book is. If I did I guess I would be an author instead of a reader. Mark Dawson has the ability to make you feel like you are where the characters are, that you are on the page with them and share their thoughts and actions. John is again on the run. This time he ends up going to several different countries, will he survive? For once the man who is trying to kill him is a stronger, better fighter than John.If you like a book you won't want to put down and will be sorry when it is over you will enjoy this one. I have read all 7 of the series and I think each one is better than the last. Action, twist, turns, mystery, this one has it all. Thanks Mark Dawson. Hurry and start on Book 8.

This is my first Lauren Carr read. I like the Mac Faraday character, Archie and David. But I suppose my favorite in the book is the dog, Gnarly.  Many have written several lines telling what the book is about so I won't go there. It is a good mystery. Good police work from a man, Faraday, who is no longer a policeman. There are many twist and turns and surprises. I gave it a three star because I really had trouble keeping up with all the people involved. There were so many. My small brain could not remember who was who or why they where mentioned again. Lordy I don't think I ever saw that many people in a book before. I would hope as Faraday gets settled down in his new place the number of people will drop. I will try one more but if this many different ones in it I doubt I will keep on.

This ended up being a very good read. I nearly put the book down after reading a while because it went on for several pages just running the roads looking for somebody. I am glad I did not. When it did get into the action part it really turned loose. Frank Shaw was a good character, true to life, made mistakes, but kept prodding along until he accomplished his goal. I thought Sam Cartwright and his Morman buddies were great. Sam was unreal that he would go to that much trouble for someone he barely knew. The lack of bad language was good. If you like a book with a lot of action, kept wondering how it was going to turn out you will like this one.

I think this is the best effort by Mr. Atkins on the Spencer books. This one has more of the old wise cracking, smart talk Spencer is famous for. He again is tough, although he is still having trouble with his knee. Hawk is in this one as his usual self also. He does his thing. This time they are after two Judges that are taking kick backs by sending kids to prison for really doing nothing. It is a good read. You will get into the story, you will feel sorry for the kids and be glad when something finally happens. It is as good as it is going to get by Mr. Atkins, I think.

I did not like this one as well as Field of Fire. I really like the character of Alex Durante. When he gets started on something he will stay with it until the end. He will never quit. He is quite, smart and tough. His girl friend, Alice, is another good one. She will do anything for him even thought he really does not know what to do with her. I gave this a 2 star because of the violence and gore in the book. Ortiz, the person they were after would cut you up in pieces, strangle you or just shoot you for no real reason. Sometimes just because he wanted to. There was way to much savage killing for me to enjoy this one. Am sure a lot of people will and that is fine, but I will take my mysteries with less of that kind of killing.

If you have read any of this series you know by now that most of these tell the same stories several times in the same book and they are the same ones you have read in previous books. In this one Charles visits three different railroad camps and the same story is told at each camp. I almost have it memorized by now. Also the story or how he came to America and was found is told two or three times again. Same story as in previous books. If you can stand the repeats of all the same things in each book and just skim through them some of the rest of the read makes a pretty fair story.  If people were treated like Charles treats people our world would be a better place today. He finally is on a ship to England. I am guessing the same stories will appear in the next book also. But, that is just a guess. If you like reading the same things in each book and many times in the same book then hope on board for England and get book eight. We will see what we will see.

I liked the first five books better. The medicare fraud that started the book got side tracked and we ended up with another drug deal gone bad book. Billy Manchester is always good as the attorney. He and Max make a good pair. Sherry, Max's girlfriend, is still reeling from the loss of a leg in the previous book. She and Max are trying to work things out. It is a good character study on them but does not add a lot to the book, in my humble opinion. I hope Mr. King gets back to writing like the first of the series was in his next book.

I have read all the Joe Gunther series, except number five, this may be the best one yet. It has many twist and turns, I thought I had it figured out and wham, it took off in another direction. Mr. Mayor does an excellent job of keeping your interest. It is great police work. It does not come easy. Lots of questions, lot of people to find and talk to. Just hard working police work.  Willy has a much larger role in this one and that is good. If you like a good mystery, with out a much of gore, sex, and vulgar language then these are the books for you.

I was hopping I had found a new author and a new series but guess what, I did not. I quit reading about 30% into my kindle. There was just to much graphic sexual detail for me. There are other mystery writers that I can read  that do not go there and I will read them. I wish Mr. Markel well and hope he sells many books but I prefer something else.

I really hate to give it any stars. My judgment is cloudy. I think the writing very good. Mr. Panowich makes you feel like you are there, that you are part of what is going on. But I quit the read at 25% through, according to my kindle, because of the violence. I made it pretty good up to that point but I quit when and old man was beaten with an axe handle, hit in the face and head and his fingers and hands broken all for no reason. All the while the man's wife and son were pleading for the beating to stop. The son of the person doing the beating finally got it stopped or the old man would have been killed. The son of the person doing the beating even say there was no reason for it. I am guessing there was much more violence in the book, there was some earlier but not that bad. I hope the author makes a mint, I really do, and I hope many people give it 4 and 5 start ratings if this is what they enjoy reading but it is just not for me. I am sure I read other things that would not be for them. I just wish I had not paid for the book but you live and learn.

l keep on reading the Hunt series because it is good western read. They are really stories in a story. Different Marshall's are sent out to capture and bring in criminals.  The book then breaks down into the ones going out and the method they use to bring back the ones they were sent after. It all makes for an easy read and a quick read. I like all the characters and have begun to feel like I know each one. Hunt is a good leader and has good people working for him. I would read them in order if I was going to spend any time with this series.

Have read all the other Sean Drummond books and was so looking forward to this one. Boy, was I disappointed. I was disappointed in the book and if this is out the people in our government act I am disappointed in them. Nobody wins in this book. Yes, Sean does solve every thing as he normally does but he gives up his principals to do so. He will always know he did not do what was right. As far as language there is the most vulgar sexual language in this book than I have probably every read. I usually quit if I start reading something like this but  I kept thinking this could not be in a Sean Drummond book. But it was. The read is depressing and I felt worse when i finished that when I started. I would hope Mr. Haig goes back to the old Sean Drummond and does not let him end on this book.

Alex us certainly a different character. He works for ATF but still lives in a garage next to his Mother and Father. Still eats there every chance he gets. Still talks about his cases with his Father. I liked the beginning of the book, did not like the middle  and then liked the ending. So I put a star in the middle. Alex is good with his fist and feet as you will read and see. If he gets something on his mind he stays with it until the end. He is no ladies man. Does not even know what to say to them but they seem to throw themselves at him. There is lots of murders in this one. Using several different methods. Alex does stay with it and has a pretty good ending. If not getting it on Kindle Unlimited I would not get it.

The Storm Warrior books are becoming a lot of repeat of previous books and even the same thing is said in this one more than once. If I did not get them through Kindle Unlimited I would not buy them. You have to learn to skim over pages several times as what you are reading has already been somewhere else. Part of the books are good and does show the very human side of Storm Warrior or Charles as he has become known. He should soon be leaving the West, I don't know how it will still be called a Western read at that time. If you don't mind skipping pages and over looking typing errors it makes a fair read.

This was my first Tim Baker book and I really liked a big part of it. It held my attention from the start and had many, many twist and turns. I kept thinking it would soon be over and it would take off in a new direction. I did not like part of the ending. I liked what happened to Santoro but I don't think it was right with Val. There are some things that you can justify and some you can not. I won't go into detail as it seems others are ok with this and that is fine. I had hoped when I started that this would become a series but now I do not. I may try another of Mr. Baker's books to see how they turn out because except for that one thing it was a very good read.

This is the third Tasker  book I have read and the first one to give a 5 to. I think this is the best one of the three. I had this is the end of the series.  There are several write up of details of the book so I won't go there. Bill get involved in  a lot of different things. The case he is supposed to be working on an anything else that happens. He just won't let go. There are many, many twist and turn in this book, it will keep you guessing till the end and at end you are in for another surprise. If you like good detective stories with lots of thought and action you will enjoy this last one about Bill Tasker.

This series started out pretty good but the last two I have read have really all been just several short stories as Marshall's are sent to different places to help with crime in that place. Each group or person sent will fulfill his duties, head back to Denver and we will pick up some body else who will do the same thing. I thought the ending of this dragged so long, I thought it would never end. I like the series better when I was about Hunt. I like some of these other people but it is not about Hunt any more except to assign people to different places. As long as I can get these on kindle unlimited I guess I will continue and have one on hand in case I have nothing else.

I have read every Prey novel that Sanford has written. I have really like the character of Lucus Davenport and all the people that he works with. They usually make an excellent read. The best thing I can think of about this one is it does bring out Letty for a larger part. I wonder if it is leading to a series of her own. The rest of his crew is just barely mentioned and Marie not at all. There is way to much violence in this one for me. The Davenport series usually does not have that much. A lot of it reminds me of a western novel, there are shoot outs, beatings and murders for no reason. Much like a western would be.I don't know if this is the end of Lucus or not but if not I hope it goes back to he one that has been it all the previous books. I never heard of Travelers or Juggalos until now. I hope I don't again.If you are expecting a normal Lucus Davenport book this one is not for you.

Was a very good read. Could it have happened. I really doubt it. But that is why they call it fiction. The book tells of many battles and victories of Storm Warrior and the tribe of Sioux that adopted him. They fight the Pawnee and the Blackfeet and of course always win. Storm Warrior is very well educated and wants to teach the Sioux the way of the white man as the time will come that they will take over their land. Don't really think this is the way it went down but so be it.It is an easy read, does not require much thought and will hold your attention. I did enjoy it and will go on and see what the next adventures will be.

I have read the other John Puller books and really liked them. I was disappointed it this one.  I still really like the character of John and hope that if another is written it gets back to being like the first two. The starting and the ending of this one was great but the middle just seemed to drag to much, to many pages that really did not say anything. I also got really lost and confused with all the intitals that stood for different organizations. These were used quite a bit and I never did really get what they were, such as, STRATCOM, INSCOM, ISR, NSC, DTRA, and START. They kept being thrown in and I had no ideal what they were. They were explained the firt time there were used but after that they were just there. My old head could not retain what they stood for. Go back to John Puller solving the things he usually does.

I agree with a lot of reviewers. the best part of the book is the dog. Of course I am an animal lover so that might make a difference. Gideon does show that he is human, he has many faults and does tell lies to make things work in his favor. There is a lot of that going around. The enlisting of a civilian to help him was way out in left field. Seems like the writer spent several pages of talk bringing the close to a murder just to get it over with. Brought up things that had not been mentioned in the book before. Part of the book was good, part I did not think was so I ended up with the three stars.

I give Archer Mayor credit, there had to be a great deal of study into Asian gangs in our country and in Canada for this book to be written. It was very well put together. The writing was excellent. When things were happening you could almost feel like you were there. On the road, behind a door or in the air you felt like you were part of what was going on.I gave it a three star because of really two things. I thought the length of the book was a little long. I kept thinking it was coming to an end and it would take off on something else. The second and hardest thing for me was the number of people involved. I had a terrible time keeping them straight. A lot of the same people even had two names and you had to try to remember both of them. I really got lost with the names, then there were task forces set up and even more people were brought in and you had to try to keep up with who they were also. My little old brain can only hold so much and it went into overload.I really like Joe Gunther and his staff in Battleboro and know for the series to continue some it will have to go outside that town but please involve fewer people. I sure hope the next book does.

Lei has new ground to cover and a new partner in J-Boy who I really liked. People are missing, pieces of bodies are found, Lei feels like she is being cut out of the case. Her old boy friend Stevens shows up but she already is interested in someone else. Lei is trying to juggle all this at one time.Toby writes so you can, in your mind feel like you are there, you can almost walk a path or see a cave or feel the water. She does a great job with that part. She will give you twist and turns so you will wonder till neat the end who the villein really is. I thought I had it figured out twice but was wrong both times.I gave it a 3 star because I could get by with a lot less of Lei's love life. I ended up scanning the pages that were spent with her thought about should I or shouldn't I . Do I love him or don't love him. Which one do I love,  what should I do, oh, what should I do. I like the mystery part and Lei is a very good Detective but I don't read a mystery novel for romance. I little is fine but not several pages spread through out the book.I hope Toby does well and will probably get the next one to see if it gets any better with the romance part.

I really feel for Beatrix Rose. She has so much she wants to get done. She is gradually taking care of the ones who did she and her family wrong. This book is full of action, gun fights, fist fights, you name it  and  it is in this book. I only gave it a 4 because it got a little to brutal for me on more than one occasion, in fact I nearly stopped reading the book. Also did not like the action that happened a few pages before the ending.I like the character of Rose and what she is trying to accomplish but I feel I will really not like the way the 3rd book ends. I have a feeling it will not have a good ending.If you like a lot of action, gun fights, seeing a soft side to Rose and the steely, cold stare she can give to her enemies you will like this one.

I was undecided about how to rate this one. I nearly gave it a 3 but will give  benefit of doubt and go with a 4. I liked the story and the character except he can do no wrong. Hunt, the hero, knows how to do everything, say all the right things and do all the right things. Never makes a mistake and always has the best advise. That gets a little old. People are just not like that. I think Hunt needs to be more human and not as perfect. However, I am a reader, not a writer and I hope Mr. Cox does well with his series.The book is well written, has a lot of action and is easy to follow Hunt as he goes about his business. It is a good beginning to a series if only he will at least make a wrong decision somewhere. If you like a reaed where the hero does no wrong of any kind you will like this.

As usual, except for Book two, I have enjoyed this series. This one has a big surprise in it. One you will not expect. There are a lot of different things going on at the same time, I was a little lost but Nick brought it all back together at the end. Leopold shows he can do more than just think in this story. He man's up and takes care of business. You will be proud of him. If you like a mystery with twist and turns and things happening you don't expect you will enjoy this one.

I am glad for Ms. Jeppsen that she received so many 4 a 5 star reviews. I hope she does well in the rest of her Deadman Series. I don't plan on being there.The first several pages of this book were some of the sadist I ever remember reading. Everything and anything that could happen bad in this young boys life did so. The writer was good, she made me, at least, feel so sorry for him. Nothing went right.Thirteen years latter he was a Sheriff. He was after the Top Hat gang. Now if you like reading about women, young girls, young boys, teenage boys and even adult men getting raped and then having their throats cut then you will really enjoy this book. Their is a lot of that. I started more than once to quit reading but I keep thinking it would stop, but it kept on.This may have been the way the old west was as several reviewers have said, I have not read any other westerns that pictured it with that much violence and rape of both sexes.I am sorry if what I have written has offended anyone, I am a reader, not a writer and I just know what I like and don't like. This had way to much rape and perverted sex for me.

BAM! Another good one about John Milton. Many have gone into great detail about what the book is about so I won't go there.Mr. Dawson writes so you feel like you are part of the story, when he talks about cleaning a lot or slipping through weeds or just walking down the street of New Orleans you can feel like you are actually there your self. You really get drawn into the scenes and the characters.John is again trying to help the underdog as they try to rebuild houses in New Orleans. He meets problems from people and corporations but it does not matter to him. He can bring them all down, just takes some time to figure out how to do it.If you like a person that is helping those who need help and is wiling to do what ever is necessary to do so you  will like this series. I just wish there were a book 7 ready to order.

Over the years I've had success using Miracle Gro gardening products.  Their Nature's Care Garden Disease Control is a great adddition to their lineup.Nature's Care is intended to prevent and treat powdery mildew, rust, black spot, leaf and fruit spot, downy mildew, fruit rot and late blight.  (It sounds as if they were hanging around in our garden last summer.)  It contains the fungicide/batericide copper soap.Like most fungicides/bactericides it's most effective when used for prevention. Miracle Gro suggests spraying both the top and bottom of leaves two weeks before the disease normally appears.  And then at seven-ten day intervals.  It must be re-applied after rain.  Of course for many of us, it's difficult to know that disaster is going to strike in two weeks.  I check my plants daily and when one is striken, I spray all those I think may be at risk.This 22 fluid ounce bottle treats seven square yards.  Gardeners should protect their hands with disposable gloves when spraying.Nature's Care is OMRI listed for organic use and can be used up to the day of harvest.  And can safely be used on flowers, fruits, and vegetables. But it is toxic to fish and aquatic organisms.So far this season we've been pleased with Nature's Care, but the challenging part of summer gardening is yet to come.  We'll see how it does with our brief pop-up showers that raise the humidity, and are followed by blasts of summer sun.

Mark Pryor's newest Hugo Marston novel is set in Barcelona, where the former FBI profler/current Paris embassy security chief goes in search of the missing daughter of a close friend.Amy, who has told her father that she's pursuing a modeling career in Paris, has actually been stripping in a seedy club.  When she fails to meet 'uncle' Hugo for breakfast, he and his friends Tom and Claudia follow her trail to Barcelona.This is the fifth book in the series and is pretty much on a par with the others.  Hugo, with his Cary Grant looks  and his Texas cowboy boots, is an interesting creation and has more potential than Pryor has yet exhibited.  He manages to be a bit bland rather than exciting.And as in many mysteries, just going with willing suspension of disbelief rather than focusing on details leads to more enjoyment.I like the Marston series and have read all five books.  And in each book I've found the first third to be a bit slow and the last third to be difficult to put down.So keeping all that in mind, what are Pryor's strengths?  His books are readable; the prose and syntax are both easy to read and flow; there's nothing awkward or cumbersome.  The supporting characters are well-drawn.  The settings are interesting and at no time do I get the feeling that I'm reading research; descriptions are well-integrated into the prose.  The plots are interest-worthy and, as mentioned, suspense builds to a dramatic conclusion.I enjoyed "The Reluctant Matador," but it's time for Pryor to up his game.

The Contigo Glacier Stainless Water Bottle keeps 20 ounces of water cold for up to 18 hours.The stainless steel body is BPA free.  The bright blue color is attractive, however, the color coating is light and easily nicked and scratched.When filled with water the 12.8 ounce container weights in at slightly over 2 pounds.  My filled Camelback 20 ounce bottle weighs 1.6 pounds.  So I find the Contigo more suitable for car trips and picnics rather than walking and the gym.The Contigo has a push button lock that helps protect from spillage. Its one-handed operation is convenient, however the resultant snapping sound is a bit disconcerting.  And an inflexible carry loop folds down over the top.  Frankly, I can't envision using the loop, but others might like it.  I prefer the flexible loop on my regular bottle.The body itself has a wide opening and is easy to fill with ice cubes and water.  The drinking spout is far wider than I'm accustomed to, and I've already had a cold bath on a cool morning from the Contigo.  Perhaps I'll learn caution.  Perhaps not.Purchasers are warned that this bottle is not suitable for hot or carbonated beverages.  And lazy folks like me should note that while the lid can go in the dishwasher's top rack, the body should be washed by hand.

Par Avion Ginger Darjeeling Peach Tea provides a quality mild brew.The clean and fresh tea leaves are mixed with generous amounts of ginger, cinnamon, peaches, apricot, and cloves.  And the resulting flavor is a mild spicy peach tea.  The underlying tea notes are not overshadowed by the fruit and spices.The sales notes list the ingredients as "Black tea, honeybush, ginger, cinnamon, peaches, apricot, flavors, cloves."  Then goes on to add this legal disclaimer:Actual product packaging and materials may contain more and different information than what is shown on our website. We recommend that you do not rely solely on the information presented and that you always read labels, warnings, and directions before using or consuming a product.

Several years ago I discovered Eagle Creek Pack-It Garment folders.  And I've been relying on them ever since.The concept is simple:  Carefully follow the folding directions on the packing board, place the board on the top, and close your wrinkle-free clothes inside.In order for the Pack-It to be effective, users must fold the garments as smoothly as possible and not over-pack the case.  This medium size case is suitable for shirts, the larger size would be more effective for jackets and skirts.The medium case will hold 3-4 shirts, no more.  The fewer garments packed in the case, the less the likelihood of wrinkles.By packing our clothes in cases, I can attach a sticky label to a packed case and then only remove the cases I need from a suitcase, leaving the others packed until needed.

Monster Octagon In-Ear Headphones have a lot of offer both exercise enthusiasts and casual users.Earbuds to be effective must be 1) comfortable, 2) sturdy, and, most importantly, 3) provide good sound.1) Comfort - Like most quality earbuds, the Octagon comes with various sized earpads and ear attachment pieces.  They're both comfortable and fit securely and I have no problems wearing them for extended periods.  At 3.5 oz. they're light-weight.2) Durability - They appear well-made and are sweat-resistant, a boon to hard exercisers or those doing outside work.  A small zippered carrying case is included; it has room for an I-Pod and will easily fit in pocket, bag, or purse.3) Sound - The sound is balanced, crisp, and clear with a good solid bass.  They're advertised as 'sound insulating' and after an hour at the gym lifting weights and doing the treadmill, I couldn't really notice much lessening of typical gym noises.  I usually wear  Onkyo In-Ear Headphones and I haven't noticed any difference.  Neither insulates from outside sound as well as promised. But the Monster Octagon does offer slightly better sound quality.Octagon offers an Apple friendly inline remote and microphone.  Since I'm a Samsung Galaxy user, I can't comment on its effectiveness.There's a control button on the cord, but it's placed near the left ear and I can't use it unless I unhook it from my ear; others may do better.I'll be using these at the gym from now on, but I don't expect them to block out the sound of the treadmill or the dreadful gym music.

Scott-Vincent Borba's Anti-Fatigue Skin Care/SPF 29 Mineral Foundation is an interesting innovation.  The packaging, as far as I know, is unique.  And the accompanying 'foundation tool' is the best makeup brush I've ever encountered.  Frankly for the price, they should both be stellar.  And they come close.The compact allows the user to twist, grind, and mix a fresh batch of mineral foundation each time.  The resultant mix (which looks more like a powder than a cream), is both light and moist.  And there's some user control over the shade achieved.It's then applied with the truly luxurious brush.  The texture of the brush is extremely soft and flexible, yet it holds the powdery mix and delivers it exactly as desired.The foundation is light in feel, long wearing, and according to my spouse, brighter than my usual Lancome.  It doesn't do much for my wrinkles and other imperfections, but works well over my usual cover-up.It's first rate and the brush is fantastic; I like both.  It's fun to try and works well.  Potential buyers may want to try an internet price check.

The Omron HJ-327T Alvita Wireless Activity Tracker is Omron's latest entry into the highly competitive fitness tracker sweepstakes.  Omron's is a small, light Bluetooth enabled pedometer that relies on an internet connection and a smartphone app to work.The tiny one-square-inch tracker weighs in at only 45 oz. and can be slipped into a pocket or clipped at the waist.  However, it has to be shaken to be read, then tapped to change the setting from steps to calories burned, aerobic steps, distance or the clock.Anyone comfortable with smartphone use will probably find set up simple; the battery is included and just requires slipping into place.I've used Omron pedometers in the past to track steps and found them simple to use.  But their small size is for me both a pro and a con.  I like slipping it into my pocket, then  worry that I'll send it through the wash.One minor annoyance is that to extend battery life, the tracker face switches off when not being viewed.  To turn it back on, the user must shake it a few times.  That's simple if it's in a pocket, but more difficult if it's clipped on.  An 'on' button would make all this much simpler.The Omron Wireless Activity Tracker is obviously designed with a lower asking price and fewer bells and whistles than many competitors.  Yet it does require smart phone use. It's good at step counting.  I compared it to my Fitbit Charge and Samsung health app.  Wearing all three devices and going for a brief 20 minute walk told me that I'd gone 2106 steps (Fitbit), 2507 steps (Omron), and 2545 steps (Samsung). In reality, of course, the Samsung phone is far too large for me to slip into a pocket and ignore; plus I often don't have a pocket.  The Fitbit is on a bracelet and measures arm movement rather than actual steps. The Omron is much more efficient than the Fitbit at counting the steps I take in Target while pushing a basket and the steps my son takes while pushing a baby carriage as he jogs.  The Omron does have a niche.  It's probably a better step counter than the Fitbit and is so much smaller than the phone.However, the calorie counting element is dubious.  Any dieter will testify, metabolism rates vary with age, gender, and for all I know time of day.  And as I've learned to my dismay,  muscles adjust for daily activity; the 400 calories I once burned on a 45-minute bike ride are now less no matter what the bike fitness tracker says.  No tracker in my price range is a true calorie burn counter.  They are calorie burn estimators.The Omron is a efficient, basic step counter.  Its app provides access to Omron's Wellness.com site that also has exercise plans and users' stored data.  But an 'on' button to activate the face is sorely missed by this user.

I've been using Eagle Creek Travel aids for years, and, while I find the packing cubes less helpful than their packing boards, I still find them useful.The cubes in this light-weight set are 4" x 8" x 2", 7" x 10" x 2 1/2" and 10"x14" x 3."  Each has a zipper and handle.  I find all the sizes useful for items such as pill containers, pajamas, a spare change of underthings, socks, cords. I find that items such as t-shirts and pajamas pack more efficiently if folded cube size then rolled up. I like that after a long flight I can grab my pajama cube, shower and rest.I travel with my husband and while we each take a suitcase or carry-on, we mix our belongings, so that if one case is lost or delayed, we still have something to fall back on.  The colored cubes make it easy to claim ownership.  We also use them in our carry-ons.  They separate our traveling devices, hairbrushes, etc. from our clothing, and I've never had TSA open a cube and touch the items inside.Budget minded potential buyers may well want to keep in mind that zip or slider top plastic bags can serve the same function and, as an added bonus, are water proof.

I wrote the review below on April 21; today is May 28 and I've come back to say that my soundbar no longer works.  It switches itself off after  about ten minutes of use.  I had it professionally installed and it worked well for a few weeks, so that's probably not the issue.  I visited Polk's website forum and saw that others have reported the same issue with their sound bars.  The Polk expert responds by suggesting that users unplug the sound bar or call CS.  Keeping the sound bar unplugged when not in use seems to be doing the trick at the moment,  but in reality, Polk should either improve their product or provide instructions to avoid this problem with the product.  I can't justify giving more than one star to a product that worked for about thirty days and then quit or one that requires constant unplugging,This is the original review:The Polk Audio Magni-Fi Soundbar with Wireless Active Subwoofer is as sleek and understated as it is effective.  At 38" L, 2" high, and 3" wide, it sits comfortably below our TV screen, but it can also be easily wall mounted.We compared the sound with our Bose Wave, and the Polk was a tad better.  And with three drivers, it has left, right, and center channels.  The center, voice channel, can be turned up for better defined speaking voices or to lessen background sounds.  And the volume, voice, and base can be adjusted separately using the remote or soundbar buttons.Set up is simple and the setup guide is easy to follow.  The package contains the sound bar, subwoofer, 6' analog stereo cable, 6' optical cable, subwoofer power cable, sound bar power cable/power supply, and remote control (battery included).The remote is small and must be aimed directly at the sweet spot on the soundbar (no waving in the direction of the TV for me; I have to get up and move closer to use the tiny remote).Polk has designed and manufactured a first class soundbar.  Unfortunately they failed to include an adequate instruction manual.  I've had to spend more time than I like at their website learning how to use the system.  So I've downgraded a five star product to four stars.Here is a bit of what you may already know and I've recently learned:  The LED's behind the speaker grill flash and change color but no explanation for the changes is offered.At the website I learned that the orange light indicates optical audio; two orange indicates aux audio; green is Dolby digital; blue is bluetooth audio, and red is off.The TV remote is easy to sync to the soundbar.  Until the TV remote is synced using it will turn off the soundbar. (At least it did at our house.) And once the TV remote was paired, I could stay in my chair and wave in at the soundbar to adjust sound.I synced one Kindle to the soundbar, but when I tried to add a second Kindle I couldn't.  I kept getting messages that the PIN was incorrect.  A call to customer service at 1-800-377-7655 got the quick answer I needed.All of my minor annoyance problems could have been easily covered in a good user's manual.  Polk,  surely it's not too late to add one.

Miracle-Gro Quick Start Transplanting Solution lives up to its name.  It's easy to apply and gives transplants a better chance at survival.My screen name tells it all.  I'm a lazy gardener.  And even I find this transplanting solution worth the added effort.It can easily be used with a conventional watering can:  just attach  the included spoon to the bottle, fill to the line, and add the liquid to a 2-gallon bucket or can.  Add water and pour at the base of your plants.  One gallon feeds about 10 sq. ft. or one bottle covers 400 sq. ft.  Apply at planting and then again a week later.  For larger areas, it can also be used with a sprayer.The 4-8-4 fertilizer boost it contains helps stimulate root growth and promote flowering, so it increases the plant's chance of survival.Frankly, once I've gone to the trouble to visit the nursery, select plants, bring them home, dig those holes, and plant them - I want them to survive!I think of it as a small insurance policy.  And speaking of that. Miracle-Gro says they will refund the purchase if it doesn't work.  Just send them your proof of purchase.  I haven't had to resort to that yet.

Here's a quick look at the pros and cons:Pros:1) The assembly was quick with clear directions for use.2) It weighs 12.6 pounds plus one tank of water.  That's light for a floor cleaner.3) It's cordless, therefore much easier to use.  (This comes with a downside to be discussed later.)4) It does a good job of keeping the clean and dirty water separate with a two tank system.5) There are three modes: wash, dry, scrub.  And switching from wash to dry is simple - it washes as you move forward, dries as it moves back.Cons:1) The PR blurb promises 'fade-free power for the entire life of the battery.'  I discovered that as the battery lost charge, the drying action diminished.By the time I got down to two cells, it was no longer picking up water.2) I couldn't get all my cleaning done on one charge.  We have a small kitchen/breakfast room and one tiny bath and one larger one.  I got about 25 minutes charge (and keep in mind that for half of that my drying action wasn't working).  A new charge takes over an hour; at that point the water is cold and the tanks have to be emptied.3) The cleaner is added by manual action as you move the cleaner forward.  I'm a klutz.  I kept squirting on the backstroke.  For me, there's a learning curve.4) Cleaning out the dirty water tank is much less than pleasant than emptying a mop bucket (which is not on my list of fun chores either).5) I found it clunky to maneuver.  Cordless is great, but it doesn't get under furniture or against the baseboards.Frankly for the price, it should be a bit better.

Ortho Bug-Getaa Snail and Slug Killer, despite its too cute name, is an effective deterrent to slug and snail pests.  (And if there's any garden pest that I loathe, it's slugs.  If you're reading this you probably already know what it feels like to step barefoot on a slug on a cool summer morning.  It's a mood spoiler.)Our combination of hostas, mulch, shade, and moisture seems to be an ideal slug habitat.  And since we feed the birds and have no animus against the chipmunks and rabbits who wander by, we can only use wildlife and pet safe products.Bug-Geta is composed of sulfur with slug and snail bait additives and degrades over time.  The sulfur actually turns into sulfate, which is already present in the soil.  It's no threat to bees and the run off is safe for fish.A light scattering of the small granules is effective for several weeks even after rain or sprinkling. Since the package says 'effective UP TO 3 weeks,' I assume that means 2+ weeks.It's safe for vegetables, berries, fruit trees, citrus, ornamentals, shrubs, flowers, trees, lawns, gardens, and in greenhouses.The single hazard listed is eye irritation.

The Cosco Avery Line 4-Drawer Classic Kids chest looks like a piece of classic wood furniture in the picture.It acually looks far better than our attempt.  Our version, made from the kit, has a few flaws.1) The feet are indeed wood, but the rest of the chest is particle board.  And according to the USDA, particle board is manufactured as panels from dry wood particles that have been sprayed or dusted (speckled) with a binder resin, and are bonded together with pressure and heat.  Particle board varies in quality and the added coating is key to a 'real' wood look.2) The Avery chest has a very thin coat of veneer.  It came complete with scratches even before we began assembly and managed to add a few scratches of our own.  The veneer is thin enough that a close look shows the particleboard underneath.3) Assembly took more patience that I sometimes displayed (sorry!), but luckily my husband is a veteran of the furniture assemble wars.  (He's done bookcases, consoles, tables, shelves, planters....)  But this was the most difficult job so far.  The screws and particleboard are both soft and really easy to strip. The pieces are heavy and it often required two of us to hold the pieces together and screw them together.4) Our drawers don't always stay on the gliders.  Perhaps we did something wrong?5)  And, and for me this is the clincher, once assembled, the chest manages to be both heavy yet not sturdy.I understand that particleboard and wood are not in the same price point and that many people need an inexpensive chest.  But unfortunately this one comes with numerous drawbacks.

In January, 2009, I purchased a Philips Sonicare Essence electric toothbrush from Amazon.  And although Philips has moved on to other models, my original Sonicare is still going strong.  I expect the new Philips Sonicare Flexcare Plus to live up to this standard.The Flexicare has five brushing modes:  clean, gumcare, refresh, sensitive, and massage.  I asked my dentist and his hygenist if the massage mode was safe to use and got a resounding 'yes!'  In fact, this is the same electric toothbrush that the hygenist recently purchased.She suggested that if the new bristles seem a bit too firm, that running warm water over them for a few minutes while they're new would help.I prefer the slim handle that this model has (my old one was  bit clunky).  And I like the interval timer.  To be honest, it's the only way that I brush for a full two minutes.  And the interval beeps do help me give each section its due.  My dentist commented that some of his more zealous patients tend to overbrush (so not my problem!) and that the shut off after two minutes is a worthwhile precaution.Philips says that the battery lasts three weeks between charges and they include a plastic travel case for the brush heads.And speaking of brush heads, they do need to be replaced after three months of regular use.My check ups truly have improved since I've been using a Philips Sonicare and my teeth really do look whiter and feel smoother.

'OS X Yosemite: The Missing Manual' lives up to its title - it truly is the manual that should have been included with the initial purchase.And like a true user manual, it's not meant to be read cover to cover; it gets a new user started, then acts as a reference book with an efficient index.As a first time Mac user, I did read parts one and two in detail.  Part One explains the OS X Desktop in detail, and Part Two, programs such as email, browsers, word processors, etc.) are explained.  I was also greatly aided in my switch by the appendix section on transitioning from Windows.Part Three explains the components - system preferences and programs.  Four details networking and file sharing, graphics and media.  Five discusses internet features such as email and web browsers, and Six is the appendices.  It contains both a troubleshooting guide and keyboard shortcuts that proved expecially helpful.I'm slowing aborbing information from the manual as I need it (and frankly as slowly as it takes to read, understand, and retain).David Pogue's manual has made my introduction to my airbook and Yosemite much faster and simpler than I'd anticipated.

Lyric Chickadee Wild Bird Mix is a quality blend of shelled and unshelled black oil and striped sunflower seed with shelled peanuts, pecans, and pistachios.  It is composed primarily of unshelled sunflower seeds.We normally use black oil sunflower seed (as suggested by a national university sponsored bird counting program we participate in), so it was with great interest that we tried this far more expensive blend.We saw no difference in feeder activity.  Our feeders are visited throughout the day by mixed winter flocks of chickadees, titmice, cardinals, wrens, and a variety of finches.Our feeder birds have always preferred the black oil sunflower seed to the striped, and this is holding true.So for us, this seed blend costs more than twice what we are accustomed to paying.  (Twenty-five pounds of black oil sunflower seed sells here atAmazon for about $25.)On the other hand, those who live in more wooded areas are far more likely to have visits from nuthatches and woodpeckers who will be quite pleased to see the shelled nuts and seeds.

The Lonely Planet 'Pocket Boston' is a travel guide that seems primarily intended as a 'use as you walk' guide to a few Boston highlights.It's highly portable at 4.2x.4x6" and with map included it weighs a mere 6.05 ounces on my kitchen scale.  So it should easily fit in a purse, pocket, or backpack.It's organized by neighborhoods with eight sections and fifteen neighborhood maps.  Top sights, shopping, entertainment, and restaurant suggestions, transportation tips are included, but are limited by the size and scope of the book.Day Planners also suggest activities for up to four days.All in all, this is a greatly scaled down version of Lonely Planet's Boston travel guide.  And it would be an easily included accessory for those lacking access to a smart phone.  The included detachable map is adequate but it's not the map that I would select (it's so large and general that it covers only the basics). And it's not 'free,' itscost is included in the price of the book.Printed travel guides are facing increasing competition from free access internet sites and e-book versions.  And I'm afraid that this offering does nothing to dispel that.For those who lack a smart phone and want a small travel guide this may well surfice.  For those who wish to plan a trip of more than a day, may I suggest a larger guide or the use of internet sites.

The T.S. Shure Pictorial Map of the United States was a winner with our six-year-old grandson.At 24" high and 35" wide, it's large enough to display and small enough for a bedroom wall.  It's brightly colored, and visually interesting, with cartoons representing state birds, flowers, and sites.  Grommets in each corner and a lightly laminated finish make it easy to hang.  (Though it does benefit from being counter rolled overnight to loosen it up a bit.)Sixty-two removable stickers are included for the child to mark favorite vacation spots, where friends and family live, arrows to indicate places he hopes to travel, and even suitcases to show trips.  As a distant grandmom, I especially like the 'my grandmom live here' sticker, but also appreciate the options offered by the blank circles with '______lives here.'The PR accompanying the item suggests that it is suitable for ages 36 months to 15 years.  However, children in grades K-4 is probably more realistic.  The cartoon images are charming, but I honestly can't see a fifteen year old enjoying them.  And the map lacks the geographical definition use by older children would require.

On first glance, the SABRE Home and Personal Alarm Kit sounds as though it will provide a bit of extra safety.  However, most of the elemets just don't work for me.The Door Stop Alarm can't be used with our doors.  The doors are fitted so tightly into the sill that we can't slide the alarm in.  So potential purchasers may want to try sliding a flat screwdriver under theirs to see if it fits.  And if we could slide it in, the angle to the hardwood floor would be fairly high and woud affect its steadiness.  (This may be a one off problem just for our house.)The Window Alarm comes with batteries installed and on the right window should be easy to install.  I used these in the past in my mother's apartment and she liked them.  However, we have double hung windows and haven't been able to get the connection right. (I had no idea we were buying such a persnickety house.)  There's a 15 mm connection limit (that's about 9/16 of an inch), so again potential purchasers may want to measure first.The Personal Alarm can fit on a key ring or can hold keys on the included ring.  Again, battery included.  Like the other alarms, it sounds at 120 decibels and sounds a lot like a car alarm.  And that may be part of the problem.  I've never seen anyone rush to aid or stop a sounding car alarm.  The small flashlight is easy to use, but the alarm itself requires two handed operation.  It weighs less than an ounce and is 1/2" thick, 2.5" long, and 1.5" wide.  So it should fit easily in the hand or pocket but is a bit large for a key chain addition.

One of the items that we replace yearly in our house is dishtowels.  They get heavy use and all too often fade or wear through with use.  On first use, I really like the Dil Cotton Dishtowels.  It looks like they may last the full year.The size is generous -  20x30 inches.  And since they're preshunk, after washing they retained their full size and color.They're also soft and absorbent.  Company PR credits the 'twisted yarn' and high density weave. I often use terry towels, but I find these equally absorbent and much better on glassware.The stitching appears firm and I'm not anticipating frayed ends, and thanks to that high density weave, I have hopes that they will hold up with use.And I like the bright aqua color.

The time has come for a Bluetooth fob that helps locate lost objects.  But unfortunately the KiiTAG-B was released before the functions were fine tuned.The Bluetooth enabled plastic key is placed on a keyring, in a backpack, or carry-on (the potential is limitless) and communicates through a smart phone app.  So in theory, when I misplace my keys or walk away from my carry-on at the airport, an alarm will sound on my phone and I can use the 'find' page on the app to locate the object.  I'm led to the object through a method similar to playing the 'hot/cold' childhood game.  So if I'm lucky the app leads in the general area of my lost item. (The keys are somewhere in the bureau, the missing wallet is somewhere in this group of strangers, etc.)It's truly an idea whose time has come.  However....The finder key is light-weight but bulky.  If it's on my keyring, I can no longer slip it into the usual compartment of my purse.It's advertised as working up to 200 feet, but I'm actually getting lower numbers.  It's best within a 100 feet.  Both this and the size rule it out as an addition to my dog's collar.  (Dear KiiTAG, I'd love an affordable activated dog collar with a greater range.)I found installing the battery to be far from easy; the cover piece on mine doesn't fit well.  And battery life seems to be much shorter than usual.Now add to that that the alarm doesn't consistently work when the item goes out of range.  The fault may lie with my phone for all that I know, but I do know that it decreases my confidence in the KiiTAG.Three stars - there may be potential buyers who have far more patience than I and are willing to put up with the kinks.  I'll be waiting for the next model.

Fitbit PR says that the Charge will stay attached (if properly joined), but I'm so not a trusting buyer.  So when my daughter and I each bought a Charge about a month ago, I bought a Bilbelt for my Charge.And good mother that I am, I gave my daughter the spare.We both still have our Charges, but there was That Incident where one of us spent a hour or two at work trying to locate her lost Charge. It was found and now we're both Bitbelted in place.But if potential buyers are wondering if the Bitbelt is easy to use, it's not.  I really find sliding the band through the small clasp to be both awkward and  time  consuming.  So I wear my Charge (with Bitbelt in place) just loose enough to slide over my hand.  When I want to wash my hands, I can then slide it up on my arm.  And since it's not always in the same place on my arm, there's less chance of irritation.

The Villeroy & Boch Shower Towel is not a towel that will see much use in our house.It's really large and heavy.  At 2.4 pounds both my husband and I find it heavy.  He likes the large size (11.8x24x11.8 inches).And although it's absorbent, the short nap makes it far from soft.  That's the deal breaker for us.It is strong thanks to the combed cotton and two ply yarn.  But it's just not the towel for us.However, if potential buyers aren't concerned with softness and are looking for strength and size in a bath sheet that dries well, this one deserves consideration.  And the bright royal blue color was true to the depiction.

Welcome to Anne Tyler's Baltimore.  It's not a land of magic, nor of super people who jet from place to place, nor the dark land of gritty noir fiction.  Tyler's Baltimore is peopled by real folks, average in their accomplishments, unremarkable in their everyday activities.  But through Tyler's lens we come to know them, understand them and their stories, and in so doing we learn a bit about ourselves.The Whitshank family is the centerpiece of "A Spool of Blue Thread."  There's Abby and Red who live in the Whitshank family home, and as the novel opens are facing their final years.  Age brings a gradual decline that threatens them and frightens their adult children.  But change is inevitable.Tyler's view shifts through the various stages of their lives, and the reader comes to know how Abby and Red became the people that they are.  But because this is a novel and not a history, our view is not chronological, but rather is carefully arranged by Tyler, who skillfully exploits our perspective. (Like the man on the flying trapeze, it looks so easy because it's so skillfully done!)Part of the beauty of reading Tyler is that the words seem to flow from her pen effortlessly.  But in reality it's a tightly interwoven plot that introduces the reader to the stories of three generations and the family myths and misunderstandings that have developed over the years.In their way Tyler's novels are gritty and real.  This is real life as lived by real people.  Tyler offers no false promises; all dreams aren't achieved and living brings pain as well as joy.  However, no one stands alone;  her characters are capable of growth and change, and, most of all, no matter where they are, they are a part of the fabric of family.

The Dorman Hardware Peghooks were a welcome addition to our garage pegboard.My husband likes them because 1) they're sturdy, 2) they're made of stainless steel, and 3)  the sizes are convenient for hanging small tools ranging from trowels and screwdrivers to a hammer and drill.I like that they were easy to install and that the twenty-eight pieces offered variety - we have four 4" straight, four 2" single, two 2" double, six 1-1/2" curved, six 1-1/2" angled, and six 1-1/2" side-angled pegs.Our only caution is to check your pegboard - the 1/4" seems to be standard, but do confirm that that's what you have since the fit is perfect.

Our new Black and Decker 12-Cup Thermal coffee maker is a fair mid-priced coffee maker, but it's not the coffee maker of my dreams.  Here's a quick list of the pros and cons from my point of view.Pros:1) It's attractive with a small footprint.  At 12.75 inches tall, it fits under our kitchen cabinets for storage.  The stainless steel and black fits in well in our kitchen.2) It's easy to set up and program.3) The carafe is sturdy, pours well, and is easy to clean.  The carafe and brew basket are both dishwasher safe.4) It can make up to 12 cups, yet it's easy to sneak a cup as needed.5) And it can be programmed for three brew strengths.Cons:1) The brew basket works best with a paper filter.2) The time display lacks a backlight and is difficult for my tall husband to see.3) There's no battery backup for the programming, so when the lights blink, the program is lost.4) Steam escapes from the back of the unit when the end of the cycle is reached.5) A brewing of 12 cups of coffee set at 'Strong' requires 25 minutes.6) And most importantly for us, the brew temperature isn't as high as we'd like.  The National Coffee Association suggests a brewing temperture of 195-205 F; the B&D coffee maker doesn't seem to reach that temperature.  After it's brewed, our coffee about 180 F.  (I do understand that hitting the grounds cools the water a bit.)May I suggest that potential purchasers read a few of the one star reviews.  It seems that initially a few of the units had issues.  The warranty by Black and Decker and Amazon's return policy seem to have functioned well, but buyers should be aware.

Edie Cat likes the Sheba Perfect Portions Salmon Pate.  I assume that she likes the taste and the texture, but she really hasn't said much other than 'more!'We like that there's no corn, soy or wheat and no artificial flavors or preservatives.  I like the small cans because MsE doesn't really care for fish from the frig.We haven't had problems opening the tubs and Edie seems to like the pate texture.All cat owners know how unpredictable and picky their cat is, but this is working for us.Four stars because it's a bit pricey, but then, MsE is worth every nickel.

The three Dorman Peggable Wire Baskets fit well on our garage pegboard.  They only fit 1/4 and 1/8 inch pegboard, but that seems to be standard sizes; nevertheless, measure your pegboard grid before you order.  They can also stack or stand alone.The rust resistant baskets measure 12x6x4 inches, 8x4x3.5 inches, and 5x3x2.5 inches, with the wire grid ranging from 1.5 inches on the largest baskfet, to 1 inch on the small.They're a welcome addition to our garage; we're currently using them for small tools and cans of spray paint.

The blue 1888 Naked Brand 6 piece bath set is soft and smooth.  And while color preference is personal, I like the light blue.Soft, absorbent towels seem easy to find in department stores, but few seem to hold up after repeated washings.  Most cotton towels now appear thick and lush before that initial washing, then the waste fibers that have been added to thicken the pile turn loose and each time I wash there's less towel.  The 1888 towels are a cotton/modal combination; I did notice fiber loss after the first trips through the washer, but it was not as bad as many 100% Egyptian cotton towels that I've purchased in the past.  Modal is a rayon derived from birch, so it should be safe to use.The towels have proven absorbent, yet the lighter weight (thanks to the modal) shorten dryer time.While these are not the luxury towels of my dreams, they don't come at luxury prices.  They're smooth and soft, and dry well.  The true test of a towel comes with repeated use.  And at this point, I can't speak to that.

My 9-year-old loves LEGOS and built this 819 piece Mega Bloks Terminator Genisys Prisoner transport with little help from us. We love to participate (I'm his piece sorter!), but let him take the lead. The manual is basic and explicit, and easy for a younger kid to understand. If you've got a builder on your hands, you're in luck because this is challenging yet exciting to put together.My son is too young to watch the movie IMHO, but he's still intrigued by anything "Terminator". This toy was right up his alley.

My son who loves Terraria went wild for this set because it's like the video game come to life. However, after a single day, it's like the unplayed elephant in the room.It's got light up torches, although one came broken, and a light up sword with was very cool. I wish it came with more than one figure, and he's a big LEGO fan of minifigs and I think he'd enjoy it more with more than one character.Kids who love imaginary play, or are younger kids will love this set--for about one day. Keep in mind this is NOT Minecraft, they are two different games. This set is really big: 1.5' high and almost 2.5' wide.

I love my Dead Sea Essentials AHAVA Witch Hazel hand cream. I didn't know what the scent would be, but was pleasantly surprised. The fragrance is very light, and smells lightly floral.One reviewer said they couldn't stand the highly perfumed scent on their hands all day. I'm quite sensitive to fragrances, and can't use many products because of the pervasive problem of over-scented products. I'm the person who gets headaches from scents. The Witch Hazel Hand cream is most certainly NOT one of those stinky moisturizers. It's such a light scent, it won't bother you or conflict with other scents.

This is a beautiful watch, in person it's very shiny and looks classy and solidly made. It's larger sized, which I love, and it's got this feminine yet industrial design. You can also set the time quickly--you just pull out the side button and move the hands--super basic, super easy. I really like this watch.My problem is that it's very large on my wrist, the very short manual doesn't describe how to remove watch band links to make it smaller. I went onto their website and when I clicked on "instruction manual", the same exact manual showed up. I wish their website was better. It looks good, just lacks substance. I ended up on Wikihow, under "adjust a watch band".Gorgeous watch, easy to set, just expect a band adjustment period before wearing.

Fun for kids who like to break things, but also enhances building and building design skills. I like that it's an open ended toy that caters to 9 + 10 year olds imaginations.My son and his friend played with this for hours. I think this would be better though with higher quality building materials.

Simple basket weave towels look better in person. They shrink after washing, but color doesn't bleed and they become very absorbent.In person, the red stripe is a classic barn yard red, less orange-red than it looked in the photo.

As a generously busted woman, I've never had an apron actually cover my full chest. I've had lots of pretty ones that leave my clothes vulnerable to oil splatters, but nothing protective.The Now Designs apron is a plain black, thick cotton apron that actually cover the entire expanse that is my buxom breast glory. I love this thing! I am thrilled that I can prepare food without having to change into a slub shirt! Thanks for making a generously sized apron!

This is a nice gel moisturizer for my aging, yet oily skin. It doesn't leave a sheen like other moisturizers which I appreciate, since I make my own sheen fast enough. It absorbs quickly and leaves a slight tackiness which is typical with many gel products I've tried.Overall I'd recommend.

I'm using this Continental Sleep Mattress Cover to protect my (beloved) mattress from bedbugs and water damage while in transit during a long move. It's like a huge zippered condom for your mattress, like a giant zip-lock bag with a zipper closure.It's a bit "crinkly" sounding while on my mattress, so I doubt I'll keep this on outside of moving--and once I'm certain that bed bugs aren't a problem. I'm more sensitive to sensory input than other people, so if you're less bothered, the sound probably won't be an issue for you. It feels fine to lay on because it's not super thick or odd feeling.For $30, I think it's a fair price for protecting a $3K mattress and would recommend to anyone storing their mattress, or moving it in a container.

This dragon is really attractive, one of the better poses I've seen. The body is red and black, and the wings are yellows with black trim. It has less red than I'd originally thought, but it looks really good in person. The dragon's facial expression is fierce!Schleich is THE brand for dragon figurines, they're really well-made and durable, plus artistic. Your dragon lover will enjoy this.

Recommended age is 4-10, but my son who's on the higher end of this range, could care less about assembling Hot Wheel's track. It's been sitting on the floor in a heap for weeks. It was great for the first few hours, but not since. He has zero interest in riding cars on tracks at this point.My recommended age range would be 4-8, not for 9-10 year olds.He used to love this stuff, now it's all about LEGOs and higher level kid play engineering.

This is a lot of fun, and I think my child will get lots of use out of it. Hot Wheels sets can get boring for the older end of the 4-10 age range, but because the involves water, it's great for sensory exploration.This one is a keeper. BTW, hotter water will revive the cars that aren't 'color shifting' anymore.

All three products smell great, not overly scented like other product lines. We all love the body wash, it's got a rich lather, rinses well, and smells lightly fragrant, good for a man, fine for a woman too. The shampoo was a hit with my husband since it's shampoo and conditioner in one. He also likes the deodorant, even though it doesn't go on clear. He's used Dove deodorant a lot before and liked it.This could be a strange 'gift' since it's drugstore products, however, if someone gave me a ladies version, I'd be happy enough.
