Hollie's love of otters hit close to home for me, literally.  I live near Monterey and always find it comforting when I can relate to the character in more ways than one.  Although this story carries fine on it's own you really need to read them in order, the references will make more sense.  This is a couple that has great chemistry and many secondary characters that could easily carry a story for a dozen books.  I hope to read more about the Fieldings.  My copy was given through Netgalley for my honest review.

Enjoyed this short story as part of the Shiver anthology but the second time was better.  College romance set in Salem during Halloween between a skeptic and a loner.  Prescott dazzles us so easily with smart banter and an intriguing storyline.  Hoping for a story on Sam and Tate with more Madison and Andrew.

A truly captivating love triangle, sometimes square, for  this magical Elven story.  Perfect for any age group, a sweet and inspiring young love story.  This series has been exciting to read and must be read from the beginning.  The novella, Sway, is an insight into Vancia's life - a great addition to the series.  The author keeps you on your toes guessing who Ryann chooses and how the "big" plan goes down.  These teenagers are making very adult decisions about the future of their people yet get to behave like the kids they are.  The innocence in their actions mixed with the seriousness of their endeavor makes the story intriguing.  The creativity behind the Light and Dark Elves is beautiful.  Her storyline involves the power of addiction (not drugs), the influence of technology and the magical Saol water.  The theme touches on many current topics and events, while having a little fun with pop culture (a few movie references might make you giggle).  I needed to read a fun and powerful story, this was it.  Thank you Ms. Patrick for sending a review copy my way.
My new favorite love story.  Through trips and falls, and loads of flirting, these two found each other.  Fun, hilarious, sexy, and outdoorsy. The perfect mix.

The first story continues with Willie's Aunt Alana, we met her at a party for her son.  She finds herself after the death of her husband.  The story was relatable and heart warming however it lacked an editor.  Simple mistakes like missing words, extra commas, and wrongly used semi colons.  Sort of throws off the flow.The second story is about Caroline Lang, mother to Nate and Noel from the first two stories.  We get to know her life before William, past relationships and a terrible childhood shaped her into the strong woman she is today.  I really enjoyed learning about this strong yet subdued woman.  We finally get an end to the Jessica saga, however I feel the story was slightly long winded.  After all the years Caroline has known William it was never discussed if he learned to sign, she seems to speak a lot with him and that means tremendous amounts of lip reading.  If he loved her I feel it should have been mentioned whether he made the effort to learn or not.

Out of the park!  Baseball players seem to have a bad reputation, girls in every city and a party hard attitude.  Despite those crazy tabloid rumors there are men that carry a torch for their women and have respectable lives.  Gavin, an injured player traded down to rehab an injury and is dating a beautiful model, fits that typical baseball player stereotype.  But unlike the usual baseball guy he has respect, adoration and is quite charming for his new love.  He realizes the move to Jersey was a good thing and allowed him to see his girlfriend for the fake she is and find out what it feels to love.  Jessica, the physical therapist to the Sonics, has a tough tomboy attitude.  Growing up with 6 brothers all in pro sports hardened her attitude toward other athletes, plus a terrible ex-boyfriend didn't help either.  Jess and Gavin have this electric spark that can't help but ignite.  Their relationship is playful and true but aggressive too.  They seem to fit together naturally and it's really adorable listening to their banter.  This is the third book with the Sonics.  While it's a standalone story it helps to read the others as the characters interact and reappear.  My copy was given through Netgalley for my honest review.

Extremely funny and randomly suspenseful, this is one of my new favorite books.  May Wexler, a freelance photographer, receives a text directing her to a seedy biker bar.  Assuming it is her sister she goes unknowingly getting involved in a situation.  Ozzie comes to the rescue in more ways than one.  From the bar and her boring job, May is saved by this hot military type stud.  You always hear actors say never be in a film with kids or animals and now I understand why.  Felix and Sahara, two of the most opposite of animals, are great comic relief.  May's nieces and nephew are a riot with a fantastic bathroom scene full of innocent mischief.  Ozzie's crew is a great set of people with interesting personalities that keep things hopping.  Thankfully this is the first in a new series and we can enjoy more of this motley crew.  Thank you Netgalley for my review copy.

A powerful and loving series!  Maria and Thom are developing into a full fledged relationship.  Maria is experiencing new feelings and thinking about the future.  Thom is battling his ex-wife, Rachel, while she battles her own demons.  While we don't get answers to Rachel's craziness, yet, I assume she's on drugs or experiencing emotional backlash from her own childhood.  She is definitely off balance and her daughter, Emily, acts much more mature than her mother.  Really enjoyed reading the alternating perspectives from Maria, Thom and Emily.  If all men were like Thom we'd be much happier women.  Thanks to the authors for my review copy.

Johnson's firefighter series was fabulous and I hope this new one can  be just as good.  As a prequel we get a short look at Link's priviledged life and military career.  A rich brat given anything he wants, never held accountable, and the girls love him.  One last straw and the judge gives him choice prison or military.  Lucky for him Link chose the Army.  We get to see him grow up in about eleven chapters.  It's a quick read with an underlying romance, Mattie from high school, and an exciting moment near the end proving Link to be a courageous soldier.  My copy was given for my honest review.

Wonderful book with two novellas about strong women, both physically and mentally.  The first woman is an undercover detective with an edge, one that gets her suspended.  Keeping with the Scottish theme she is cousins to Jenna from Just a Little Kilted and falls for a firefighter/paramedic with Scottish and Italian ancestory.  The second continues the other story from Just a Little Kilted, from Noel's perspective.  We get more background about her and what she and Rick are doing for Nate and Zoe.  It's sort of in tandem with Nate and Zoe's story.

Fantastic conclusion to this exciting series.  This is not a standalone as the story is continuous.  Gage and Beth stumble upon information that changes everything.  The cult and the cave they found gets wrapped up, but the explanation and the reasons for our perps involvement wasn't detailed enough.  The story is quick paced and easily concluded but I was still slightly dissatisfied with some of the details.  My copy was given for my honest review

Superman is weak compared to Slade.  This guy throws himself in harms way any chance he gets.  Trouble magnet for sure and a softy to boot.  Britton, pronounced like Britain, had a twin sister, Perris.  She died and Brit can't get over the guilt she feels so she needs to talk to Perris' boyfriend.  Slade and Britton bond over the long roadtrip to find out some answers.  Slade has deep emotions kept close to his heart and only Brit brings them out.  Made me swoon with his dirty yet sweet talking words.  It wouldn't be a Tess book without steamy-burning-the-sheets sex so you can be rest assured it's HOT.  Two authors with one voice blended really well to make this a fun and exhilarating ride.  Honestly, I ignored the family while I read this one, nobody needed food anyway.  Thank you for my review copy so I could leave a review.

Murder has it out for Gladie.  It just follows her everywhere but she's committed to matchmaking.  The side characters are hysterical and give this town a quirky and loveable vibe.  With one guy temporarily gone you'd think Spencer would step up but Remington and his nerdiness showed up.  What happened to Holden anyway?  This series could go on forever with silly shenanigans and a random murder.

Cannes is a quaint town, but throw Gladie in the mix and you've got trouble.  Another murder, a crazy alien cult and a ridiculous pink tulle bridesmaid dress kept me in happy tears and fits of laughter.  With two men vying for her affection Gladie is one lucky lady.
Quirky, silly, sexy and deadly.  Great story of murder, mystery and a crazy love triangle.  I am pulling for the cop.

My first Sidney Halston book and I choose the fourth one in a series.  Luckily it didn't matter because this was a standalone with a new couple.  Cain is retired military and a professional fighter.  Violet is a nurse, her fiance died in battle and the three of them were best friends.  Talk about an awkward friendship, two guys and girl since they were babes but the guys go off to join the military leaving said girl behind.  Unknowing to the girl both of them loved her, in their own messed up way and never expressed it.  Despite Cain's messed up communication skills he has a deep appreciation and love for Violet.  Her whole life she's battled self esteem issues concerning her weight and Cain makes sure she forgets it all.  Even though he's a fighter the amount of violence and cage fighting scenes were pretty minimal.  If you like the caveman type, you know the kind that grunt and demand, Cain is perfect for you.  This novel had everything from hot sex, sassy comments, humor and suspense.  I loved it all and hope to read JL's story real soon.  My copy was given by the publisher through Netgalley.

Saved by HOT once when her husband led a terrorist cell, Emily is in hot water again.  Bribed with gaining her freedom, being able fly anywhere and change her name, she heads back to the desert to work with Ian Black.  Ryan, aka Flash, doesn't realize the extent of his feelings until they meet again during her mission.  Tempers flare, steamy sex is had and commitments are questioned when a secret gets revealed.  As in the other HOT novels we get a realistic mission with the hottest military team ever and a sassy independent chick thrown in the mix.  Each novel is a standalone with a different couple however the back story is continuous and the teammates reappear.  Highly recommend reading from book one.  My copy was given for my honest review.  Waiting for Colonel Mendez to get a story.......

Given a copy for review I had not read a book from this series before now.  Quick and sexy with a playful energy that claimed a wolf and soldier together.  She is the submissive wolf and he is the Dom soldier and part owner of the club.  Although they visit the BDSM club I didn't feel like their experience was overpowering with that lifestyle.  Tastefully done and exciting to read, ready to read the others.

My mind is going crazy with clues and trying to piece it all together.  The first 40%, or so, we are getting inside the mind of Ashley trying to find her kidnapper/rapist/murderer.  It's a sick and twisted mind ride full of clues.  The rest is Jane and her team solving the most twisted and psychotic case ever imaginable.  Brown does a phenomenal job of inserting clues along the way that only make sense near the end.  The entire time you need to just read and enjoy the way she conducts her investigation and let the story capture you.  Although this is part of a trilogy you could probably dive into this without reading the first but I believe you would be a little lost.  The first book sets the stage and the history of the characters is extremely important in this second book.  I highly recommend reading Blood and Bone and immediately follow with Sin and Swoon.  My copy was given by the publisher through Netgalley for my honest review.  It will be awhile before my mind fully recovers but I am excited for the third and last book.

Finally, we get the date from Unexpected Date.  A lovely, sweet story that gives a look at a beautiful relationship.  A kinship is developing along with mutual understanding, and overprotective moms.  Ending with that perfect kiss.

Years ago, someone gave me the original album of the 78 rpm records. I loved listening to them and regretted no longer having access to the beautiful music when "record players" became obsolete. This CD rendition retains the quality of the original presentation of Andre Kostelanetz's outstanding arrangements of these classics of Jerome Kern. Many remind me of the sweeping orchestral openings of movies of the 30's and 40's and 50's. This album would make a wonderful addition to anyone's collection of nostalgic and excellent music.

If you want an absorbing, coming of age story, told in an alternating stream of consciousness and flashback form, then you will enjoy this debut novel by Jan Ellison.Although the writing is very good in most parts, the pace of the story frustrated me. I actually skimmed the end of the book to relieve the tension and then returned to read the novel in its entirety. I’m not sure I have ever done that before. However, it made the reading of the story far more enjoyable, and I could better appreciate the quality of Ellison’s literary style.Annie Black, the main character, and through whose eyes we view “reality,” spent a year in London as a young unmarried secretary. She fought feelings of attraction to several men through binges with alcohol and more than “small” indiscretions. These events appear as flashbacks, contained within her description of her current life, now full of sadness and anguish. Her decades of a solid marriage, family life and career as a lighting designer all crumble after her son, Robbie, lies in the hospital following a harrowing car accident. Past and present blend as she searches her soul to find the “shadows” that have emerged from childhood, early adulthood and being a wife and mother.Ellison provides a deep, insightful look into the mind of her main character-narrator. She develops her characters well and adds an air of mystery. I found “A Slight Indiscretion” to hold elements of forgiveness and redemption. These attributes carry the novel, and cause me to recommend it, despite frequent agonizingly slow paces.

Take one talented, 19 year old black woman college student; add an international crisis,  world leaders trying to save face, yet prevent nuclear destruction, and you have the makings of an interesting, if not believable, novel of intrigue and suspense. Stephen Carter unfolds a story in Back Channel that makes the reader wonder how much could be veiled accounts of what really happened in October 1962.Margo Jensen demonstrates her excellent mind in her Conflict Theory class at Cornell University. Her professor hand picks her to participate in a special mission that sends her to Bulgaria. Based on her performance there, she suddenly finds herself becoming the “back channel” for unofficial negotiations to parallel the official negotiations during the Cuban Missile Crisis. This leads her into seemingly clandestine meetings with President John Kennedy and puts her life on the line to receive and pass information behind the scenes.Although the book presents a number of involved and dangerous escapades, I found reading it became laborious and drawn out in places. Having lived through this period of history, the plot seems to drag on compared to the real series of events. The author takes time out of the ongoing story to fill in past events, characters and subplots. The interruptions to the twists and turns never seem to end.The book creates a realistic backdrop of Washington, D.C., the White House and  dialogue among key political and military figures. Most of the characters seem realistic enough.It made for an interesting read, but certainly is more fiction than historical.

The Answer to Bad Religion is Not No Religion delivers a great synopsis of the differences between Christian religions that do not practice and those that do embody the teachings of Christianity. The first are toxic religions which breed judgmental and destructive thinking. The second model provides practical, loving ways to live out an authentic faith. He advises not to give up on religion. History has proven one can’t stamp out faith. There is hope.Thielen uses a straight forward manner. He interweaves stories and examples with Biblical quotations to support his ideas. The concepts are easy to grasp and demonstrate the strength of the Gospel through living it in church communities and individual lives. He clearly points out how narrow minded, reactive thinking cripples the true expression of Jesus’ teachings and the guidelines that more mainstream and moderate religions follow..Fundamentalists will probably not buy into Thielen’s theories. Those seeking relief from the legalistic, judgmental religions will find standards by which to determine how other faiths can meet their needs.I highly recommend this book to those “turned off” by religion and by those who want to make their religious congregations even stronger and more vibrant.

Ever had a bad day? Cara Kryzik has a string of them. She awakens to one of a series of crises in Mary Kay Andrews’ latest, “Save the Date”.  A talented, but struggling florist who is trying to make it on her own, Cara meets one challenge after another, some of them comedic, but many of them threatening her livelihood.Will her talents be recognized by the clique of snobbish, aristocratic circles who dominate the southern city where she lives?  Will Cara survive the many crises that continue to pile up despite her sincere efforts to make a success of her business? Will Cara let pride prevent her from being a successful businesswoman and find love?These are some of the questions Andrews creates for the reader. Interesting characters and quick dialogue offset the wordy descriptions that slow down the momentum of the book. The author demonstrates her knowledge of flowers and arrangements with accurate and exact descriptions of Cara’s creations.Humor comes from Cara’s pet dog, Poppy, and Jack Finnerty’s, Shaz. Through a strange mix-up, both owners become acquainted. The friendship is very rocky at first, but builds as the storyline progresses. Cara’s extremely efficient and helpful assistant, Bert, adds color to the novel. He and Cara even wager how long the marriages of their bridal clients will last. They see the brides’ emotions run rampant, mothers of the brides who interfere and make decisions for their daughters, and controlissues that prevail.Lots of characters and subplots weave through the story: uncaring landlords, reactions of Cara’s father (a demanding retired Air Force Colonel), a stolen heirloom Cara used for one of the weddings, Jack’s relationship with a former girlfriend, Cara’s ex-husband, a new competitor florist who tries to sabotage Cara’s successes. Each one creates a crisis that leads to further crises.Although an unnecessarily lengthy novel, I found the book to be an interesting and sometimes quite humorous read.

Dark shadows sweep over normally spunky red-haired Maggie Hope in The Prime Minister’s Secret Agent.  Maggie is now an instructor at the British training center in Arisaig, Scotland.  Her past experiences continue to haunt her and create a “black dog” (as she’s names it). She has become depressed, speaks sharply to the trainees, and searches for stability and direction. Maggie admits she’s become a professional and “no more the plucky ingenue.”  To serve as a “stand alone” read, the author cleverly weaves in prior characters and incidents that have affected the heroine to catch the reader up with the fourth book of the Maggie Hope Mystery series.On orders to take R & R, Maggie goes to Edinburgh to see her friend Sarah, a professional ballerina. This leads Maggie into a baffling murder investigation. Floriography (language of flowers) helps her discover the British secret plan to develop biological weapons to continue their war efforts. As she probes the mysterious deaths and helps her friend recover from being poisoned, her depression begins to fade and she slowly regains her confidence as an agent.Meanwhile, two other subplots emerge:Errors and obstacles in communication lead to the surprise attack on Pearl Harbor. The author’s meticulous research techniques are apparent in the exchanges among the diplomats, Army and Navy officers and staff of the U.S., Japan and Great Britain.Maggie’s mother, Clara Hess, awaits execution in England for being a Nazi spy. A doctor recognizes the possibility Clara may have multiple personalities.Although I enjoyed the book, it didn’t read as evenly as the other three novels. The storyline does pose some questions: How ethical is the use of biological warfare?  How is Maggie affected by allegiances to two countries?  Will she and former boyfriend, Hugh Thompson, reconcile? The book provides a transition for Maggie to de-program from her harrowing stint in Berlin to her next upcoming adventure - to accompany the Prime Minister to the United States. I look forward to the next installment.

.What great memories this CD brings back in the fresh and upbeat style of Ray Conniff.  The re-recording is crisp and clear.  The album features the orchestra with the chorus in the background. They perform without distinct words, just the "Conniff" sound of harmonizing with the various instruments. This makes for easy listening. I consider the CD a real find and am delighted to add it to my collection.

The original LP of this Ray Conniff recording was one of my favorites in college.  I was so glad to find it in a CD format that captures the classics with clarity and the same Conniff-style sound I liked so well.  I highly recommend this for Conniff fans and those who enjoy good music.

I looked forward to the “irresistibly smooth” taste of the Lindt Lindor peanut butter truffle. However, the flavors blended together into more of a “rough” texture and no distinct flavors. I decided to share these samples with friends who gave varying degrees of comments from “unimpressed” to “delicious.”  It certainly depends on the individual preferences to evaluate this chocolate treat. Personally, I liked it, but it isn’t among my top favorites of the Lindt Lindor collection. I’ve enjoyed other combinations much more.

This truffle combination is quite good and smooth. I received good comments when I offered them to guests. The smooth chocolate and tasty caramel flavors, however, are so blended, that it’s hard to distinguish them. The “center” of caramel isn’t distinct as I’ve tasted in other Lindt Lindor offerings. There is also a “hint” of coconut in the taste of the truffles. For a special treat, I recommend these chocolates as a good choice.

The fact the Taylor 5863 Timer/Clock is water and impact resistant made it an appealing product to order. It also appeared to be a good substitute for my travel alarm which doesn't provide good accuracy anymore. When it arrived, I found it to be larger than I anticipated for travel, but still a compact, smart looking device.Having to find a special tiny screwdriver to open the battery case was my first obstacle. At least the batteries were provided. After that hurdle, it became a challenge to read the directions and start the digital clock. I decided to wait until later to turn on the timer.However, without my knowledge, the timer had somehow been set and hours later sounded a loud, disconcerting noise at an inconvenient time.I read the instructions again and thought I got the gist of it, but it's not all that easy and efficient. One has to press the volume button to change from clock to timer. That can alter the sound of the alarm to very loud to not ringing at all.  Frankly, over repeated uses, I've found the timer to be a nuisance, rather than a help. The light button lasts for a momentary time and makes the same jolting "beep" noise when pushed.About the only redeeming qualities are the large, easy to read numbers on the digital clock and the handy pull out easel, which allows the clock to sit nicely on a tabletop. I don't foresee using it much as a timer due to the difficulty of setting it, changing it to the clock mode and the annoying alarm sound. This device was a big disappointment.

American Saint: The Life of Elizabeth Setonby Joan BarthelElizabeth Ann Bayley Seton “had it all” and “lost it all” by ordinary standards. By ecclesiastical standards, she gained it all, becoming the first American-born Saint to be recognized by the Roman Catholic Church.  Born into aristocracy just prior to the Revolutionary War, she braved illness, deaths of her husband and two of her five children, disapproval of her family to become a convert to the Catholic faith and weathered many challenges to follow her heart and God’s will as she saw it.Raised a Protestant, she married wealthy Will Seton and had five children. She had barely weaned her baby daughter when she and Will embarked on a trip to Italy, hoping the favorable climate would enable his health to improve. He died of tuberculosis and left Elizabeth a widow with five children at the age of 29. Her experience in Italy exposed her to the Catholic faith through the Filicchi family who assisted her after Will’s death. Following her return to America, her interest in the church led her to convert to Roman Catholicism, much to the disdain of her family. Catholicism was not recognized in her home state of New York.Elizabeth gave up the wealth she had known and moved with her children to Maryland, a haven for Catholics. Under the American Bishop, John Carroll, Elizabeth began her work as a teacher. When she was sent to the remote area of Emmitsburg, MD, she established the first order of active nuns in the United States. Her faith, prayer life, dedication and abilities to supervise children’s education, despite severe health and rudimentary conditions, became pivotal in founding American parochial education.She became the first American-born saint named by the Roman Catholic Church on September 14, 1975.Barthal describes Elizabeth’s spirituality through her writings, prayer life, quotations from letters to  friends and family to exemplify why she was considered a saint. “She had been a Protestant, a Catholic, rich, poor, an aristocrat, an outcast, a wife, a mother (working mother), a widow, a teacher, a social worker, a nurse and the founder of the first order of active women religious in U.S.” all in 46 years.An engaging book, I found parts of it to detour the reader from a chronological flow of Elizabeth’s life. Albeit interesting details, a couple of the early chapters became confusing, almost going into a stream of consciousness that detracted from showcasing Elizabeth in the historical framework. Barthal makes clearer Elizabeth’s later progress in establishing a school, standing up against authoritarian clergy and securing her place in American Catholic history. For a serious reader who wants to learn more about St. Elizabeth Ann Seton, I recommend this book.

A very interesting and different plot drives A Circle of Wives and makes for an absorbing read. When prominent cosmetic surgeon Dr. John Taylor is found dead in a hotel room, no one initially can imagine the intriguing and shocking details that will emerge. Upon investigation, the police discover his death actually to be a murder. Then the plot really thickens.Who would murder this highly successful and admired plastic surgeon? What would the motive be? Who would benefit from his death? And...how in the world did this distinguished doctor live a secret life that included three wives?These are among the many questions that confront young investigator, Samantha Adams who sets out to unravel the startling and complicated case. Answers only lead to more questions and more suspectsLaPlante writes each chapter from a separate individual’s perspective. At first, this is a bit confusing, with the chapters alternating among the characters. Eventually it becomes easier to differentiate the characters and reveals the story in a very creative way.  In addition to Samantha, we have the three wives: Deborah, the declared wife of over 25 years; MJ  who finds her life shattered at the kitchen table while reading the obituary; and Helen, the self-composed, compassionate pediatric oncologist, and newest wife. Somehow, none of them know about each other.  The story builds and keeps the reader guessing to the end who really killed the doctor who had three wives.Although the plot stretches the imagination, I found the book to be well written,  intriguing and worth recommending.

What a smooth and soothing voice Perry Como had.  This is one of the best Christmas albums I have. All the songs feature his signature style and are great even as background music. His voice has a calming effect and provides a gentler rendition of some of the old familiar songs.I especially like the title song, "I Wish It Could Be Christmas Forever."  I don't really remember it being popular, but when I heard it recently on the TV music station, I decided to track it down. The other songs are equally as pleasing to the ear, especially "Ave Maria." Perry sang it like no one else could.  I was so pleased to find the album at a very reasonable price. I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys Christmas music at its best.

The Ray Conniff singers had a very distinctive style and it is a thrill to listen to them again in this collection of Christmas music. With an upbeat rhythm, they bring back memories of many a Christmas of the past.  It's a delight to hear the songs one after another and not put in between some of the less melodic tunes that play on the radio and TV music stations.  With "Winter Wonderland," "Sleigh Ride," and "Frosty, the Snowman," I find myself wanting to play and hum along with them as I drive, even after the holidays fade and snow falls again.The recording has preserved the original sounds and captures the vibrant group that were so popular in the 50's and 60's. I highly recommend this album.

When entertaining, I need more than the traditional 6 mugs I normally have on my counter. I thought the Francois et Mimi Stainless Steel Coffee Mug Tree Holder would add accessibility to more mugs. I was very disappointed to find it will hold only 4 of my mugs (11" in circumference). The 3" space between the lower rung and the base is insufficient to accommodate 6. The advertised capacity states, “Holds 4-6 Mugs, Depending on Size.”  It would have to be a demitasse or espresso-sized mug to fit, if that. Neither of these are what I use to serve warm beverages to my guests.In it’s favor, the mug tree is very sturdy, has a non-skid, textured base and looks attractive enough. The “arms” are straight, with small knobs at the end to keep mugs from falling off. I would prefer more of a “hook” to secure the mugs.This mug tree does not fare favorably with another one I got recently. I recommend it only for it’s sturdy stance and if you use much smaller mugs or don’t mind losing the use of the bottom rungs.

Vatican Waltzby Roland MerulloWhat would you do if you had “visions” and spiritual experiences you couldn’t explain? How could you find someone who would believe you? What if God was telling you to strike new ground and defy ancient traditions and practices?These questions challenge Cynthia Piantedosi as she grows up in the Roman Catholic Church in a small town in Massachusetts. She develops a very deep spiritual life. She seeks advice from the local parish priest who becomes a mentor and guides her until his untimely death.While Cynthia pursues her education in nursing school, her visions continue and include seeing herself as a female priest. Although the local archbishop recognizes her as a deeply spiritual and honest woman, he gives Cynthia little, if any hope the Church will change. He suggests she go to Rome to talk to a cardinal friend of his. Cynthia flies to Rome, meets with the cardinal who says her request to become a priest at this time is impossible. He dismisses her with a warning to be very careful in trying to pursue her vision any further; there may be people out there who would want to do her harm. This veiled warning begins a series of mysterious events that lead to a surprise ending.The author gives excellent insight into the character’s search for truth and a deeper spirituality amid the doctrines of the Church. One can understand her frustration between what she believes to be God’s call and the rigid exclusion of women in the role of priests. The mystery surrounding her first mentor’s death and her adventures in Italy provide interesting reading and speculation. The book is contemporary as it addresses other themes and quotes spiritual writers who foreshadow some of the recent emphasis on social justice made by Pope Francis.My only disappointment is the dramatic twist at the end.  Not to be a spoiler, but the plot did not support the conclusion. It seems to stand alone. I do recommend the book, however. For the most part, it made for good and thought provoking reading.

Yukon Sled Dogby Judith Janda PresnallThis children’s book combines a good informative story with excellent visuals. Using a fictional husky puppy, Yukon, the story explains the fundamentals of raising huskies to be sled dogs and adds some interesting adventures for Yukon to encounter.My 7 year old grandson liked the illustrations, especially the dog’s face. He laughed as he read about Yukon’s exuberance when she would spin, only to get caught up in her chain. Another funny scene had a hare interrupting the race. This emphasized the need for the dogs to concentrate and stay on the trail.One note: a few of the pages were very dark and made it difficult to read the printing.The book provides an entertaining story, a good learning experience and colorful illustrations. I recommend it.

Motorworks TTP Sport Truck Power PackMy 7 year old grandson likes anything with wheels and this set of a wooden truck and SUV didn’t disappoint. He immediately started enjoying some of the features of the toys. This included the ability to interchange the various parts of the vehicles, allowing him to use his imagination to create new designs.The truck and SUV are sturdy, made of wood with some plastic trim. They will offer hours of creative fun with a durable and attractive product.  Although the price is a bit high, the quality is very good. I recommend the Motorworks TTP Sport Truck Power Pack.I was impressed with this selection and would highly recommend it.

The creamy caramel of this South Beach Diet Snack bar was a delight to the palate. The texture seemed softer and better tasting than other nutritional bars I've sampled. At 100 calories, the bars offer a good nutritional source. Each bar provides 6 grams of protein, 15 g. carbs, 130 mg. sodium, lower than other comparable snack bars. Anyone into good nutrition will like the fact these bars contain no high fructose corn syrup.I recommend this handy, tasty snack to anyone who wants a quick pick-me-up that will promote good taste and nutrition.

Mr. Lynch's Holiday  traces the on-going development of the relationship between a father and son who are both in transitional phases of their lives. Irish born Dermot lives in England and has recently experienced the death of his wife. He leaves Birmingham, England for a spontaneous holiday to visit his only son, Eamonn, in Spain.  Eamonn had emigrated there with Laura, the love of his life. They have become part of the housing area of Lomaverde, a community of expats who experience the decline of the once lovely setting.Both Dermot and Eamonn have unresolved emotions. They don't know each other really well at all. During Dermot's surprise visit, they become acquainted.  Dermot realizes his son's anguish over the abrupt departure of Laura, and Eamonn sees his father's discomfort in his new life as a widower.  Eamonn is ashamed of his own behavior, and doesn't seem to know how to handle his depressive reactions. Dermot is bewildered as to how to help him.  Both see faults in each other and have to come to grips with "making conversation over nothing at all." Some of these awkward moments give each insight into the other as they struggle with their relationship.O'Flynn introduces some interesting characters, expats, Inga, Cheryl and Roger, Becca and Ian, to name a few. She adds humor to the story as she describes them,the situations they encounter and interactions with Dermot and Eamonn. There's even a bit of intrigue as the residents of Lomaverde confront and potential vandals in the area.The author uses alternating flashbacks to flesh out the background of father and son and bring the two main characters up to the present. I felt this technique tended to confuse the fluidity and continuity of story. Despite this negative, I recommend the book as an entertaining and thoughtful read.

How any two people can live through such harrowing adventures in such a short time makes for a great read to include suspense and action in Lee Child's Never Go Back, the latestin the Jack Reacher series.A telephone conversation with Major Susan Turner, the commanding officer of the Army's 110th MP Special Unit in Virginia, brings Jack Reacher back to his old stomping grounds. When he arrives from South Dakota, he incurs several surprises. Lt. Colonel Morgan has replaced Major Turner and informs Reacher he's back on active duty and being charged on several accounts - one of them murder.The next ensuing days find Reacher escaping confinement, joining forces with Susan Turner and getting into major scrapes as he attempts to learn who is behind the false allegations and efforts to quiet both Jack and Susan. Will they discover who is behind the plot and cover up before being put behind bars? Will anyone in official offices believe them? Does the plot extend to federal agents, political powers, or uniformed Army personnel?  Whom can they trust to help?Reacher has extraordinary capabilities. He thinks like a chess player, has an uncanny way of counting precise time and will fight anyone who threatens to keep him from his objective. The adventures and scenarios carry Turner and Reacher across the country and leave the reader breathless trying to guess how Reacher will get out of his next dilemma.This is the first Jack Reacher I've read. I found it I highly entertaining with fast action and sometimes tongue-in-cheek dialogue. I look forward to reading more of his adventures. I highly recommend this book.

What memories these songs bring back to mind! I remember hearing them on the radio and playing the cherished LP's on my record player. How wonderful to have them in CD format so I can listen to them anytime, anywhere. I especially like disk 2 - with some of the songs from the album "The Fabulous Fifties." It would have been nice to have included the songs from both volumes of that series.One problem was the difficulty I had removing the disks the first time from their plastic cases. The center was so tight, I thought I was going to crack the disk. It took a lot of time and patience to remove them. I've since found it easier to store each separately in other CD cases I have on hand.Roger Williams was a versatile, talented and classic artist. I had the opportunity to hear him live in concert and it was a treat. So glad to be able to have these renditions of some of his greatest hits....great memories and music. I recommend this collection of his works.

Many of these songs were from my parents' younger days and I grew up hearing them played and sung in our home. What a treat to have them in disk form and be able to enjoy them at home or in the car. Most are peppy and upbeat and create a pleasurable atomsphere. Frank Pourcel created a special sound that captures the imagination. I'm very pleased I was able to get these for my collection. I recommend the set for those who are familiar with or just enjoy the "oldies, but goodies."

"No soldier dreams of coming home to an empty house." This is precisely what Dr. Mike Scanlon, orthopedist/podiatrist/soldier, does when he returns home on emergency leave from duty in Afghanistan. His wife Chole has died of a knife wound under questionable circumstances. Her sister Danielle and husband Bob have already begun to care for  Emily, Mike and Chole's infant daughter.Mike is troubled as he learns more about Chloe's death. He tries to relate to his baby daughter who doesn't recognize him and screams anytime he comes near her.  He hardly has time to go through the motions of the funeral before he has to report back to active duty. While in Afghanistan, he faces more brutality of war. The author does a credible job describing the events and emotions of what a soldier faces. As one of the characters summarizes, "Good people can't imagine evil. It catches us by surprise, and it always will."This phrase continues to haunt Mike as he returns home, injured, after serving the remainder of his tour. He relies on medicine to kill the pain and begins an effort to discover the truth behind his wife's death. Was it possibly not an accident? Is the murder of one of her best friends linked to Chloe's untimely death? Will he ever be able to relate to his little girl? Will he be able to return to being a surgeon?  Mike puts his professional and personal life at risk as he struggles to answer these questions.Don't Go is a story of war and its effects on both those who serve and those who remain at home. It's a story of a dedicated husband and father who sees his world turn upside down and challenge his integrity, strength, relationships and ability to love. He states, "War changes everything, and everybody."Although some of the personal incidents of Mike's life may be definite fiction, the story presents a contemporary view of the emotional scars our citizen soldiers and their families have had to endure in the past 12 years. I highly recommend this book.

No Way BackAndrew GrossAndrew Gross takes the reader on another wild, fast-paced adventure in his latest novel, No Way Back. He creates characters who stumble into situations that call for quick thinking and make the reader wonder how they ever get into these messes.Wendy Gould finds herself in this position when a chance encounter in a hotel room goes extremely wrong.  She's forced to kill in self defense and then literally runs for her life. She feels she's so far out of her realm, she doesn't know where to begin to clear herself or convince the authorities of the truth.Meanwhile, Lauritzia Velez, nanny to the Bachman children, runs and then hides to protect herself and the Bachman family from possible harm. A Mexican national, Lauritzia has known tragedy as she has lost several family members to the drug wars in her native land. Her hopes to reconstruct her life in a new country dissolve.How are these two women's lives entwined?  How do the tragic and wrongful deaths several years ago of University of Denver students vacationing in Mexico tie in with current events?  Will Lauirtzia and Wendy be able to find safety and reveal the truth to officials?The author keeps the reader guessing and waiting for the next turn of events throughout the novel. The plot, though a bit contrived, helps to expose the story of the Mexican drug wars and how decisions of the U.S. government inflamed the situation.I enjoyed the rapid pace of the action and the countless ways the characters devised to save themselves when there seemed "no way back." I recommend this book.

His Majesty's HopeSusan Elia MacNealIn His Majesty's Hope, Maggie Hope, our spunky, energetic and dedicated copper- headed young spy from Susan MacNeal's former novels, finds herself in a completely new assignment. This time she will become England's first woman spy to enter Nazi Germany. With a new identity and background, Maggie parachutes into Germany only to find herself willing to extend her time and possibly endanger her life for the sake of her country.MacNeal has done extensive research and reveals the awful truth about the Nazi's heinous plan - Operation Compassionate Death. This program exterminates "unsuitable" people, particularly handicapped, sick children, or kinder-Euthanaise. The novel exposes a horrifying insight into the realities of war and the effects on innocent children through the eyes of both onlooker, Elise Hess, a nurse at a German hospital, and Maggie, whose life eventually intertwines with Elise's.The reader gets an early indication the characters will be drawn together, yet it is of interest to learn how the author achieves this. What will happen when Maggie's life crosses with Clara Hess, Maggie's birth mother, who was formerly presumed dead and now works for the Nazi's? How can Maggie help Elise's efforts to lead a Jewish friend and a mysterious hospital patient to safety?As in the previous novels, Maggie continues to unwittingly involve herself with twists and plots that leave the reader wondering how she will manage to get out of this last hot spot. Even Maggie admits she feels her cover might be reaching it's "expiration date."I recommend this book. I look forward to another in the series. One can only guess at what her next escapade will be.

What does a person do when someone kills their child? How does, or should, a person get vengeance? How do such actions affect them? Rough Men examines these questions.When his son Alex is shot and killed as part of a robbery gang escapade, Will Daniels finds himself facing these issues.  Will insists that he find the killer and learn why his son was shot. He goes to great lengths to fulfill this mission.  He persuades his friend Jason to help him seek vengeance. Both experience great pain because of their quest.Rough Men provides one view as to the consequences of seeking revenge and  presents some serious questions to deliberate. This is an action filled book with lots of violence and killing. I recommend this book.

Edge of Blackby J.T. EllisonDr. Samantha Owens hopes to begin a new life in Washington, D.C. teaching forensic pathology in medical school. Tragic Nashville floods claimed her husband and children several years before, and Sam needed to find a place to start over. A new man, Alexander (Xander) Whitfield, also has come into her life. Although a civilian, Xander has spent much of his life in the Army as a decorated Airborne Ranger.Just as she begins her new career, an incident in the Washington Metro creates widespread terror. An unknown biological or chemical agent causes many to seek medical help. At the end of the day, three people are dead. One is U.S. Congressman, Peter Leighton, head of the Armed Services Subcommittee. Sam's friend, Detective Darren Fletcher, calls her in to help with Leighton's autopsy. Her findings offer confusing and disturbing results.Meanwhile, Fletcher is pulled into an assignment with the Joint Terrorism Task Force (JTTF). He meets his new woman boss who is a "stickler for details" and tough as nails under a facade of friendliness. Tension builds while Fletcher pursues the case.As the pieces of the mystery begin to fall into place, the action really picks up. It alternates between Washington and the Colorado Rockies where Xander was born and raised by "hippie" parents.  Xander believes he may have some clues as to who might be behind the terrorism.Many questions arise: Did the terrorist plot originate outside the U.S. or within?  What is the deadly toxin? How are the three victims related? Can they identify and catch the person behind the attacks before more terror is unleashed?Ellison sets up an interesting plot and creates good interactions among the characters.  I enjoyed reading the book and recommend it.

The Ambassador's Daughterby Pam JenoffAn intelligent and outspoken young woman, Margot Rosenthal, accompanies her father, Friedrich Rosenthal, to Paris where he is to serve as an advisor at the Versailles Peace Treaty meetings post World War I.During the war, Margot lived with her father, a scholar and academic,  while he taught at Oxford. She finds herself now in a strange city and somewhat bored with little to do. Originally from Berlin, she has used Paris to distance herself from her fiancé, Stefan, as he recovers from disabling injuries incurred in the war. It's difficult for her to face the reality of the impending marriage when so many things in her life have changed.Margot meets a woman musician, Krysia Smok, who befriends her and introduces Margot to some liberal thinking colleagues. Unwittingly, Margot involves herself with an espionage situation and finds it difficult to unweave the web she has created. She also finds herself attracted to a German naval officer, Georg, who invites her to work for him as a translator.She questions loyalties to all those whom she trusts and who trust her. How can Margot be true to her father, Georg and Stefan? Can she betray the trust of Georg?  Can she admit her feelings have lessened for Stefan?How does she confront secrets her father has withheld? Can she be true to herself?With historical events as backdrops, Jenoff examines the discrimination between the French hosts and the German delegation.  We see events and challenges of that time from the viewpoint of young Margot. Jenoff uses stream of consciousness well to enter into the heroine's thoughts and deepest emotions. Often she includes this technique in the same paragraph as the dialogue and causes the reader to confuse what is being said with what the character thinks.I've read several of Jenoff's books and enjoyed them. This one proves to be another interesting read. I recommend it.

.  .Recently I purchased a Turkish cotton bath wrap.  For that purchase, the tough decision was whether to get a wrap or a robe.  After much consideration I decided that the wrap would be better because it was smaller, lighter, and allowed natural drying more than the robe.Unfortunately, with a wrap a person can become chilly in the areas not covered by the wrap ( for me usually the chest and back).  This Luxury Extra Large Bath Towel" solves my problem.I recommend this product.  The towel is really huge - bigger than my best beach towel - and can cover my entire body if necessary.

.My body needs to cool down after my shower.  For awhile I used a bath towel wrapped around my waist while I cooled down..  I have been looking for something better.This "bathrobe" functions so much better than the bath towel - it is really more of a wrap than a robe.I like "Spa Wrap Towel" for several reasons.  First, the wrap has a velcro strip that secures the garment well.  I can now relax and accomplish a few tasks during my cool down period.  As a bonus,  the Turkish cotton of this wrap increases the comfort while assisting in the drying process,  My physician  said it is better to have my body dry itself naturally instead of rubbing it with a towel..I recommend this wrap.

.Just as Maggie Hope prepares to become a spy for MI-5 behind enemy lines in Germany, she learns she will stay in England instead. She's assigned to tutor the young Princess Elizabeth in mathematics at Windsor Castle. British security have moved Princesses Elizabeth and Margaret to this location to protect the future monarch and her sister from German air raids in London. In reality, Maggie is on secret mission to discover who is sending messages to the Germans from Windsor Castle.The murders of two women, one a lady-in-waiting, seem unrelated until Maggie begins to learn more information about each. Who was responsible for their deaths? How do the persons living in the castle play a part in the plot?  Who is the person getting messages to the Germans?  How will these events and characters impact the safety of the Princess?  How can Maggie protect her?  Is her own life in danger?Princess Elizabeth's Spy is the second in the Maggie Hope Mystery series. In the first novel, Mr. Churchill's Secretary, Maggie appears as a sprite, intelligent, driven and quick witted individual who is highly skilled in mathematics and code breaking. She continues to fulfill the image as she moves through her new experiences. Since she has felt the betrayal of many people before, she isn't sure whom to trust and has to "take care not to let feelings trump logic" as she begins to acquaint herself with the personnel at the castle.Other threads of the story include Maggie's new found unsettling relationship with her father, the disappearance of her military boyfriend over German territory, and her growing feelings for other co-workers. A complex character, Maggie finds her attempts  to separate her personal life from her job as a spy sometimes very challenging. .To develop a historical mood as a backdrop for the intrigue, MacNeal describes vintage music playing in the background, what kind of food is being served and activities going on to support the war efforts. She describes the castle's floor plan and surroundings and the lifestyle of the residents with authenticity. Anecdotal conversations between the future queen and her sister add a special quality to the story. The two princesses rehearse and perform a play for their parents, the King and Queen of England, and Prime Minister Churchill during his Christmas visit to the royal family.While Maggie's efforts to save the Princess are a bit unrealistic, a suspenseful pursuit of kidnappers and potential traitors ensues.  Maggie ends her assignment as Princess Elizabeth's tutor and prepares for her next adventure of intrigue.I enjoyed this mystery even more than the first and look forward to reading the  forthcoming  Maggie Hope Mystery, Hitler's Nightingale.

.Irish Gold is a double mystery story, one in current day and the other set in the 1920s.  Dermot Coyne, a twenty four year old "retired" commodities trader, travels to Dublin Ireland to investigate the story behind his grandparents emigrating to the United States.In his wanderings, while attempting to gather clues, he meets a teenage (nineteen) Irish girl who is a student at Trinity College and an excellent singer.  Although he does not realize it, he has fallen in love.The historical mystery provides an excellent tale of the caution and intrigue involved in the Irish Revolution.  Dermot's grandparents emerge as two patriots emboldened by the cause for liberty, while fearful of repercussions on family and faith.  The story is well told and reveals the history without abusing the reputations of the historical characters.Irish Gold is mostly love story, of Dermot and Nuala.  The repartee between the characters makes the tale fun.  I found Dermot's incompetent pursuit of Nuala humorous and believable.  This is a fun read.

.The opening sentence, "The President is...dead." sets a rapid pace for the new political intrigue novel, I Do Solemnly Swear, by D.M. Annechino.As Katherine "Kate" Ann Miles becomes President of the United States, she immediately faces a major international crisis. At the same time, her personal life begins to disintegrate and she feels her life is in danger. Whom can she trust?  How strong are her instincts to guide the nation into a potential conflict? What force is threatening her presidency and the nation? Even former first Lady, Elizabeth Rodgers, warns Kate to be careful, as her life may be endangered like her late husband's.Excellent descriptive phrases, sometimes pithy analogies and comments illustrate the perspective of the main players to set the background for the political intrigue. A list of characters at the front of the book clarifies the positions of people Kate has to interact with as President.The engrossing story is haunting and sometimes chilling as Annechino presents fictional scenarios that possibly have overtones of truth in them. Descriptions of independent acts of violence are so explicit they often distract from the major storyline, however. The sinister plot weaves a web of intrigue and mystery and leaves the reader to wonder if Kate has defeated all her enemies. How will she continue to carry out her presidency? Will there be a sequel?Although somewhat unrealistic, I found the book interesting and entertaining. I recommend it.

.There are numerous events when I need a greeting card:  birthdays, anniversaries, Valentines Day, and other special days.  The problem is that sometimes I can not seem to get out to get a card.  Now, in my life, failure to get out to get a card is not an excuse.  I simply can not fail to have a card for my wife for her birthday, our anniversary, Valentines Day (or St. Patrick's Day as she is Irish).These Quickie Greeting Cards are part of my solution.  First I select one with a nice image on the front of the card.  This particular card has a pretty heart.Then I examine the words to find a card with a good sentiment.  On this face of this card, it says "To The Love Of My Life", just the right sentiment for my feelings.Third, I ponder the verse on the inside.  In this card it speaks of the joy I feel being part of her life.  Good view, so I simply personalize it by writing her name at the top and a couple of verses on my own at the bottom (like - "my love for you just keeps growing, you are so dear to me").These are good generic cards with a pretty image and a nice greeting.  All I need to do is  personalize it and make comments to fit the season.  I highly recommend these cards.

.I remember in American History class in school, the first thing we studied was the explorers and conquistadors. We focused upon how they came from Europe and "opened" the "new" world. We thought of them as heroes. The peoples that already lived here, Native Americans, were mentioned, but mostly as some odd savages available to be civilized. The Native American reaction to having their land taken was seldom given any emphasis - - except the occasional Cowboy vs Indian battle / skirmish.Coming of the Storm is historical fiction written by archeologists. I like novels that tell a story while revealing information about a culture and people that appear different from my own culture.  This novel is an excellent example of this.  Although this book is about Spanish conquistadors, the focus switches from the heroic invaders to the courageous indigenous people fighting to save their land and culture.Set in Florida, among the many tribes of native people the story uses two fictional characters, Black Shell and Pearl Hand, to narrate the tale of a growing revolt against the forces of Spain.  With Pearl Hand as his partner, Black Shell must discover how to unite the separate tribes of his native land and defeat the soulless armies of Hernando de Soto. The book provides an excellent revelation of native culture - religion, holy practices and rituals as well as wars against and among the tribes.The authors do a superior job picturing the tactics of the Spanish forces. They include very detailed descriptions of the weapons and how they were used. Details are so  exquisite and one can understand how natives could not defeat the Kristianos, even  with 10 to 1 odds. The Spanish  are trying to subdue or eliminate indigenous people who infest land they consider their own.  After all, they claim the Pope gave this land to the Spaniards.This is an engrossing  book and I recommend it.

.Chloe Harding could be one of the happiest persons alive.  She is a successful student enrolled in a prestigious college, has a boyfriend she loves and lots of friends.  Chloe is suddenly expelled from school and is being harassed by the local police.  How could this have happened?My initial expectation was that this story would focus on Chloe's problem.  Why was she expelled?  Was she actually guilty of a crime?  How could she have been in the wrong place?  Who could do this to her?  In Between Days however, emphasizes relationships.  This is a character driven novel.  The plot has multiple storylines, but is predictable.  The characters a well drawn and real. They narrate four different, alternating perspectives.Chloe comes from a dysfunctional  family.  Her father Elson is stuck in a dull job, drinks to excess and is recently divorced by his wife Cadence.  Cadence, after thirty years of marriage, finds herself questioning the meaning of her life and why she dropped out of college to marry Elson.  Their son Richard recently "came out" and resents his father for not supporting him.The plot is typical, father and mother fighting, children feeling unloved and neglected, siblings becoming close and keeping secrets.  The parents try disparately to keep control.  Each of the people slowly learn how little control they have over othersWhat makes this story worthwhile is its close exposure of the feelings and problems typical of people in a disjointed family - a fractured family.  This is all set in homes and cafes of Houston, with satisfying enough detail to make the reader picture sections of the city that the author obviously loves.The novel is full of psychological suspense, with each of the family members worrying about the others and hoping to manipulate them a little.  A sub-theme is an intriguing tale of betrayal and forgiveness of a friend.  I recommend this novel for those who enjoy character studies.

.When I try to imagine travel in the seventh century I see a dangerous adventure that requires a lot of effort.  The Dove of Death is a story about the journey Sister Fidelma and her husband Eadulf take to return to Ireland from south eastern France.First if one takes a route on land, roads in that part of Europe are rather crude, mostly dirt paths going up and down hills and mountains that may allow one to travel fifteen miles each day.  Water travel is better as it requires less effort fro the traveler.  When you cross part of what we now call the Atlantic Ocean, you might encounter pirates.  I would be tempted to travel with an army, but that might lead to war.Fidelma and Eadulf encounter pirates while crossing the ocean.  The pirates are a brutal lot and,  after the boat surrenders, kill both the boat captain and Fidelma's cousin, a royal emissary traveling to Cashel to see  Fidelma's brother the king.  Eadulf and Fidelma escape by jumping overboard,  losing all  their  luggage and money.  .Our travelers become involved in a political power struggle that costs the lives of several local citizens and threatens Fidelma as well.The mystery of this book is Fidelma investigating the murder of her cousin.  The investigation is complex with Fidelma getting only reluctant help from the locals.  The final resolution is much simpler than most of Fidelma's work, but the descriptions of the locale and customs are superior.The Dove Of Death is an excellent mystery and a well told story...I recommend this book.

.Can spells put on a person continue to harm his offspring?  Toward the end of the Civil War, a Confederate Officer held in a prisoner of war camp,curses JJ Cardin because he had supplied spoiled meat to the Prisoner of War camp for Confederate solders.  JJ had a contact with the Union to provide a regular supply of meat at a low price.  Many soldiers died from poison that came from the bad beef.  As years passed each generation of the Cardin family lost someone in the family at an early age.  So, the Cardin family lives for generations believing  that the family is cursed, a curse that condemns  one member, minimum, from each generation, who will die at an early age  - forever.Chantal Cardin asks Blackie for help.  She requests a "general confession" to insure her soul is in good shape as she thinks she will be killed soon.  Despite Blackie's counsel Chantal knows she will die soon.Chantal Cardin has been a major donor to the Archdiocese of Chicago and has served with Cardinal Cronin on may civic action committees.  The Cardinal becomes concerned about Chantal and assigns His assistant, Auxiliary Bishop John Blackwood Ryan to work the case.  Bishop Ryan, who insists on being called "Blackie", takes the case but struggles with how he can help.How do you defeat a curse made over 100 years ago?  How can one persuade  members of the Cardin family that the only curse is their love of money?  How can you redirect their image of success and happiness from extreme wealth to people and family?In Happy Are The Oppressed, Blackie struggles with his mission.  The Cardin family is reluctant to accept his help, information concerning the curse event is small and tough to obtain.  Blackie's struggle with his mission enhances the story.  I recommend this novel.

There are two offerings on this product page and I am reviewing both.I’ve been drinking tea for years but I’m new to Matcha. I was excited to try these and I’m happy to report that I’m not disappointed. The difference between the two kinds of Matcha is that Kazuma is organic and Kiwami is non-organic . Also that Kiwami tastes a wee bit sweeter than Kazuma.I received a 5gm sample each of Kiwami and Kazuma , directly by the seller , in return of an unbiased and honest review from an end users point..In the package that I received, there was also a copy of the USDA certificate that verified that Kazuma is indeed organic. Both products are well controlled by strict standard of quality control. Also, both products are ground by a stone grinder. Such a stone grinder can take up to one hour to grind 30grams of Matcha and thus maintains the good taste and nutrition. Both Kiwami and Kazuma are finely ground and smell really fresh .It is best to keep the Matcha powder in the refrigerator . While making the tea , it is important that you DONOT pour in too hot water because hot water ‘burns’ the freshness and makes it taste a little bitter . I prepared the ‘koicha’ , i.e. thick tea . Although I did not have the traditional Japanese three piece set for making matcha – Whisk (chasen) , bowl (chawan) and spoon ( Chashaku) ; I managed okay by using a bowl and spoon . Another important thing to keep in mind is the process of preparing it. Instead of circular motions it is better to move it back and forth like making a ‘W’ shape until the powder is all dissolved and there are no lumps.The green tea powder by iMaccha Tea Company is undoubtedly high in quality , taste and nutrition. I personally love the taste and feel that it is an excellent quality product . I Recommend it !

Minecraft has a strong following, and it is no wonder that the characters and concepts from this popular video game is now in books.  The Two Little Cowboys has created a series of the unofficial Minecraft stories that really develop great characters from the mobs that are well known.  In The Super Mob Squad, Punchy has noticed that zombies are disappearing, and not in the painful way that they burn up in the sun.  In order to find answers, he calls upon his old friend, Dr. Bones.  From there, the adventure continues with a lot of funny interaction, great action scenes, and a plot that will keep you reading and wanting more. My teenage nephew enjoyed it !! Editing issues aside , it is a good read.

This was my first story from Sarah but I'll definitely be back. It was a very fun and fast read.I really enjoyed the characterization and set up for the train trip. There was a bit of action and suspense and some really hot romance! I can't wait to read more in this world and Sarah's other books!

My little nephew enjoyed this story .A sweet , simple and short one about BIG FISH who was named because of its large size . A delightful and cute story . The author has drawn some reallly cute illustrations and that adds to the charm  .As the write up is not top-notch , it is apparent that the author's first language is not English but I would still rate it 4 stars for Ahmad's efforts ! :-)PS : I was informed by the author of the free promotion.
Great book worth the purchase and love the prep and tips before you start the diet.

The speculative fiction of Three Cultural Shocks is a collection that combines the well-known fiction of Tony Thorne with time travel from the dinosaur period and stories  that are more like a fairy tale with witches and ancient statues.  "Spellbind" follows the plan of the village witch Old Mother Megan as she wants changes in her favor.  She may not be the most skilled witch, but her plans demonstrate her cunning.  "Invasion" combines the high intelligent life forms thought to be forever wiped out by the meteorites. What are their intentions in the modern world? "Demonstration" reminds us to always be cautious when applying for a job.  A seek-and-find mission puts a young but wise woman in a tight situation.  You will not expect this ending.  You can read each story one at a time, but you may prefer to read it all in one sitting and question what you know about the past and who you know in the present.  All of them are well written.  "Spellbind" is not what I typically read from Tony Thorne, but it was riveting and satisfying to the end.  If this is your first book by the author or another one to add to your personal library, you will be pleased with what you read for sure.

Tony Thorne has created a collectible treat.  His speculative fiction Time Travel Troubles is all about the fantastic idea of traveling to the past, future, and parallel universes and the trouble it can create.  Some refer to more intelligent life on our own planet from the dinosaur age while some describe instances in which people try to escape to the future.  The author takes the theories and the "what ifs" and takes the risk through fiction to determine outcomes.  The points of view of the characters who take the risk in these situations put us in the predicaments that we could not easily imagine on our own.  It also makes you wonder about the last thoughts and observations that were taken with the guinea pigs and scientists who did not survive one of those types of experiments.  Time travel is an impossibility that could make life better for the good or more destructive if in the wrong hands.  Tony Thorne has crafted a collection of thought-provoking, technical and literary time travel stories that you may want to reread every few years to see if we have come any closer to making the impossible possible.  If he is right, we will never see it in our lifetime or never witness the failures on the other side of the portal.

James Aquas is a character my nephew likes to follow. He is not a rebel in a disobedient way, but rather one who asks questions about the world around him.  He has the good qualities to treat people with respect and does not discriminate by the district where others live.  His curiosity is what interests him in the Recon Unit that protects the people of Lapis City.  When the city is under attack, James and the new recruits become part of the fight to save their underwater world.  This book is full of action , fun and adventure . Even I enjoyed reading it. I will highly recommend this to everyone and give it a happy 5 stars for the wonderful adventurous story. I can't wait for the second book !! :)

Location can contribute to the outcome of dating success.  It can affect the pool of eligible dating material in terms of numbers, personal values, and interests.  Dating in LA  takes the metropolitan dating scene and breaks it down to the reasons and excuses that strong, meaningful relationships are more difficult to find and keep.  It identifies dating rumors we hear from other parts of the country and breaks down the reasons and problems that we do not see.There is a logic about LA relationships in general.  The goal of moving west to LA is so vastly different than most regions in the country and plays a big role in LA dating.  The author's no-nonsense approach is agreeable to most and a forehead-smacking "aha!"moment for those who are just opening their eyes about their failures and struggles in dating.  This is a well-written book with great facts and resources, but the tell-it-like-it-is voice is what sets it apart from comparable books.

The concept of artificial intelligence taking over humanity, or THE Singularity, is not a new idea.  Classic science fiction novels, comics, TV, and movies played on the fears of invasions of robots, cyborgs, and other invaders bent to destroy human beings and take over the world.  Those who survived fought to maintain control.  I grew up wondering if a scenario like The Terminator could really happen, in which a computer and its creation of cyborgs could ever be more than entertainment.  Also, could we even stop the progression of taking technology and intelligence to a higher level, that is to a point that we do not have to do anything laborious because computers will do it for us?  Tony Thorne's book - ' The Singularity is Coming ' addresses these concerns and beyond with factual detail and personal accounts to the progress artificial intelligence has made.  His prediction based on expert forecasts of a disaster greater than global warming and nuclear war.  I have read many of his speculative fiction stories, and have awed with his creativity and imagination in crafting a probable society in which we are comfortable with the common use of robots, cyborgs, androids, and other artificial intelligence that was more of a fantasy even 50 years ago.  This book takes into account his research in the area and puts it into perspective that is more likely now than it has ever been before.  You will enjoy reading in his voice and truly contemplate the future of the singularity.

This is an amazing book that would give you some really good insight on how simple household items can be re-purposed and re-used to clean up and organize the space in your home. Laura Myers has mentioned some really good ideas using which you can create storage space for items around your bedroom , kitchen and living room. The positive thing about this book is that these ideas are super easy to follow and execute. These ideas will also help you to use everyday items as your storage solutions in turn leading to less clutter and less mess !! The last chapter of the book which states ideas for de-cluttering from everyday life , is the best one. I already knew some ideas which were mentioned ; however there were many new ones as well. All in all , a good read. Worth a try if you’re looking for DIY ideas as storage solutions.

JFK, was a famous American politician who served as the 35th President of the United States from January 1961 until his assassination in November 1963. Over 50 years later there are still many questions being asked about the assassination. The conspiracy theories persist for a number of reasons, one of which was that he was a charismatic figure taken from us so young. Kennedy was a young . dynamic and highly charismatic, graceful figure who, in the view of many, was taking the United States in a new direction with a sense of mission and purpose. It is difficult to think clearly about Kennedy because of the memories his name evokes, coupled with the assassination and the United States' subsequent political history. A positive thing about this book is that it provides a realistic appraisal of his presidency.. Worth a read.

What would you say if someone told you that all religions and philosophies were valid?  It would contradict what many have learned in their most impressionable years and have practiced for their life.  While author Aaron Laird is not promoting a particular thought, he is using the thoughts of other famous philosophers and sciences to explain this theory.  When an open mind and a critical eye examines this point of view, it opens up an honest discussion about the similarities of belief systems and the efforts of man who fight for their beliefs both in battle and in word.  References to Hilter and the religious wars are a few examples of the misinterpretation of religion and human ignorance.Dr. Laird's book is very thought-provoking and an interesting, short academic read.  It read more like an essay and I am sure that a deeper analysis could come through in a similar discussion if not an extended book.

A friend of mine is a Tony Thorne Fan and she literally insisted that I read this book. I'm glad that I did :)In a time where citizens worry about drones invading their privacy, this story about model helicopters initially used for a part-time aerial photography job only to be used for questionable business practices.  Bill enjoys his hobby flying model helicopters and equips them with cameras and attachments to complete different tasks in the air.  When he is approached by a secretive man, he is unsure about his role in the jobs he wants Bill to do, but the money is a big incentive as is keeping himself alive to use it.  Will he find himself caught in a web of shady deals or can he walk away at any time.Tony Thorne is well known for his speculative fiction and science fiction stories, so this realistic fiction was a nice change for me to read.  It makes you think as to how far would you go to do a job, and is what you are doing legal even if you are not doing it directly.  It is easy to ask yourself situational questions and "what ifs" to put yourself in Bill's place.  Bill's wife also finds herself involved, mostly out of worry for her husband, but it is the wonderful teamwork that helps Bill brainstorm and weigh the rewards and consequences of the jobs he is asked to do for the mysterious man.  This short story is a good one to read and will keep you in suspense until the end.

A friend of mine recommended this book ....Books about Dystopic societies such as the one set in Tesla make the reader imagine themselves in a life unlike any they have ever known and one they may fear to be in their future.  The storyline makes that a possibility by explaining the events that lead up to the life they know in the book.  Seb loses everything about his family and home, and discovers he is hunted for termination but he doesn't know why.  All he knows is that he needs to get to the Steam Academy, which was his mother's last wish.  Along the way he is chased by cyborgs and helped by friends and strangers.  As the people around him are dying or struggling with their own survival, he is on a hunt to find out what happened to his mother and get to the academy. Strong for young adults, but interesting enough for mature readers as well.  It is also part one of the series, so I am interested in seeing how the story continues.  It is a powerful, exciting story of a future I hope we never see.

I love Oliver Hart's writing still on Magick, paranormal, Wicca and everything in between. Magick And Empowerment is presented in an easy to understand way for the beginner, but also proves of great value to the experienced magickian's bookshelf (or Kindle). The guy really knows his stuff, it's obvious. This is a must have for any practicing Chaote (or Chaoite).
