The rubber coating on the hard plastic structure of the grip is a good texture: Not too soft, not too hard, and tacky enough for a good grip. The release for the storage compartment is an absolutely silly design that's hard to describe. There's a recessed little cavity (almost too small for a finger) on the back of the grip that you have to poke the tip of your pinky nail into or otherwise use some sort of tool to press the release. As pictured, the grip also features a bold ridge about three-quarters of the way up the grip-- presumably to to separate some of the fingers. This is a personal preference, but I hate such finger grooves or ridges. Let the shooter/operator put his/her fingers wherever they want! I knew going in (based on pictures) that this grip would have that ridge, but I didn't know it'd be as annoying as it is. It doesn't separate the trigger finger (as I thought it would), but rather the middle finger. The placement is strange.For me, the deathblow for this grip-- and the primary reason I returned it-- was that the grip comes with a short Allen-head screw to attach it. For my AK (a milled, very popular, Bulgarian model), the long stock bolt will not work in this new grip. You have to already have-- or be prepared to buy-- a unique and very long Allen wrench to fit inside the length of the grip to use the short Allen bolt that's provided with this new grip. I have no idea why companies that make tactical firearms gear wouldn't use a more common flat-head or Phillips-head screw/bolt (like those that are commonly used on AR-15 grips). It makes swapping grips out in the field or repairs so much easier when you don't require unique tools.This grip didn't work for me, but your mileage may vary.

The texture and color is a passable stone-look from a distance, but the fact that it's plastic means it's not going to rust like metal or crack like pottery. It's also lightweight so it's easy to move from one place to another with the coiled hose inside.

I have several digital/computer/smartphone calendars I juggle for my business and personal matters, they all work great, and they are generally superior to written calendars (e.g. they are backed up automatically, can be easily shared, can be viewed on multiple devices, and are easy to update). However, a laminated calendar like this where you can see everything at once is really nice. The boxes are too small to really write a lot of details, but this is a "big picture review" or "long-term planning" calendar in my opinion (that's why I bought it at least).The only minor comments I'd make about the calendar's quirks are that it's rather wide (so make sure you know WHERE you're going to hang it), comes unframed (so think about HOW you're going to hang it), and has a slight curl to it (because it's shipped rolled up tight). Overall, these are very minor issues.

I bought the five-pack (two black, one green/red/blue) for use on an erasable laminated 6-month calendar. The pens work great. These pens remind me of the ones my middle-school math teacher would use on an overhead projector. The teacher would sometimes need to make a correction, would not have water or cleaner available, and would therefore use spit on a finger or two to smear or "wet erase" a few numbers, and it always looked disgusting. The whole class would freak out and go, "Eeeeww!"Ah, memories.Anyway, good pens.

This protein is okay as far as plant-based proteins, but I wouldn't call it delicious by any means. It seems to be a no-nonsense protein source (which many people may be looking for), but it's pretty gritty, tastes bland, almost has a bit of a pea taste (where part of the protein comes from), and a slightly strange after-taste. Just the protein, ma'am.Spiru-Tein is still my go-to protein powder. It's so great-tasting that I enjoy making a shake for the sake of just having a nice shake. It's like having dessert.

Ordered two. One worked with a clunky install of drivers, the other was dead on arrival. Quality control for these devices doesn't inspire a lot of confidence. When you intend to use these in a professional office, you don't want to be worried that one (or both) of your monitors are going to completely fail.This is covered in other reviews, but important to mention: These adapters do not appear to have any actual graphics processing power. That means that when you use two of these things, your computer is trying to use all it's horsepower just to properly display things on two monitors. Be aware of that if you intend to do anything graphic-intensive or video-intensive.

It works as described, but with a couple of issues:- The bottom of the stand is a sort of powder-coated metal with a somewhat abrasive finish. There is absolutely no felt or soft coating on the bottom of the stand so it will scratch and damage any wood surface you put it on. Even if the monitor is stationary most of it's entire life, there will be some movement of the stand to when adjusting the angle of the screen, so scratches to the desk or desktop will be inevitable if something soft isn't placed below the stand.- Adjusting for height is not an easy operation. Rather than using knobs or wing nuts (which could be loosened and tightened with fingers), the engineers/designers who built this stand made it require tools to loosen or tighten the screws that clamp the main vertical pole. This means the height cannot easily be adjusted.- Adjusting for tilt or angle is not an easy operation either. Again, rather than using knobs or wing nuts (which could be loosened and tightened with fingers), the engineers/designers who built this stand made it require tools to loosen or tighten the screws that clamp the plate around the ball-joint. This means the angle or tilt of the stand cannot easily be adjusted. There is a *small* bit of adjustment that can be made if you find the sweet spot when tightening the Allen screws *just enough* that it allows for enough friction to hold the monitor upright but not *too much* so that it prevents slight adjustments.Bottom line: This is a decent stand at a good price, but you need to apply felt at the bottom to prevent scratching, and nearly any adjustments will require an Allen wrench.
Stunning soundtrack. Sparse, but rich. Subtle, but intense. Love it.

I love everything that Brandi Carlile and the Twins put out. I like Bear Creek a little more than this latest release, but there are some gems here-- including a couple of rockers and some great lyrics.

I bought this keyboard to use with a Lenovo Yoga 10 HD tablet, and-- to the keyboard's credit-- it paired in seconds and seems to work well with the tablet. However, the keyboard is unimpressive for a number of reasons:- It feels very cheap. Something about the plastic, it looks very glossy, and more like a toy than a business device. And while devices should be functional vs. fashionable, this one just doesn't match the quality of most tablets.- The backlit keys are cool looking, but not very functional. The backlighting is primarily visible around the keys (where there's translucent plastic}, but the actual printing remains mostly unlit and is really uneven from key to key (especially in red). Another thing that's not really the fault of the keyboard, but interesting to note: If you're using this anywhere near your actual tablet, the tablet will light up the keyboard. I found that the backlit keys weren't nearly as big of a feature for this keyboard than I thought they'd be. They are very pretty when you change the colors, but that's about it.- Lastly, but most importantly for me, the keys are too loud. Super-loud. I would drive anyone at a business conference or meeting absolutely crazy if I were to type on this while in their presence. It's just too damn loud. CLICK CLACK CLICK CLACK! I have three different computers, and none of them have keyboards this loud.+ On the positive side, the keyboard is very inexpensive, comes with a soft carrying case, and appears to work with all three device types (Windows, Android, and iOS).Unforuntatley, overall, the keyboard just won't work for me. The loudness is a deal-breaker.

Very cool. Better than expected. No wires, no cables, no switches. Just mount it, aim it, and forget it. I even like the color (it's kind of got a pearlescent cream color)Some of the reviews said the light was dim (wrong, it's quite bright) or that the motion sensor didn't work (mine works great). My only criticism of the light is that it uses three D batteries and that's an odd number (literally) given than most packs come in four. The light will hopefully last a year (or more), so you're going to have a few single D batteries laying around unless you plan ahead and buy a 12 pack (the lowest common denominator). I know, I know, that's a dumb thing to get worked up over, but I don't understand why they didn't just make it use four D batteries or four C batteries. It's like these damn tv remotes today that use one single AAA battery. Where do you get one single AAA battery!? By the time you replace the battery in the remote, you go digging through a drawer full of expired or past-their-prime single AAA batteries. Lol.Anyway, all joking aside, this light is fantastic, and I'll be buying another.

I bought the audio version of this book because I'm an OK Cupid user, and I've followed the OK Cupid blog. OK Cupid-- by being one of the most popular dating sites in the world-- has collected an enormous amount of data from it's users. Data which is very intimate, personal, and unique because it is information that can be analyzed in order to determine patterns or draw conclusions. However, Rudder does an absolute hack job in interpreting the data and it's painful to listen to him attempt to play alchemist or voodoo witch doctor. It's as if he's never taken a single class in the fields of logic, statistics, or psychology. Google "spurious correlations" by Tyler Vigen, and you'll get a good overview of the problems when people doesn't understand correlation vs. causation. Rudder also completely fails to take into account (even in the subtitle of the book) that users on OK Cupid are typically answering questions publicly so it is a mistake to assume that all self-reported answers are accurate and candid. Also, many of the questions on OK Cupid are broad unscientific questions, compound questions, or allow very restricted responses in the form of multiple-choice answers (many of which are casual/informal and don't allow for the ideal and most accurate response).I don't mean to dump on the author, but there is one more strong criticism of Rudder's choice of topics for this book: When he spends a third of the book discussing Google searches and Twitter, it's like watching one of those pathetic interviews with a retired ball player who's asked how the college team needs to win (duh, they need to score more points and prevent the other team from scoring point). By this, I mean that he has no insight at all, no private or proprietary information, and he simply talks about popular Google search terms, what Twitter is, how popular it is, the volume of tweets, and the most common tweeted words or phrases, and he then makes wild conclusions based on such little information. He'd be better off sticking to what he knows-- or has the potential to know-- and that is how people behave and answer questions on OK Cupid.Given the economic value of the data collected, Ok Cupid will likely never turn over the bulk of the data for academic review or peer-review. That's a shame, because it'd be the only way to really learn anything from the data (and to get a book or journal article that is better than this book). So we're stuck with this book. I will say there were just enough nuggets of interesting material in here to make it worth a loan from the library or to borrow from a friend, but I'd say the ratio was a half hour of good material in seven hours of audio (again, I had the audio CDs of this book). It really is awful to have to sit through hours of complete nonsense (nonsense that is deliberately package-wrapped to sound like legitimate science) just to get a few interesting pieces of information, but if you're an OK Cupid user, it might be worth it.

I have an old Radio Shack model, but I honestly don't think I'll use it anymore. The Radio Shack unit can select two weightings (which is nice), but I don't like having to dial-in a range to get readings. By comparison, this BAFX unit simply turns on immediately and is good to go at any range. The lighted display, ease of use, size, and price all add up to a great little meter.

Not much I can say about these. They work, they are easy to clean, and they are inexpensive. I've used them on three different brands of dog food. Better than using tin foil to cover my dog's leftovers!

I carefully read a number of reviews of this unit, a more expensive American-made classic version (which the makers of this cheaper Chinese model apparently ripped off) and also a digital/electronic (as opposed to mechanical) white noise maker.What I like:+ The mechanical noise is superior (to my ears) to digital recreations. I've tried sound/noise makers with recordings, and they always sound very phony and of poor quality. Some noise makers with sounds of beaches and rain or forests are so bad that the awful imitations are a distraction.+ By twisting the top of this unit, you can dial-in the sound you're looking for. Pitch changes a bit, and so does the volume.+ The unit does what it's supposed to do. It creates a nice, neutral, white noise.+ The unit is inexpensive.What I don't like:-The foam on the bottom is very, very cheap looking and I suspect it will get torn off or chewed up if you transport or travel a lot with the unit. Not a huge issue for me, but travelers be forewarned.- Contrary to a few reviews I read, this unit is loud. In a small office, I have to keep the unit on low, with the top dialed in the medium-sized vents, or it's simply too loud. With the unit on high and dialed-in using the large vents, the noise is actually hysterical: It sounds like you're in a tent during a mountain wind storm in Nepal. Or maybe strapped to the wing of a 747 at altitude. I can't image you'd ever leave this unit on maximum settings unless you lived in the ghetto and were attempting to mask the sound of drive-by shootings.- The unit has a definite mechanical sound. It's not all wind or white noise. I'd say it's similar to an aquarium pump or the motor on a fridge. It's subtle, but it's definitely there (more so than in a regular good-quality fan). On the absolute lowest settings, it's a bit bothersome. On the mid-to-higher settings, the white noise is greater than the motor sound so it's not a deal-breaker for me.Bottom line:The price of this unit makes it too good to pass up. It's an easy choice and, while I hate to admit it, it was the main reason I bought this unit over the nicer original/classic that was nearly four-times the cost. Even with it's shortcomings, it's a good white noise maker, I'm keeping it, and I'm satisfied with the purchase.

It's simple, clean, shiny, and real stainless steel.  Very simple and quick to install.  As others have noted, the metal isn't as thick as the typical cast metal frames, but it works just fine and is plenty rigid once installed.I purchased two frames for both front and back plates on my car.I used the screw caps on my front plate, but I didn't use them on my back plate since I want to be able to remove the rear plate to clean off the registration stickers every few years, and I'm not sure I would be able to find a non-destructive way of taking those caps off. (Maybe super glue something to the inner cap to pull it off, then release the glue with heat?)Anyway, it's a nice looking frame that I expect to last forever.

I have both the Whynter ARC-12SD and this ARC-14S.  In summary, both have been great and I would recommend either, as long as you understand the limitations and downsides to an indoor portable air conditioner (primarily noise and reduced efficiency vs. window/wall unit).I originally purchased the ARC-14 last year to cool my 22' x 24' insulated garage because I had several servers running in the garage, but I have since consolidated machines and moved everything in my office--so I have more computer heat in addition to the summer heat.  So this year I am trying the ARC-14 in my office.  I only need air conditioning from June to September, and I only need to cool my home office, so a portable unit works well, is inexpensive, and I can store it out of the way in the garage during the winter.This unit is physically larger and has noticeably more cooling capacity than the ARC-12SD.  Last summer I used the 12SD in my home office, which is about 12' x 15'.  The 12SD did a decent job, but it would run for quite a while before it could cool the room from 82 to 78 degrees--perhaps 45 minutes.The ARC-14S is definitely more powerful, and the difference is noticeable in my office.  The room cools much quicker, and the compressor therefore shuts off sooner.  The ARC-14 seems to easily bring the temp down to 76 degrees in my office.However, the downside is that the ARC-14S seems noticeably louder in my office.  The compressor is lower frequency, but the combined compressor + fan noise just 3 feet away is loud enough that I wear Bose QuietComfort headphones to cancel out the noise.  I have laminate floors and a minimally furnished office, so there is no sound deadening.  In my carpeted living room, the ARC-14 doesn't seem as loud.  Just like the ARC-12, a lot of noise comes from the air flowing through the two hoses, so I put a large folded bath towel over the top of both the hoses, which dramatically reduces the high frequency noise.Aside from that, the other con is that this unit does not have a drain port to constantly drain the water.  Whynter says that this model does not need it--while that may technically be true, and the unit may run fine and not collect enough water to shut off, I found there is a downside.When the ARC-14 first runs and brings the room down from 82 degrees to 77 degrees, the relative humidity drops to 45 percent.  But when the compressor stops and only the fan runs, the humidity rises to 60 percent.  The room feels more humid.  So I'm wondering if the accumulated water in the unit is potentially adding moisture back into the room when the compressor turns off.While writing this review, I just watched the humidity read 60% when the compressor was off, and now that the compressor is running, the humidity reading dropped from 60% down to 51%.  So there are significant swings in humidity that I don't recall having with the ARC-12.I need to do some testing with the ARC-14 vs. the ARC-12 with a drain hose to see if constantly draining the water makes any difference with the room humidity.But if you have a room larger than 150 - 200 sq feet and you want faster cooling, I would still recommend the ARC-14 over the ARC-12.  The larger compressor makes a big difference.  When I researched portable and window AC units, the BTU recommendations seemed too low.  For instance, the Home Depot web site recommends 12,000 BTUs for a 400 sq ft room, which is completely unrealistic based on my experience.  If such a room is not fully enclosed and doesn't have great insulation, I know I wouldn't be satisfied with the ARC-12 in a room that large.

I just used one of these to hard wire a dash cam to my car.  The adapter seems well made and the wire is nice and thick.  I crimped the power lead for my Cellink B dash cam battery to the wire, plugged it into my fuse block, and it worked perfectly right away.I bought this pack in case I ever need one or two more, and the price for this 5 pack was only slightly more than a single one.Worked great, I'm very happy with it.

I have previously used suction-cup style phone holders, but my new 4Runner doesn't have a single flat surface on the dash for a suction cup, so I purchased this cup holder model.It works well, with a few very minor caveats.1. The plastic pieces in the base that expand to keep it tight in the cup holder are soft plastic, so they deform when they are tight.  It is holding just fine for now, but I don't know if this will be an issue over time.2. The clips at the bottom and sides hold my iPhone very securely.  But I have to squeeze the side clips very tight to get that last click, to make it snug on my iPhone 6.  Doing this every time I get in my car is getting annoying.  I may trim some of the rubber off the side pads to reduce the pressure a little.3. One of the rubber pads on the side clips fell off after less than two weeks.  I reattached it, but it just fell off again when I had the car washed and found it on the ground outside the car.  So I put a few drops of super glue on each pad and reattached it, so I'll see if the superglue will hold.Other than the downside of using up one of my two cup holders, this works very well and seems well designed.  Exactly what I was looking for.

While sitting in slow traffic on an Los Angeles freeway several years ago, an old Honda sedan started driving erratically and suddenly swerved across four lanes of traffic, right in front of me, with people frantically climbing out of the car, in the middle of the freeway, as the car was still moving.  I was very puzzled.  The car rolled into the barrier wall on the right side of the freeway as smoke started to pour out of the car.  Ahhh, that explained the circus act I just saw.At the time, I didn't have a fire extinguisher, so there was nothing I could do, and fortunately the people all got out of the car before it caught on fire.I've been meaning to get one ever since, and finally purchased this extinguisher to put in a new car I just purchased.  I haven't had a need to use it, so I can't yet comment on the effectiveness of the extinguisher, but the size is great.  I just kept it in the box, which tucks perfectly in a storage area in the back of my 4Runner.  Hopefully I'll never need to use it, but having seen a few car fires in LA, I know it does happen, so I'm happy to have an extinguisher around just in case.

This works well for groceries.  It has two loops on the top to attach to the plastic hooks in the car, and two plastic clips to attach to the metal D-rings in the bottom corners.As others have noted, the bottom edge isn't tight or tied down, so things do shift or slide when you open the rear door, and it doesn't stop objects behind the net from moving or potentially falling out when the door is opened.  But it works for my needs.

I've tried a few woven hats in the past, but they all itched or were uncomfortable, so I never wore them. I needed a warm cap for camping, so I tried the Turtle Fur based on the positive reviews.This hat is great.  It fits my big head well, is nice and warm, and best of all, it is super soft and comfortable.  It doesn't itch or irritate my forehead or ears at all.I was nice and warm and slept well on my weekend camping trip.  Highly recommended.

I bought a pair of these about 5 years ago from a local retailer.  I loved them and wore them for everything from gardening to moving furniture to hauling trash.  My wife even loves them and wears them instead of the woman-sized gardening gloves I bought for her.  After 5 years of solid use and abuse, including water, they are finally falling apart.  A finger has a hole and the leather is worn thin.I bought these on Amazon hoping they would be the same, but unfortunately they are slightly different and don't fit as well as my old ones.First, these are noticeably smaller.  My old gloves are Medium and are not tight at all, and I don't recall them being tight or snug when I first bought them.  The new ones are slightly tight and my fingers solidly touch the ends  of the fingers in the glove.  And they added some additional padding to the palm of the glove, which while nice in concept, makes the glove thicker, making the fit tighter and making it a little harder to feel and grip with the gloves.While I think the design and materials are great, the Medium size is now slightly too small for me.  I'm still reaching for my old worn out pair instead of using these new ones.I'm going to try a Large and see how they fit.UPDATE:  Despite the slightly small size, I started using the gloves for gardening work. I found that when they become damp, the fingers seem to stretch out and become more comfortable.  I suspect that my old pair stretched quite a bit over the years, so I am going to try and break these in a little more.

After trying several different impromptu methods for setting up a single iPad so that two kids could watch a movie on a long drive, I finally broke down and bought this.  Given the limitations of car interiors, it seems like a good solution that will work with most / all cars.It is a bit weird to install and fit the first time, but once you see how the pieces work and adjust, it's a simple process to install or remove.It is fairly light weight construction, so I'm not sure how it will hold up over several years or potential roughness from the kids, but the design seems sound and I was able to adjust it and tighten everything down so that the iPad was very secure, didn't shake, and didn't tilt.What is very nice is that it's easy enough to install and remove that I don't feel the need to keep it in the car.  I plan on only installing it when I know we have long road trips more than an hour or two.  The rest of the time I just store it in a cabinet in the house.

I was thrilled when I saw this DeWalt track router adapter.  I used to hate routing dados.  I don't have a table saw, so I have had to use my DeWalt router for dados.  I tried one of those "exact width" dado jigs, but it was very tedious to use.  I then tried a simple straight edge, but that is also tedious if you need a dado that is slightly wider than your router bit.  And when the router jumped or I wasn't applying pressure properly, the router would move off the straight edge slightly, messing up the dado.I own some Festool tools, so I looked into the Festool router + track solution, but the price of the total solution is absolutely insane.  I don't use a router nearly enough to justify that type of expense.And then I saw this track router adapter and I was thrilled.  The price for this adapter is dirt cheap by Festool standards, and the price for the DeWalt track is also very reasonable.  I bought both right away.I used the router adapter to cut dados in a plywood cabinet that I was building.  I marked the locations of the dados, set down the track, did some learning and fiddling to figure out where the track needs to be to get my bit in the right location, and then did a dry run, sliding the router across the width of the board to make sure it moved smoothly.  After adjusting the tensioning knobs and getting things dialed in, I turned on the power and gently pushed the router across the track.  The dados were absolutely perfect.  Perfectly straight and perfectly clean.  What a huge improvement over the jig and straight edge methods.  So much simpler, easier, and the results were unbeatable.Out of the box, the adapter may not slide smoothly on the track--Festool products can be the same way.  I put a little bit of Renaissance wax on the track and it made the adapter move much easier and smoother.  And the knobs and adjustments on this adapter are a bit odd and not nearly as refined and easy to adjust as a Festool design, but the two rods were very stable and once you figure out how to set it up for your router and workpiece, it works well enough.I also purchased the DeWalt track clamps. They aren't fancy, but they work well with the track.If dados are a hassle for you and you want an easier solution, I highly recommend this adapter and the DeWalt track.

These cables are great.  They are soft and flexible, and I really like the design of the snagless clip cover--it is much better than the "hooded" snagless clips.I replaced my entire rainbow mess of network cables with these using the appropriate lengths and the wiring looks so much cleaner now.Definitely recommended.

These cables are great.  They are soft and flexible, and I really like the design of the snagless clip cover--it is much better than the "hooded" snagless clips.I replaced my entire rainbow mess of network cables with these using the appropriate lengths and the wiring looks so much cleaner now.Definitely recommended.

My two daughters put these on their walls by themselves, to my surprise.  They are good quality and stick very well to the matte paint on the walls.  I don't know how well they would work on a glossier paint, but they seem well made and look nice.

I bought these to keep in my refrigerator and freezer.  They are low tech, but simple and effective.  You can check the temp at a glance and see the acceptable ranges using the color bands.  Much easier than digital alternatives.

I was skeptical of this trimmer, but given the tedious alternatives, I thought I would try it.While it is far from perfect, it is the best option I've found so far for trimming edge banding.  I found using a utility knife to be too tedious and inconsistent, especially on long boards.  A block plane was similarly tedious.  I only have a full size router, so I'm not about to use that for trimming.This tool does a fairly good job at trimming the bulk of the edge banding.  The challenge I have is getting consistent results.  Sometimes it produces a perfect cut and leaves a clean edge.  Other times I just can't get it to clean up an overhanging edge no matter how many passes I made.  I don't yet know if it is position, pressure, or something else.The one limitation is that if you have to use it on an intersection, it can't cut the final 1-2".  Not a big deal, but if you have a cabinet with several dado shelves, all of which are edge banded, it is tedious cleaning up that last piece on each side of the shelf.Despite these limitations, I have found it better than the alternatives.  I take off as much as I can with this trimmer, then clean up with a block plane or blade.

Very simple, relatively easy to use.  The 3/8 pair that I used were sized such that they didn't stay in the hole on their own, making it a little tricky to use in a few spots, but they worked just fine.

I'm on a mission to find a great countersink for woodworking.  So far I haven't found it, but this one is decent.I first tried the cheap DeWalt combined bit + adjustable countersink set.  Junk.  They wobbled and the teeth broke after using it a dozen times on plywood.  I am now resigned to using only dedicated countersinks.This Bosch countersink is obviously solid and strong, does not wobble, and appears to be well made, but the results are not very polished.  On plywood, the hole is not smooth--it seems to produce a "faceted" circle, which surprised me.  Apparently some people call it "chattering".  And the top edge of the countersink often wasn't clean--sometimes the veneer fibers would stick out around the hole like fuzz.But I will say that this countersink is relatively easy to control--it doesn't suddenly plunge into the wood like the DeWalt ones often would.  It is easy to produce a consistent countersink with slow consistent pressure.Next I'm going to try the counter sinks with the hole through them.

Like all of my other Freud router bits, this one is very sharp and worked well.  I had to make dados in over 30 feet of kiln dried 2x4s and this plowed right through the wood, packing shavings in the dado faster than my dust collection could remove them.As I always warn, use gloves whenever you remove a Freud bit from the box--the bits are often very tight and stick in the base, and you'll slice your hand open if you don't use gloves.

I am puzzled by all of the positive reviews of this coupler set.  I installed them on a new hose and blow gun and they leaked like crazy.  It was a constant large leak--not just when I moved the tool or angled the hose.The problem appears to be with the male connectors. All of them leak constantly when used with the included female connector.  The machining of the "ridge" appears to be slightly out of spec, causing the male connectors to leak with certain female connectors, including the Tekton female connector. The male connector doesn't leak when connected to my compressor, but it leaks with other female connectors.They look well made, but the leaking is so bad that they are unusable for me.The morning after posting this review, Tekton customer service posted a reply and they offered to send me a new set.  They certainly aren't making any money at this point by having to replace an $8 product, so the customer service is very impressive.  If you have any issues with their tools, try contacting them at support@tektontools.com.UPDATE: I received the replacement set yesterday, and they have the same problem.  The male connectors are unusable.  The female connector seems okay, and the threaded male coupler is okay, but all three male connectors leak.  I'm now using a spare male connector from a set I bought at Home Depot--that set works just fine, so I'll be buying them from Home Depot in the future after reading the reviews.

I think these oval closet rods have an interesting and different look and more character than the typical boring round closet rod.I just used them in a new closet organizer that I built.  They are easy to install and work great.  I used an inexpensive Harbor Freight metal cutoff tool to cut the rod to size for my closet.  The chrome is clean and the rods look great when installed.I am puzzled the high price on Amazon.  Rockler offers these for about six dollars each on their site and Rockler has 5 different lengths with three different finishes, so these should not be selling for over twenty dollars each.

As soon as they arrived, I put one of these in my dead G3.  It fit perfectly and installed easily.  I like that they come with the retaining ring, so now I'll have a few extra rings.I fired up my G3 and it has been hopping around my pool for the last two hours.  It seems that my pool pump is a little too powerful for the new diaphragm--I had to reduce my RPMs and adjust my valves to reduce the flow to the G3--which is a good thing.I'll see how long the diaphragm lasts, but at this price, I don't mind replacing them a few times a year.

While this DeWalt guide does work and you can get basic jobs done, the design has some flaws, and mine has a quality issue.When I first tested it on some scrap, it seemed great.  But only after using it on some real cuts did I see the flaws.First, while I appreciate the vacuum adapter, it got in the way, preventing me from making my full dados.  Fortunately, the plastic adapter can be removed, and in the case of my dado, it wouldn't help anyway.The second issue is with the single point of attachment to the black metal "base".  If you look at the photo, you'll see the thumbscrew in the center of the gray metal piece.  That is the only thing that is maintaining the position of the fence relative to the router.  While it has a fine adjustment knob, the threads on my knob didn't mesh with the threads in the gray metal bracket, so I could barely turn it, and I could see the threads getting flattened out.Using the fine adjustment knob became very frustrating, so I ended up using trial and error to get close.I would agree with the other reviewers that this is not a precision accessory.  If you do not need exact placement, it will probably work fine.  But if you need to have even 1/16" of precision and have to change the position several times during your project, I suspect you will be as frustrated and disappointed as me.If I need a router edge guide again, I will try the Bosch model recommended by another reviewer.  I don't think I'll bother to use this one again, unless it is for a project that doesn't require any precision.

This bit is HUGE. I think the photo is of the shorter 1" version, while this 42-204 model has a full 2" of cutting area.  It's a monster.But it's exactly what I needed to trim the edge of a 1.5" workbench top made from two pieces of 3/4 MDF.  Very smooth, very stable, and cut well.As always, wear gloves when trying to remove the bit from the case--the Freud cases often hold the bit pretty tight, so don't try and grab this bit with your bare hands.

I purchased this to replace a Penguino 7,500 BTU single hose portable unit that I bought used from a friend.  While the Penguino worked okay, it could barely cool a small 10x12 bedroom.  It would blow cold air and pump out very hot air through the exhaust hose, but the compressor ran constantly and it just never seemed to be able to cool the room with me and a few computers in it.I recently moved to a house that is older, has less insulation, and where my office has two 4' x 5' windows.  I knew the Penguino wouldn't cut it.  While the recommended BTU guidelines say that 12,000 BTU is overkill for my new 11x17 office, I didn't want something under powered, and I wanted to be able to move the unit to the living room, garage, or sun room and have it handle those rooms as well.After learning about dual hose portable AC units, I ordered this Whynter from Amazon based on the generally positive reviews.  When I received it, I let it sit in the box upright for a full 24 hours just to make sure that the compressor was happy.I then got it setup, got the hoses connected, plugged it in, and....nothing.  No lights, no sounds, no power, nothing.  The buttons on the front didn't do anything, and while the remote LCD display worked, the remote didn't turn the unit on either.  I triple checked the plug and reset it to make sure that it wasn't tripped.  I double checked my outlets, checked the voltage on the outlets, and even verified that there was electricity going up the cord using a non-contact voltage detector.  All seemed fine with my electricity.I called customer support, but they were closed since it was Sunday, so I left a VM and then emailed support.  They called me on Monday and explained that it was likely the cable to the display panel on the front of the unit.  They said that they have found that during shipping, the cable apparently gets disconnected.  They emailed me some instructions on how to open up the unit, remove the back and front cover, and check the cable.  I opened it up, and sure enough, the cable had fallen out.  I would hope that since they know about this issue that they will use a piece of tape or glue on future production runs to fix this issue.While plugging the cable back into the front display panel, I noticed that it had been pinched under the front cover, and this had ripped the insulation and exposed the wires.  I emailed a photo of the damaged cable to support, and the next day they shipped out a replacement cable and new display circuit board.  Two days later those parts arrived, I installed them, and got everything reassembled.  I then plugged it in and immediately heard a beep.  I turned it on and the front panel lit up.  The compressor kicked in, and cool air quickly started flowing.  All fixed.While that process took about a week to get through, I thought the customer service was very good.  They knew my problem as soon as I described it, sent me instructions so that I could fix it myself, and then sent me new parts.  It generally took a day to receive each reply, but they were responsive and helpful.  Some customers might not be comfortable taking apart the unit, but I didn't mind doing the fixes at all, as it was a lot easier than having to re-pack and return the unit.Now that I have it working, I like it, but it does have some fundamental drawbacks.  The drawbacks aren't necessarily the fault of this particular product, but rather the inherent challenges with portable AC units.While the compressor on this Whynter unit is quieter than the noisy clanky compressor on the Penguino, the Whynter generates quite a bit of noise when running.  The noise seems to be coming mostly from the fan and air flow of the exhaust hose.  Once the unit cools the room and temporarily drops into fan only mode, there is a huge drop in noise.Using two iPhone apps, I'm measuring about 70dB about 5 feet away from the unit in my office.  While 70 dB isn't necessarily "loud", the constant white noise and frequency of the sound feels very loud and is actually fatiguing in my office, which is currently sparsely decorated, so there is probably lots of sound reflection making it sound even louder.  It feels similar to being on a passenger airplane, but not quite as loud.  Fortunately I have some Bose QuietComfort noise cancelling headphones that I can wear--otherwise I would want ear plugs.  If you have a larger carpeted room with less noise reflection and can position the unit farther away from you, it would help.The Whynter is able to easily cool my 11x17 office from 84 degrees to 76 degrees and have the compressor shut off for several minutes before it turns on again.  That's pretty good compared to my old AC unit, especially considering the poor insulation and large windows in my new house.As for the dual hose design, while it may be more efficient than a single hose unit, the down side is that the hoses are very large, bulky, unsightly, and tedious to setup and position.  You basically can't put the unit closer than 2 feet from the window since the hoses are so large and stiff.  The larger hoses are obviously more efficient, but the downside is the appearance and bulk.  There is no hiding this thing.As for draining the water, I haven't yet dealt with that, but I'm okay with having to rig something up if necessary.  I'm going to call Whynter to ask about the "upper drain port" in the middle of the back of the unit to see if that can have a hose attached instead of having to fight with the bottom drain.The unit is relatively compact and light compared to my old air conditioner.  The plastic body and frame make it much lighter than a metal design, and it's smaller overall than the 7,500 BTU Penguino.Overall I'm happy with the unit so far.  I will probably only use it 3 months of the year for summer here in the Los Angeles area, so I'm hoping to be able to tuck it away in a closet during the rest of the year.UPDATE 1 - NOISE REDUCTION: After three days of running, the noise was frustratingly loud, so I tried to see if I could reduce the noise.  My impression is that there is a significant amount of noise just from the air flow out of the exhaust hose.  So I grabbed a large shower towel, folded it in quarters, laid it over the first foot of hoses, and immediately I noticed an improvement.  I then just covered the exhaust hose, and that was what reduced the sound. It doesn't dramatically reduce the overall volume, but it significantly reduces the highest frequency of the noise which is what was bothering me the most.I'm now going to look into some kind of hack to neatly wrap the exhaust hose with a towel or insulation to see if that works.  The one possible downside might be that by insulating the exhaust hose, it increases the temperature of the plastic hose and causes it to degrade faster.  But given my office layout, I need to try and quiet it down, so I'm okay with that consequence.UPDATE 2 - UPPER DRAIN PORT: On the back of the unit, near the middle, there is an additional plastic cap that holds a rubber stopper, which goes into a plastic port on the unit.  The instruction manual calls this the "Upper Drain Port", and later mentions in "Dehumidifying Mode" that it can be used for "continuous drainage".  I called Whynter customer service (866-949-6837) and the woman who answered confirmed that it can be used for continuous draining of the unit rather than the lower drain plug.I don't know if this is a new feature, but for all the people complaining about having to lift or tilt the unit to drain it, locate the ** Upper Drain Port ** on the back and give it a try.Unfortunately, despite the manual saying that "a garden hose" can be used for this port, the male threads on the port do not match my standard garden hose threads.  The diameter is correct, but the threads are slightly different, so I can only get a few turns before the threads tighten up. But it looks like it should be possible to rig up a piece of tubing and gasket that will work to allow draining outside or into a bucket.UPDATE 3 - WATER DRAIN SOLUTION: I went to Home Depot and found some parts to make a simple and effective water draining solution for the Upper Drain Port that uses gravity, no pump required.Here are the parts and the Home Depot SKU numbers, which cost about $13.3/4 Sch 40 PVC threaded female-female coupling (SKU 610798)Watts 5/8" ID x 3/4" MIP Nylon Hose Barb with 90 degree elbow (SKU 558915)Watts 3/4" OD, 5/8" ID x 10 ft. Clear Vinyl Tubing (SKU 702554)Optional: HDX 2 1/2 quart plastic All Purpose Mixing Container and lid (by the orange buckets at HD)The threads on the PVC coupling aren't exactly the same as either the Whynter drain port, or the Watts Hose Barb, but since there is no pressure involved, it works well enough.  Just be gentle and don't over tighten it.First, remove the plastic cap and rubber cork from the Upper Drain Port on the back of the unit (be ready for water to pour out), then gently thread the PVC coupling on to the drain port.  Then thread the plastic hose barb into the PVC coupling, pointing it downwards.  Then cut a piece of the clear vinyl tubing and attach it to the hose barb (I used about 15").  Point the hose into a container or bucket, and you are all set.This morning I had collected about 20 ounces of water after running for a few hours.UPDATE: August 2015: This AC unit has been working great this summer.  Over the winter, I had new windows installed and insulation blown into the exterior walls, so that has greatly improved the home office where I use this unit.  Although it does make a fair amount of noise, It is definitely quieter than the larger ARC-14 and does a good job for my office. Today it is 98 degrees and it is working very hard to keep the room temp at 78.  It has been running continuously, but is holding the temp steady. When I first used it this summer, after it had sat in the garage all winter, it did act a little funny, with the compressor not turning on for several minutes, but after that first day of use, it has been working fine.

Why, oh why, did I not buy this type of drip-free caulk gun years ago?I foolishly thought that all caulk guns were the same, so when the guy at Home Depot handed me their $3 model, I didn't think twice.  I must have wiped up a half gallon of caulk that kept oozing out of the tube even after I had stopped pulling the handle and even released the plunger.The reduced waste alone is enough to justify the price of this type of caulk gun.  It works great, has minimal drip, and is very well made.I highly recommend it, even if you only rarely use a caulk gun.

This switch works well, but what I didn't notice when I bought it was that it requires the use of a wireless "canopy" unit, which is included in the package for this model.I needed to replace a mechanical slider wall switch for my ceiling fan.  The switch box had been wired with an extra wire to use a hard-wired controller, so that's what I thought I was buying with this Lutron.  I was hoping to avoid having to climb up to the fan and wire in a canopy controller.Unfortunately, the canopy controller is required for this unit, so rather than return it, I just got on the ladder and installed the wireless unit on the fan.  The installation was easier than I expected, since my fan mount had enough room for the controller and wires.  I'm no electrician, but following the instructions, the installation was simple and relatively easy.  I just capped off my extra wire at the switch and at the fan, and was able to easily connect the other wires.The switch works great and I'm happy that I kept it.  It is much better than the "mechanical" slider switch that it replaced--the metal contacts on the slider switches burn and eventually start sizzling, so I prefer this solid state design.

I bought several of these to run 200mm fans to cool a home-made server cabinet.I read some negative reviews that the product couldn't power multiple fans, but I am able to run two 200mm fans without any issue.  I didn't try 3 or 4 fans--but with two fans, the power adapter seems to work just fine.They were inexpensive, so I bought a few extra to have as backups.

The physical device seems to work pretty well, at least for my needs.  But as others have noted, the software is pretty bad.  The software appears to work on a standard Windows PC, but the Chinese translations to English are often puzzling, and the software itself is pretty unrefined.One problem I had was that the software didn't work at all on Windows Server 2008 R2.  I purchased this product and the TEMPer unit with the external probe for two servers that I wanted to monitor.  I couldn't get the supplied software or the UTAC software to work at all on the servers.  I was finally able to get ThermoHID to work on both servers, although it is limited to only one sensor with the newer TEMPer units.ThermoHID seems to work fine and has all of the features I need, plus dozens more that I don't need.  It is a bit flaky, but when I used Compatibility Mode, it seems to work okay.As for accuracy, these units do not seem to be terribly accurate. Two of them gave readings that were a few degrees different than each other, and 3-4 degrees different than another thermometer I have.  Not knowing which was correct, I just used the Calibration feature in ThermoHID to have the TEMPer units match my stand alone thermometer.  Since I'm measuring the room temperature for my servers, I don't need the temp readings to be 100% accurate--I just wanted the two units to read about the same temp.

The physical device seems to work pretty well, at least for my needs.  But as others have noted, the software is pretty bad.  The software appears to work on a standard Windows PC, but the Chinese translations to English are often puzzling, and the software itself is pretty unrefined.One problem I had was that the software didn't work at all on Windows Server 2008 R2.  I purchased this product and the USB-only TEMPer unit without the external probe for two servers that I wanted to monitor.  I couldn't get the supplied software or the UTAC software to work at all on the servers.  I was finally able to get ThermoHID to work on both servers, although it is limited to only one sensor with the newer TEMPer units.ThermoHID seems to work fine and has all of the features I need, plus dozens more that I don't need.  It is a bit flaky, but when I used Compatibility Mode, it seems to work okay.

While I absolutely love the dust collection capability of the UDD 2, there is a serious static electricity problem with "version 1" and even "version 2" of this product.  If you buy, make sure you get the latest version with black cyclone or request the newer parts from Oneida.What I call "Version 1" did not have any conductive material on the translucent cyclone.  After a few Festool vacuums got fried, they realized they had a problem.In "Version 2" they added 1/2" strips of metallic tape to the cyclone and plastic hose connectors that they claimed had been "independently tested and verified" to connect to the vacuum ground to dissipate static electricity.  In my experience, this tape did not work well--I tested it and found that the overlapping layers of tape did not have conductivity.While using my Version 2 UDD, I was zapped repeatedly by static electricity whenever my TS55 hose touched my arm. Not comforting when pushing a saw through wood.  I called Oneida customer service and the woman basically ignored what I said, saying only that the UDD had been tested by a third party and that nothing was wrong with the product.  She emailed me the updated instructions, that did NOT come with my UDD, that had some additional brief instructions on how to make sure the metallic tape and other anti-static hacks were setup properly to avoid static discharge issues.  I reset every connection and had to use a piece of tape to connect a wire to the UDD box (since their instructions didn't relate to the CT26 at all, and there was no extra metallic tape to follow their instructions).  After that, I haven't been shocked again, thankfully, but I would not recommend Version 2 of the product to anyone.They have since released what I call a "Version 3", which has the black cyclone.  It looks like they may also have designed a new hose for the cyclone to get rid of the hacked together hose connector.  To their credit, I just received a letter from them today saying they are offering the new components at no charge.  FINALLY.The problem is that until you open the box, you will not know which version you purchased.  But if you do get the translucent cyclone or older parts, you can request the newer parts.They have a form on their web site to order the parts:www (dot) oneida-air (dot) com / udd-partsOr call them at 866-387-8822One last critical point:  If you use the UDD on a Festool vacuum, you void your Festool warranty.  Oneida states this loudly and clearly somewhere in their updated documentation or on their web site.  Obviously Festool is not enamored with their product and the fried circuit boards it has apparently caused.  I didn't know about voiding the warranty until well after I had started using the UDD.With that very significant gripe complete, I will say that the dust collection is phenomenal.  I have zero reservations shoving my Festool CT26 hose into a giant pile of wood chips and saw dust.  It sucks them up, they spin in the cyclone, and then are dropped into the box without loading up the vacuum.The UDD box plus cyclone on top of the CT26 does make it pretty large and bulky, so I wouldn't recommend it if you regularly transport your vacuum--it would be a pain to take off and put back on repeatedly.  But it works fine for my garage and is much more convenient and space saving then a separate cyclone or dust collection device.  I was considering getting the standard "bucket" style Dust Deputy, but the guy at Woodcraft pointed out that I'd have to drag the bucket everywhere with the vacuum.  I'm glad he made that point--the UDD is very convenient to roll around on top of the vacuum.Once I get my "Version 3" parts, I will see if they have done a better job with fit and finish and if they have properly addressed the static issue.UPDATE: August 2014:  I received the Anti Static "Retrofit Kit" from Oneida that includes the black anti-static cyclone. I swapped out the cyclone, added the mesh wire straps to the clips on the dust collection box, and took out my digital multi-meter to verify conductivity between all of the parts and from the hose to the grounding pin on the vacuum plug.While I now finally showed conductivity for all of the Dust Deputy parts, the one item that did not have full conductivity was actually the Festool hose that came with my TS55.  The  hose material itself was conductive, and the large plastic connector to the vacuum was conductive, but oddly, there was no conductivity between the hose and the connector.  So I got conductivity between the ground prong on the plug all the way to where the hose connects to the cyclone, but then there was a gap from the hose connector to the hose itself.  This isn't Oneida's fault, and I'm surprised that the Festool hose didn't have full conductivity.To address this, I got a 2 foot piece of standard copper electrical wire and removed the insulation (or you could use the bare ground wire from some Romex).  I looped one end of the wire a few times around the Festool hose by the cyclone, putting the wire in the corrugated channel in the hose.  I then wrapped the other end of the wire around the top vertical port on the cyclone a few times.  With that wire connection between the Festool hose and the cyclone, I now get full conductivity from the end of the vacuum hose to the ground prong on the plug.I'm now, finally, happy with "Rev 3" of the Ultimate Dust Deputy II.  Given that I've tested and verified the conductivity of all of the parts and the entire vacuum, I'm not particularly worried about static electricity.As long as you are comfortable personally verifying the conductivity of the entire solution, and utilizing the "copper wire" hack to ensure conductivity with the Festool hose, I think it is now a good solution.Upgrading my review to 4 stars.

I have a garbage disposal but over time I’ve realized you can’t and shouldn’t stick everything in the there. The catcher that comes with the sink sucks because it gets stuck.This one is made of silicone and stainless steel. The silicone is good because it is easy to get under it and the stainless steel middle is good with catching all the crap. The silicone is also good because it doesn’t scratch up the sink when it is just in the sink. It isn’t rock science using putting this in the sink, it does the job and would recommend it. It fits the standard sink and does what it is suppose to. I received this product free of charge in exchange for my unbiased and honest review. All opinion stated are 100% my own and has not been swayed.

If you own an apple product you know all too well how many charging cords we go through. What I look for in a good cord is does it last longer than a month, is it long enough to charge and use the phone at the same time, will it sync to my itunes, and my favorite does it not show it is not a supported accessory.The Beam charging cord comes in 3 3ft long charging cord. I’ve had it over a month so I can do this review. Question 1 does it last longer than a month? Yes, I bought it on 09/07 and today is 10/12 and the cord is still working without the turtle neck (meaning no sign of it separating from the plug). Question 2 is it long enough to use while charging, the answer is yes at 3ft it is long enough to charge while laying in bed with plenty of extra cord. Question 3 does it sync, they answer is yes works just as good as the original. Last question does it support my device, the answer is yes. Being apple certified means it will work without the annoying message saying it won’t charge because it doesn’t support the device.Overall this work as describes. I never expect a cord to last longer than a month and so far so good. I received this product free in exchange for my unbiased and honest review. All opinions stated are 100% my own and has not been swayed.

I’ve battled acne all my life. I am also looking for something to replace my current face wash that contains benzoyl peroxide, which dries out my face. I use it because it seemed to be the only thing that worked.I’ve currently been using the Relogy 2 part system and a bonus pore exfoliating cleansers which doesn’t contain any benzoyl peroxide but 0.5% salicylic acid. Step one is a foaming cleanser. I use 2 pumps for my entire face with warm water, followed by cold water to rinse and close my pores back up. I use this with the kongac sponge which is all natural. Step 2 is the skin balancing lotion with coconut milk. It comes in a pump which I love, there is no contamination with opening and closing a tub. I only use 1 pump for my entire face and it smells so good just like coconut. It keeps my face hydrated without being shiny. Allow it to dry completely before applying makeup. It doesn’t affect my makeup application. I use the pore cleansing exfoliating scrub once a week. It has tiny micro beads that deep cleanses the skin. I only use it once a week because over using sometimes causes break out. Don’t scrubs hard the micro beads will do the work and just let the water do the work when rinsing off. It has minty smell and is very cooling to the skin.Overall since using Relogy I haven’t had any breakout and my skin is glowing without the over drying that comes with benzoly peroxide. I received this product free in exchange for my unbiased and honest review. All opinions stated are 100% my own and has not been swayed.

Self balancing wheels are the new trend. Honestly after getting mine I really think they are super awesome.First the bad my box has a white board on it when I ordered a blue board. I was hoping while I opened it that it was a blue board and I wouldn’t have to return it. When I opened the box it was in fact the blue board and the battery comes in 2 pieces that connect. When I tried plugging the charger in the board I looked at the prongs and the holes on the charger and when I plugged it in it didn’t fit. I immediately contacted them thinking it didn’t work and they emailed me back to help me. Come to find out I needed to line up the plug looking at the little dent that tells you to turn the plug then plug. You can look at this 2 ways. 1 I need to read instructions or 2 they need to make the plug the same way it is on the board, buy after reading the instructions its clear in the picture that I had it wrong. If you’re like me and don’t read instructions and what to blame someone else before getting the right information, READ INSTURCTIONS.After I charged it for a few hours it was fully charged and ready to go. The on button is that a bottom. Once on it lights up and ready to go. I was able to zoom around the house and walking the dog is a breeze. I love the lights in the front, now the lights come on when turned on and when you have your foot on each side. If you have no experience on skateboards, wake boarding or any type of recreational sport that requires balancing it will take a little time getting use to. I personal don’t so it has taken me over a week to get on without falling, but my fiancé is into wake and snow boarding it took him all of 10 seconds to figure it out. Even though it’s not Bluetooth which personal I like because I don’t want to hear his music while he’s riding.Overall we love this thing and I’m planning on buying more for the entire family. It works as described. I received this product at a discounted rate in exchange for my unbiased and honest review. All opinions stated are 100% my own and have not been swayed.

I have super long hair and love a tight curl. The Xtava spiral curl is something that takes getting use to. When you turn it on it there is just one no temperature setting of any kind, no high, medium or low. On the instructions it says it goes up to 400F.I don’t suggest taking big sections of hair at a time. From my experience you need to do small sections at a time. If you have long hair past your bra line, you will find that this curling want will only get the tips. This is really meant for medium to shorter length hair. It does give a beach wave look.It is time consuming because you have to do little sections at a time, but it is well worth it. The curls are beautiful. Just like anything else practice makes perfect. I do recommend it for medium length hair or shorter but for us long hair woman, it will only really get the ends.The few things I would change would be temperature options. Whether it be high, medium and low or setting a your own degree. Also if the barrel could rotate more to for people with longer hair.I received this product free in exchange for my unbiased and honest review. All opinion stated are 100% my own and has not been swayed.

Every day I can count on my dog barking at all the hummingbirds in our yard. The kit comes with everything you need to start with including great instructions. The top of the feeder is a bright red cap with a yellow flower and inside that flower is the little opening for the bird feeder. The first few nights I left it out there on its own because my dog usually scares them away with all the barking. In the morning when I could hear them, I would run to go check and see if any birds went to it. It took a couple of days but finally I saw a bird feeding from it. Before I could grab my camera, here comes the dog barking and scared the bird away. Even if you can’t get the bird to come directly to you, I do like watching from my window. Check all that apply:1. You love music.2. You want to be able to crank up the volume without disturbing your roommates/officemates.3. Money is no option.If all of these apply to you, look no further. The Fostex TH900 is superb in every regard: comfort, build quality, and of course sound.I work in an open office environment, with a lot of background chatter, so I've always sought headphones that could let me focus on my music while I work throughout the day. Comfort, isolation, and sound quality are my three priorities, in that order. Previously, I wore the Beyerdynamic T5p, which is also excellent, but which unfortunately broke after 3 years of regular use. The T5p has a loose, flimsy feel to it, so it wasn't entirely surprising, though it was disappointing to have to seek out a replacement. The TH900 came highly recommended by the audiophile community (moreso than the T5p), and I was delighted by what I found: A headphone with all the virtues of the T5p that feels built to last a lifetime.Comfort-wise, the TH900 is superb, with incredibly soft synthetic leather cups and a spring mechanism that distributes their weight evenly around your ears. Despite their bulk and pressure, they feel light and breathable. I find most headphones exhausting after an hour, tops. But I could wear the TH900 all day long.The wooden cups give the TH900 excellent isolation—about the best you'll get in a full-sized headphone (as opposed to an in-ear). I can turn up my music to near-piercing levels without bothering the colleague at the desk next to mine.And perhaps it goes without saying that the sound quality is amazing. The TH900 is never shrill, which makes it ideal for extended listening.For the opinion of an audiophile who is far less easily impressed than I am, I'd recommend reading David Mahler's review of the TH900 in his famous "Battle of the Flagship Headphones" article. As he sums it up: "The TH900 is a very versatile headphone, capable of sounding good with every genre." Coming from him—a connoisseur of luxury headphones—that's strong praise.

This is a decent dock, designed to be compatible with all Lightning-powered iPhones/iPads. It comes with its own cable. There are no problems with the Lightning technology here. However, there is a more mundane problem: In order to provide compatibility with open-bottom cases, there's an extra 1cm or so of space between the Lightning plug and the back of the dock. What this means is that if your device is uncased, you can't just press it against the back of the dock and slide it down. Instead, you have to carefully line up your device's Lightning port with the dock's plug. Since the whole point of a dock is to be more convenient than plugging in a Lightning cable, this little bit of extra effort is disappointing.Aesthetically, the dock is nothing to write home about. The grey-and-red color scheme feels washed-out. The plug wobbles slightly, making it difficult to tell whether the device is precisely centered.All of these are nitpicks, but docks are luxuries. Why bother to get one that doesn't feel first-rate?

Pros: Cheap, fully functional (no warnings experienced when connecting it to recent-model Apple devices).Cons: Thick plastic around the Lightning plug means that it won't fit in some docks/cases, poor aesthetics compared to authentic Apple cable (looks worn-out right out of the box; why is the "M" on just one side of the Lightning plug when the connector is symmetrical?)The thick plug is a major "gotcha." If you need a cable that will fit through an accessory with a hole that barely fits around the authentic Apple Lightning plug, this one won't work for you.
Good texture and absorbency. Just the right size. Reasonable price.
The Alex + Ada trilogy is remarkably good. Taken as a whole, it tells a smart, original, good-hearted story, accompanied by beautiful art. I recommend it to anyone who likes graphic novels.

This is an excellent piece of historical non-fiction aimed at young readers (ages 9–12). The prose is clear and straightforward, never condescending to the book's target demographic. The narrative is engaging and well-researched. And the author does a fine job with the delicate task of describing segregation, the essential historical backdrop of the story, without sermonizing or resorting to hyperbole. He simply lets the facts drive the narrative, and the facts are fascinating.Highly recommended for readers of all ages.

It's very difficult for me to say, after consuming this supplement at the recommended dose (2 pills/day), whether it's had any effect. I would say that it definitely has not improved my skin, though one would expect such an improvement to be very gradual. The more interesting question is whether it's done anything for my joints. I'm young, but I've always experienced (painless) popping and cracking while making certain movements. Since starting the hyaluronic regimen, those sounds seems to have dissipated. I remain skeptical of the benefits of hyaluronic acid, but if those irritating sounds return after I go off the supplement, I may buy another bottle.

The idea of an air purifier with built-in Febreze makes sense for bathrooms. Febreze is uniquely adept at covering up foul odors, while an air filter is the best way to pull potentially harmful bacteria out of the air.In practice, though, this unit isn't much use. For a small fraction of the price, you could get a Febreze plug-in. Meanwhile, the air filter—note that "HEPA-type" is a marketing term meaning that that the filter doesn't meet HEPA standards—is underpowered and over-obtrusive. Even on the lowest setting, the internal fan emits an unsubtle, high-pitched hum. And at that setting, it's barely moving any air. An adaptive fan (which would remain silent until, say, a toilet flushes in the vicinity) would be far more useful.In short, the Febreze Air Purifier is a clever concept, but the execution here is underwhelming.
Great hand-feel, perfect thickness for wiping up liquids, a nice modern look... this kitchen towel has it all! Recommended without reservations.

The Fluance Fi30 advertises that it "automatically pairs your Bluetooth device when in range." That sounds like a cool feature, but it leads to a lot of annoyances:* Let's say you have two devices that you've paired with the speaker before, a phone and a tablet. You want to pair the phone, but the tablet is already paired. So you have to unpair the tablet before you can pair the phone. (Trying to pair the phone while the tablet is already paired will just give you a generic Bluetooth connection error.) The more devices you have, the more frustrating this becomes.* Most Bluetooth speakers have a button that you have to press to allow new devices to be paired. With the Fluance, anyone can pair a new device at any time (as long as no device is already paired). So if, say, you live in an apartment, any of your neighbors can—intentionally or accidentally—pair their device with the speaker and use it. There's no solution other than powering off the speaker. And, of course, when you power it on, it'll try to auto-pair with their device again.* The speaker makes a (LOUD) jet engine-like noise every time a device is paired or unpaired, exacerbating these pairing annoyances.In the end, I decided to return this speaker and instead get a Logitech Bluetooth Audio Adapter, which has much better pairing behavior: no auto-pairing, requires a button for pairing, and multiple devices can be paired simultaneously (though only one can stream audio). It's a tiny device and you can connect it to any speaker with an aux in port. All-in-one Bluetooth speakers are great in theory, but their designers tend not to put much thought into how Bluetooth pairing works in the real world.

These are powerful cleaning products, as you'd expect from the Clorox brand name. Although bleach-free, they do leave a strong bleach-like smell in the air, so be sure to use them only in well-ventilated areas and either use gloves or wash your hands thoroughly after touching them. The smell is so strong that it seeps from the box as well. Also be aware that you need to run some water on them in order for them to work.With those caveats out of the way, these are an easy way to clean virtually any surface.

The presentation isn't exactly luxurious, and I'm baffled as to why the different chocolates are all mixed together (if you're doing a tasting, you'll have to sort them yourself), but what really matters is that you're getting a good amount of high-quality chocolate and a unique suggestion for how to enjoy it.
