The single suction cup simply isn't sufficient to keep the basket from falling down—even when it's empty. Additionally, the basket is too large, even for unusually large soap bars. In any sink or shower, it's going to feel obtrusive.

Kelly Link is a writer's writer, someone who plays with words and narrative structures in ways that are likely to go over casual reader's heads. For some, this provides an intoxicating challenge. For others—and I find myself in this category—it's admirable but frustrating. At their best, Kelly Link's stories work as Neil Gaiman-esque fables, with everyday characters dealing with unexpected and magical occurrences. But whereas Neil Gaiman can always be relied on to deliver some kind of payoff—a twist, a revelation, or at least a punchline—Kelly Link's stories tend to taper off, leaving readers like myself unsatisfied. For certain readers (Neil Gaiman among them), Kelly Link's unconventional writing is a breath of fresh air. But if your tastes tend more toward the mainstream, Get In Trouble is not the short story collection for you.

This is a good night-time moisturizer. It doesn't have the annoyances of others I've tried: it's fragrance-free; it has a rich texture yet applies evenly; and it doesn't contain any ingredients that irritate my skin or eyes. I can't really say anything to the "brightening" claim, but it certainly moisturizes effectively.My one quibble is the jar lid, which feels loose even when screwed on all the way. If I ever traveled with this stuff, I'd worry about it bursting open. For home use, it's fine.

There's nothing quite like a good cup of English Breakfast tea in the morning. At only $2/ounce, this particular blend is remarkably inexpensive for tea of this quality. If you have a daily tea habit, I highly recommend it.

This is a truly excellent blender. First off, it has an elegant look and feel that's perfectly suited to a modern kitchen. It also has a relatively low height, so it fits easily on the counter under my cabinets. Second, it's one of the most powerful blenders on the market—Blendtec is well known for their "Will It Blend?" videos. And third, Blendtec is a solid company that stands by their products.After nearly 3 years of frequent use, my blender developed a motor problem. I called Blendtec's 800 number and was promptly connected with a support representative. After a brief and polite chat, they offered to send me a replacement. I received it a few days later, along with a pre-paid label with which to send back the old one. So when Blendtec advertises a 7-year warranty, they're not kidding. Treat this blender well, and it's going to serve you well for a very long time.

This is pretty much what I expect from a protein bar: as sweet as candy, followed by an acrid aftertaste that reminds you that what you're eating is a cocktail of artificial sweeteners and texture agents stirred in with pure protein.I was offered these to review after giving a positive review to the MET-Rx Prime peanut butter and banana bars. The Met-Rx Prime bars contain only natural ingredients, and the result is a better experience. Both bars are just vehicles for getting ~20g of whey protein into your stomach, but the natural bar tastes much more like food, doesn't leave a bad aftertaste, and doesn't crumble (the Pure Protein bars leave a trail like a powdered donut as you bite them). The MET-Rx Prime bars aren't perfect—they're too chewy—but I'd much rather eat those than these.Really, though, I don't feel like I need protein bars in my life. After a vigorous workout, how about a handful of nuts?

Does the world need a reusable Ziploc? The motivation here is admirable, and the product has a high-quality feel, but it lacks one essential feature: easy-to-clean. Yes, it's advertised as machine-washable (as long as you set your machine to "cold")... but it's a bag. How effectively can a dishwasher wash a bag? Not well enough to prevent that bag from smelling like last week's tuna fish sandwich, I fear.A simple, easier-to-clean solution already exists: Tupperware. And by Tupperware, I mean all resealable plastic boxes/tubs. Yes, they're slightly heavier/bulkier than bags, but they also have the advantage of preventing your sandwich from being smushed. And with their smooth corners and separable lids, they're truly easy to clean. In a world full of reusable plastic sandwich boxes, I don't see the Re-Zip concept taking off.

With previous iPhone generations, I've never felt the need for a protective case. The iPhone 6 is different. With its round sides, the phone always threatens to slip out of my grip. With its awkwardly protruding camera, it won't lie flat on a table, and I constantly worry about the lens getting scratched. And the big screen makes me more concerned than ever about a drop leading to cracking. So I'd been giving serious thought to buying a case when, luckily, I was offered the Silk Stealth Armor Tough Case to review.And it's a terrific case. It looks very sleek, exactly as pictured. It's sturdy, yet light and flexible enough to put on and remove without too much effort. It protects every part of the phone, yet keeps everything accessible. The designers have clearly paid a lot of attention to detail on that front; for instance, the hole around the headphone jack is wide enough that you shouldn't have a problem even with L-shaped plugs. Also, because the case is far enough from the edges of the screen that "swipe from the edge" gestures will work fine.I personally don't care for the adhesive screen cover that the case comes with, but I've never liked any kind of iPhone screen cover, and it's purely optional. If you're worried about scratch damage, use the screen cover. If you're comfortable having your phone's bare screen exposed, don't. Either way, the Stealth Armor Tough Case will keep your phone safe from serious damage.All in all, this is a

Simon Rich's latest collection of humorous short stories is second only to B.J. Novak's extraordinary One More Thing among the best of 2014. In addition to the title-inspiring stories about the foibles of privileged millennials (Simon Rich included), it includes one of the funniest New Yorker pieces in recent memory, "Guy Walk Into A Bar."Every story in this book is either funny, very funny, or extremely funny. There isn't a dud in the bunch.

Given the deeply discounted price, I was pleasantly surprised by the high quality and great fit of this V-neck. If you're looking for a good light-weight sweater and you have a slim build, look no further.

I've been using these disposable wipes to keep my eyeglasses clean for years. The difference between them and the standard spritz-and-microfiber solution is dramatic. It's not just convenience; it's clarity. No streaks, no specks of dust will remain after using one of these little wipes. If you wear eyeglasses, I highly recommend them.

This is a beautiful stainless steel spoon that's great for tea aficionados, especially those (like myself) who use the wonderful Teavana PerfecTea tea maker. A heaping spoonful provides just the right amount of tea leaves to accompany the 16oz. of water that fill the PerfecTea.

This lotion has a pleasant feel to it, moisturizes well, and has not inflamed my acne-prone skin. My only complaint is that it has a thick texture, making it difficult to spread evenly or rub into my skin completely. But this is a minor complaint in an otherwise excellent product.

In Search of Stupidity is a snarky business history revolving around the personal computer, from its invention in the late '70s to its ubiquity in the late '90s. While most stories focus on the winners, here we see the losers make catastrophic mistakes again and again. Of course, the "stupidity" involved is usually just rational decision-making under a set of assumptions that turned out to be false, such as IBM famously failing to realize that by allowing Microsoft to develop the OS for their PC, they were ceding control of the whole platform.Chapman, who worked at various software companies during those turbulent years, is happy to point fingers and laugh, but it's hard to infer any broader insights from these stories. After all, Chapman himself is hardly clairvoyant: He uses Apple's computers  and their devotees as a running joke throughout the book. Today, 1 in 4 computers sold is a Mac, not to mention Apple's dominance of the smartphone and tablet categories that they invented just a few years after In Search of Stupidity was published.Overall, I enjoyed In Search of Stupidity as a light-hearted look back at a fascinating time in the tech world. I just wish it had more substance.

For the last 3 years, I've owned a RabbitAir MinusA2, and it's dramatically improved the air quality in my apartment, all but eliminating the old building's musty odor. I received the Coway air purifier to review, so I'll attempt to compare the two. I don't have any basis for measuring performance, so I'll focus on features and aesthetics.The Coway features 3 layers of filters: a washable pre-filter (for dust and hair), a carbon odor filter, and a HEPA filter for tiny particles. That's a good, minimal design for high-quality air filtration. The RabbitAir has all of those plus two more: a "medium" filter between the pre-filter and the HEPA, and a "custom" filter tailored toward whatever type of microparticle you're most worried about. I'd say that anything beyond HEPA + carbon filtration is overkill, but those with certain allergies may disagree. If that's you, take a close look at RabbitAir's custom filters.Both the Coway and the RabbitAir can automatically adjust their fan speed, from near-silent to about 50dB (roughly the volume level of a normal conversation), based on air quality measurements. This feature could be very annoying if it were implemented poorly, but both devices actually work quite well. Both stay quiet enough that I can keep one in my bedroom and never be woken up by fan noise. Both stay at near-silent level most of the time, only kicking into overdrive when I'm cooking (because of the smoke) or vacuuming (because of the dust). I'm impressed at the technology involved here. I should mention that the RabbitAir can also be adjusted with a remote control (the Coway doesn't have one), but I never use it.The only clear win for the RabbitAir is it looks. The Coway is a decent-looking appliance, but the RabbitAir is friendlier and less obtrusive. While the Coway is curvy in the front and boxy in the back (like an old CRT TV), the RabbitAir is flat and easy to keep flush against a wall or in a corner. I'll also say that the RabbitAir's filters are a bit easier to install: it took a little bit of difficulty to snap the Coway's into place.In summary, I don't like the Coway quite as much as I like the RabbitAir, but it has 90% of the RabbitAir's features at half the price. If money is no option, spring for the RabbitAir. But if you're looking for the sweet spot in price-to-performance, the Coway might just be it.

I received the Assorted Herbal Teas  to review. It's exactly what I'd expect from Twinings: flavorful teas at a reasonable price. The Pom-Raspberry is sweet (but not sweetened). The Orange & Cinnamon Spice is strong with cinnamon, but doesn't oversteep. The Pure Chamomile is, well, chamomile. The Bedtime Blend is my least favorite, combining chamomile with spearmint—good try, but contrary to popular belief, mint doesn't make everything better.These teabags are a good deal, and the assortment has enough options to keep any caffeine-averse guest happy and warm.

I received this item to review, and compared it with my existing Simplehuman Adjustable Shower Caddy.The Simplehuman is a more expensive product, and it looks that way, with a beautiful stainless steel gleam. The InterDesign opts for simplicity: 4 equal-sized baskets, all metal with a matte finish.There's no soap caddy, which seems like an oversight. But then, most showers have room for a soapdish. Or perhaps you use body wash.My only serious complaint is that the single suction cup is nowhere near sufficient to hold the shower caddy in place. The slightest nudge (say, from the shower hose) causes the caddy to wobble on the axis of freedom that the suction cup provides. An only slightly harder nudge causes the suction cup to come loose. As much as I like the simple symmetry as the single suction cup in theory, in practice, a shower caddy that mounts at the hose should have at least 2 suction cups. Or, you could opt for an even simpler and less obtrusive solution: A mesh shower caddy that hangs on the shower curtain. InterDesign makes one, and it costs half as much. I'd give that a try first.

This book is a rarity: A story revolving around computer security that's both exciting and accurate. Anyone who wants to know what much-hyped words like "cyberwarfare" really mean must read this book. Zetter has a great understanding of computer security and a sharp eye for important technical details. The book vividly describes every aspect of the Stuxnet attack, without losing sight of its global context.Countdown to Zero Day is likely to be the most comprehensive account of Stuxnet until the NSA files surrounding its creation are declassified.

This is, without a doubt, the sharpest novel on the subject of dating that I've ever read. Yes, it has things to say on other subjects as well—the state of higher education today, how quick we are to categorize people, the BuzzFeed-ification of the intellectual essay—but it is, first and foremost, a story of a relationship, and the author's insights in that context are boundless. For anyone who is young, bright, single, and lives in a city, this is a must-read.
Really great feel on my fingers. I was using Elixir Mediums before, and haven't noticed any compromise in tone from the lower gauge. I'm going to stick with these.

The main thing I look for in a mouthwash is texture and rinsability. Some mouthwashes are very thin and watery, which makes them feel ineffective. Colgate Optic White goes in the opposite direction, with a very thick foam that works well at cleansing your mouth and removing odors, but will also coat your tongue, gums and cheeks with a layer of gel that's difficult to rinse away. It makes sense that, for whitening, this mouthwash would have to stick to your teeth, but that stickiness has the unpleasant effect of leaving you with a mouthful of chemicals. To me, that tradeoff doesn't seem worthwhile.

As other reviewers have pointed out, this is definitely not heavy-duty tape. It's not as good for packing and shipping as other 3M tapes, and it's more expensive. Unless you really need to add a "Check Seal Before Accepting" message all over a ton of packages, this isn't the tape for you.
This stuff is excellent. A little bit goes a long way to eliminate frizz (this small tube should last months). And unlike other products I've tried, I've never had any problems with residue.

Countless players (myself included) have been made into competent tournament Texas Hold'em players by the classic Harrington on Hold'em books. A decade later, Harrington has updated those classic works for today's tournament scene and condensed the result into a single, all-new volume.Actually, Harrington on Modern Tournament Poker is more of a sequel than a revision: It's organized differently (more on that later), and it's dropped some of the early sections that made it approachable to true beginners. This is an intermediate book, one you'll get the most out of after playing a tournament or two and wondering, "What went wrong?"The original Harrington books were a gentle introduction in part because common techniques like bluffing and slow-playing were relegated to the second volume, so that the first could focus purely on making reasonable value bets. The new Harrington is broken down instead into the different phases of a hand: pre-flop, the flop, the turn, and the river. At first, this structure is a bit jarring, but it has the advantage that it allows you to look up any scenario you've experienced and find Harrington's answer. "Should I have called my opponent's bet on the turn?" "Should I have led out on the river?"A concluding section contrasts Harrington's prescribed style of play (tight but imaginative) with the now-ubiquitous LAG style, and offers some basic recommendations for playing against the LAG players you've identified at your table. Page-for-page, this may be the most valuable section of the book. Unfortunately, it's very short and doesn't cover ever situation.Still, this is a truly great poker book that should satisfy the many players who've been waiting to sink their teeth into a more advanced volume that maintains the virtues of the Harrington on Hold'em series: readable prose, well-explained reasoning, and a plethora of useful example hands. No one else writes about poker the way Harrington does.
I use these for miscellaneous household polishing: mirrors, kitchen counters, my guitar. They work perfectly well—no lint. The price seems reasonable.

I love my Manduka Black Pro yoga mat. It's perfect—except for hot yoga, where it becomes a slip-and-slide. That's where a mat towel comes in. I thought the Gaiam would suffice, and it's certainly an improvement over the bare mat surface, but it still gets a bit slippery. Plus, the 68" length is a bit short for me. If I get another mat towel, I'm going to spring for the Manduka eQua.

A picture is worth a thousand words. In business, pictures of data can be a powerful tool for making decisions, both big and small. But which data do you visualize, and how? Therein lies the challenge that The Visual Organization helps answer through a series of case studies. Take inspiration from these examples, and you'll be able to use "big data" fruitfully in your own business.

Back in 2006, I splurged on Shure's top-of-the-line SE530 in-ear headphones, priced at $500. They offered superior clarity and dynamic range, thanks to a tiny tweeter and two woofers (aka a "3-way driver" design), making them one of the best IEMs of their time (and still very good all these years later). With the XBAH3, Sony is now offering a similar 3-way design with similar audio quality, with a lighter yet smartly-balanced design, at half the price. To sweeten the deal, they've included a detachable cable with built-in controls for your iPhone.I'm very impressed by these. If you're looking for some great IEMs under $400, look no further.

I have a SimpleHuman Adjustable Shower Caddy, a product that costs nearly twice as much as the InterDesign Hanging Caddy. The SimpleHuman is more obtrusive (getting in the way of the showerhead) and requires more maintenance (its suction cups come loose, its stainless steel rusts). SimpleHuman is a great brand, but the hanging caddy is, quite simply, the better design for holding shampoos and other shower knickknacks. It lies flat against the shower curtain and doesn't interfere with my ability to open or close it. The pockets make it easy to "feel for" whatever item you need. Need more storage? Get a second one!This is, quite simply, the best solution I've seen yet for the problem of shampoo storage. The only reason I'm giving it 4/5 stars is that there are cheaper products with similar capabilities, such as the Maytex Mesh Bath Shower Organizer.

Because they're one-size-fits-all, they're going to be loose around your hands (unless you have very large hands), so you don't get any more precise control than you would get with a microfiber cloth you hold normally. And, of course, there's a certain dorkiness factor on top of the premium price. So I'm not crazy about them. However, as other reviewers have said, their texture makes them better for dusting many household surfaces than a flat microfiber would be. If that's something you do often, they may be worth the investment.

I wouldn't say that the detergent itself is anything special, but the dissolvable packets are an ingenious novelty. You just pull one out of the bag and drop it in. No more leaked liquid or powder finding its way all over your laundry room!The only reason I haven't given it 5 stars is the "Fresh Scent." It's not a particularly bad scent, but I much prefer unscented products.

Though this cleanser touts itself as "gentle" and "for sensitive skin," it has a tendency to irritate my eyes and nose slightly. It's not a terrible product, but there are better cleansers out there. Those with truly sensitive skin should try Cetaphil's classic, simple cleanser instead.

I don't have the requisite level of Updike expertise to hail this biography as "definitive," but it certainly comes close in both breadth and detail. Though sufficiently footnoted to suit literary historians, this is an outstanding book that will reward anyone with 500 pages worth of curiosity about the subject.

This is a great game that takes 5 minutes to learn and 5 minutes to play. It's great as a warm-up before a night of more intense board gaming, since it goes so quickly and can be played with anywhere from 2 to 6 people (3 to 5 is ideal). Highly recommended.

I wanted to like this game, but the card text is far too ambiguous, leading to constant arguments about exactly what they do. There's an entire forum on BoardGameGeek dedicated to these debates: [...] I'd love to see a second edition of this game with more precise language. As it is now, it's barely playable.

Full disclosure: I took Rob Dobrow's probability class as an undergrad nearly a decade ago, and worked as a research assistant for him one summer.This is an excellent textbook for anyone looking for a mathematically rigorous introduction to probability who also wants to jump right in to writing simulations. This fills a critical gap: Books that introduce probability and statistics tend to assume that students will figure out how to put that mathematical knowledge into working code later (easier said than done), and books that introduce R tend to require that you already have a good grounding in probability theory. All this book requires is some familiarity with formal mathematical notation, and by the end of it, you'll be able to create useful simulations for any quantitative field. I would recommend this book to any student in a field where the ability to formulate and test precise theories is valued, from economics to biology.

I have sensitive, combination, acne-prone skin. As a result, most sets of skincare products are either irritating, too drying, or too oily for me. This set is practically ideal. The cleanser is gentle but effective, the toner removes surface oils, and the oil-free moisturizer compensates for the toner's drying effect while leaving the skin matte. Also, the set is very reasonably priced given the generous quantities involved: this is a 3-4 month supply.

The Aurvana is trying to compete with cool, travel-friendly headphones like the Sennheiser Momentum and Bowers & Wilkins P3 at half the price. That's a lofty goal, and Creative achieves part of it: These headphones feel comfortable, fold nicely into the included travel pouch, and look very cool. Unfortunately, they don't come close to those rivals in sheer audio quality. Vocals are muffled, bass is weak, and detail is poor. This might be in part because Creative made the bizarre decision to have an old-fashioned in-line volume slider, which works by weakening the incoming signal rather than communicating with the connected device.There are better options out there. If you're willing to stretch your budget to the $200 range, the options I mentioned above are excellent, as is the Onkyo-ES-CTI300 (which I recently reviewed). On the other hand, if you just want good cheap monitors, check out the Sennheiser HD449, a no-frills headphone that sounded far better than the Aurvana in my side-by-side comparison despite its lower price point.

This is a good assortment of adhesive bandages. My one complaint is that the assortment is unorganized. If someone has a cut and you want to find the right size of bandage for them, you have to dig through the whole pile. To save time, you might want to transfer the bandages from this box into a first aid kit with separate compartments for large and small bandages.

I suppose it helps to be a magic nerd to really enjoy this show, but I have a hard time believing many people would not be wowed by what these young, up-and-coming illusionists are able to accomplish. And one of the most amazing things is that they have to work with first three and then four "common objets" (a can of Spam, say, or a pirate's costume), and create the rest of the illusions around these objects using items found in a sort of magic attic that includes a workshop.I have a pretty good idea how several of the tricks worked, but there have been a few that have left me utterly baffled. Veteran magicians Penn & Teller, too.And by the way, among the show's other pleasures, Penn Jillette provides wise, witty commentary on the performances. You can love him or hate him for his brash, bigger-than-life persona, but when it comes to magic, the man is a knowledgeable and serious expert. I am a deep admirer of success that results from a passion toward excellence, and Penn & Teller embody that virtue, I think, and impart that value in "their" (in quote because Teller doesn't actually speak publically) critique.I don't know if "Wizard Wars" has enough going for it to last more than a season. I haven't run into very many people yet who are even aware of the series. But I think it's a worthy experiment that deserves an audience. If you enjoy magic--the nuts and bolts of illusions, and the ability to puzzle out how a trick might have been accomplished--then you'll almost certainly enjoy "Wars." And if you're even a little more serious about magic? You'll love the hell out of it.

This was an interesting story, mostly well-told--except for the breathless prose and soapy score. Also, it kind of lost my sympathy when the main character, the guy who discovered Sue, had to go "visit her" and "talk to her" when the fossil was "in captivty" in storage after having been confiscated.Look. I love dinosaurs and science, and I'm glad I saw this documentary. And you will probably like it, too, pretty much whoever you are. Just be warned--there are some real eye-rolling moments in this thing. I was shocked to see that it was a CNN production. It doesn't play like news, or even an unbiased documentary. It plays like a drama, and not a nuanced drama. And while there ARE dramatic (and outrageous) elements to the story, it's not a MELODRAMA, as this movie seemed determined to become. Cut it down to an hour, remove the purple haze of emotion, throw in a few voices with a different perspective, and THEN you would have a truly first-rate documentary.

I agree with everything Ian says. He's just really tedious and unfunny. This would have been a pretty amusing TED Talk, and I like TED Talks. But on the basis of promotion from the usually trustworthy Friendly Atheist website I downloaded "Critical & Thinking" as stand-up, and as that, it is not very successful. I wish I could say that think the material or the Ian shows a lot of promise, but--and I hope I'm dead wrong here--I so far don't see it. His delivery sounds like an immitation of what a comedian should sound like, his joke structure ignores opportunities, and his range of topics, while refreshingly devoid of rote "observational" and dating material, is not broad enough to garner much of a following. I will say that I took an immediate liking to Ian as a person and bet he would be a lot of fun to get drunk with and discuss the state intellectual state of the union. But I only laughed about four times over the course of this entire set, and the stuff I didn't laugh at was sometimes bordering on painful.

Richly illustrated with top-notched photos, comprehensive and informative, and practical, this is a the ideal reference resource for outdoorspersons interested in our cold-blooded buddies. I have only seen a lizard (skink) in Minnesota one time, and have never seen a mudpuppy here, but I have been fortunate enough to see a timber rattlesnake, western hognose, and most of the frogs, toads, and few of the salamanders in the book. But I had no real good idea what I was observing! With this book, I have learned so much more about range, habitat and threat of extinction than I ever knew before.One of the book's coolest features is a sort of disc-Venn diagram graphic that can be used, working from the inside out and comparing various morphological features, to determine what kind of reptile or amphibian one has seen. Now I will be better able to tell the painted and map turtles apart,along with a bunch of other critters.This book is a great value, but I will still grouse about the price just a little, but for a good reason: it should find its way into more hands than the price barrier may allow. I realize smallish academic presses cannot realize the savings available to large publishers with economies of scale on their side, but it's a shame this attractive and useful book is not more affordable, especially for enthusiastic young students. Perhaps someday a cheaper abridged version could be printed as such a resource.

Well-illustrated, written at the appropriate level, comprehensive without seeming padded--this is the best biology enrichment book I know of. And it helps that "waterbears" are so damned cute and interesting.I recommend this book most highly on my blog, covering Minnesota science standard enrichment activities:http://mnscistandards DOT blogspot DOT com/2014/08/waterbear-tardigrade-book-is-perfect.html

I am a huge fan of DK's books--they are to that medium what BBC is to nature documentaries on video, and that's the highest compliment I can pay any work.However. From the advanced word on this particular book, and from the cover, I feel I was made to expect a more unusual, less typical visual approach. It really just looks like a textbook inside. Even that wouldn't be so bad, but from DK, even a typical textbook is a step DOWN in creativity and effective presentation.There's nothing wrong with the content. I will enjoy finding some young person to give this book to, knowing that I might be introducing her to a world of awe and discovery, secure that that information is solid and accessible. But none of those are the reasons I ordered this book, I got it for ideas on how to present science in inventive, cogent, interesting and entertaining ways. On that level, for those like me who know science but seek inspiration, it is not a success.

I can't think of anyone I'd rather learn about Paine from more than Hitch, a fellow hard-drinking, revolutionary heretic. The affinity Hitchens has for Paine is palpable, but the prose does not gush purple. Paine is presented warts and all, but through it all emerges as an essential character in United States of America (a phrase he might just have coined) history. Let Hitchens introduce you to this oft-derided, little-understood giant of thought and conviction, and marvel at the variety of personalities that gave rise to our republic.

Brinkman continues to surprise and delight as he educates and provokes. The music and rhyming in this album are easily the equal of those in his "Rap Guide to Evoluton" albums (original and 2.0, both of which are very solid works). Among the terrific features of this exploration of human nature's relationship to evolutionary biology are the actual "peer review" phone call messages Brinkman received on a few of his songs. Also, his fresh, honest, humane and hilarious take on human sexuality, which does carry over from his "Gude" albums. I can't recommend "Human Nature" highly enough. If I were a high school teacher, I'd have the students sign a waiver saying they won't be troubled by adult language, and then I'd let this play, the whole thing, and spend the rest of the quarter delving into the fascinating topics Brinkman gestures toward. Like, what IS the relationship between conservatism and germ theory? And is menstrual blood really no different than that from "cutting a finger"?

This is a very good introduction to shark evolution, history, ecology, and conservation. There's nothing splashy here--talking heads, a few well-produced animated segments, some live footage--but the information is solid and attractively presented. It is presented at a popular level, not a scientific one, but it's way more scientifically rigorous (and consequently more accurate) than most of what you'll find on "Shark Week" or other sharksploitation shows. These are truly amazing animals, which have survived two mass extinctions, and now need our help to survive. Surely we don't want a planet with organisms no more interesting than corn and cows, do we?One amazing fact from the film: From an evolutionary standpoint, humans are more closely related to salmon than than salmon are to sharks.

I read some of the negative reviews that say this is boring and lacks functionality. I beg to differ. It's true that it's not terribly educational, but I have planetarium apps for that. This is just beautiful. Hypnotic to watch. And I did actually learn ONE thing at least--I had never fully appreciated what axial tilt LOOKS like as the Earth orbits the sun. Seeing the orbit at a fairly high rate of speed (it's adjustable) really helped me understand what's going on better.And the whole beautiful thing reminded me (because I'm generally more into biology than astronomy) of something Charles Darwin wrote:"...Whilst this planet has gone cycling on according to the fixed law of gravity, from so simple a beginning endless forms most beautiful and most wonderful have been, and are being, evolved...."

The most shocking thing about "Jug Face" is that the acting in it was way, way beyond whay we've come to expect in low-budget horror movies, and the bluesy electric guitar score was so excellent, I plan to download it (it is available from Amazon--Sean Spillane is the composer/musician).This movie is creepy and disturbing rather than frightening, and while I applaud the instinct of the fillmmakers in not stopping the action for scenes of pure exposition, a breadcrumb here or there to help us follow what the hell is going on would not have gone amiss. But having said that, maybe never understanding the nature of the menace, the qualities of the supernatural beings, or the exact ethos the characters found themselves in was part of what made it creepy. I really felt like I'd been plunked down among some odd folks with strange customs, and that was before the sacrifices to a deep mud puddle.Don't spend a lot to watch it, but if you want to see some way-above-average acting in the service of a gonzo backwoods script--this one's for you.

I was excited to get this pen, being a big fan of fountain pens generally, and classy, attractive ones in particular. But the problem is, I can't yet figure out how to get the ink cartridge installed into the pen in such a way that the ink flows correctly. And it came with no instructions. You can call this review unhelpful if you like, but to me the most important aspect of any product is its usefulness, and knowing now how difficult it is to make this item useful to me, I would not purchase it, no matter how well it might work once I am able to set it up properly. It's the same reason I don't buy stuff from Ikea. I like things to work right out of the box. If I wanted something difficult to assemble, I would have gotten a jigsaw puzzle.

It's easy to dismiss genre TV shows as mindless entertainment, but some of the greatest explorations of ideas and of what it means to be human have come through sci-fi and fantasy shows such as Star Trek, Buffy the Vampire Slayer, Dexter, The X Files, and others in a similar vein. Perhaps no series has raised more interesting questions than "Supernatural," and this thin volume does a good job of introducing the issues raised (and gesturing toward some philosophical responses).Chief among the issues "Supernatural" raises is the moral issue of when it's right to kill. Not all monsters are immoral and some humans are monstrous--so how do Sam and Dean decide? The moral landscape of "Supernatural" is fraught, and a few of the book's earlier essays help provide guidance for we, as fans, can decide for ourselves which actions might be justified, and when gray becomes black.Other issues addressed include the fascinating "theology" of "Supernatural," with a special emphasis on hell. In God's absence, it seems hell is a democracy. What to make of that? Also, what about the Cartesian dualism present in some episodes--what does it mean for us to be not one substance (a physical brain, the activity of which constitutes "mind") versus a mind or spirit that's dwelling within a body. Only dualism can explain the rampant possessions that occur on the show, but that raises some prickly philosophical issues.In fact, that's what "Supernatural and Philosophy"--much like the other books in this philosophy of pop culture series--is mainly good for. The essays are too slight and the treatment too facile to provide anything like a rounded philosophy, and it's in the nature of a lot of good storytelling not to be strictly consistent philosophically, anyway, so one can find, for example, nods to both capitalism and Marxism, animal rights and carnivory, and so forth. "Supernatural" is not guilty of foolish consistency, and has always shown a whimsical willingness to go anywhere a good story can be found.The least successful essays in this book--and here I present a personal bias--are the ones that are issue or identity oriented. There is certainly nothing WRONG in examining the role of women in the "Supernatural" universe, but I tend to think of such issues as separate from the more philosophy-philosophy questions raised. In fairness, it certainly is practical application of philosophy, but I suppose I like my musings more abstract and less pedantic, and identity issues feel to me like a distraction.Having said that, this is a quick, invigorating read with few false steps, and will appeal to fans of the who wish to dig deeper into the ideas that propel the story, and to fans of philosophy looking for narrative hooks that can be used to think about issues more concretely. Highly recommended.

I LOVE Quiet Company, and this take on Christmas classics is pure QC, with novel arrangements of traditional tunes, great instrumentation, and reedy vocals made profoundly evocative by supporting harmonies. A splendid contribution to contemporary holiday music. How ironic that the two Christmas albums I most love this season--this one and "Christmas Songs" by punk rockers Bad Religion--are both produced by people who are not at all religious. I guess the music is so affecting and wonderful on its own that whether the singer actually believes in the lyrics is of little account.Highly recommended.

How much did I want to love this book? It's on a topic that I find utterly fascinating, using a medium I adore. And to be fair, James Lu Dunbar handles the subject matter with some aplomb--he shows great promise and even this work is not a total flop. Incidental and background artwork, for example, is amazingly lovely and detailed and includes such design elements as the Mandelbrot fractal. But the main characters are very unappealing, and much of the "poetry" is sing-songy doggerel that does not much succeed in conveying important facts. I’m all for making science fun and accessible, but accuracy and meaning should not be sacrificed on an altar of “cute.” This was by no means the worst example of that sort of thing I’ve seen, but for a much better graphic treatment of evolution, take a look at “Clan Apis” or “Sandwalk.” Those books do a much better job of balancing entertainment and solid science.Again—it pains me to write anything critical about this book for which I held out the highest of hopes, but my hope now is that James makes good on the incredible promise he shows and continues to produce better and better works, perhaps with a willingness to compromise some art for the sake of matter.

People who criticize the quality of the audio aren't wrong, and some parts of some lectures--accompanies as we know they are from the oral description by slides and chalk drawings and equations--are a bit of a loss in audio. BUT. Feynman's reputation for lively, entertaining, accessible lectures on sometimes challenging physics topics is on full display in these recordings, and they are a sheer delight to listen to. My partner and I listened to them while on a very long drive to visit relatives, and they made us feel that rather than being in a Kia Rio chugging down a highway in Iowa, we were actually in an early 1960s classroom, where Russian cosmonauts had recently done the unthinkable and orbited our planet, and this everyday, plain-spoken genius was reeling out science as if it were beat poetry.  This is some crazy good stuff, and worth it either as science, or nostalgic entertainment.

Maybe it's because I first heard this in a dive bar in Key West, but I think it's their most evocative and accessible song since "Under the Bridge." I always think of bands like RHCP that if you're capable of something this sophisticated and great, why does so much your stuff sound like pop filler? But of course if I were a rock star, I'm sure I'd find it impossible to make every song sound as great as my greatest songs do. This is one of their greatest songs.
This song is a LOT of fun, and any person--especially woman--"of a certain age" and with a good sense of humor, will love it.

This is a lovely, classy set, its only drawback being an essential component of its greatest strength: the chains and clasps are as delicate as air. What this means visually is that the pearls seem to dance suspended by nothing around the neck and wrist, which is really eye-catching and pleasing, but on a practical note it makes it pretty hard to manipulate the clasps to get them on without a struggle. If you have nimble fingers and good eyesight, this will not be a concern, but if you are older or impaired, consider that there might be some frustration attached to wearing these.But fashion always comes at a price, I guess, and to reiterate--once on, these are some supremely stylish and classic pearls that will accent a range of clothes, from sweaters to little black dresses. I'm a dude, OK, and not much into jewelry, but I've seen these pearls on two women now (relax, one was my mom), and they looked really nice on both ladies. Other dudes--if you're looking for something versatile and not so unique as to maybe be inappropriate, you could do a LOT worse than going with this sort of high-utility classic style.

A few years back when I first got Norton Internet Security for a then-new laptop, I became annoyed at what I took to be the extra time that the security was adding to my work. It seemed to be fussily buzzing around in the background and doing little more than adding friction to my efforts, slowing me down. So I disabled the protection. And then things really ground to a halt.It's impossible to overestimate the number of beasties and bogies creeping around all over the internet, waiting to infect your computer with crippling and lethal contagions. After trying a few different brands, I've concluded that Norton represents the most comprehensive and least obviously intrusive remedy. The protection I receive from Norton's software approaches 100 percent effectiveness, and their service has been prompt and responsive when called upon. There are features I, as a more casual Internet user, never or seldom need to use, but one thing everyone needs is a way of determining in advance whether it's safe to go to a certain site or download anything from it. Norton, leveraging superior technology and an army of users, goes a great distance toward making me feel safe. If they say somethings OK to do, I'll assume it is indeed safe. So far they've never steered me wrong.Another benefit, especially for non-techies like me: installation is relatively intuitive and painless. Once installed, I all but forget about the program except on those occasions when it asks me to review a report or run a scan and corrective measures. Yes, that takes several minutes each month. Compared to a permanently slowed browsing and processing speed, that's an amazing bargain. Highly recommended.

Within one sturdy plastic container the size of a toaster oven students will find the electronic componenets, the structural components, the software, and the instructions to explore a world of robotics, physics, electronics, design and engineering. The projects that can be undertaken using this kit are limited only by imagination--the components are almost endlessly modular and can be purposed for a wide variety of end uses. The greatest feature is the opportunity to learn programming skills. With relatively simple on-screen programming tools, students can learn about how interfaces between computers and the projects work, including for models of cars and a swing bridge. I did not try the other models so cannot comment on them, but they include an amusement park ride and a toll booth. Software is compatible with PC, OS is Vista or XP. While this is designed for classroom use (but seems a little small for an entire public school sized classroom of more than 20 students--probably one kit per 5 students or so would be optimal?), would also represent an excellent homeschool learning aid for the STEM-inclined.

I watched V/H/S dutifully, as a genre fan. Interesting concept. Heavy on the fetishes, light on interesting ideas. So I wasn't prepared for the occasional full-on BRILLIANCE of VHS2. The thing to remember is, you have to take these vignettes for what they are supposed to be--collected found footage of horrifying scenarios. If you view this anthology as a traditional horror movie, you will of course be disappointed. This is more like being in a fist-person videogame with no control over the action. It is unsettling, unnerving, and often enough, downright terrifying. Yes, it's gory. Possibly excessively gory--although I was in awe of how they got some of those shots, like the exploding guy. The wraparound story was relatively weak, but it ended fairly strong. For genre fans, 2 is much more of a must-see than the original was. And I hope they make enough money from this one to make another, even stronger entry.By the way, if you already saw and enjoyed this movie, you might like The Bay [HD]. It takes first-person, found-footage storytelling to the most artful lengths I've seen employed so far.

I received these stereo Hi-Fi headphones to review under the Vine program, so they were not necessarily something that I had an initial felt need for and went shopping to find. They were spoon fed to my because of my interests. Having said that, I'm happy to have them, but as they are no more mobile than ear buds--which, if good enough, provide comparable sound quality--and don't seem to represent a huge advantage over my Bluetooth enabled Eton Rugged Rukus All-Terrain Portable Solar Wireless Sound System (Green) for casual listening (except that of course it does allow PRIVATE listening that would not disturb a mate or partner). I also found this headphone initially difficult to pair with my music device, although once the trick is understood, it's no more challenging than any other Bluetooth pairing.The price is good, for their size the headphones are quite comfortable (although you must keep your head fairly vertical to prevent them sliding off your head), the sound quality is outstanding, and the battery life is so far superb. I can't bring myself to give it more than three stars, however, because I don't see what added utility I've achieved over ear buds on one hand and conventional speakers on the other.

We were extremely fortunate to see a local professional presentation of this play (put on in the chemistry auditorium of Catholic university, which was just about perfect stagecraft) a few months ago. It is very funny, very powerful, and ultimately had me melting into a pool of sob-wrung tears. Few plays have affected me more radically than "Emilie" (but another that did is "Photograph 51," about Rosiland Franklin who helped discover the structure of DNA, also a female intellectual, so maybe I have a thing about that?).What is surprising is that for my partner and I simply to exchange reading lines back and forth in this book, paying little heed to character consistency or even gender, was almost as powerful as seeing the play had been. Actually, I'm sure having seen the play within memory helped aid the potency of the experience, but even if I had never seen it, I think just the printed version would have moved me by itself.I say that by way of stating: See they play, by all means. If it is as well-performed as the version we saw, you will be delighted and possibly shaken. But if you just can't find a staging of it anywhere, get the book, and gather a few folks whose reading voices you like, and do it yourself. I doubt you will be disappointed.

This staging of Jesus Christ Superstar is so fresh and powerful, it hardly seems like the same musical as Jesus Christ Superstar (1973), the venerable and well-intentioned hippy version. Live Arena JCS is for our times, set in our time, with real-world concerns and references (texting, reality TV, One Direction, corruption among the power elite, surveillance, etc.). But it's the music that really ups this JCS's game, from a harder-edged, less strings-driven instrumentation to vocals that run a gamut from wispy and crooning to primal scream and rabid growl.I ordered this DVD right away because I'm a big Tim Minchin fan, having seen him in concert in Minneapolis a couple of years ago and at his performance at last year's Reason Rally in Washington, D.C., and Minchin has the key role of Judas. Minchin does a terrific job with that role and gives dramatic voice to the character's ambivalence about who Jesus is and how to respond to the unfolding story.Two slightly false notes in an otherwise sterling experience: I didn't care for the staging of King Herod's song (but to be honest, the campy, comedic song has always seemed a little intrusive given the dire events that surround it--still I've seen it done better in other stagings); and the "Superstar" production near the end, with Judas posing that all-important question, "Are you who they say you are?" to the crucified Jesus, was so glitzy and glittery with twerking angels (well--almost twerking) that the seriousness of the song's intent is easily lost.But maybe that's OK. The effect of JCS is to humanize Jesus, and to reclaim what amounts to a kind of folk hero from theologians who seem more intent on creating finely crafted, almost algebraic, dogmas and doctrines ABOUT Jesus, than to let his story wash over them with all its power and drama. I am proudly and happily an atheist. But I have never been immune to the appeal of a person who tries to stand against the oppressors of his or her time, to identify with vulnerable people, to love and lose and feel betrayal and denial, and to courageously face an uncertain destiny with defiance and courage. Stripped of some frankly irrational and unappealing theological elements, the Jesus story presented in Jesus Christ Superstar--and especially, THIS Jesus Christ Superstar--is one for the ages.

I was pretty hard on Prof. Cox's turn with Wonders of the Universe series. I just thought he was being too much of a hippie. And now I have to revisit my opinion, because it could just be that I am the problem--if I knew as much about astronomy and physics as I do biology, would I understand better the breathless, cow-eyed wonder that Cox brings to the topic, as he does with Life?Because I have to say, every sigh, every pause and glance and meaning-pregnant moment of the "Life" series seems utterly justified by the subject matter, even as it is astonishingly, beautifully illustrated with BBC's best nature photography (which is saying something). I even appreciated the physicist's perspective that Cox brought to the topic, as when he explained that the electronic gradiant sensing organisms use is analogous to the phenomenon of lightning.This is an arresting, brilliant series that can be faulted only for being too short--I hope there are sequals. And Cox--the wonderstruck everyman who guides us on this journey--is the perfect host and narrator.Still a hippie, though.

Having lost electricity twice this summer already, I thought this could be very useful. Once I breached the impenetrable packaging and treated myself for injuries, things got better. There's almost more to love in the extras here then in the light itself. Several mounting options (screws, tape, magnets), all included, as well as a nice little mounting bracket. Even a door hanger strap with quick-release mechanism (for when I need to liberate the light in a hurry?). The light's beam is strong and broad. I like that I can use it in motion-activated mode or as a flashlight. Good addition to the tool kit. I haven't tested it in an emergency yet, but I'm crocheting little outfits for it. It's that cute.

With 80x magnification, this is a powerful spotting scope that can be used over a wide range of distances.  It's also robust enough to sling into a backpack without having to worry much about knocking delicate optics off-kilter.  I found it to be a useful tool for wildlife spotting and bird-watching, and I appreciate the tough, portable design--clearly engineered with hunters in mind.HOWEVER. I don't find it as easy to use as my comparably high-mag binoculars, especially for initially spotting the subject. If you are looking at something a great distance away at high magnification, the difference of a fraction of an inch aiming on your end means many feet different at the end where your subject is located, and that can mean a lot of flailing around, trying to get the subject centered in the scope. The scope DOES come with a handy tripod mount (and clever way to connect to a digital SLR camera--which I do not own), and using a tripod would no doubt have helped.  But lugging a tripod around means, basically, good-bye to the compact convenience of the scope otherwise.  By balancing and bracing the scope against solid objects--like a stump--you can replicate fairly effectively the stability afforded by a tripod.Overall, I can't say that I am displeased with the product, and in situations where packing space is at its most premium (think fly-ins, for example) I'll prefer the scope to my binoculars.  Otherwise, for everyday use, I think I still prefer to better ability to find my subject using the double tubes.Afterthought: I see that the five-star reviews are getting a large number of "not helpful" votes, but few comments.  I am curious, if anyone reads this who has had a much different experience of the scope, or who is looking for different kinds of product information, how are those reviews coming up short in your mind? I see one seemed to be nothing more than plagiarism from the company's own product description, and I get how that's not helpful, but I wonder about the other votes.

I just can't say enough bad about this movie.  It appears to work from no script whatever--a hypothesis practically confirmed in the "making of" feature--and characterization is limited to "be as annoying as humanly possible."  Michael Cera's character was the worst of the lot, a mincing, lispy queen-to-be in the midst of gay panic.  I had no sympathy for any of the characters, thoroughly disliked the lot of them, and could not be bothered to care about what happened to them.  The movie buzzed and droned for what felt like hours (and that was with some fast-forwarding), and then fizzled through a protracted ending that explained nothing, resolved nothing, and made little sense.All of which makes it seem like if a movie is not perfectly plotted and wrapped up at the end neat as a bow, I won't like it.  Not true.  I love, for example, the ending of Limbo.  Sucker Punch was a bit of a mess, and I loved that, too.  Hell, I even liked Human Centipede, just for the pure novelty of it.  But "Magic Magic" is pointless trash with nothing to recommend it.I see I've garnered four out of four "not helpfuls" already.  Please, comment.  Defend this movie.  I really want to know what anyone would see in it.  I'm not being snarky--I'm really curious to know what you think.

I was GOING to say that the great thing about this product is packaging that allows one to easily have a couple of tasty crackers and then put the lid back on to save for later, and that the cup shape makes them the perfect snack-buddy to nest in one of the ubiquitous cup-holders most of us have in our vehicles now.But what I'm ending up saying is that once I opened the package and had a few, that's it.  They were gone.  I was doomed to consume a very tasty if not very nutritious snack in one sitting.  It's the tangy real cheese bite, combined with the crispness, that makes them so dang addictive.So keep in mind, with good intentions, the packaging does make it easy to satisfy a craving for salt, tang, and crunch a few crackers at a time.  But the crackers themselves don't exactly encourage self-control.

“Our web of less-than-desirable circumstances was complex and gut-wrenching to think about.”♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫“All of Me” by John Legend captures the longing and their epic, soul-searching love!♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫ ♫AFFAIRyTALE is a candid account of one woman’s affair, but as name would indicate parts of her story has a fairytale feel to it, more specifically the epic love she found with her lover.Charmaine (Summers) English, C.J. had an affair; she is forthcoming about that.  This is not her story about making excuses.  In fact she owns being vile and bitchy lying and sneaking, she owns going about it wrong she even admits and explores why…. But this is not so much a story of if or why rather of “what if?”What would you do if you felt trapped in a toxic marriage and you loved another man for half a decade?Yup this memoir spans over a decade, from around the time an eighteen year old C.J. met her husband-to-be, Levi Summers and after a tumultuous courtship married him so that they could be a family unit with their daughter, Dani. But they were toxic together…C.J. had already met Grant English by then. In fact, she was utterly miserable on her wedding day because she was thinking of him. Grant was her brother’s best friend and they all vacationed at the same lake each summer.  For years she carried on a flirtatious friendship under the watchful eye of a very jealous – and rightfully so – Levi.Though C.J. was absorbed, obsessive even in her dealings with Grant much of the story is her trying to get Grant out of her head, forging ahead with her life, her career and motherhood, while her marriage remained dysfunctional.  She stayed and made do, taking her anger and bottling up.Then each summer they’d be back at the lake house; drawn to each other like magnets, the intensity of their attraction and bond palpable their destiny inevitable… But their timing always seemed off, with so much in their way.  Add to that Grant’s hot-cold demeanor.What finally gave and how did it all play out?  This is their tale of an affair and an epic love.“That kiss was a kiss goodbye.  A let-me-down-easy, I really do care about you but this was a mistake.”GRANT ENGLISH:  24-37 years/Entrepreneur/Security consultant/Pilot/Musician/Athlete/Brown hair/Ice Blue Eyes/Single/Divorced.Grant English, her brother’s best friend and the love of her life. An enigma, a gentleman, the too good to be true guy!  At times I wanted t to scream to him: “Do it!”  “Tell her!”  “Grab her!”  “Make her!”  My heart bleeds for all the years lost.“He lured me in with his tenor and then held me captive with his timbre.”CHARMAINE (SUMMERS) ENGLISH, C.J.:  19-32 years/Masters in health/Health consultant/Brown hair/Brown Eyes/5'4"/scars/Mother/Wife.Charmaine (Summers) English, C.J. well this is your memoire a candid look into everything you were and weren’t; are and aren’t; your fears, insecurities, heartaches, anger…. longing, frustration… and then that once-in-a-lifetime love.“Mostly I pondered why he kept showing up in my life and why I had such an unbreakable attachment to him.”AFFAIRyTALE told from C.J.’s POV, is a poignant look into an affair; the pain and devastation it caused.  But also a thought-provoking and inspiring story about finding a love of a lifetime.  It’s not an easy read, it was angsty, frustrating and even painful to read at times, depicting a gut-wrenching yearning.For me it was mostly un-put-down-able, addictive, beautiful, hopeful, mesmerizing, breathtaking and spectacular! Thanks for sharing C.J.!“I want ten-thousand more days with you.”***Hero rating: 5 starsHeroine rating: 4.5 starsSexual tension rating: 5+ starsSex scenes rating: 4.5 starsSex scenes frequency: 4 starsPlot rating: 5 starsDialogue rating: 4.5 starsStorytelling rating: 4.5 starsStory ending rating: 5++ starsBook editing rating (5 = no edits spotted): N/A, ARC************************************************Overall rating: 4.75 starsWould I recommend this book: Yes.Would I re-read this book: Yes.Would I read future books by this author: Yes.C.J. and Grant, here’s to another 10,000 days!  I wish you continued happiness and love and a long and beautiful life together.  May AFFAIRyTALE be a huge success taking you places and giving you more opportunities.Levi, may you find your destiny and the happiness you deserve.  Remember NOT too stare too long at the closed door or you will miss the window that just opened up.A gifted copy was provided by author/publisher for an honest review.

“There was something wickedly thrilling about both of the jobs I did.”Books in Knives & Flowers series should be read in order:Book 1: Breaking LeilaBook 2: Breaking JosephBreaking Leila (book 1) opens up to law intern Leila Vaughn, Lei-Lei aka Charlotte wrapping up a day of work at the law firm where she has been interning in hopes of future employment.  And for the last year she has been grave-yarding as a high class escort after discovering her parents buried in her students loans were about to lose everything.To cope with this second career she has created an alter ego.  It’s the vixen Charlotte who seduces men, explores her sexuality and pushes boundaries, but she has discovered she quite likes and has mixed feelings about her escort career coming to an end.Imagine her shock when her clients for the evening turns out to be her boss the mysterious , mercurial and somewhat sinister law firm partner, Joseph Merchant, Joe aka Chairman of the Whored along with her coworker and friend, law intern Matthew Gordon, Matt aka Mattman/Matt-Matt.It was a night of mind-blowing sex; kinky, raw, possessive and in the midst of it all an aloof Joseph.  While Matt makes plans for the future in hopes of an exclusive relationship with Leila, Joseph makes arrangement for Leila to finish her last jobs with him.  A devious yet exhilarating plan. Her decisions are complicated by a web of lies and omissions. “He went full frontal in The Evidence Locker.  America swooned and my v*brator got a fresh round of batteries.”Hollywood Dirt (stand-alone) opens shortly before a Hollywood production is heading to a small Southern town to film a big budget movie.  Center stage is Hollywood heartthrob and too-handsome-for-his-own-good, Hollywood royalty Cole Masten aka Big City.  This movie is his baby, his first production.  When his world is rocked by deceit and divorce papers served by his gold-digging soon-to-be ex-wife, a jaded Cole turned man-whore must fight to keep the movie production on schedule and in his name.Summer Jenkins aka Country is the polar opposite from Cole, except since the movie announcement Summer has caught the first break of her life helping the movie scout with local logistics with the hopes of staying on as crew once production starts.  But Summer has a bit of a temper accompanied by bluntness much due to being born to a single mom and an outcast for most of her life followed by a scandal in recent yearsThe story alternates between Hollywood in stark contrast to the small Georgian town as Cole and Summer prepare for the big production while also slowly digging further back into their secret pasts.  When they finally meet the sparks fly and everything pretty much goes downhill from there sprinkled with intense sexual tension, sizzling clandestine sex, humorous bantering and a tempestuous working relationship made for the tabloids…COLE MASTEN aka Big City:  35 years/Heir/Movie star/Producer/$$$$/Dark Hair/Green eyes.Cole Masten aka Big City is the perfect blend of imposing beauty, entitled heir, broken boy, larger-than-life movie star and successful businessman.  Yet in all his jaded cockiness there is both vulnerability and humor to him.  I predict he’ll wrap himself around your heart.SUMMER JENKINS aka Country:  28 years/House sitter/Blond hair/Hazel eyes.Summer Jenkins aka Country has never had anything handed to her.  Her good looks and feisty personality compounded by her background has always worked against her – until now. This is her moment, her time to make piece, grow up and grasp her big break.Hollywood Dirt, told from alternating POVs is a hilarious, feel-good read about second chances, about working the cards you were dealt and grasping opportunities when they arise.  But ultimately it’s about forgiveness and making peace with one’s past and how, in life, some of the best moments don’t come with a huge price tag, yet have blockbuster written all over.Story also comes with some surprises for Alessandra Torre fans.  It ends on a high and laughter much like Hollywood endings where dreams can come true.Effortless story-telling!  Entertaining dialogue!  Feel-good plot!  Swoon-worthy heartthrob Cole Masten!“Liar.” I accused.He laughed and leaned in, close enough for only me to hear his response.  “Yes, baby.  And so are you.”***Hero rating: 5 starsHeroine rating: 4.5 starsSexual tension rating: 5+ starsSex scenes rating: 5 starsSex scenes frequency: 4 starsPlot rating: 5 starsDialogue rating: 5 starsStorytelling rating: 5 starsStory ending rating: 5 starsBook editing rating (5 = no edits spotted): N/A, Beta************************************************Overall rating: 5 starsWould I recommend this book: Yes.Would I re-read this book: Yes.Would I read future books by this author: Yes.A gifted copy was provided by author/publisher for an honest review.

“ And for a few seconds, it was just us – the patient, the doctor, and the pressing realization that there was nothing we could do about it.”They met at a cross road in life…Mia Holloway aka Little Fox the much too young university student having an anxiety attack after having been cheated on then dumped by her boyfriend. Ready-to-settle-down and not-looking-for-anything-complicated Cardiologist Dr. Alex Greene is the doctor on duty that nightIncreased heart rates, beeping monitors…Stolen glances, tender smiles, jagged conversations, innuendos, but mostly fear and reservations.  Mia knows her immaturity is an obstacle, but is smitten and in awe with the mature, accomplished and charming doctor.  Though he knows it’s wrong, Alex is taken by the young petite beauty and shows her extra care and attention and even calls her pet names.Forbidden romance, doomed before it even begins…Alex can lose his medical license for even flirting with Mia.  He is torn yet embarks on a clandestine affair with the young student. Stolen moments and hidden rendezvous, but Alex is conflicted.  In addition to the inappropriateness of their affair he is overworked and has secrets he rather keep.Lies only begets more lies….They are lying to their friends and family, co-workers, but soon also to each other; White lies, secrets and hidden agendas…  When deeper feelings surface and their world come crashing down… Will Alex mend or break her heart?[beep beep beep]“ And I was still swimming in the deep-end that was Dr. Greene.”Dr. ALEX GREENE:  32 years/Cardiologist/$$$/Dark Brown hair/Green eyes.Ten words to describe  Dr. Alex Greene: Charming, honorable, conflicted, moody, hot-cold, closed off, thoughtless, immature, interesting and complex.“I became a doctor so I could fix people, so I could help the sick. But I can't help people like us. I can't fix this, Mia. I just don't know how.”MIA HOLLOWAY aka Little Fox:  22 years/English student/Brown hair/Brown eyes.Eight words to describe  Mia Holloway aka Little Fox: Sweet, timid, lonely, meek, impressionable, transparent, immature and loyal.“ He was a doctor. I was a patient. He was a man, and I was a girl. What more could I have expected?”Pulse, told from alternating POV is the romance that should never be and I had to keep in reading, needing to know what would happen next.  It is sexy, sweet, angsty, intriguing and bittersweet.  As for ending… it left them at another cross road; happy and at peace.  I am happy to report that the author is writing an EXTENDED epilogue.Intense and addicting plot!  Excellent story-telling! “You’re my best friend,” he said tearfully, “my lover, my strength, my reason for being, which I never thought was possible. I never thought there was anyone for me.” He was openly crying as I looked down at him.”Loving the White Liar is Hilary A Monroe, Hil’s story how she came to be and had to cope with being in a relationship with man with ADHD (attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder).While doing laps in the pool at her apartment complex travel agent Hilary meets a charming neighbor woodworker Jayden Monroe, Jay.  They both feel an attraction; flirting leads to dating which quickly leads to a deep friendship and much more.  But along the way their relationship plateaus Hil not understanding why.  There are signs... subtle at first; white lies Jayden not have had any successful relationships…It turns our Jayden has a secret; He has ADHD.  Naïve, ignorant and unprepared Hil forges ahead with their relationship.  The story goes on to follow them in sky-high ups and rock-bottom lows as she discovers what dealing with ADHD truly entails.  Needless to say this causes both stress and strain on their relationship.It’s a candid look into the complexity of ADHD.  That said contrary to what I expected this is Hil’s journey.  Jayden had already been proactive with his condition, structuring his life is such a way that he was functioning.  I have so much respect for him.JAYDEN A. MONROE, Jay:  27 years/Woodworker/Dark brown hair/Purple eyes/Tattoos/ADHD.Jayden Monroe, Jay has overcome so much and learned to function in a very intolerant, fast paced society despite his ADHD.  There was nothing that bothered me about what he said or did.  I felt there were mitigating circumstances for everything.  Nine words to describe Jayden: forthcoming, insecure, loving, temperamental, focused, determined, proactive, hard-working and lovable.HILLARY A. MONROE, Hil:  27 years/Travel agent/Marketing/Auburn hair/Blue eyes/5’5”.There were times Hilary A Monroe, Hil angered me.  Her immaturity, ignorance, insensitivity and poor timing caused more stress on their relationship and Jayden’s health.  For me this was HER journey of growth. In the end I forgave her.  Eight words to describe Hil: Loving, sweet, immature, ignorant, naïve, thoughtless, determined and loyal.Loving the White Liar is an intense mixture of romance and angst. Though my heart broke a couple of times it is a heart-warming life story of hope and love.  As mentioned Hil frustrated me at times with her ignorance and inability to see the big picture, but she came around and I forgave her.  Plus that ending more than made up for any angst.  It was perfection through and through.Candid and insightful story-telling!  Thought-provoking plot!  Oh so sweet hero!  A beautiful message of love and hope!“Playful Jayden was adorable. Nervous Jayden was endearing. Affectionate Jayden was beautiful. But this Jayden... this Jayden was molten.”***Hero rating: 4+ starsHeroine rating: 3.5 starsSexual tension rating: 4 starsSex scenes rating: 4 starsSex scenes frequency: 4 starsPlot rating: 4 starsDialogue rating: 4.5 starsStorytelling rating: 4.5 starsStory ending rating: 5+ starsBook editing rating (5 = no edits spotted): N/A, ARC************************************************Overall rating: 4+ starsWould I recommend this book: Yes.Would I re-read this book: Maybe later.Would I read future books by this author: Yes.A gifted copy was provided by author/publisher for an honest review.

“There are too many ways to die.”Songs of Corruption is the whirlwind saga of alleged mobster Antonio Spinelli and Theresa Drazen. It’s a sequel series to Songs of Submission and Songs of Perdition and thus most enjoyed if read after and in order:Book 1: SpinBook 2: RuinBook 3: RuleIn Songs of Corruption book 1 and 2, heiress, socialite, part-time script supervisor and former head of accounting Theresa Drazen, Tink aka Contessa met a man who rocked her world and gave her an excuse to break out of her good-girl-mold.  Attorney, business owner and “alleged” mobster, money launderer and murderer Antonio Spinelli, Spin aka Capo wasn’t looking to complicate his life, but Theresa intrigued him.With little in common and much to lose they couldn’t seem to stay away. Story went on to follow Antonio and Theresa as they dealt with their attraction and got entwined with the darker side of Hollywood’s organized crime, corruption and politics until it all imploded…Rule (Book 3) opens up to the aftermath of book 2’s explosive ending.  Antonio and Theresa have been through so much yet nothing could have prepared them for the battles ahead. It’s a raise against time with traitors, villains and enemies plotting to destroy them with family and friends looking on powerless to help.Follow them, in their against-all-odd’s love, as they set out to rule their future tainted by their pasts in a high-stakes game of cut-throat politics colliding with ruthless organized crime for Songs of Corruption.ANTONIO SPINELLI, SPIN aka CAPO: 35 years/Italian/$$$$/Attorney/Biz owner/Alleged mobser, money launderer & murder/Black hair/Black eyes/6’.Antonio Spinelli, Spin aka Capo stole my heart and it was my pleasure to the see him shaped by his youth and past adapting to his circumstance to become the man he needs to be.
